methodology:
1) Monitoring within Enclosure – Majority of animals initially released into the RTD enclosure were fitted with radio transmitters and monitored for survivorship and day/nest locations mapped.  Animal’s movements within the enclosure will be analysed using ArcView and Ranges 6.

Initially mala, marl and dalgytes are released into the north enclosure and boodies and merrnine are released into the south enclosure.

2) Trapping within Enclosure – Both enclosures have a fixed trapping grid of 7x4 at 40m intervals marked with dropper posts.  Trapping is undertaken in each enclosure on a three monthly basis.  In the northern enclosure two cage traps with restrictors and an Elliott trap are set at each post for dalgytes and marl.  Mala are trapped annually using Bromilow traps baited with lucerne.  In the southern enclosure two cage traps are set at each post.  Two additional lines of 12x2 traps are set; one in thick scrub in the NE and one in the SE corner of the enclosure.  All captured animals are weighed and measured (head, pes length, tail length and width, scrotum length and width), reproductive status determined and all new animals have a DNA tissue sample taken.  All animals are ear-clipped and implanted with a PTT for identification.

The numbers of individuals Known to be Alive is determined.  Survivorship determined using Cormack-Jolly-Seber Population Analysis (Program MARK – G White: Colorado State University), this will allow survivorship to be determined for a Closed Population. 

3) Release methods outside RTD enclosure – two-release method will be compared: soft release verses hard release.  Success of a particular release method will be determine by post release survivorship analyses using Known Fate (Program MARK – G White: Colorado State University) this will give an estimate of survival probability.  A minimum dispersal distance from release site will determine success.

Ho: no significant difference in survivorship between soft and hard released CWR marsupial species.

Ho: no significant difference in dispersal distance between soft and hard released CWR marsupial species.

4) Monitoring outside Enclosure – All released animals will be fitted with radio transmitters (where appropriate mortality type).  Initially animals will be monitored on a daily basis for the first four weeks, then every week for four weeks, then fortnightly for eight weeks, then monthly for the duration that the animal is fitted with a transmitter.  Locations will be obtained using a GPS and habitat and situation will be recorded.  This data will be analysed using Ranges 6 and ArcView.

5) Trapping outside Enclosure – Trapping grid sites will be determined based on early radio tracking results.  All captured animals weighed and measured as above.  New animals marked as above and tissue samples taken.

Known to be Alive determined and population models developed using Jolly-Seber Population Models (Program MARK – G. White: Colorado State University), population size, survival and birth rates can be determined using this model

6) Genetic Analysis – Ear tissue is collected from all RTD animals both inside and outside the enclosure.  It is proposed that mitochondrial DNA analysis be undertaken to determine genetic variability and relatedness within the population of these species.  It will also be possible to compare variability to samples collected from other site throughout the state.
no_specimens: Carcasses or remains of deceased animals will be sent to the museum when all data has been collected from them.
data_management: Data from monitoring both within and outside the RTD enclosure is held at Woodvale; all data is entered and stored on a dedicated MS Access database. Copies of Field Data sheets are distributed to Districts DCLM staff and participating Scientists.

background:
Primary productivity is the basis of marine food webs, providing the energy that sustains invertebrate and vertebrate survival. As such, oceanic primary productivity is closely correlated with secondary production (fisheries) and ecosystem measures of diversity (Frank et al. 2007, Chassot et al. 2010). However, rates of primary productivity can be spatially and temporally variable and shifts in primary production due to factors like climate change have the potential to affect both the production of fisheries (Barange et al. 2014) and broader patterns of marine biodiversity (Brown et al. 2010).

While marine productivity is primarily attributable to oceanic phytoplankton (Sigman & Hain 2012), productivity from benthic macrophytes becomes increasingly important in coastal food webs (Wyatt et al. 2010, Davis et al. 2014). However, the link between benthic productivity by vascular plants and algae and secondary production remains equivocal (Saenger et al. 2013). Moreover, local variations in hydrology are likely to influence the supply of nutrients, temperature and (turbidity) light, all of which are fundamental determinants of primary productivity.

Nearshore marine benthic productivity originates primarily from certain intertidal (seagrass, mangroves) and sub tidal (seagrass, seaweed and coral reef) habitats. Primary production in these systems is a likely source of energy for associated communities and a potential driver of abundance, diversity and secondary production. Animal movement between habitats or detrital transport from one habitat to another may also subsidise local productivity (Hyndes et al. 2014), particularly when these habitats are in close proximity to each other (Granek et al. 2009). As a consequence, assessing connectivity among marine habitats has become an important consideration in conservation planning (Olds et al. 2012, Berkström et al. 2013). The diversity of primary producers in coastal systems makes it difficult to explicitly link sources of local production to community attributes, circumstances that may be further complicated by inputs from oceanic phytoplankton and energy from detrital pathways (Bouillon et al. 2008). Natural isotopic signatures of primary producers may, however, provide a mechanism to evaluate the relative importance of different primary producers to consumer diets and therefore secondary production (Hyndes et al. 2014, Lee et al. 2014).  

Primary productivity in this study is defined as the net primary productivity. It is the growth rate at which energy is stored as biomass by primary producers and made available to the consumers in the ecosystem (Foley 1994). Which makes it the measure most relevant to our question of energy transfer. The north-western coast of Australia provides an ideal opportunity to investigate the influence of different benthic primary producers on the diversity and secondary productivity of coastal marine systems. The Dampier Archipelago, in the Pilbara region, has extensive island and coastal mangroves in relative proximity to seaweed, seagrass and coral reef habitats. The adjacent landscape is arid with infrequent input to the marine system from riverine catchments. Strong tidal currents are likely to promote movement of organic matter between habitats. Thus, results from Dampier will not be confounded by riverine inputs and will provide unique perspective of connectivity of primary productivity within turbid coastal environments.
aims:
The overarching goal of this project is to assess how spatial variation in primary productivity effects energy transfer among marine ecosystems and biodiversity.

The specific project aims include:

  • Provide coarse maps of primary producers at up to 16 sites.
  • Develop fine scale oceanographic modelling of the Dampier Archipelago to provide valuable water flow/retention data.
  • Measure primary productivity in different marine habitats (mangroves, seagrass, seaweed and coral reef) and assess how rates vary among locations in the Dampier Archipelago area.
  • Measure abundance, diversity and growth rates of fish and benthic communities and assess how this relates to spatial variation in primary productivity.
  • Measure stable isotopes of primary producers and secondary consumers, and use isotopic signatures to assess the extent of transfer from different primary producers to secondary consumer tissues.
outcome: The project will map the spatial arrangement of major primary producers in marine coastal areas of the Dampier Archipelago. By quantifying the transfer of energy from primary producers to consumers, the project will directly investigate the influence of local primary producers on secondary production and biodiversity. Incorporating information from multiple sources of primary production among adjacent habitats, including the phytoplankton in the water column, the project will also assess the extent of connectivity between nearby habitats and how their proximity within the seascape affect secondary productivity and diversity. This ecosystem approach of assessing productivity and energy flows among marine habitats, often considered as discrete conservation values, will help to identify areas of high conservation value for planning and management in the Dampier Archipelago. The outcomes of this project will increase knowledge and awareness of key ecological processes and allow conservation planners and managers to consider the marine ecosystem rather than individual habitats to achieve effective conservation outcomes.
knowledge_transfer:
This project will provide knowledge that can be used by marine planners, policy makers and regional staff responsible for managing marine parks, particularly in the Pilbara. The information derived from this research will:

  • Inform decision making relating to the design of marine reserves.
  • Contribute to developing accurate DBCA advice relating to development proposals.
  • Provide DBCA management staff with an improved understanding of the structure and function of high-conservation value Pilbara marine ecosystems that will improve their capacity to make informed engagement with key stakeholders and the general public.
  • Enable DBCA marine scientists to collaborate with other State agency scientists and the broader scientific and marine management community.

It is anticipated that the knowledge generated by this study will be disseminated through various methods such as internal meetings, presentations of findings and information sheets. More broadly, the results will be presented at workshops, conferences, popular articles, web resources, social media and peer-reviewed publications in international journals.

methodology:
• Mapping habitats

The spatial arrangement of primary producers is important for many ecosystem processes, including carbon fluxes, dispersal, breeding and resource use, and can improve ecosystem resilience (Davis et al. 2014). Sea-scooters with a GoPro and tow-GPS attached will be used to film the benthos at up to 16 sites around the archipelago. Images will be analysed in EcoPAAS and the data will be geo-referenced to make habitat maps of all the chosen sites.  This will be conducted in collaboration with Kathy Murry in Remote Sensing and Spatial Analysis Program, where the site data will be used as training for habitat mapping using ARCGIS and ERMapper. The process involves conducting a supervisor maximum likelihood classification of Sentinel 2 satellite imagery (10m resolution) and newly acquired 10 metre resolution bathymetry data from Dr Mick O’Leary at UWA from the intertidal to a depth no greater than 8 m. To avoid problems associated with turbid waters a minimum pixel composite of the Sentinel 2 imagery has been created using low tide, calm images from six capture dates in June to September 2019 providing a clear image of benthic features for classification.

  • Develop fine scale oceanographic model of the Dampier Archipelago

Through collaborations with Professor Ryan Lowe at UWA, deploy current meters in bays across the archipelago as well as an acoustic doppler current profiler (ADCP), at various locations, and combined with bathymetry data from Dr. O’leary, to inform and improve a quantitative model of water flow/retention at sampling sites over tidal, seasonal and annual cycles. This information will also be used to model the spatial and temporal variation of oceanic primary productivity.

  • Measuring spatial variation of primary productivity

Primary productivity will be assessed in mangroves, seagrass, seaweed and coral reef habitats of the Dampier Archipelago using established techniques (Table 2), with a focus on the most prominent primary producing taxa within each system. In addition, productivity within water and sediment samples from each site will be assessed to understand productivity of plankton and microalgae at local scales. Productivity within each of the habitats will be assessed at up to 16 sites. Productivity will also be assessed over recognized temporal durations (Table 2). Spatial differences in primary productivity will be assessed using metric multidimensional Scaling plots, PCA and Permanova. A full subsets approach (Fisher et al., 2018) will be used to identify which environmental variables most influence variation of primary productivity.

  • Comparing primary productivity to secondary abundance, diversity, and growth rates

The abundance and diversity of fish communities within each of the habitats will be assessed using a combination of visual and video techniques over spatial scales (transects) relevant to fauna size and movement patterns (Table 2). The growth rates of prominent fish species common to all sites, or dominant in each habitat, will then be measured at each site (Table 2) and compared to local rates of primary productivity. Fish will be collected using minnow fish traps, speargun or clove oil and barrier nets from mangrove, coral, seaweed habitats and seagrass (if fish available). Muscle tissue will also be collected from fish for stable isotope analysis (see section v).

The importance of local primary productivity relative to other environmental factors will be explored using a full subsets approach (Fisher et al., 2018). Environmental variables considered will be measured in-situ (temperature) or downloaded remotely from the NOAA ERDDAP website (KD490, Chlorophyll-a), as well as metrics derived from the oceanographic modelling and the habitat mapping conducted as part of this project.

  • Stable isotope signatures and mixing models

Five to ten samples of the most abundant primary producers (mangrove, coral, seagrass, seaweed) will be collected from each site for stable isotope analysis. These will be compared to stable isotope signatures (ẟC13, ẟN15 and ẟS34) of fish and invertebrates, using mixing models (Le et al 2019), to assess which sources of primary production are assimilated and contribute most to secondary production. As transport of particulate organic matter (POM) and dissolved organic matter (DOM) plays an important role in the energy transfer between habitats (Alongi et al. 1989; Dittmar et al. 2006), measuring isotopic signatures of sediments (detrital/microplankton) and oceanic influence (phytoplankton) at each site will also allow an assessment of these sources influence on secondary productivity. Sediment cores (10cm diameter, 10cm deep) at increasing distances from each habitat will be taken and water samples will also be taken at each site to understand planktonic influence on the systems.

background:
_Acacia_ is the largest genus of flowering plants in Australia (960 species comprising almost 1 200 taxa) and is an important component of many ecosystems, particularly in arid and semi-arid areas.  Within Western Australia there are 700 described taxa of Acacia (and perhaps as many as another 100 currently undescribed) of which 12 are listed as Critically Endangered, 7 as Endangered, 3 as Vulnerable, 2 as Extinct and 183 as Rare and Poorly Know (Buist et al. in Conservation Science Western Australia 4(3): 36-53).  Many of the Australian taxa of Acacia have the potential for economic, social and commercial utilization.  However, in order to undertake effective conservation, utilization and management of this enormous resource it is essential that the taxa be meaningfully defined and effectively named (Maslin in Conservation Science Western Australia 4(3): 1-9).  It is against this background that the current SPP is undertaken.

This project commenced in 2000-01 with a focus on those species considered to have agroforestry potential.  Current work involves taxonomic discrimination and investigations of the biology of _Acacia microbotrya_ (for Forest Products Commission), _A. saligna_ (for Natural Heritage Trust), and an assessment of the southern Australian Acacia flora for its potential as a new wood crop for semiarid regions as a means of salinity controp (for Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation under the title of AcaciaSearch).  These projects will be finalized in 2003.
aims: Undertake research to provide taxonomic and other advise to enable the effective utilisation of Acacia for nature conservation and applied purposes.  The initial focus is on species with agroforestry potential (see above) but future work is expected to concentrate on re-assessing the systematic and conservation status of the W.A. Acacia flora, with a particular emphasis on rare and geographically restricted taxa.
outcome: Taxonomic discrimination of W.A. Acacia species (commencing with A. microbotrya and A. saligna); identification of southern Australian acacias with agroforestry potential; maintenance of Departmental Declared Rare and Priority Flora lists; scientific and other publications.
knowledge_transfer: professionals and others involved in farm forestry, landcare and flora conservation; botanists; ecologists; foresters; Departmental regional and other staff. Technology transfer: publications as noted above; corporate databases.

Date

Comments

1/06/2003

Acacia microbotrya group: produce scientific publication detailing taxonomic variation and description of entities on the group [by June 2003].  This will satisfy obligations to FPC.

1/04/2003

Acacia saligna: complete field and herbarium studies to examine variation patterns within the species and prepare preliminary taxonomic review of the complex for inclusion in M. Byrnes’ report to NHT.

1/03/2003

AcaciaSearch: complete field study to assess and prioritize species and prepare Report for publication by RIRDC.

1/07/2004

Conservation status of the Western Australian Acacia flora: complete review of W.A. Acacia species represented in W.A. Herbarium collections to assess (and where necessary, re-assess) their conservation status [by July 2004] and undertake on-going taxonomic characterization of the species.
methodology:
A.  Standard taxonomic procedures will be employed which will involve:

·           Comparative morphological study of herbarium collections to analyse variation and assess taxonomic status of the taxa.

·           Field examination of taxa to acquire additional information and specimens for taxonomic work and to understand their biology and ecology.

·           Multivariate analysis of variation as needed (e.g. A. microbotrya). 

·           Genetic analysis of variation where needed (e.g. A. microbotrya and A. saligna): to be conducted by M. Byrne.

B.         Progress the development of the WATTLE information system for the identification of taxa plus the capture and delivery of relevant taxonomic, biological, ecological, geographic and utilisation information.  The data derived via this project will represent a major enhancement of WATTLE.

C.        Determine the conservation status of the W.A. Acacia flora through herbarium survey and field study.

D.        Publish results via appropriate media.  For example, the AcaciaSearch report will be published by RIRDC as a colour book; the A. microbotrya study will be published as a scientific paper; the A. saligna study will be summarized in a NHT report; the conservation assessment of W.A. acacias will contribute to the updating of Departmental DRF and Priority Flora lists.
no_specimens: Voucher specimens will be collected, processed and deposited in the W.A. Herbarium. Around 200 have been collected in relation to the A. saligna, A. microbotrya and AcaciaSearch projects.
data_management: Specimen and names information will be maintained through the Corporate databases, WAHERB and WACENSUS respectively and will therefore be available via FloraBase. The results of the assessment of the conservation status of W.A. Acacias will be managed through the Declared Rare and Priority Flora List. Other relevant data will be managed through the WATTLE information system.

background:
At the request of the Executive Director, the Science Division has prepared a scoping document for a comprehensive biological survey of the Pilbara IBRA bioregion.  The biota of the region is still poorly documented, despite a considerable amount of localised survey by government institutions and mining companies.  This hampers assessment of the likely environmental impacts of many economically important development projects, as well as development of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.  New species of terrestrial plants and vertebrates, as well as very large numbers of terrestrial and aquatic invertebrates, are still being discovered in the Pilbara.  In addition, the region has recently been shown to contain a very rich groundwater fauna, which has considerable conservation importance and a high degree of local endemism.

 

 

A regional biological survey will provide an overview of biodiversity in the region and a context for assessing the significance of localised occurrences of surface and groundwater species (see Burbidge et al. 2000).

 

 

Stygofauna has not previously been included in the broadscale biological survey program in Western Australia (eg Burbidge et al. 2000) but lack of information about stygofauna and its distribution in the Pilbara is hampering economically important resource development projects and making it difficult to assess their likely environmental impacts because of the large number of new species being discovered in impact statement surveys. The urgent need for a regional survey to provide a framework for decisions about the conservation and management of stygofauna was identified in Recommendation 1 of Dr Phillip Playford's recent review of stygofauna for the Environmental Protection Authority, as well as at recent workshops involving government and industry. Hatton and Evans (1998, p 2) concluded in their review of the groundwater systems in Australia for LWRRDC that "virtually nothing is known … of biodiversity", although worldwide there is a recognition that groundwater probably contains a greater array of freshwater species than surface waters (Gibert et al. 1994).
aims:
• provide a regional perspective on biodiversity and nature conservation priorities
  • provide a regional context for the conservation implications of development proposals
  • assess the adequacy of the existing reserve system and identify particular species or communities that warrant protection
  • identify gradients in community composition, and the environmental factors related to these gradients, to provide a better understanding of plant and animal distributions and better data on which to base management actions
  • provide systematic baseline data on the distribution of the biota of the region and a framework for future monitoring of regional scale trends
  • undertake taxonomic studies to define and describe key species that define groundwater communities and provide keys for easy identification of the fauna
outcome:
• Recommendations on gaps in the CAR of the existing conservation estate
  • A basis for preparing detailed biodiversity conservation plans, and cost-effective on-ground management both on and off-reserves.
  • More sustainable regional development.
knowledge_transfer: Gov't -- for land-use and sustainable development planning Industry -- as a regional context for environmental impact assessment Education - encourage public interest and concern for nature conservation in region Technology transfer strategy: Scientific publications on biodiversity patterns at the species level or below (including predictive models of occurrence in terms of environmental attributes), and on species/community status, briefings, seminars, data-bases, taxonomic improvements, management priority recommendations to NRM planning group.

01

A four-year field program is envisaged, followed by one year of writing up. Formal analysis and publication of survey results is seen as a vital part of the scientific process. It allows peer review and is an essential quality assurance mechanism. It will not delay local dissemination of results: this should happen rapidly through workshops and informal communications with other interested parties. Between July and August 2002, collation of existing information on the location of boreholes and springs will begin and there will be preliminary liaison with landholders. Stygofaunal sampling will begin in August or September 2002. In July 2003, collation of existing information on terrestrial and surface-water invertebrates will begin, followed by surface-site selection; aquatic sampling will commence in August or September 2003 while terrestrial sampling will begin in April 2004. The final report, ready for publication, will be produced in June 2007.

methodology:
The area to be surveyed is the Pilbara IBRA bioregion. Points to be sampled will be chosen after existing biological data, and relevant climatic, soil and stratigraphic data, from the region have been compiled and reviewed. Metadata for most of the biological datasets have been compiled by government and will soon be housed in the Science Division (Pilbara Environmental Surveys database). In combination, maps available from the above studies and recent work by the Department of Agriculture on vegetation and land units in the region provide a rational basis for stratifying the biodiversity sampling program. The Water and Rivers Commission's database of bores in the Pilbara will be used to locate potentially suitable bores for stygofaunal sampling and results of the recently completed First National Assessment of River Health, using AusRivAS, will be used in the selection of aquatic sites.

The approach being taken is that the survey should be point-based, as comprehensive as possible in terms of the number of taxonomic groups and habitats surveyed, and provide regional-level information about species-level biodiversity patterns in the Pilbara. The survey will focus on four broad components - terrestrial fauna, terrestrial flora, aquatic flora and fauna, and stygofauna.

Sampling methodology for the surveys will be explicit and repeatable. Taxonomic groups to be covered are listed in Table 1. They include the biological groups of most public conservation interest. Other factors influencing selection of taxa were that the survey should focus on a mix of trophic levels, show biogeographic pattern at a variety of scales, and include taxa with well known habitat associations elsewhere to provide an extrinsic context for interpreting survey results.

A range of physical and chemical measurements will be taken at each site to document environmental tolerances of the biota and to enable species and community distributions to be related to environmental gradients. This will allow some predictive modelling of species and community distributions and interpolation across sites that were not sampled.

Sampling strategies

The Pilbara is a large region, with a total area of almost 200,000km2. A large number of sampling sites will be needed to encapsulate the full variation of geological and climatic conditions and to maintain similar site densities to that of previous CALM surveys. The suggested number of sites in each survey component is listed in Table 2.

Survey techniques will conform to accepted practice. At terrestrial survey points, birds will be censused in large quadrats, within which terrestrial mammals (other than bats), reptiles, frogs and spiders/arachnids will be pit-trapped, bats echo-located and plants scored in smaller quadrats. At aquatic survey points, waterbirds will be censused and invertebrates will be collected in sweep nets using a range of mesh sizes. Stygofauna will be collected mostly from boreholes but sampling will also occur at surface springs where groundwater discharges. In most cases, existing boreholes will be used although it is expected that a small number of purpose-drilled holes will be required as well.

Table 1. Taxonomic groups for survey in the six components

  1. Terrestrial fauna

Vertebrates - birds, small/medium mammals, reptiles, frogs, bats at selected sites

Invertebrates - spiders, scorpions and associated arachnids

  1. Terrestrial floraAll vascular plants

  2. Aquatic flora and fauna

Vertebrates - waterbirds

Invertebrates - allFlora - all vascular plants

  1. StygofaunaInvertebrates - all

Staff and associated institutions

The survey will be coordinated, and largely undertaken, by the Department of Conservation and Land Management but staff from the Western Australian Museum will also have a major role. A small number of specialists from other institutions will be involved. Table 3 is a list of staff and institutions with potential direct involvement. We will be seeking assistance and indirect involvement from a wider range of institutions and companies, especially those based in the Pilbara, and will endeavour to maintain a high level of liaison.

Table 2. Number of sampling points and frequency of sampling at each point for different survey components

     Number of sampling points        Frequency

Terrestrial fauna 300 2 x 8 days for vertebrates in good seasons, 1 x 12 months for invertebrates with permanent pit-traps

     50           sub-fossils mammal remains (1 trip ca 3 weeks)

Terrestrial flora 300 2 x 1 day for plants in different seasons. Use existing data from another 300 sites to elucidate finer scale vegetation patterns

Aquatic 90 2 x 1 day in different seasons for plants, invertebrates and waterbirds plus 1 extra visit for waterbirds. Re-sample some of sites previously sampled in the AusRivAS program

Stygofauna 360 4 x 1 day over 3 year period (several collections from the borehole during each day of sampling)

UA University of Adelaide WAM, Western Australian Museum * Terrestrial site selection - McKenzie (0.2), Kendrick (0.1), van Leeuwen (0.1)

Statistical analysis

Data will be compiled as site X species matrices (presence/absence mainly) and analysed deductively to relate gradients in species composition and richness to a separate matrix of the environmental attributes of the sites (climate, soil, geomorphology etc). Numerical analyses will involve classification (e.g. UPGMA), ordination (SSH) and multivariate statistical procedures (including GLIM and information theoretic approaches). Interpolation procedures will be used to generate biological composition surfaces across the region.These will entail updates of the types of analyses used on matricies compiled from the Carnarvon Basin and SAP surveys).

data_management: During the project, data will be compiled and maintained by the relevent sub-project teams. Subsequently it will be both archived, and disseminated in electronic form. Voucher specimen data will be lodged with the Herbarium and WA Museum.

background: The development of perennial-based land use systems for the management of dryland salinity promises significant environmental and economic benefits.  Large scale planting of perennial pastures and woody crops also pose risks to existing natural biodiversity.  These risks include the establishment of new plant species as environmental weeds, hybridization with native species and gene flow from cultivated populations into natural populations (Bennett and Virtue, 2003). Invasive species have been identified as the second greatest threat to biodiversity after habitat destruction (Walker and Steffen, 1997).  Genetic contamination by native species planted outside their natural range can also have negative impacts on the viability of native vegetation.
aims: This project aims to assess and manage the risk posed by introducing large scale plantings of new perennial pastures for managing dryland salinity.  Processes will be established to ensure the protection of biodiversity and prevent newly domesticated plant species from becoming environmental weeds.  The risk of genetic contamination between planted and naturally occurring species will be evaluated, and management processes designed and implemented.  All germplasm released by the Salinity CRC will undergo a rigorous weed risk assessment prior to release, and if necessary, appropriate management plans will be designed and put in place.
outcome:
A strategy for the management of environmental weed risk associated with the development of exotic and naturalized germplasm including pre-release assessment protocols. 

A strategy for the management of genetic risk associated with the development of native Australian germplasm including pre-release assessment protocols. 

Establishment of a national working group involving the CRC for Australian Weed Management, the CRC for Plant-Based Management of Dryland Salinity, Department of CALM, and other government agencies and research groups to develop a co-ordinated national approach to post border weed risk management.
knowledge_transfer: The main users of the knowledge will be plant breeders, revegetation officers, and community groups. Plant breeders will be trained on how to do weed risk assessments through interactive workshops. A weed risk assessment culture will evolve among plant breeders through regular interaction with weed scientists and by developing weed risk assessment systems that are transparent and user friendly. Genetic risk analysis for woody germplasm will be incorporated into development of revegetation systems by Natural Resources Branch

Draft weed risk assessment protocol produced for management of CRC germplasm.  Communication strategy developed for weed risk assessment protocols.

Training courses in weed risk assessment protocols undertaken by half the plant improvement research groups in the CRC.  Formation of a national working group to develop co-ordinated approach to weed risk management.

1/12/2006

Training courses in weed risk assessment protocols undertaken by all plant improvement research groups in the CRC.

1/12/2007

Pre-release weed risk assessment protocol adopted throughout the CRC.  Results of genetic contamination studies presented to national working group and incorporated in CRC risk assessment protocols.  Results of benefit:cost analyses approach to plant assessment and management presented to national working group.
methodology: Initially, existing weed risk assessment will be collated from State and Federal agencies and plant improvement research groups.  This will be used to develop management strategies acceptable across the range of jurisdictions within which the CRC operates.  The specific data sets required for weed risk assessment will be defined, and assessment protocols developed with collaboration from State based weed risk assessment officers.  This will lead to a Pre-release Weed Risk Assessment Protocol for all germplasm developed by the CRC.  Measurements necessary to complete a weed risk assessment will be incorporated into experimental protocols for all plants studied within the CRC.  Weed risk awareness and how to do assessments will be communicated to plant improvement scientists through training workshops.
data_management: Data will be backed up regularly using shared files and hardcopies.

aims: to monitor the post-fire

background:
Aquatic habitats in the south-west of WA are under increasing threat from changes in hydrology, water quality and fire as a result of the drying climate and historical and current land use. At present, there is an inadequate understanding of the responses of aquatic communities to these threats to inform the management of many aquatic systems in the Forest Management Plan area, including the Muir-Byenup Ramsar wetlands.

This project has two components. Priority will be given to component 1, component 2 will be dependent on funding.

1) Re-surveys of aquatic invertebrates in Muir-Byenup Ramsar wetlands sampled in 1994 and 2004 and suites of wetlands further south sampled in 1993. This addresses KPI3 of the 2014-23 FMP.

The FMP area has many high value wetlands, particularly in the Warren region. Some of these are listed as nationally or internationally significant and many are priorities in regional nature conservation plans. These support numerous priority flora species, priority ecological communities, significant waterbirds, 6 of the 8 species of south-west endemic fish and a very high diversity and endemicity of invertebrates. Threats to many of these wetlands have intensified over the last decade. The available biodiversity data is 10 to 20 year old and up to date information is required to assess responses to threats and inform the allocation of resources to management actions.

 

2) Continued monitoring of high condition streams, with a focus on effects of the drying climate and forest management. This addresses KPI1 of the 2014-23 FMP.

KPI20 of the previous FMP scored 24 of 51 monitored stream sites as impaired. This was not clearly related to forestry activities but could, in part, be related to reduced rainfall. This project would see continued monitoring at ‘reference condition’ streams and those that are already affected by reduced rainfall. A focus on these streams aligns with KPI1 of the current FMP which focuses on change in ‘currently healthy ecosystems’ and will allow us to track condition in relation to the ongoing decline in rainfall combined with forest management. In a region with high climatic variability long-term studies are essential to understand ecosystem responses.
aims:
• To address KPI3 of the 2014-2023 FMP by determining responses of fauna of high value Warren region wetlands to changes in hydrology, water chemistry and fire over the last 10 to 20 years.

  • To address KPI1 of the 2014-2023 FMP by monitoring the condition of currently healthy streams in relation to reduced rainfall and forest management practices.

  • Provide baseline data for some internationally significant wetlands, e.g. Lake Muir.

  • Use the above information to report on the current conservation significance of key DPaW managed wetlands and their response and vulnerability to threats.
outcome:
1)    FMP commitments met with regard to measuring and assessing change in condition of: 1) currently healthy (reference condition) stream ecosystems (KPI1); and 2) Ramsar and nationally listed wetlands (KPI3). Results will provide information on the effectiveness of forest management practices in protecting stream and wetland biodiversity.

2)    Warren Region conservation managers will have the information needed to address a priority identified in the 2009-14 Warren Region Nature Conservation Plan: Target 5, candidate action 1, including the milestones.

“Analyse condition trends [of 7 nationally listed wetlands] and update adaptive management targets on the basis of these trends” and

“Establish and consolidate benchmark information for Broke Inlet, Doggerup, Marringup, Mt Soho Swamp, and Byenup to determine condition, identify threats and to determine interim management actions.”

Indications from Warren Region staff are that these wetlands will be a priority in the new 2015-20 Regional Nature Conservation Plan.

Using the above information on knowledge of the biodiversity trajectories of wetlands in the Muir-Byenup Ramsar system and other wetlands Warren Region staff will be better placed to prioritise conservation actions.

3)    DPaW will be able to report on the condition of a significant Ramsar site.
knowledge_transfer:
The main users of the knowledge gained in this project will be DPaW Warren Region staff and other DPaW staff working in areas which require them to understand and manage streams and wetlands, especially those in the conservation estate.

Results will also be used by Forest and Ecosystems Management Division and the Conservation Commission to assess compliance with the FMP 2014-2023.

Project results will be disseminated by:

  • Reports on the aquatic invertebrates of the Muir-Byenup and South Coast wetlands (KPI3 component)
  • Reports on condition of selected streams in the FMP area (KPI1 component)
  • Science Information Sheets and scientific publications as appropriate.
  • Presentations at workshops etc.

Below is a timeline for a five year project including sampling the Muir-Byenup Ramsar wetlands and significant wetlands along the south coast, plus an additional sampling of a selection of the KPI20 streams. Further sampling of these streams would be dependant on continued funding.

Autumn 2018 to Summer 2018/19  Process south coast samples

2019 onwards Optional further stream sampling

Data will be entered into the Wetlands Conservation Program aquatic database.

Data will also be uploaded to Naturemap where biological and physichemical data will be described in the catalogue.

Specimen vouchers will be lodged with the Western Australin Museum and the Wetlands Conservation Program aquatic invertebrate voucher collection.

related_projects: western ringtail possum translocation outcomes SPP number to be allocated
background:
Findings from CALM’s _Operation Foxglove_ resulted in recommendations to increase the standard operational 1080 baiting regime from a frequency of four baitings per year to six baitings per year for large areas of the multiple use northern jarrah forest.  The findings were based on a long term study of survivorship of translocated populations of the brush-tailed bettong, or woylie, _Bettongia penicillata_.  The preferred model to describe the survivorship data was constrained by the covariate “released in winter” and suggested survivorship was lower for woylies released in winter.  This model found the probability of woylie survivorship in areas baited six times per year was significantly higher over the duration of the study than in areas baited at the standard operational baiting frequency of four times per year (de Tores_ et al._, 1998; de Tores_ et al._, in prep-a).  Population modeling also showed translocated populations were unlikely to persist in the presence of the standard baiting regime (de Tores_ et al._, in prep-a).

 

The survivorship study, based on a sample size of 366 radio collared woylies monitored continuously over a 33 month period, also indicated the number of radio-collared woylie mortality events attributed to predation by cats was greater in two of the three fox baited treatments than in the unbaited control (de Tores_ et al._, in prep-a).  The data suggest a reduction in the number of predation events attributed to foxes was compensated for by an increase in the number of predation events attributed to cats.  This pattern is consistent with the principle of mesopredator release.  Similar conclusions were drawn from survivorship data for woylies translocated from Western Australia and South Australia to Yathong Nature Reserve, western NSW.  The Yathong Nature Reserve translocation was deemed to have failed as a result of predation by cats.  Foxes were considered to no longer be a threat to wildlife at Yathong, however, in the presence of fox control, 74% of the known predation events were attributed to predation by cats (Priddel and Wheeler, 2004).  Results from woylie translocations elsewhere have rarely been able to demonstrate translocation success.  Of approximately 34 translocations in Western Australia, only four (to Yendicup forest (Perup), Batalling forest, Boyagin Nature Reserve and Karakamia Sanctuary) have unequivocally demonstrated translocation success.  Of these, Batalling is a known anomaly as it supports a suite of rare fauna with populations of at least two species established as a result of translocation.  Boyagin Nature Reserve is within 50km of Dryandra (the source of the translocated woylies) and it is hypothesised that translocation success is a function of the presence of critical habitat attributes and effective fox control.  Similarly, the habitat at Yendicup is comparable to that in neighbouring forest areas where woylies have persisted.  Karakamia Sanctuary is enclosed by a predator proof (fox and cat proof) fence and provides no opportunity for re-invasion by cats.  The combined results suggest that in some sites, fox control alone is insufficient to result in translocation success for the woylie and successful translocations are dependent on cat exclusion and/or the presence of specific habitat attributes.  In the absence of a target specific cat bait, CALM’s ability to control cats will be limited (i.e. cat baiting may not be possible in the south-west forests where non-target species occur).  

 

Foxglove data also demonstrated re-invasion of foxes occurred within two weeks of an aerial baiting event and fox density was higher in forest areas closer to the interface with agricultural land than in core areas of the forest.  The number/proportion of foxes surviving a 1080 baiting event in the northern jarrah forest was unknown, as was the extent to which foxes may be bait shy or bait wary.

 

The interactions between the two introduced predator species (fox and cat) and the resident native predator species from the northern jarrah forest, the chuditch, _Dasyurus geoffroii_, are also poorly understood.  Predation by chuditch was thought to be limiting translocation success of the western ringtail possum, _Pseudocheirus occidentalis_, in baited areas of the northern jarrah forest (de Tores, unpublished data).  Data from other western ringtail possum translocation sites has also clearly implicated predation by cats and  pythons to be limiting translocation success (de Tores, 2005; de Tores_ et al._, 2005a; de Tores_ et al._, 2005b) and mesopredator release has been strongly implicated as a potential reason for this lack of success (de Tores, 2005).  There has been no assessment of the effect of fox control on the two large predatory varanids, _Varanus gouldii_ and _V. rosenbergi_.
aims:
Specific aims are to test the mesopredator release hypotheses.  The conservation significance of mesopredator release will be examined in relation to pythons, chuditch, both large varanids and both introduced predator species (fox and cat), as will the conservation significance of intraguild predation.  Assessment of population density, habitat use, behaviour, survivorship and fecundity of these species will also be examined in the presence and absence of fox control.  The long term result will be to determine if fox control leads to mesopredator release, and, if so, which predator species show this mesopredator release response.  The research will also determine whether the effects of mesopredator release can be mitigated by baiting to control feral cats.

Hypothesis tested are set in an Information-Theoretic approach context:

Hypothesis:       In the presence of sustained and long-term fox control which effectively reduces fox abundance, other predators increase in abundance - i.e. there is a mesopredator release effect.

Hypothesis:       The resulting level of predation from mesopredator release outweighs the conservation benefits from fox control.
outcome:
The project will determine whether fox control results in detrimental indirect effects.  Specifically, it will determine if cat abundance increases in the presence of fox control and if so, does this result in negative conservation outcomes.  In achieving this, the project will test the mesopredator release hypothesis.  The project will also assess fauna response in relation to fox and cat abundance and a suite of environmental factors.

Managers will be better placed by knowing if fox control does result in detrimental indirect effects and can make more informed decisions on the benefits of fox control in the absence of cat control.
knowledge_transfer: Wildlife researchers and managers (e.g. biologists involved in assessing fauna response/recovery generally and CALM staff involved in Western Shield) responsible for a broad range of monitoring of survivorship (particularly those interested in adopting appropriate new technologies), habitat use and density/abundance estimates. The project will provide critical information on the genetic structure of the south-west carpet python from the northern jarrah forest and will therefore be of immediate value to CALM employees involved in wildlife licencing and law enforcement.
