methodology:
Baiting regimes

The northern jarrah forest component of the Western Australian Demonstration Site will implement the major findings from Operation Foxglove and adopt “best practice” fox control for large areas of the northern jarrah forest by implementing a 1080 fox baiting regime of six baitings per year.  This baited area will be divided into two zones, both initially baited six times per year (see Fig 1).  One of these zones (nominally the northern zone) will, subsequently (two years post commencement of the project) be baited concurrently with fox baits and the cat bait, “Eradicat”.  Use of Eradicat is subject to further development, trials and confirmation of its suitability for broadscale application in a forest environment.  An alternative regime is proposed in the event a suitable cat bait is unavailable.  Under this alternative scenario, fox baiting will be withdrawn from the northern zone and this zone will effectively revert to an unbaited area.  Under both scenarios, the suite of predator and prey species will be monitored.

The study site will retain the majority of the former large (unbaited) control site from Operation Foxglove (Fig 1).  The size of each baited area is still subject to negotiation.

Estimating fox abundance and assessment of use of the landscape by foxes

Estimates of fox abundance will be derived through modified use of the sandplotting technique previously used and validated in Operation Foxglove (de Tores_ et al._, in prep-c).

A description of the technique and findings is extracted below from de Tores et al. (in prep-c):

25 sandplots, each 1mx1m were established within a grid/roading network of approximately 25km2, with a minimum distance of 500m between neighbouring sandplots.  Each sandplot was placed at the edge of an existing road or track, with the shape of sandplot grid/web network determined by the existing road and track network.  The exact area required to capture all 25 sandplots within each sandplot grid/web network was determined by calculating the minimum convex polygon (MCP) which encompassed all sandplots (Ranges6 software) (Kenward_ et al._, 2003).  A 500m buffer (ESRI, 1999-2004) was added to the Ranges determined MCP to estimate the final area capturing all 25 sandplots within each grid/web network.

A small cube of approximately 50g of fresh mutton was buried 5-10mm below the surface of the sand.  The sand was then raked smooth and lightly sprayed with water.  Each sandplot was monitored daily for ten consecutive days.  The presence/absence of fox spoor (i.e. track or scat) or other recognisable evidence of fox activity on each sandplot was recorded daily.  Presence of spoor was interpreted as an indicator of fox presence.  Identifiable spoor and evidence of activity of other species were also recorded.  The removal of rewards (mutton) was recorded and each removed reward was replaced.  All rewards were periodically checked and partially decomposed rewards were replaced.  Sandplots showing evidence of activity and/or removal of rewards were re-raked and each sandplot, whether showing activity or not, was lightly re-sprayed with water daily.  Sandplots were monitored immediately prior to the delivery of 1080 baits. 

Where neighbouring sandplots showed evidence of fox activity this was interpreted as indicating the presence of the same fox at those plots.  A break in continuity of sandplots showing evidence of activity, with two or more sandplots without evidence of activity between sandplots showing activity, was interpreted as indicating the presence of an additional fox.  Similarly, a break of more than 1km between plots showing activity was interpreted as indicating the presence of additional foxes.  The pattern of sandplots showing activity was mapped daily.  The estimated number of foxes was recorded daily at each sandplot grid/web and the cumulative mean after ten days was derived as:

Cumulative mean number of foxes = (cumulative number of foxes /

number of days monitored).

A pairwise correlation matrix (StataCorp, 2005) was then generated for the daily cumulative mean for days one to ten for the pooled data for all years, pre 1080 baiting.  The correlation value (r) was then plotted for each day.  An r value (correlation) of 0.9009 was observed at six days.

Fox density was estimated for each sandplot grid/web network by dividing the cumulative mean number of foxes at day 10 by the area derived from the MCP, inclusive of the 500m buffer. 

Proposed variations to the above are:

·       The number of sandplots with a reward will be halved and selection of sandplots with a reward within any sandplot area will be random (this will reduce the take by non target species);

·       Each sandplot will also be treated with the Pestat Ltd developed lure, synthetic fermented egg (FeralMone®);

·       Up to four sandplotting areas (each with 25 1x1m sand plots within an area of 25km2) will be established within each of the baited treatments and will be monitored for approximately 6 consecutive days each season.  Spacing between sandplotting areas will be maximised to maintain independence of each sandplotting area.

Fox scats will be collected seasonally, during and immediately post sandplotting.  Scats will be used in a collaborative program (with IA CRC UWA post doctoral researcher, Dr Oliver Berry) using molecular techniques aimed at determining the number of individual foxes present.  The presence of fox activity will be used to select trap placement (Victor Soft Catch, padded leg hold traps) for fox trapping.  Trapped foxes will be fitted with ARGOS satellite telemetry radio tags which, subject to developmental trials, will incorporate contact/proximity circuitry.  Satellite tags will be “duty tasked” to enable collection of diurnal and nocturnal location records and to minimise the effects of autocorrelation.  The number of radio collared foxes and hence the sample size for analyses of habitat use and use of the landscape, will be determined by capture rates.  Trapping will be carried out seasonally, post sandplotting, and opportunistically when fox presence is observed, to maintain the radio collared sample size.  The use of contact/proximity is proposed to assist in determining the predator responsible for predation events (see native fauna monitoring below) and to assist in the detection and extent of intraguild predation.  Radio telemetry monitoring will also determine if the fox population within the baited areas is being “turned over” by successive baiting events, or if there is a resident “bait shy” / “bait avoiding” population.  Similarly, molecular analyses of scats will determine if individual foxes are surviving successive baiting events.  If shown to be a viable technique for identifying individuals, the molecular analyses may also reveal the population genetic structure, specifically, it should indicate the extent of stability of the populations within the baited and unbaited areas.  The conservation implications of this, i.e. the extent to which introduced predator population stability affects native prey populations, is unknown and will be examined.

Estimating cat abundance and assessment of use of the landscape by cats

A combination of lures (the felid attracting phonid, or FAP), rewards, leg hold and wire cage traps and camera stations will be used to monitor for the presence of cats.  At worst, data from these techniques will be used to derive an index to abundance.  A suite of techniques will also be trialled for collection of hair/hair follicles for identification of individuals through molecular techniques.  As per the molecular analyses of fox populations, the conservation implications of the cat population genetic structure will be examined.

Trapped cats will also be fitted with also ARGOS satellite telemetry radio tags which, again subject to developmental trials, will incorporate contact/proximity circuitry, as per the fox satellite telemetry.

Fox dietary analyses

The fox scats used for molecular analyses will also be examined to determine the major dietary items and to examine the temporal and spatial variation in fox diet.  This variation will be compared with the temporal and spatial availability of medium and small mammal prey species, reptile species and invertebrate prey species.  The latter (temporal and spatial availability the invertebrate food resource) is subject to securing a stipend for a PhD student for this work.

The fox scats will be collected seasonally from each of the four grids/networks from each of the two baited treatment zones and the control site within which sandplotting is carried out.  Collection of scats will be during and immediately post sandplotting with scats collected from open ground, roadside and tracks from within the sandplot grid/network only.  The location of each collected scat will be recorded (GPS) and attributed according to the category of road/track from which it was collected.  All collected scats will be individually labelled and frozen for storage.  Post thawing, scats will be oven dried at 50-600C for 48 hours to minimise potential of survival of parasites.  Scats will then be washed over a series of sieves and retained material allowed to dry before sorting into the major groups of interest – fur, bones, teeth, reptile skin and scales, feathers, plant material and invertebrates. 

The percentage of occurrence of each category of prey and total number of prey items will be recorded seasonally.  This will be compared with results from the seasonal availability prey for each category of prey (below).  Ideally this will be in a “resource selection” framework.

Native fauna monitoring

Survivorship monitoring of indicator species

Woylie survivorship and population modeling (de Tores_ et al._, in prep-a) showed the previously translocated woylie populations are unlikely to have established self sustaining populations.  However, some individuals and/or populations may have persisted.  Initially, a one-off trapping program will be carried out at sites at and near the original Operation Foxglove translocation release sites within the current study area (Fig 1) and subsequently more widely within the study area.  Any trapped woylies will be fitted with movement sensitive mortality transmitters.  Subject to developmental work and trials, woylies will subsequently be fitted with contact/proximity collars.  Survivorship will be monitored weekly.  Monitoring emphasis will be on determining the predator responsible for mortality events attributed to predation.  Subject to the number of woylies trapped and incorporated into monitored sample, monitoring will also assess the fate of all radio collared woylies, will re-assess survivorship probability and will model the probability of the population(s) becoming self sustaining under the new baiting regimes.

Translocation of the boodie, Bettongia lesueur, is proposed for both baited areas and the unbaited control.  The translocation and the number of boodies translocated is subject to CALM approval of a translocation proposal and, as per the seasonal trapping, will proceed subsequent to the treatment areas receiving their requisite number of baitings in the preceding 12 months.  Boodies will be fitted with contact/proximity collars and monitored weekly to assess survivorship.  The use of surgically implanted transmitters will also be investigated for sub-adult and juvenile boodies.  Data will be analysed to model the probability of the translocated individuals establishing self sustaining populations in the presence and absence of fox control.  Monitoring will also focus on determining the cause of any known mortality events, with particular emphasis on the extent of cat and fox predation pre and post implementing cat control (cat baiting) in the northern baited area.

Distribution, abundance and survivorship of monitored populations of the common brushtail possum, Trichosurus vulpecula, in the northern jarrah forest was shown to be a function of multi-dimensional factors, and not simply a function of the level of fox control imposed (de Tores_ et al., in prep-b; de Tores et al._, in prep-d).  However, survivorship of sub-adult and juvenile possums was not assessed.  Subject to securing a CRC PhD stipend, survivorship of the common brushtail possum will be assessed with emphasis on juvenile and sub-adult possums.  This is now achievable through use of recently refined breakaway collars.  Where possible, this technology will incorporate contact/proximity telemetry.  If deemed necessary, surgically implanted transmitters will be assessed for use in juvenile and sub-adult common brushtail possums.

Results of survivorship monitoring of radio-collared indicator species (woylies and/or boodies and/or possums) will be analysed through use of a set of a priori candidate models and model selection based on Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) (Burnham and Anderson, 2002) in “Program Mark” (White, 2001).  The set of a priori candidate models will be examined to determine the model(s) which best describe survivorship.  Candidate models will include variables on fox and cat abundance and abundance estimates of other predator and alternative prey species.  Candidate models will also include habitat and environmental variables. 

Animal handling and marking

All mammal species trapped (woylies, possums, chuditch – see post doctoral research component for the chuditch study) or translocated (boodies) and fitted with radio collars will be anaesthetised using isoflurane gas anaesthetic (delivered using a conventional Modified Bains small animal anaesthetic machine) when collars are fitted.

Species collared will be restrained in calico or hessian bags while being mask-induced using 5% isoflurane.  Once anaesthetised, animals will be placed on a heat pad and maintained on 1.5% isoflurane concentration and an oxygen flow rate of 1.5 litres/min.  Intubation is not necessary; however, endotracheal tubes and a laryngoscope will be available in case of emergency.  Once collaring processes are complete the isoflurane will be turned off and animals will be allowed to breathe pure oxygen for a few minutes until they start to regain consciousness.  They will then be returned to calico or hessian bags, put onto heat pads and allowed to recover in a quiet place.  They will be regularly checked until fully conscious. 

All animals captured and held for collaring will be processed during of capture/trap clearing.  Unless identified as being unsuitable for release, each animal will be released that evening. 

Each medium size mammal will also have a subcutaneously implanted passive transponder (Trovan® brand) for unique identification.   A reflective ear tag will also be applied to radio collared possums.  For radio collared animals, transponders and ear tags will be applied when the animal is under inhalation anaesthesia.  Transponders will be implanted subcutaneously between the shoulder blades. 

A small ear biopsy will be collected from each woylie, boodie, chuditch and possum captured for radio-collaring.  Biopsy samples will be stored for future genetic analyses.  With the exception of woylies (and possibly boodies) which have a marginal vein in the pinna, ear biopsies will be taken from the outer edge of the pinna when the animal is under inhalation anaesthesia.  Biopsies will use a 5mm biopsy punch, leaving a notch on the edge of the ear.  In the case of woylies, the ear biopsy will be taken from a more proximal part of the pinna.  Biopsy punches will be flame sterilised between uses, and the animal’s skin will be disinfected prior to taking of the biopsy sample.  Ear tissue samples will be stored in DMSO4 until genetic analyses can be carried out.

Alternative marking techniques will be investigated for all varanids – toe clipping is unlikely to be used and use of transponders and bird banding techniques will be investigated for allocating a unique identifier to each animal.

Seasonal and spatial availability of native prey species

The study will establish native fauna trapping webs to assess the temporal and spatial availability of the suite of small and medium size mammal fauna, the reptile fauna and invertebrate fauna.  The latter is subject to securing a CRC PhD stipend.  The trapping webs will be configured in accordance DISTANCE sampling web design (Buckland_ et al., 2001; Lukacs et al., 2005) to ensure data are suitable for analyses through DISTANCE (Thomas et al._, 2005) and conventional mark-recapture techniques (Burnham and Anderson, 2002; White, 2001).  These trapping webs will each be approximately 3.8ha in area, will incorporate wire cage, Elliott and vertebrate pitfall traps and will representatively sample the major habitat units within each of the baited treatments and the unbaited control.  Trapping will be conducted seasonally to determine the spatial and seasonal variation in the suite of prey species.  Seasonal trapping will commence once the treatment areas have received their requisite number of baitings in the preceding 12 months.

Monitoring of pythons

The south-west carpet python, Morelia spilota imbricata, is recognised as a threatened species.  The ecology of Western Australian wheatbelt and insular populations has been studied (Pearson, 2002) and a wealth of information exists on these populations.  However, populations from jarrah forest are poorly understood.  Predation by the carpet python has also recently been linked to the lack of success of translocation programs of the threatened arboreal mammal species, Pseudocheirus occidentalis, at coastal sites in the south-west of Western Australia (de Tores, 2005; de Tores_ et al., 2005a; de Tores et al._, 2005b).  In collaboration with Murdoch University, CALM has commenced a PhD program studying various aspects of the ecology of the south-west carpet python.  This PhD program will assess the carpet python’s response, in a spatial context, to broadscale and localised introduced predator control (fox baiting programs) and will determine the role and importance of this ambush predator to translocation outcomes.  The program will also determine if there is a mesopredator release response by the south-west carpet python in the presence of fox control.  A sample size of approximately 10-15 radio-tagged (implanted) pythons is envisaged in the northern jarrah forest with an equivalent sample size at coastal sites.  The implanted transmitters (Holohil Systems) will incorporate temperature sensitive circuitry to provide information on seasonal variation in activity patterns.  Pythons implanted will be those known to have preyed on native species, as detected through monitoring of those species, and opportunistically collected pythons.  Monitoring will assess the frequency of prey species taken by pythons through periodic recapture of pythons and assessment of regurgitated gut contents and scat contents.  A broad range of data will also be collected on refuge and habitat use in the presence and absence of fox control.

This component of the project will also assess relationships between micro- and macro-habitat use, thermal biology (temperature regulation) in relation to microhabitat use and the influence of prey consumption, and prey distribution and abundance, to provide information for conservation strategies for this threatened species.  The work will also determine whether implanting a radio transmitter into pythons causes any infectious or inflammatory response by examining python haematology pre-and-post implantation of the radio transmitters.  Blood samples will be collected prior to, and following, implantation to enable assessment/detection of any infectious and/or inflammatory processes that may be caused by the implantation process. The thermal biology of the pythons will be monitored very closely post-implantation (using the heat-sensitive transmitters and a lazar temperature reader) for the following few days. Human patients will show signs of infection within 2-3 days post inoculation with increased body temperatures.

The study will also examine the genetic variation of carpet pythons within the northern jarrah forest.  This will allow baseline genetic data to be established. It will be valuable to conservation mangers to assess if populations are diverging genetically as increasing habitat loss may not be allowing sufficient genetic flow between populations. Genetic data will also be useful for people managing reptiles as pets, where captive bred reptiles are genetically monitored and illegal taking of pythons from the wild can be traced more effectively. The genetic information will be analysed through a collaborative effort with geneticists at Murdoch University. Measurements of genetic variation within the python population will involve scoring the presence or absence of attributes (genes or genetically determined morphological features) in the individuals, then extrapolating to arrive at estimates of the relative frequency of the attributes in the population (Lindenmayer and Burgman, 2005).

Capture marking and identification of study animals

Pythons will be captured in the following ways:

(a) Pythons found (through the above radio telemetry monitoring of native prey speies) to have preyed upon native species, will be captured and held for inclusion in the python ecology component of the research.  Pythons collected as a result of known predation events will be temporarily housed at the Dwellingup Research Centre until such time as the remains of the prey is regurgitated with the collar, or the collar is passed in a scat.  Alternatively, if the collar is not regurgitated or passed, once it is deemed that all prey has been digested and all faecal matter naturally passed, the python will be physically massaged to encourage it to regurgitate the radio collar.

(b) Attempts will be made to capture all pythons opportunistically sighted within the northern jarrah forest.  These captures will most likely be a result of sightings at night when driving, during summer (when pythons are most active and may cross roads more often) and sightings by the research team and/or District CALM employees.  Guidance and approval from CALM’s Nature Protection Branch will be sought when developing protocols for CALM employees to opportunistically collect pythons that they find within the study areas.

Opportunistically caught pythons will be physically restrained using conventional methods for handling snakes (pythons will be collected with care using either or a combination of conventional ‘head-grab’ behind the quadrate bone and the use of specialised snake hook and metal rimmed rounded calico bag). Following capture the pythons will be placed into a Hessian or calico bag to be transported to the Dwellingup Research Centre for the procedures documented below.

Each python will be individually marked by scale marking as described by Pearson (2002), however, use of Trovan® inert passive transponders will be also be investigated as an alternative identification technique.  The south-west carpet python is known to be able to “pass” surgically implanted transmitters (Pearson, 2002) and this phenomenon may make use of transponders ineffective.

Radio telemetry and transmitter implantation

The monitored sample size will be determined by the number of known predation events of native prey species, however a sample of 10 to 15 pythons is envisaged from the northern jarrah forest (exclusive of an approximate equal number of pythons monitored in the concurrent research at the western ringtail possum translocation sites).   Sterile radio transmitters will be surgically implanted into the abdominal cavity of each python. Different types (four sizes) of the temperature-sensitive radio transmitters (Holohil Systems Ltd., Canada) will be used depending on the size of the python.  All transmitters will be <5% of the python’s body mass.  Aerials will be encased in 2mm non-toxic Silastic® tubing and the entire unit sealed with 734 flowable sealant (Dow Corning Corporation).  The battery cell life of each transmitter package used will vary depending upon the size of the snake to be implanted (larger pythons can be implanted with a larger battery cell/transmitter package).  Smaller cell/transmitter packages (3 or 5 g) will last for approximately 28 and 35 weeks respectively, whereas, the larger cell/transmitter packages (13 or 21 g) will last between 18-24 months.

Transmitters will be calibrated using a waterbath and circulating heater (Thermoline, Australia) against a certified mercury bulb thermometer (±0.1ºC). Temperature will be increased by 5ºC increments from 0-40 ºC. The period between pulses will be recorded using a Period/PPM meter (Titley Electronics, Australia) together with the time taken to hear 10 pulses using a stopwatch. The former measure is used for calculating body temperature from an automated telemetry system and the latter for data collected during fieldwork. Body temperatures of the pythons will be determined by applying third-order polynomial equations derived from calibration data. Transmitters will be calibrated following removal from the pythons to ensure there has not been significant drift in calibration.

Pythons will be anaesthetised using Isoflurane (“Forthane”, Abbott Pty. Ltd.) gas anaesthesia, intubated and with intermittent positive pressure ventilation used to induce and maintain the anaesthesia. Once under anaesthesia, each python will be given an intra-muscular injection of Ceftazidime 20mg/kg, which is a long-acting antibiotic used to prevent peri-operative infection. While maintaining each python under anaesthesia, surgical implantation of the radio transmitters will be achieved using an aseptic technique into the peritoneum through a mid-lateral incision 10% of the snake’s snout-vent-length (SVL) anterior to the vent. Absorbable sutures will be used to close the incision. Once the python shows signs of recovery from the anaesthetic procedure they will be given an intra-muscular injection of Butorphanol at 0.5 mg/kg. Butorphanol is an analgesic agent and is thought to provide pain relief for up to approximately 4 hours in reptiles. It has a slight sedative effect so the snakes will be maintained in a warm, quiet environment for one-three nights following the surgery and then released to point of capture. The administration of Butorphanol is important for initial post-operative pain relief. Further medication for pain relief is not warranted since the surgery is a relatively simple procedure that does not involve incision through muscle, organs or bone. During anaesthesia, standard morphometric data will be recorded. Pythons that have been implanted will be followed using radio telemetry for the duration of the study period. When possible, pythons will be recaptured close to the end of battery life of the transmitter and removed or replaced if necessary.

Study pythons will be tracked on a week-to-fortnight basis over the study duration. Pythons will be tracked on foot using a 3-element yagi aerial (Sirtrak Ltd., New Zealand) and receiver (RX3, Biotelemetry Services, Australia). The exact position of the pythons will be determined using a differential GPS system (post-processing using Thales MobileMapper software). Previous studies suggest that most pythons do not typically flee when approached by researchers in the field (Pearson, 2002). Therefore, behaviour, posture, proportion of body in sun, cloud cover and aspects of micro- and macro-habitat use will be recorded. Temperature recordings will be taken to gain information on microhabitat use and thermal regulation of the pythons. Temperature recordings will be taken to assess the various insulator capabilities of microhabitats and thermoregulation of pythons, quantified with data loggers.  This aspect will investigate different options for data logging information including implanted data loggers (encased within the implanted vhf radio transmitter) and stand-alone loggers to record physiological and immediate microhabitat environmental data.

Dietary analysis

Pythons collected for implantation of radio transmitters will be held for brief periods (1-2 days) for dietary analysis, including analysis of diet in relation to body size (the south-west carpet python shows strong body size sexual dimorphism (Pearson, 2002)).  Captive held pythons that have recently consumed prey will be palpated to obtain regurgitated and faecal material (this will occur also to ensure pythons have an empty stomach prior to anaesthesia).  Additional collection of faecal and regurgitated material for analysis will occur in the field through the radio telemetry study. This will limit the time spent in contact with, and limit/negate time spent in captivity for the python. Collection for dietary analysis will most likely be made on a bimonthly basis for each study animal. Limited additional collection of regurgitated material will occur opportunistically, where there is clear evidence (bulge in python) that there is recently obtained prey.

The results from the dietary analysis will be compared with the seasonal availability of prey (see above) and analyses will examine whether any species is preferentially selected as a prey item.

Haematology

When pythons are anaesthetised (to implant transmitter) a blood sample will be collected from the ventral midline, prior to and post implantation. The serum collected will be used to undertake haematology analysis. The haematology testing will enable the detection of any infectious and/or inflammatory response to the radio transmitter being implanted. Without haematology testing, information on the health status of the study python may otherwise go undetected by basic visual examination.

Telemetry data

For each individual python, location datasets will be divided into various categories (e.g. day/night, season, breeding status).  Survivorship will be modeled through the use of Program MARK (White, 2001).  Ranges 6 (Kenward_ et al._, 2003) using harmonic mean analyses will be used to generate an overall home-range estimate for each individual.  Home range estimates will be incorporated into a GIS (ESRI, 1999-2004) or analysed directly in Ranges (Jacobs Index) to determine if there is preferential use of any of the major habitat units (as identified and delineated through use of digital imagery in the GIS).  Habitat use will also be analysed between baited and unbaited sites. 

Genetic analysis

Genetic analysis will be undertaken in collaboration with Peter Spencer, Murdoch University, and CALM’s Nature Protection Branch (to be confirmed).  The scales removed from each study python at their initial capture will be used to provide the sample for genetic analysis.  In the absence, or in addition to scale marking, genetic analysis may use blood obtained for haematology analysis (as reptile red blood cells are nucleated and each cell therefore contains that individual’s DNA). A smear of blood will be placed onto FTA paper, dried and stored in a cool, dry environment for future analysis. Additional to blood smears, mouth swab sample collection for genetic analysis will occur.  Mouth swabs will be collected onto sterile cotton buds then smeared onto FTA paper, dried and stored in the same manner as the blood samples.

Post doctoral research

The chuditch, Dasyurus geoffroii, has been shown to respond to fox control.  This response has been through increases in detectability and inferred increases in survivorship and abundance.  However, the mechanisms driving this response – i.e. less direct predation, increased prey availability, less competition for resources – are unclear.  The chuditch post doctoral research program will address these issues in collaboration with the concurrent research on fox and cat interactions and the issues of alternative prey availability in the northern jarrah forest.

Unconfirmed anecdotal accounts suggest the two large predatory varanids, Varanus gouldii and V. rosenbergi, known to occur within the northern jarrah forest, have increased in abundance since the commencement of fox baiting.  These reports are yet to be confirmed and cannot be supported by quantified records.  As for the chuditch, the mechanisms driving these increases, if they are occurring, are unclear.  The varanid post doctoral research program will address these issues in collaboration with the concurrent research on fox and cat interactions and the issues of alternative prey availability in the northern jarrah forest.
no_specimens: The number of voucher specimens is dependent on the number of mortality events of monitored indicator prey species (woylies, boodies, possums). A subset only of these mortality events will be forwarded to the WAM. Python, varanid, chuditch, possum, woylie and boodie mortalities will be held initially for post mortem and, if required, subsequently forwarded to the West Australian Museum. A representative sample of each of the reptile and small mammal species trapped will be forwarded to the WAM – exact number is unknown. Retrieved fox and cat carcasses will be held for examination of gut contents and, subject to the requirements of the WAM, subsequently forwarded to the WAM.
data_management: The following general principles will be adopted: • Hard copies of data collected during processing of animals or in the field will be filed and stored for backup and reference. • All data collected during the project will be entered into the relevant relational database (in MS Access) which will be built to conform with database normalisation principles. Databases will have a purpose built front end. • The databases will be designed to enable component data sets to be easily linked and analysed. For example, the unique identifier for each individual possum/python/fox/cat will be used as a key field in a base table, with referential integrity links to secondary tables holding data on health screening, radio-collaring, radio-telemetry location monitoring records, predation events and ultimate fate. Habitat data will be stored similarly.

related_projects: Northern jarrah forest mesopredator release research, SPP to be allocated
background:
The following has been extracted from the 2005 translocation proposal (de Tores, 2005), the 2004/2005 Science Division Activity Report, the publication prepared for the 2003 review of western shield (de Tores_ et al._, 2004), two popular press publications (de Tores_ et al._, 2005a; de Tores_ et al._, 2005c) and amended and updated where necessary:

 

 

 

Background  -  Distribution and conservation status

 

At the time of European settlement, the western ringtail possum, _Pseudocheirus occidentalis_, had a distribution which encompassed the south-west of Western Australia and extended from north of Jurien, to the south-west of Western Australia and east to the Esperance Plain (de Tores, in prep).  As recently as the 1970s the distribution included Wheatbelt areas near Pingelly (de Tores, in prep; Jones_ et al._, 1994).  Although there are recent unconfirmed reports of western ringtail possum presence from the Pingelly area, from Sawyers Valley/Mundaring and from the Darling Scarp near Jarrahdale, the distribution is now thought to have contracted to the south-west corner of Western Australia, with the most northerly confirmed record of occurrence (exclusive of translocated populations) in jarrah/marri forest and peppermint riverine habitat northeast of Harvey (de Tores, in prep).

 

The recent review of distribution and conservation status (de Tores, in prep) found the western ringtail possum met the IUCN (World Conservation Union) criteria (IUCN, 2001) for listing as a threatened species in the sub-category “Vulnerable”. 

 

History of previous western ringtail possum translocations

 

Despite being listed as a “threatened” species, the western ringtail possum is locally common in the Busselton area of south-west Western Australia.  Orphaned, injured and “nuisance” western ringtail possums are regularly brought into care and nurtured and/or rehabilitated by wildlife carers.  Historically, when the wildlife carers decided these possums were suitable for release, the animals were “provided” to the Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) and released as part of a translocation and monitoring program.  Many were not “provided” to CALM and were released, and continue to be released, in an _ad-hoc_ un-monitored manner.  The latter has not been sanctioned by CALM.  The pre-release health and disease status and subsequent fate of these released animals are unknown.

 

In the Busselton area in particular, local and State Government approved developments have resulted in fragmentation and removal/destruction of western ringtail possum habitat.  Resident populations of western ringtail possums are regularly displaced as a result of this habitat fragmentation and habitat loss.  If unchecked, this habitat fragmentation will present a major threat to the western ringtail possum.

 

Existing known threats to the species include (de Tores, in prep; Wayne_ et al._, 2000):

 

·                population fragmentation through urbanisation and development in the Busselton, Bunbury and Albany areas;

 

·                predation from introduced predators;

 

·                increased predation in the presence of timber harvesting operations; and

 

·                climate change.

 

Translocation has been adopted as a management strategy to mitigate the effects from habitat clearing.  However, results from translocation have been equivocal.  Translocations of the western ringtail possum have been carried out by CALM since 1991.  A total of 381 western ringtail possums was translocated to four release sites in the period 1991 to 2001.

 

Of these, 106 rehabilitated possums, ex wildlife carers, were released at Leschenault Peninsula Conservation Park in the period from 1991 to 1997; 142 were sourced directly from the wild (development sites, where habitat was destroyed), and released at Yalgorup National Park (two sites) in the period 1995 to 2001; and 133 were rehabilitated possums, ex wildlife carers, released at Lane Poole Reserve/Keats forest Block in the period 1996 to 1999 (various unpublished data).  The total number of translocated possums is thought to represent only a relatively small proportion of the number of western ringtail possums relocated, as many more rehabilitated ringtails have been released by wildlife carers as part of unsanctioned and un-monitored translocations.

 

All CALM sanctioned translocations were to release sites baited for fox control (dried meat baits impregnated with the toxin sodium monofluroacetate, or 1080).  All sites were monitored as funds permitted.

 

Each release site has shown some level of translocation success.  However, the full criteria for translocation success have not been met at any site.   Monitoring results from the primary release site, Leschenault Peninsula Conservation Park, confirmed this population declined to a level where extensive survey effort was required to confirm western ringtail possum presence (de Tores_ et al._, 2004).

 

Changes to the 1080 baiting regime, specifically lapses in the baiting effort, a reduction in the number of baits delivered and a change to burying the baits, was proposed as the most parsimonious explanation for the decline at Leschenault (de Tores_ et al._, 2004; de Tores and Rosier, unpublished-a).  However, fauna declines are unlikely to be the result of a single dimensional causal factor, such as predation (de Tores, in prep) and this no doubt also applies to translocation failure.  Alternative hypotheses proposed as possible causes for the translocation failure at Leschenault include competition with the common brushtail possum, _Trichosurus vulpecula_, predation by cats and/or chuditch and/or pythons, drought, unsuitable habitat, wildlife health related issues, presence of disease (toxoplasmosis has been confirmed in the ringtail population at Yalgorup) and prey switching (rabbit control has been conducted concurrently with fox control at Leschenault and has resulted in an observed, but unquantified, decline in rabbit abundance.  With this decline there is the possibility of prey switching by the suite of introduced and native predators and the potential for increased levels of predation on the western ringtail possum) (de Tores and Rosier, in prep).

 

_Post-hoc_ analyses using DISTANCE sampling techniques (Buckland_ et al._, 2001; Thomas_ et al._, 2002) of data from spotlight transects at Leschenault (1996 - 1998 and 2002) and Yalgorup (2002) identified increases in brushtail possum and western ringtail possum density at Leschenault in 1996-1998, and an additional, but small increase in density in brushtail possums in the period 1998-2002 (the period when the western ringtail possum declined at Leschenault) (de Tores_ et al._, 2004; de Tores and Rosier, in prep; de Tores and Rosier, unpublished-a).  Further analyses also indicated partitioning of the nocturnal foraging habitat by the two species .  These results combined, suggested competition with the brushtail possum alone was unlikely to have been responsible for the western ringtail possum decline at Leschenault (de Tores_ et al._, 2004).

 

Additional translocations of displaced western ringtail possums have taken place in 2004.  These translocations have been necessitated by the requirement to relocate western ringtail possums displaced by developments which have removed western ringtail possum habitat.  The releases were at Leschenault Peninsula Conservation Park (where monthly baiting was re-instated) and an unbaited control site established within Yalgorup National Park.

 

A subset of 37 of the 100 western ringtail possums released at Leschenault since January 2004 has been radio-collared and monitored.  Interim results have demonstrated a higher rate of predation-caused mortality at the baited site.  At 1 June 2006, there had been 11 mortality events attributed to predation by pythons, 10 attributed to predation by cats, 3 attributed to predation by a fox/cat? and 1 attributed to predation by fox.  33 of the 55 released ringtail possums at the unbaited Yalgorup site since January 2004 have been radio-collared and there have been only 5 known predation events, 1 attributed to a raptor and 1 to a fox, 2 to a fox? and 1 to a cat.  The results suggest a pattern of increasing predation events by cats and pythons in the presence of fox control.  This is consistent with the concept of mesopredator release.

 

Disease/wildlife health

 

Disease is often overlooked as a potential agent of population decline (Caughley and Gunn, 1996) and infectious diseases can result in significant declines of wildlife at the local population level and at the species level (Caughley and Gunn, 1996; Daszak and Cunningham, 1999; Spielman, 2001).  Disease poses an additional threat to wildlife populations already at risk from threatening processes and in some situations may be the final factor responsible for driving a species to extinction.  

 

In particular, introduced diseases can have a detrimental effect on naïve wildlife populations when trans-species infections occur from infected reservoir hosts.  Wildlife species known to have suffered significant population declines associated with infectious diseases include African buffalos (_Syncerus caffer_), black-footed ferrets, _Mustela nigripes,_ (canine distemper virus); the heath hen , _Tymphanuchus cupido cupido_ (by blackhead), the Indian wild ass, _Equus hemionus khur_ (by surra and African horse sickness), amphibian species (chytridiomycosis); lions, _Pantera Leo_, (canine distemper virus); and African wild dogs, _Lycaon pictus_, (rabies, canine distemper virus) (Caughley and Gunn, 1996; Daszak and Cunningham, 1999; Daszak_ et al._, 2000). 

 

There are potentially significant disease risks associated with wildlife translocation programs. Woodford and Rossiter (1994) outlined the disease risks which should be considered by conservation managers when undertaking a translocation project.  The risks for each translocation project will vary depending on the type of animal and epidemiological situations at the founding source location and release destination (Woodford and Rossiter, 1994).  Capture, transport and quarantine are stressful events for wild animals and stress in such animals can result in immunosuppression, increased susceptibility to infection and recrudescence of latent disease (Woodford and Rossiter, 1994). 

 

There are two aspects of disease transmission which must be considered for translocation projects.  Conservation managers must ensure the wildlife species being translocated, especially those originating from captivity, do not introduce novel pathogens to naïve populations of wildlife at the release site (Warren_ et al._, 2003; Woodford and Rossiter, 1994).  Conversely, they also need to be aware that resident native and introduced animals inhabiting the release site may carry pathogens to which the released animals have had no previous exposure.  Infection with such pathogens could adversely affect the survival of the released animals (Woodford and Rossiter, 1994).

 

Issues

 

The ongoing requirement to clear land for housing and industry in the greater Busselton area will continue to result in habitat loss and displacement of resident populations of the western ringtail possum.  There will be a continued need for land use planners and wildlife managers to address the conservation management issues associated with this habitat loss.  Although translocation has been identified as a possible management option for displaced and rehabilitated western ringtail possums, translocations are yet to be shown to result in sustainable populations at the release sites.

 

Monitoring of translocations to date has been opportunistic (i.e. as funds permitted) and has lacked a strategic approach whereby the suite of factors potentially limiting translocation success can be objectively assessed.  Although there are sufficient published data to suggest the western ringtail possum is highly susceptible to predation by foxes (see for example Augee_ et al._, 1996), the importance of other factors in terms of translocation success has not been determined.  Specifically:

 

(1)          There are no base-line data on the disease status of western ringtail possum populations in the wild.  During previous translocation procedures the pre-release health status was not assessed.  There was no identification or investigation of any disease conditions resulting from holding rehabilitated possums “in care” for short or extended periods.  There has been no comparison of survivorship and long-term health status of rehabilitated possums and possums translocated directly from the wild.

 

(2)          Toxoplasmosis was identified on post-mortem examination of a ringtail possum recruited to the translocated population at Yalgorup National Park (de Tores and Rosier, unpublished-a).  The animal showed neurological signs following routine capture for radio collar replacement.  The possum was not released due to its clinical condition and was taken into captivity for care.  It failed to respond or show any evidence of recovery.  It was subsequently euthanased and the presence of Toxoplasmosis confirmed (de Tores and Rosier, unpublished-a).  The prevalence of toxoplasmosis in ringtail possums in Yalgorup National Park and the other release sites remains unknown.  The prevalence of toxoplasmosis in feral cat populations (host) at each of the release sites is unknown.

 

(3)          The influence of the suite of site specific habitat factors has not been assessed.

 

(4)          The effect of competition, should it exist, between the western ringtail possum and the common brushtail has not been rigorously assessed.

 

(5)          Predation of western ringtail possums by pythons, _Morelia spilota imbricata_, has now been confirmed at the Leschenault Peninsula release site.  It is unclear if these predation events are a result of site specific factors, increased python abundance resulting from a reduced level of predation by foxes, increased python abundance and different use of the landscape resulting from a mesopredator release effect, learned behaviour, or seasonal predation patterns.  Similarly, it is not known if on-going predation by pythons, should it occur, will jeopardise translocation success, or if these effects can be ameliorated by the timing of translocation releases.

 

(6)          The potential for cat populations to increase in the presence of fox control (mesopredator release) has not been assessed.  Anecdotal accounts have reported such increases, however, no unequivocal data are available to support this assertion.  Even if such changes in cat abundance do occur, these changes cannot be assumed to equate with an increase in the net level of predation of the translocated species, or other _in-situ_ species.

 

(7)          There are no data available from this study, or other translocation studies, to differentiate between individual animals responsible for predation events.  The frequency of predation events of western ringtail possums at the Leschenault Peninsula release site since January 2004, combined with the spatial pattern of the retrieved carcasses and the nature of the predation events (i.e. predation attributed to a cat) suggests many of the mortality events attributed to predation by cats, may be the result of predation by one cat.  If this is the case, it provides managers with a very different long-term problem from that posed by an increased rate of predation resulting from an increase in cat abundance.

 

(8)          Wildlife carer records for the ten year period 1994 to 2003 revealed an average of 123 western ringtail possums per year had been handled by one carer alone.  Only a small proportion of these animals has been passed on to CALM for release as part of the formal release programs at Leschenault, Yalgorup and Lane Poole Reserve.  This suggests there is a very large number of ringtails “passing through” the wildlife carer network and released in unsanctioned translocations.  The fate of these animals is unknown.  The conservation value of releasing animals, post rehabilitation and/or post being held in care for other reasons, can only be assessed if releases are monitored.

 

(9)          The genetic structure of wild populations of the western ringtail possum is unknown.  Specifically, there is no information on mating systems, population sizes, gene flow and the effect of population and habitat fragmentation.  Similarly, the genetic structure of the founding stock used for translocations and the genetic structure of the establishing populations at translocation release sites are not known.

 

The translocation  -  General

 

The release and monitoring program is proposed to build on the results from previous translocations to Leschenault Peninsula Conservation Park and Yalgorup National Park (de Tores_ et al._, 2004; de Tores and Rosier, in prep; de Tores and Rosier, unpublished-a).  Translocation releases and monitoring re-commenced in 2004.  These translocations were sanctioned under interim approval from the Department of Conservation and Land Management and were deemed necessary as a result of habitat destruction from developments in the Busselton area.

 

138 western ringtail possums were relocated from three development sites in the period 13 January to 17 July 2004, with an additional 17 rehabilitated ringtails, ex wildlife carers, released in August 2004.  Capture, relocation and monitoring of these displaced and rehabilitated ringtails has been undertaken on an _ad-hoc_ basis as funds permitted.  The continuity and intensity of monitoring was again determined by the amount of funds available from developers.

 

Translocations and longer-term monitoring are now proposed through an integrated program structured in an active adaptive management framework, whereby monitoring (performance evaluation in a research context) is used to trigger changes to management (Possingham, 2001).  If sufficiently funded, monitoring will address the issues of mesopredator release and intraguild predation.  Mesopredator release is defined as an increase in the abundance of subordinate predators following the removal of a dominant predator which previously held the subordinate species in check (Soule_ et al._, 1988). Such an occurrence may constitute one link in a larger trophic cascade.  Intraguild predation is a combination of competition and predation and is the killing of one species by another species where both species use similar, often limiting, resources (Polis_ et al._, 1989).  It is different from “classical predation” as the act of intraguild predation reduces potential exploitation competition (Polis_ et al._, 1989).

 

The translocation program (de Tores, 2005) is innovative as it advocates development and use of novel “contact” telemetry for monitoring of predator and prey species.  The use of contact telemetry will also enable examination of the issues of mesopredator release and intraguild predation.  Contact telemetry utilises a technology whereby a data logger is incorporated into the radio-tag circuitry.  The data logger records when two tags (radio-collars) come in contact with, or are within close proximity of, each other and records the identity of the two tags (i.e. the two individual animals) in contact.  The data logger also records the time of the contact event.  For example, when a western ringtail possum (wrp1) is in contact with a radio-tagged cat (cat1), the contact event is recorded and the data is downloaded when the tag is subsequently recovered.  The data recorded by the data logger of “wrp1’s” tag include the specific ID of “cat1” and the exact timing of the contact event.  The corresponding information is recorded by the data logger in “cat1’s” tag.  Adoption of this technology will enable collection of detailed information on intraguild predation (i.e. it will enable detection of predation of cats by foxes, should it occur), on inter-specific competition (i.e. it will enable detection of cats and foxes coming into close proximity, similarly it will enable detection of ringtails and brushtails coming into close proximity) and will allow identification of the species and the individual responsible for each predation event.

 

The technology is currently advanced to a state where contact circuitry can be incorporated into collars of a weight suitable for fitting to foxes and cats.  However, pen/aviary enclosure trials are required to ensure the technology can be used on animals as small as western ringtail possums.  Ethics Committee approval has recently been given to trial these collars on western ringtail possums and common brushtail possums.  These trials will also enable assessment and adjustment of the “contact” distance, i.e. the distance between the collars required to activate “contact” mode.  The contact telemetry collars proposed for trial do not currently incorporate mortality circuitry.  Further development is required to re-instate mortality circuitry, without the collars becoming too heavy for use on the western ringtail possum.  Similarly, the option of incorporating the time of activating mortality mode into the data logger is being examined.

 

Development work is also being carried out by the collar manufacturers to determine whether contact telemetry can be downloaded remotely from satellite collars.  If this is able to be achieved, cats and foxes will be fitted with satellite collars incorporating contact circuitry.  The use of satellite telemetry will not only provide a more reliable data collection mechanism for contact events involving foxes and cats, but will provide a more cost effective mechanism for collection of fox and cat location records.  The accepted alternatives (triangulation from various ground locations and/or use of towers) are inherently difficult logistically and require an extensive commitment of field time with a lower level of precision and reliability.

 

The satellite telemetry data on fox and cat movement will also complement the mesopredator release research proposed at a landscape level (de Tores_ et al._, 2005b).  This work will incorporate to use of satellite telemetry to examine mesopredator release within the northern jarrah forest of Western Australia.  Specifically, the work will examine the extent of cat movements in the presence and absence of fox control.  The research will examine, _inter alia_, whether the pattern of use of the landscape by cats changes when fox control is implemented over large areas.  This has ramifications for CALM’s Western Shield program, specifically for translocation programs planned for large tracts of land where fox baiting has been/will be implemented.  The western ringtail possum translocation research will complement this large scale mesopredator release research by examining the same issues at a smaller scale, i.e. at smaller habitat patches in the presence and absence of fox control.  These smaller patches are representative of many of CALM’s translocation release sites in the south-west of Western Australia.

 

The western ringtail possum translocation program (de Tores, 2005) also proposes to introduce a system whereby wildlife carers are required to notify the Department of Conservation and Land Management within 72 hours of a western ringtail possum being taken into care.  A similar system is in place for several other species (Peter Mawson, pers. comm.).  Under this proposal, wildlife carers will be required to ensure all western ringtail possums suitable for release (as determined by health screening protocols outlined in this proposal) are released in accordance with the translocation and monitoring protocols of this program and only at sites identified in this proposal.

 

It is further proposed to ensure all proponents of development proposals are aware of their requirement to seek approval from the Federal Environment Minister where the proposed development _“has, will have, or is likely to have a significant impact on a matter of national environmental significance”_ (Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, 1999 – EPBC Act).  The EPBC Act defines _“matters of national environmental significance”_ to include proposals which may have an impact on listed threatened species.  Translocations from development sites will only be undertaken where the development proponent has sought and been given translocation approval from the Commonwealth of Australia, consistent with the EPBC Act, or where the Commonwealth has deemed such approval is not required.
aims:
The project aims are to:

  • determine whether translocation is a viable management option for displaced and rehabilitated western ringtail possums;
  • determine, if in the presence of fox control, there is an increase in other predators and if so, does this lead to a net increase in the level of predation of the western ringtail possum;
  • quantify the importance of predation and disease to translocation success of the western ringtail possum;
  • quantify the prevalence of disease in naturally occurring populations of the western ringtail possum and the common brushtail possum.
outcome:
The project will provide land use planners and policy/decision makers at a local, regional and national level with critical information required to determine a response to development applications which have the potential to destroy and/or fragment western ringtail possum populations and habitat.  Specifically, it will determine if translocation of displaced possums is a viable management option.

The project will also quantify:

  • the extent of competition between the common brushtail possum and the western ringtail possum at sites where the two species occur sympatrically and at translocation sites and will thus determine whether competition is limiting translocation success;
  • the extent to which predation by natural and introduced species limits translocation success.  This will be assessed for each predator species separately and for the combined effect of the suite of predators;
  • The prevalence of disease in naturally occurring populations of the western ringtail possum and the common brushtail possum; and
  • The role of disease in translocation outcomes.
knowledge_transfer: Land use planners and policy decision makers within the Commonwealth (DEH), WA State Govt agencies (CALM, DoE, DPI) and local government. Wildlife researchers generally and wildlife managers responsible for planning and implementing translocations. Wildlife researchers and managers (e.g. biologists involved in assessing fauna response/recovery generally and CALM staff involved in Western Shield) responsible for a broad range of monitoring of survivorship (particularly those interested in adopting appropriate new technologies), habitat use, density/abundance estimates, wildlife health and disease issues. The project will provide critical information on the genetic structure of the south-west carpet python at a series of coastal sites and will therefore be of immediate value to CALM employees involved in wildlife licencing and law enforcement.

methodology:
1) General methodology

Rehabilitated and displaced western ringtail possums will be translocated to the five translocation sites above (see Section 5(d)).  Animals will be sourced from wildlife carers and from development sites.  Rehabilitated possums residing with carers in Busselton will be translocated once deemed healthy and suitable for release.  Numbers of translocated possums sourced from carers may be in the order of 100 per year.  Timing of translocation events and the total number translocated will be dictated by the number of western ringtail possums made available by carers and by development activities in Busselton. 

A subset of animals from each source will be “health screened’ and radio-collared prior to release (10 animals per study site).  These animals will comprise the main radio collared study population for the duration of the research project.  To maintain the study sample size, any deaths will be replaced with new animals (i.e. subsequent releases and/or recruits to the population).

Rehabilitated animals coming out of care will be “health screened” and returned to care for two weeks prior to collaring and release.  This will enable results from the “health screening” to be reviewed and interpreted prior to release and will ensure there are no clinical contraindications for release into the translocated population.  Ringtails captured from development sites will not be held in care after screening.  Release of these animals will occur immediately after capture and screening.  The health screening and radio-collaring processes are described in detail in the section on Specific Procedures below.

All translocated animals will be identified by means of subcutaneous passive transponders (Trovan®) and fitted with a reflective ear tag (right ear for females, left ear for males) to enable visual differentiation between translocated animals and recruits to the population.  Ear biopsies for future genetic population studies will also be taken.  These procedures will be undertaken under gas inhalation anaesthesia (see Specific Procedures below).

Radio-collared animals released into the five translocation release sites will be monitored weekly.  Radio collars used will incorporate movement sensitive mortality circuitry and monitoring will entail: (a) checking that the animals are alive, (b) locating any that die and determining cause of death and (c) locating and marking diurnal rest sites and nocturnal foraging locations. 

Western ringtail possums that die will be located (by radio-tracking), and the cause of death determined if possible (fox, cat, chuditch or python predation; other cause).  Carcasses will be autopsied if sufficiently intact.  Radio-collars will be retrieved for re-powering and re-use and the site at which the animal died will be searched for indications of predator identity (scats, teeth marks, burial method, presence of python etc). 

Weekly radio-tracking will alternate between day-time and night-time.  Rest sites and foraging locations will be marked using flagging tape, and differentially corrected GPS coordinates recorded.  Home range sizes, overlaps between individuals and species, and habitat use will be analysed using GIS techniques (ArcGIS 9) (ESRI, 1999-2004) and Ranges 6 home range software (Kenward_ et al._, 2003).  Radio-tracking will also enable determination of recruitment levels through visualisation of dependent offspring during nocturnal tracking sessions.  

Brushtail possums already resident in the study sites will be captured using wire cage traps (a minimum sample size of 5 common brushtail possums per study site), anaesthetised, health screened and radio-collared (see Specific Procedures below for details).  Radio-tracking of these animals will be carried out weekly as for the western ringtail possums to provide data for comparison of habitat use and foraging range and to determine likely levels of inter-specific competition (spatial analysis using GIS). 

Predation of western ringtail possums by carpet pythons will be investigated in collaboration with the PhD project examining the ecology and diet of the carpet python (see below).  Frequency of python predation rates will be analysed and any pythons ingesting collared western ringtail possums will be captured for inclusion in the python project. 

Interactions between individual possums of both species and between possums and predators will be investigated through the use of contact telemetry in collaboration with the study on fox/cat interactions (subject to development of this to a stage where the technology can be use on the western ringtail possum) (see below also).  Contact telemetry technology is currently under development and is unlikely to be used on western ringtail possums until the 2nd or 3rd year of the project. 

Fox baiting will take place at three of the five study sites (see tables in the Specific Procedures section below).  Survivorship and rates of predation will be compared between sites to determine whether fox baiting has a positive, negative or neutral effect on survivorship of translocated western ringtail possum populations. 

Spotlighting transects will be carried out in each of the study sites towards the beginning of the project to ascertain numbers of western ringtail and brushtail possums present in the sites prior to introduction of newly translocated animals.  Western ringtail possums from previous translocation efforts are likely to be present at low density in all sites except site 5.  These spotlighting transects will be repeated annually to determine whether population numbers are increasing, decreasing or remaining stable as time progresses.  Recruits to the western ringtail population will be identifiable due to the lack of reflective ear tags. Transects will be designed to include representative structural habitat categories for each site so that possum density estimates can be stratified on the basis of habitat variables (see section on Analytical Techniques below).   Transect lines will be marked by reflective tape on jarrah stakes and will be walked over several consecutive nights using hand-held 35W spotlights to detect eye shine. 

Habitat categories will be delineated, following ground-truthing of digital data, on the basis of floristics and structural vegetation units as previously mapped by Trudgen (1984).  A suite of habitat variables will also be monitored during radio-tracking activities.  These will include aspects of individual trees in which possums are resting or foraging (species, height, proximity to other vegetation, types of rest site, possum position within tree) and landform variables such as aspect, and slope. 

Data on environmental and climactic conditions will be collected throughout the duration of the project to provide covariates for statistical analyses of habitat use and survivorship.  Rainfall, temperature and humidity data will be obtained from the Bureau of Meteorology, and data on soil type and nutrient status of vegetation obtained through collaboration with projects examining Tuart decline in the region. 

2) Specific Handling Procedures

a) Capture and holding

Western ringtail possums will be captured at development sites using a dart gun (de Tores_ et al._, unpublished) and the intramuscular anaesthetic, Zoletil.  Possums will be transported and held captive within calico bags inside boxes with heat pads for warmth.  Rehabilitated western ringtail possums residing with carers are similarly transported in calico bags but not anaesthetised until health screened or collared.

Brushtail possums will be trapped (conventional “Sheffield” wire cage traps) at the translocation sites and transported to the field station in hessian bags.  Field stations used will be at Busselton (western ringtail possums) and Preston Beach (brushtail possums and western ringtail possum recruits and previously released western ringtail possums re-captured for radio-collar replacement). 

b) Anaesthesia

Possums of both species will be anaesthetised using isoflurane gas anaesthetic (delivered using a conventional Modified Bains small animal anaesthetic machine) for all health screening and radio-collaring activities.

Possums will be restrained in calico bags whilst being mask-induced using 5% isoflurane.  Once anaesthetised, animals will be placed on a heat pad and maintained on 1.5% isoflurane concentration and an oxygen flow rate of 1.5 litres/min.  Intubation is not necessary; however, endotracheal tubes and a laryngoscope will be available in case of emergency.  Once screening and collaring processes are complete the isoflurane will be turned off and animals will be allowed to breathe pure oxygen for a few minutes until they start to regain consciousness. They will then be returned to calico bags, put onto heat pads and allowed to recover in a quiet place.  They will be regularly checked until fully conscious. 

All possums captured and held for screening and collaring will be processed during the day following the night of capture.  Unless identified as being unsuitable for release, possums displaced from development sites will be released the same evening as the health screening to ensure they have ample opportunity to forage.  Possums provided by carers will be returned to care or housed at the Fauna Rehabilitation Foundation, Malaga in the period post health screening and prior to availability of the results from the health screening.

c) Health screening: sites, numbers and rationale

Background:

Although western ringtail possums have previously been translocated into four of the five study sites that will be used for this project, translocation success has yet to be demonstrated. Reasons for the previous lack of demonstrated success are unclear.  Possible explanations include: competition with the common brushtail possum, increased predation by foxes, cats or pythons, prey switching, unsuitable habitat, climactic effects and disease.  The most parsimonious explanation is an increase in the level of fox predation as a result of changes to the 1080 baiting regime (de Tores_ et al._, 2004).  The influence of disease on translocation success is unknown and there is minimal information on levels of disease in the natural and translocated populations is presently available.  The current project aims to redress this knowledge deficit and to ascertain whether and how the presence of disease is likely to affect the outcome of western ringtail possum translocation programs.

Objectives:

·       Determine baseline haematology and serum biochemistry values for western ringtail possums and brushtail possums, both in the Busselton region (western ringtails) and at translocation sites (western ringtails and brushtails).

·       Detect western ringtail possums with abnormal haematology, serum biochemistry and urinalysis values, especially those coming out of care, to ensure that overtly unhealthy animals are not translocated.

·       Determine infection status and/or evidence of exposure to single-celled blood-borne parasitic diseases such as Toxoplasmosis, Leptospirosis and Cryptococcosis in western ringtail and brushtail possums, both in the Busselton region (western ringtails) and at translocation sites (western ringtails and brushtails).

·       Determine infection status and/or evidence of exposure to Chlamydia in western ringtail and brushtail possums, both in the Busselton region (western ringtails) and at translocation sites (western ringtails and brushtails).

·       Determine (both pre- and post-translocation) whether western ringtail and brushtail possums show evidence of infection by Ross River Virus, and thus whether they may act as reservoirs for this mosquito-transmitted disease.

·       Determine normal levels of infection by gastro-intestinal parasites and ectoparasites in western ringtail possums and brushtail possums, and detect ringtails with unusually heavy parasite burdens that might require treatment prior to translocation.

Methods:

See Table 1 for numbers of animals to be screened at each site, and Table 2 for details of parameters to be screened.

Possums will be anaesthetised using inhalation anaesthesia (Isoflurane, as above) prior to sampling for health screening.  Blood will be taken from the lateral tail veins to a maximum of 5 ml blood per kg of animal.  Whole blood will be allowed to clot (after removal of 400µl for haematology) and then spun down to obtain serum for biochemistry and health screening (Toxoplasmosis, Leptospirosis, Cryptococcosis and Ross River Virus).  The bladder will be expressed to obtain a urine sample and the cloaca swabbed for microbiological screening.  Swabs will also be taken from the conjunctiva, pharynx and cloaca for Chlamydia screening. A faecal sample will be obtained opportunistically during the period that the animal is in captivity.  Samples will be analysed at Murdoch University (Veterinary Clinical Pathology laboratory) and also sent away for specific tests (Leptospirosis tests by Lee Smythe at the WHO/FAO/OIE Collaborating Centre for Reference & Research on Leptospirosis in QLD, Cryptococcus tests by Mark Krockenberger at Sydney University, Chlamydia tests by Peter Timms at the Queensland University of Technology, Toxoplasmosis testing in Tasmania).

Rationale:

General health screening (routine haematology, biochemistry, microbiology, and parasitology) of western ringtail possums prior to translocation will provide a measure of the general health status of animals at the time they are first introduced into the translocation sites.  Animals with overt signs of disease will not be translocated.  Comparison of initial screening values with results obtained 4-6 months after translocation will show whether the health status of animals changes, and whether there is evidence of exposure to disease post-translocation.  These results will help determine whether disease is a limiting factor in translocation success and whether sites vary in exposure rates to different diseases. 

Western ringtail possum disease screening (Toxoplasmosis, Leptospirosis, Cryptococcosis and Ross River Virus) will take place both prior to translocation to determine levels of disease in the natural population or evidence of infection whilst in care, and 4-6 months post-translocation to determine transmission rates of disease from other animals in the translocation sites to the newly introduced western ringtail possums.  Brushtail possums in the translocation sites will be screened to determine levels of disease in the natural population and the potential for transmission of diseases to translocated western ringtail possums that might not have been previously exposed to disease.

Results will be compared to those obtained from naturally occurring populations (see below) for the western ringtail and brushtail possums in the greater Busselton region to determine (a) whether diseases are likely to be transmitted into translocation sites via translocated western ringtails and (b) whether brushtail possums in the translocation sites are likely to infect western ringtail possums with diseases to which they have not previously been exposed.

d) Radio-telemetry

The major objectives of the radio telemetry work at the translocation release sites are to:

·           derive home ranges estimates (diurnal rest sites and nocturnal foraging locations) of translocated western ringtail possums and in situ populations of the brushtail possum to determine the extent of competition for food and resting habitat between the two possum species.

·           determine population densities of translocated western ringtail possums in the study sites, and migration of translocated animals following release at the sites.

·           determine survivorship and reproductive rates of translocated western ringtail possums in the months and years following release and derive estimates of population growth and stability or otherwise of the translocated western ringtail possum population.

·           investigate rates of predation of radio-collared animals and determine the predators responsible to explain observed survival/mortality rates.  This will be carried out in conjunction with other aspects of the larger project which is investigating mesopredator release and python ecology at the same study sites (see below).

·           use the newly developed contact telemetry to examine detailed interactions between individuals of various species (western ringtail and brushtail possums, pythons, cats, foxes and possibly chuditch). 

Methods:

See Table 3 for numbers of animals to be radio-collared at each site, and Table 4 for details of parameters to be monitored.  The adult animals used for radio-collar attachment will be the same individuals used for the health screening aspect of the project.

Both western ringtail and brushtail possums will be anaesthetised using inhalation anaesthesia (isoflurane) for the entire collaring process to minimise stress of handling.  Radio-collars used on western ringtail possums weigh approximately 15-17g, and those used on brushtail possums are slightly heavier.  Battery life of the collars is 4-6 months and 10-12 months for the ringtail and brushtail collars respectively.  Collars are carefully fitted to the anaesthetised animals, checking that they are neither too tight nor too loose.  Animals will be re-captured towards the end of the collar’s battery life for collar replacement.  This enables long-term monitoring of survival and reproduction of individual animals.  Removed collars will be sent back to the manufacturer for refurbishing and reused.

Juvenile or sub-adult western ringtail possums captured opportunistically from translocation sites (e.g. captured along with the mother when re-collaring the latter) will be radio-collared with specially developed breakaway collars that do not interfere adversely with animal growth (de Tores and Rosier, unpublished-b).  Monitoring of these animals will provide data on survivorship, dispersal and reproduction of recruits to the translocated population.
