Geographic positional data on possum resting and foraging locations obtained by radio-tracking will be imported into Ranges 6 (Kenward_ et al._, 2003) and ArcGIS (ESRI, 1999-2004) along with vegetation maps and analysed spatially to determine home ranges, dispersal patterns of animals and overlapping use of territories and foraging grounds. 

e) Application of ear tags, transponder implantation, ear biopsy

Small reflective ear tags will be applied to every translocated western ringtail possum, whether or not the animal is part of the radio-tracking and health screening program.  This will enable differentiation between translocated animals and new recruits to the population as time progresses.  Each translocated animal will also receive a subcutaneously implanted passive identification transponder (Trovan® brand).  These provide unique identification for ear-tagged animals that may later be captured or found dead, and enable an animal’s history to be traced through data records.  Ear tags and transponders will be applied under inhalation anaesthesia.  Ear tags will be applied to the left ear on male possums and the right ear on females.  Transponders will be implanted subcutaneously between the shoulder blades.  Brushtail possums captured for health screening and radio-collaring will also receive ear tags and identification transponders.

A small ear biopsy will be collected from each animal captured for translocation, health screening or radio-collaring for future genetic analyses to confirm genetic diversity and population sustainability.  This will be an essential follow-on from the translocation project if the latter appears successful on the basis of specific criteria for success (see Analytical Techniques section below).  Ear biopsies will be taken from the outer edge of the pinna of the ear under inhalation anaesthesia using a 5mm biopsy punch, leaving a notch on the edge of the ear.  Ear punches will be flame sterilised in between uses, and the animal’s skin will be disinfected prior to taking of the biopsy sample.  Ear tissue samples will be stored in DMSO4 until genetic analyses can be carried out (these analyses are not part of the current project). 

3) Analytical techniques

a) Spatial analysis of data using GIS techniques and home range analysis software

All positional data (resting and foraging locations) will be imported into ArcGIS for visual display and for spatial analysis.  Location data will be collected using differential GPS to sub meter accuracy.  This will be particularly important for the results of spotlighting surveys (see below).  Analysis of home range data will be carried out using Ranges 6 software (Kenward_ et al._, 2003).  Correlations between digitally available habitat variables and characteristics of possum resting and foraging locations will be carried out to derive habitat suitability indices and to investigate partitioning of habitat use between possum species. 

b) Estimation of population density using Distance sampling techniques and software

Analysis of annual spotlighting surveys using Distance sampling protocols (Buckland_ et al., 2001) and DISTANCE software (Thomas et al._, 2005) will be carried out to derive estimates of western ringtail and brushtail possum density in the study sites.  Survey transects will cover representative vegetation strata so that data can be analysed relative to habitat types.  Differential GPS will be used in the surveys to ensure accuracy of distance estimates from the transect line.  Results of analyses will provide evidence for or against habitat partitioning between the two possum species as well as providing density estimates of the translocated western ringtail possum population to quantify population growth/decline over time.

_c) Determination of survivorship and population viability using Information Theoretic techniques _

Results of survivorship monitoring of radio-collared western ringtail possums will be analysed using Program MARK mark-recapture software (White, 2001) in an Information-Theoretic framework (Burnham and Anderson, 2002).  A set of a priori candidate models will be examined to determine the model(s) which best describe survivorship.  Candidate models will include variables on fox and cat abundance (see below) and abundance estimates of other (alternative) prey species (see below).  Candidate models will also include habitat and environmental variables (vegetation strata, vegetation density, specific attributes of individual trees, aspect, slope, climate) and results of pre- and post-release health screening.  Recruitment data obtained from observations of reproductive status of radio-collared animals will also be used, as will data from the limited number of radio-collared recruits to the population, for subsequent modeling of population persistence (population viability analysis). 

d) Demonstration of criteria for success of translocation

A major objective of the analyses will be to assess whether translocation is considered successful.  Criteria for translocation success (from de Tores_ et al._, 2004) are:

·           Released possums establish regular use of dreys and/or tree hollows

·           Home range estimates are comparable to those reported in the literature for naturally occurring populations of western ringtail possums.  (Comparison of results with those obtained for the natural population in the Busselton region will contribute to this.)

·           Females produce young and the sex ratio of young is not significantly different from parity.

·           Dispersal patterns of young are consistent with that expected from the literature (i.e. female young stay within the natal range and male young disperse). 

·           Recruits to the population breed successfully. 

·           Sustainable increase of the translocated population.

·           Maintenance of genetic diversity and confirmation that breeding is not restricted to a limited number of individuals.  (This final criterion is beyond the scope of this project.)

Methodology - Naturally occurring populations

This aspect of the project involves research on naturally occurring populations of western ringtail possum (wrp) and common brushtail possum (cbp). The research will be undertaken at selected sites supporting naturally occurring populations of Western Ringtail Possums in the Busselton/Capel region (see Section 5(d) for sites). The study will focus on determining survivorship, reproductive success and habitat use for both possum species. The importance of site specific habitat variables to abundance, habitat use and habitat partitioning will also be examined. The project will involve long-term health monitoring to determine the health status and prevalence of specific diseases for both possum species.

This component of the research will largely employ the same methodology as the “translocation outcomes” component to provide new information on abundance, survivorship, reproductive success, habitat use, background health status and disease prevalence of both possum species in different ecological states.  The purpose of both projects considered together is to identify features enabling the success of translocated populations, and of influences contributing to lack of success. Without the background information provided by the “natural populations”, the results of the “translocated populations” study may be ambiguous. The findings of both projects will be a tool for planners and conservation managers involved with urban development, reserve development and long term strategies for conservation of the species.

The health and disease aspect of the project will involve collaboration with researchers at Murdoch University and interstate facilities, which will contribute to conservation medicine of marsupials in Australia. Intended outcomes include:

§         Establishment of haematological and biochemical references ranges for both possum species; neither of which are currently listed on Isis, the international physiological reference ranges database

§         Determination of exposure of wild populations to diseases that may affect possum populations or for which they may act as carriers for other marsupials: Toxoplasmosis, Chlamydiosis, Leptospirosis and Cryptococcosis

§         Evaluation of anaesthesia techniques commonly applied to other wild marsupial species, but for which there is little data for the western ringtail possum.

The immediate benefit of the information obtained will be in contributing to conservation management of the western ringtail possum via translocation.

The research will involve spotlighting, telemetry, and physical examination and biological sample collection. Animals involved in monitoring will be periodically recaptured for replacement of radio-telemetry collars, and sample collection. Details of all these procedures are described below.

The research aims to answer the following specific questions for the sites studied:

§         What is the overall abundance and density of extant WRP and CBP populations?

§         How does abundance and density change through the year?

§         What are patterns of survivorship of extant WRP and CBP?

§         What influence do factors such as season and density of both species have on survivorship?

§         What influence does physiological and disease status have on survivorship?

§         What are the features of habitat that are preferred by possums, for different activities?

§         What is the size, variability and spatial pattern of possum home ranges?

§         Is there evidence for spatial competition between WRP and CBP? Can any conclusions be drawn as to effective competition?

§         What are the baseline reference ranges for haematology, biochemistry, urinalysis, faecal microbiology and parasitology, in the WRP and CBP?

§         What is the baseline indication of exposure to Cryptococcus, Chlamydia, Leptospira and Toxoplasma in the WRP and CBP? Is there evidence of clinical disease, and does this appear to influence survivorship?

§         What are the morphometric data in these populations of WRP and CBP?

§         In the case of death of individuals, what causes can be identified? What role does predation, by various species, play in survivorship?

Spotlighting

Determination of spotlighting transects will initially involve broadly stratifying each site for vegetation density in the lower and mid canopies. This will be achieved by examination of digital images and subsequent ground-truthing. Stratification is necessary to satisfy the requirements of the “Distance” abundance analysis program with respect to detectability. Individual transects may include more than one particular vegetation density stratum, but total length of transect of a particular stratum will be determined by the proportion of that stratum in the site. Transects will be straight and parallel, spaced 100m apart to avoid double counting of animals from the adjacent transect. It is expected that transects will be roughly between 200-1000m long.

Transects will be traversed at a slow walking pace by two operators, each scanning the habitat on one side of the transect. One of the two operators will always be the principal researcher. A third person may be present as a scribe and assistant. Hand held spotlights, powered by rechargeable batteries, and containing 20-35W globes will be used to scan all vegetation from the transect, and from ground level to directly overhead. The operators will be seeking to detect the reflection of light that signifies the eyeshine of mammals.

Spotlighting will be carried out at least once a year, to coincide with the season of greatest predicted abundance. If time permits, additional spotlighting at other times of year will hopefully indicate variation in abundance through the year.

The following information will be recorded (for use as covariates in Distance analyses) for each possum sighting:

§         Time

§         Number of individuals seen together

§         Species

§         Type of vegetation in the general vicinity: species of plants, height of canopy, approximate density of the vegetation (on a qualitative scale)

§         Species and total height of the tree containing the possum, height of the animal at the time it was first sighted

§         Special note of presence of hollow or drey

§         GPS recording of the location, using post-processing technology to increase the accuracy to within 1 metre

Analysis of location recordings to give an estimate of abundance will be carried out using the “Distance” software (Thomas_ et al._, 2005) and calculation of a detection function for the probability of a sighting with varying distance from the transect.

Radio-Telemetry

General

The aim is to have a minimum of 10 possums of each species at each of the four sites – a total of 40 WRP and 40 CBP at any one time over all sites – although more possums are likely to eventually be involved when loss through mortality is considered. This number will give sufficient data for the analyses listed above, although information on home range overlap and interactions between individuals may be limited.

The radio collars to be used are as described for the “translocation outcomes” component of the research.  Each radio collared possum will be located once a week, alternating between diurnal and nocturnal locations. Where full monitoring is underway, the following information will be recorded for each possum location:

§         Time

§         GPS recording of the location, using differential post-processing

§         Whether the possum was sighted; if so, comment on activity

§         Type of vegetation in the general vicinity: species of plants, height of canopy, approximate density of the vegetation (on a qualitative scale)

§         Species and total height of the tree containing the possum, height of the animal

§         If in a hollow or drey, details of approximate size etc

§         Details of other animals seen associated with the target animal

Time constraints may limit detailed monitoring to selected sites only, on a sequential basis. The sites not involved in detailed monitoring will be monitored for survivorship, by determining the viability of the possum at least once a week.

Trapping

The common brushtail possum will be initially captured with wire cage traps on the ground. The type of bait used, and the pattern and spacing of distribution is yet to be determined, and will depend on best results achieved in other studies. Traps will be checked every morning and removed as soon as sufficient possums have been caught to meet the monitoring quota.

Possums will be examined, sampled and radio-collared on the same day, and returned to the place of capture that evening.

Application and Reapplication of collars

The first capture for application of collars will occur by trapping for the common brushtail possum and by spotlighting and darting for the western ringtail possum.

It is expected that western ringtail possums will need to be recaptured every 4 months to renew the radio-collar within a safe time period to prevent collars going off the air. The similar interval for the common brushtail possum is 10 months as larger batteries are able to be used in this species.

Anaesthesia

Possums will be captured as described for collaring, and transported immediately to the Busselton Field Station. Immediately before processing (collection of morphometric measurements, samples for health assessment and disease screening, and re-collaring) the individual possum will be anaesthetised using “Isoflurane” administered by mask. Induction and maintenance rates are as described for the “translocation outcomes” component.  Zoletil and Isoflurane are recognised as the agents of choice for injectable and inhalation anaesthesia (respectively) in possums and gliders (Vogelnest, 1999).

Although it is intended that all anaesthesia processes will proceed smoothly, it is necessary to prepare for the emergency situation to ensure the safety and continued health of the animal.  An endotracheal tube will be used if required for emergency stabilisation of the airway. There will also be immediate access to drugs of cardiorespiratory stabilisation, such as “Adrenaline” and “Dopram”. Throughout the duration of the anaesthesia the body temperature of the animal will be supported by an electric, covered pet heating pad (Redflex); cloacal body temperature will be collected at the end of the sample collection procedure (not earlier, so as not to interfere with analysis of cloacal microbiology). A record of the anaesthetic administration (doses, heart rate, respiratory rate and depth, palpebral reflex, mucous membrane colour) will be included on the processing checklist.

Physical examination and sample collection under general anaesthesia

Purpose:

§         Physical examination and morphometric measurements

§         Establishment of baseline parameters of haematology, biochemistry, urinalysis, faecal microbiology and parasitology

§         Establishment of baseline indication of exposure to Cryptococcus, Chlamydia, Leptospira and Toxoplasma

§         Tissue sample collection for future genetic analysis

General

Collection of morphometric measurements, and samples for health assessment and disease screening, will occur when possums are captured for renewal of radio collars.  Ethics and budget plans for the project have allowed for health assessment and disease screening to be carried out twice a year on the WRP and once a year on the CBP, commencing winter/spring 2006.

Hence:

§         Only morphometric measurements will be collected at every radio collar renewal.

§         Health assessment and disease screening samples will be collected at only two of the three collar renewals for the WRP per year. Wherever possible, animals will be retested in the same and successive years to track their status through the course of the study. It is hoped that some animals will remain on the air, and be tested repeatedly, through the entire 24 months of fieldwork.

§         Health assessment and disease screening samples will be collected at collar renewals for the CBP to a maximum of 20 samples per year, with an additional allowance of 10 possums to allow for predation or other losses and hence inability to retest original animals; total annual samples = 30.

It is likely that the recollaring will become staggered through the year, hence sample collection will be similarly staggered across the seasons; comparison of results over various months will provide a good picture of changing health and disease status over the year.

Identification

The very first time an individual is captured a reflective ear tag (for identification of the individual as involved in the study) and microchip (for unique and retrievable identification of the individual) will be applied while the animal is under anaesthesia.  An ear biopsy will be taken for subsequent DNA analysis as described for the “translocation outcomes” component of the research.

Morphometric Measurements

The following information will be collected:

§         Bodyweight

§         Head length

§         Head-body length

§         Tail length

§         Right pes length

§         (Females) Presence and measurements of pouch young

Health Status Samples

The following information and samples will be collected:

§         Body condition / general appearance

§         Comment on normality or otherwise of eyes, ears, skin, teeth, urogenital tract

§         Collection of blood from lateral tail vein using aseptic technique – total volume allowed dictated by bodyweight of the animal (10% maximum, of 50ml/kg circulating blood volume). Collected by syringe and transferred into 1.3ml EDTA blood tube and 5ml Plain vacutainer (to the remaining allowable volume).

§         Urine – by manual expression of the bladder through the abdominal wall, where sufficient urine is present in the bladder. Placed in a vial and sent to Murdoch clinical pathology laboratory for routine urinalysis, with culture if evidence of significant pathogens.

§         Faeces – scats from the cage or bag. Placed in a vial and sent to Murdoch clinical pathology laboratory for parasitology analysis.

§         Cloacal microbiology – a moist swab will be wiped in the cloaca, to test for routine pathogens including Salmonella. Placed in transport medium and sent to Murdoch clinical pathology laboratory.

Disease Screening

The following diseases will be tested:

§         Chlamydia screening – 4 dry swabs will be carefully wiped over each of the oropharynx, conjunctiva bilaterally, and the cloaca. Placed in transport medium and frozen.

§         Cryptococcus screening – serum collected by the above procedure. Placed in plain tube and frozen.

§         Leptospirosis screening – serum collected by the above procedure. Placed in plain tube and frozen.

§         Toxoplasmosis screening – serum collected by the above procedure. Sent to the appropriate laboratory via Murdoch clinical pathology laboratory.

§         Ross River Virus screening (under consideration) – serum collected by the above procedure, sent via Murdoch clinical pathology laboratory.

§         Skin scrapings – where there is evidence of ectoparasites, or disease potentially caused by ectoparasites. Visible ectoparasites will be stored and transported in a small vial containing 70% Ethanol; skin scrapings will be stored and transported in a small vial containing a few drops of paraffin oil.

Holding and Release

Before and after processing at the field station, possums will be held in a soft cloth bag in a padded cardboard box, in a quiet environment. Temperature and air quality will be monitored as appropriate.

The possums will be released in the evening following health screening and/or radio-collaring (i.e. same day), so that total time away from the natural habitat is less than 24 hours. Immediate release during the day time is not possible for both logistical and ethical reasons: the normally nocturnal possums would be disorientated and at risk.

Analysis

Detailed mapping of each site with respect to vegetation species, form and structure, topography, special features and fire history, will be combined with the telemetry and spotlight monitoring data in GIS analysis to determine significant influences on habitat partitioning.

Survivorship monitoring data will also be as described for the “translocation outcomes” component through use of a set of a priori candidate models and model selection based on Akaike Information Criterion (AIC)  in “Program Mark” (White, 2001).

Analysis of home range and habitat use data will also be as described for the “translocation outcomes” component and will derive home range estimates through Ranges 6 software and will assess if there is selection and/or avoidance of specific habitat types through use of the “Jacobs index” (Kenward_ et al._, 2003) and/or Resource Selection techniques.

Methodolgy - ecology of the south-west carpet python

This aspect of the project will examine various aspects of the ecology of the south-west carpet python and, in particular, will examine its response, in a spatial context, to localised introduced predator control (fox baiting programs). It will examine the role and importance of the pythons as ambush predators to the translocation success of the western ringtail possum at coastal sites.  Information gained through this research will improve mammal translocation programs and will allow a better understanding of significant ecological interactions between threatened native predators and introduced predators.

This component of the project will also assess relationships between micro- and macro-habitat use, thermal biology (temperature regulation) in relation to microhabitat use and the influence of prey consumption, and prey distribution and abundance, to provide information for conservation strategies for this threatened species.

A third aspect to the python component of the research will determine whether implanting a radio transmitter into pythons causes any infectious or inflammatory response by examining python haematology pre-and-post implantation of the radio transmitters.  Blood samples will be collected prior to implantation and following implantation to enable assessment/detection of any infectious and/or inflammatory processes that may be caused by the implantation process. The thermal biology of the pythons will be monitored very closely post-implantation (using the heat-sensitive transmitters and a lazar temperature reader) for the following few days. Human patients will show signs of infection within 2-3 days post inoculation with increased body temperatures.

The fourth component will examine the genetic variation of carpet pythons at the coastal western ringtail possum translocation release sites.  This will allow baseline genetic data to be established. It will be valuable to conservation mangers to assess if populations are diverging genetically as increasing habitat loss may not be allowing sufficient genetic flow between populations of the same subspecies. Genetic data will also be useful for people managing reptiles as pets, where captive bred reptiles are genetically monitored and illegal taking of pythons from the wild can be traced more effectively. The genetic information will most likely be analysed through a collaborative effort with geneticists at Murdoch University. Measurements of genetic variation within the python population will involve scoring the presence or absence of attributes (genes or genetically determined morphological features) in the individuals, then extrapolating to arrive at estimates of the relative frequency of the attributes in the population (Lindenmayer and Burgman, 2005).

 

Capture marking and identification of study animals

Pythons will be captured in the following ways:

(a) Pythons found (through the above radio telemetry monitoring of ringtail and brushtail possums) to have preyed upon either species of possum, will be captured and held for inclusion in the python ecology component of the research.  Pythons collected as a result of known predation events will be temporarily housed at the Dwellingup Research Centre until such time as the remains of the prey is regurgitated with the collar, or the collar is passed in a scat.  Alternatively, if the collar is not regurgitated or passed, once it is deemed that all prey has been digested and all faecal matter naturally passed, the python will be physically massaged to encourage it to regurgitate the radio collar.

(b) Attempts will be made to capture all pythons opportunistically sighted at the western ringtail possum translocation release sites.  These captures will most likely be a result of sightings at night when driving, during summer (when pythons are most active and may cross roads more often) and sightings by the research team and/or District CALM employees.  Guidance and approval from CALM’s Nature Protection Branch will be sought when developing protocols for CALM employees to opportunistically collect pythons that they find within the study areas.

Opportunistically caught pythons will be physically restrained using conventional methods for handling snakes (pythons will be collected with care using either or a combination of conventional ‘head-grab’ behind the quadrate bone and the use of specialised snake hook and metal rimmed rounded calico bag). Following capture the pythons will be placed into a Hessian or calico bag to be transported back to Dwellingup Research Centre for the procedures documented below.

Each python will be individually marked by scale marking as described by Pearson (2002), however, use of Trovan® inert passive transponders will be also be investigated as an alternative identification technique.  The south-west carpet python is known to be able to “pass” surgically implanted transmitters (Pearson, 2002) and this phenomenon may make use of transponders ineffective.

Radio telemetry and transmitter implantation

The monitored sample size will be determined by the number of known predation events of western ringtail and common brushtail possums, however a sample of 10 to 15 pythons is envisaged across all sites (exclusive of an approximate equal number of pythons monitored in the concurrent research in the northern jarrah forest).   Sterile radio transmitters will be surgically implanted into the abdominal cavity of each python. Different types (four sizes) of the temperature-sensitive radio transmitters (Holohil Systems Ltd., Canada) will be used depending on the size of the python. All transmitters will be <5% of the python’s body mass. Aerials will be encased in 2mm non-toxic Silastic® tubing and the entire unit sealed with 734 flowable sealant (Dow Corning Corporation). The battery life of each transmitter used will vary depending upon the size of the transmitter. Smaller transmitters (3 or 5 g) will last for approximately 28 and 35 weeks respectively, whereas, the larger transmitters (13 or 21 g) will last between 18-24 months.

Transmitters will be calibrated using a waterbath and circulating heater (Thermoline, Australia) against a certified mercury bulb thermometer (±0.1ºC). Temperature will be increased by 5ºC increments from 0-40 ºC. The period between pulses will be recorded using a Period/PPM meter (Titley Electronics, Australia) together with the time taken to hear 10 pulses using a stopwatch. The former measure is used for calculating body temperature from an automated telemetry system and the latter for data collected during fieldwork. Body temperatures of the pythons will be determined by applying third-order polynomial equations derived from calibration data. Transmitters will be calibrated following removal from the pythons to ensure there has not been significant drift in calibration.

Pythons will be anaesthetised using Isoflurane (“Forthane”, Abbott Pty. Ltd.) gas anaesthesia, intubated and with intermittent positive pressure ventilation used to induce and maintain the anaesthesia. Once under anaesthesia, each python will be given an intra-muscular injection of Ceftazidime 20mg/kg, which is a long-acting antibiotic used to prevent peri-operative infection. While maintaining each python under anaesthesia, surgical implantation of the radio transmitters will be achieved using an aseptic technique into the peritoneum through a mid-lateral incision 10% of the snake’s snout-vent-length (SVL) anterior to the vent. Absorbable sutures will be used to close the incision. Once the python shows signs of recovery from the anaesthetic procedure they will be given an intra-muscular injection of Butorphanol at 0.5 mg/kg. Butorphanol is an analgesic agent and is thought to provide pain relief for up to approximately 4 hours in reptiles. It has a slight sedative effect so the snakes will be maintained in a warm, quiet environment for one-three nights following the surgery and then released to point of capture. The administration of Butorphanol is important for initial post-operative pain relief. Further medication for pain relief is not warranted since the surgery is a relatively simple procedure that does not involve incision through muscle, organs or bone. During anaesthesia, standard morphometric data will be recorded. Pythons that have been implanted will be followed using radio telemetry for the duration of the study period. When possible, pythons will be recaptured close to the end of battery life of the transmitter and removed or replaced if necessary.

Study pythons will be tracked on a week-to-fortnight basis over the study duration. Pythons will be tracked on foot using a 3-element yagi aerial (Sirtrak Ltd., New Zealand) and receiver (RX3, Biotelemetry Services, Australia). The exact position of the pythons will be determined using a differential GPS system (post-processing using Thales MobileMapper software). Previous studies suggest that most pythons do not typically flee when approached by researchers in the field (Pearson, 2002). Therefore, behaviour, posture, proportion of body in sun, cloud cover and aspects of micro- and macro-habitat use will be recorded. Temperature recordings will be taken to gain information on microhabitat use and thermal regulation of the pythons. Temperature recordings will be taken to assess the various insulator capabilities of microhabitats and thermoregulation of pythons, quantified with data loggers.  This aspect will investigate different options for data logging information including implanted data loggers (encased within the implanted vhf radio transmitter) and stand-alone loggers to record physiological and immediate microhabitat environmental data.

Dietary analysis

Pythons collected for implantation of radio transmitters will be held for brief periods (1-2 days) for dietary analysis, including analysis of diet in relation to body size (the south-west carpet python shows strong body size sexual dimorphism (Pearson, 2002)).  Captive held pythons that have recently consumed prey will be palpated to obtain regurgitated and faecal material (this will occur also to ensure pythons have an empty stomach prior to anaesthesia).  Additional collection of faecal and regurgitated material for analysis will occur in the field through the radio telemetry study. This will limit the time spent in contact with, and limit/negate time spent in captivity for the python. Collection for dietary analysis will most likely be made on a bimonthly basis for each study animal. Limited additional collection of regurgitated material will occur opportunistically, where there is clear evidence (bulge in python) that there is recently obtained prey.

The results from the dietary analysis will be compared with the seasonal availability of prey (see below) and in particular will examine whether the western ringtail possum is preferentially selected as a prey item.

Haematology

When pythons are anaesthetised (to implant transmitter) a blood sample will be collected from the ventral midline, prior to and post implantation. The serum collected will be used to undertake haematology analysis. The haematology testing will enable the detection of any infectious and/or inflammatory response to the radio transmitter being implanted. Without haematology testing, information on the health status of the study python may otherwise go undetected by basic visual examination.

Statistical analysis and computer programs - Telemetry data

For each individual python, location datasets will be divided into various categories (e.g. day/night, season, breeding status).  Survivorship will be modeled through the use of Program MARK (White, 2001).  Ranges 6 (Kenward_ et al._, 2003) using harmonic mean analyses will be used to generate an overall home-range estimate for each individual.  Home range estimates will be incorporated into a GIS (ESRI, 1999-2004) or analysed directly in Ranges (Jacobs Index) to determine if there is preferential use of any of the major habitat units (as identified and delineated through use of digital imagery in the GIS).  Habitat use will also be analysed between baited and unbaited sites. 

Genetic analysis

Genetic analysis may be possible as a collaborative project with a geneticist from Murdoch University, Dr Peter Spencer, and CALM’s Nature Protection Branch.  The scales removed from each study python at their initial capture will be used to provide the sample for genetic analysis.  In the absence, or in addition to scale marking, genetic analysis may use blood obtained for haematology analysis (as reptile red blood cells are nucleated and each cell therefore contains that individual’s DNA). A smear of blood will be placed onto FTA paper, dried and stored in a cool, dry environment for future analysis. Additional to blood smears, mouth swab sample collection for genetic analysis will occur.  Mouth swabs will be collected onto sterile cotton buds then smeared onto FTA paper, dried and stored in the same manner as the blood samples.

Methodology - assessment of the seasonal availability of small to medium size vertebrate prey species

This aspect of the project (carried out initially through an honours research program) will examine the spatial and temporal availability of a suite of alternative small to medium size vertebrate prey species at the western ringtail possum translocation sites and may also collect samples for subsequent analyses of the spatial and temporal availability of the invertebrate food resource.

The five western ringtail possum translocation release site will be examined.  The prey species abundance will be determined within a minimum of two major vegetation structural units at each site – the peppermint dominated unit and the more open tuart / jarrah / banksia woodland.  The relative proportions of each major unit at each site will be determine through aerial photograph interpretation (or more specifically, digital image interpretation using a GIS (ESRI, 1999-2004)).

A minimum of two trapping webs will be established within each of the five sites.  Web design (Lukacs_ et al., 2005) will be utilised to enable quantitative data analyses and estimates of abundance through DISTANCE Sampling (Thomas et al., 2002) and mark-recapture techniques (White, 2001) and will incorporate analyses through the Information–Theoretic and multimodel selection approach (Buckland et al._, 2001; Burnham and Anderson, 2002).  A major objective of this component of the research will be to assess the feasibility of using trapping webs as opposed to the more widely used, but less quantitative, techniques such as convenience and transect trapping.  The latter report only known to be alive and/or capture success rates.

Each trapping web will incorporate Sheffield wire cage traps, Elliott folding aluminium box traps and vertebrate pitfall traps (the specific design of the vertebrate pitfall traps is yet to be determined).  Invertebrate sampling will utilise pitfall traps consistent with the FORESTCHECK design.  Each web will be approximately 4.5ha in area.

Methodology - Assessment of fox and cat density, survivorship and use of the landscape

Estimates of fox abundance will be derived through modified use of the sandplotting technique previously used and validated in Operation Foxglove (de Tores_ et al., in prep) whereby 25 sandplots, each 1mx1m were established within a grid/roading network of approximately 25km2, with a minimum distance of 500m between neighbouring sandplots.  Each sandplot was placed at the edge of an existing road or track, with the shape of sandplot grid/web network determined by the existing road and track network.  The exact area required to capture all 25 sandplots within each sandplot grid/web network was determined by calculating the minimum convex polygon (MCP) which encompassed all sandplots (Ranges6 software) (Kenward et al._, 2003).  A 500m buffer (ESRI, 1999-2004) was added to the Ranges determined MCP to estimate the final area capturing all 25 sandplots within each grid/web network.

A small cube of approximately 50g of fresh mutton was buried 5-10mm below the surface of the sand.  The sand was then raked smooth and lightly sprayed with water.  Each sandplot was monitored daily for ten consecutive days.  The presence/absence of fox spoor (i.e. track or scat) or other recognisable evidence of fox activity on each sandplot was recorded daily.  Presence of spoor was interpreted as an indicator of fox presence.  Identifiable spoor and evidence of activity of other species were also recorded.  The removal of rewards (mutton) was recorded and each removed reward was replaced.  All rewards were periodically checked and partially decomposed rewards were replaced.  Sandplots showing evidence of activity and/or removal of rewards were re-raked and each sandplot, whether showing activity or not, was lightly re-sprayed with water daily.  Sandplots were monitored immediately prior to the delivery of 1080 baits. 

Where neighbouring sandplots showed evidence of fox activity this was interpreted as indicating the presence of the same fox at those plots.  A break in continuity of sandplots showing evidence of activity, with two or more sandplots without evidence of activity between sandplots showing activity, was interpreted as indicating the presence of an additional fox.  Similarly, a break of more than 1km between plots showing activity was interpreted as indicating the presence of additional foxes.  The pattern of sandplots showing activity was mapped daily.  The estimated number of foxes was recorded daily at each sandplot grid/web and the cumulative mean after ten days was derived as: Cumulative mean number of foxes = (cumulative number of foxes / number of days monitored).

A pairwise correlation matrix (StataCorp, 2005) was then generated for the daily cumulative mean for days one to ten for the pooled data for all years, pre 1080 baiting.  The correlation value (r) was then plotted for each day.  An r value (correlation) of 0.9009 was observed at six days.

Fox density was estimated for each sandplot grid/web network by dividing the cumulative mean number of foxes at day 10 by the area derived from the MCP, inclusive of the 500m buffer. 

The above methodology will be adopted at three of the western ringtail possum translocation sites (Leschenault, Preston Beach Road and Martins Tank/Lake Pollard), with the following variations/modifications:

·       only one network of sandplots will be established at each site;

·       the area estimate of each sandplot network will be derived exclusive of the buffer, or with a reduced buffer;

·       sandplots will be monitored seasonally, for six days only each season;

·       the meat lure/reward will be placed (randomly) at 50% of the sandplots; and

·       each sandplot will also be treated with the Pestat Ltd developed lure, synthetic fermented egg (FeralMone®).

Fox scats will be collected seasonally, during and immediately post sandplotting.  The presence of fox activity will be used to select trap placement (Victor Soft Catch, padded leg hold traps) for fox trapping.  Trapped foxes will be fitted with ARGOS satellite telemetry radio tags which, subject to developmental trials, will incorporate contact/proximity circuitry.  Satellite tags will be “duty tasked” to enable collection of diurnal and nocturnal location records and to minimise the effects of autocorrelation.  The number of radio collared foxes and hence the sample size for analyses of habitat use and use of the landscape, will be determined by capture rates.  Trapping will be carried out seasonally, post sandplotting, and opportunistically when fox presence is observed, to maintain the radio collared sample size.  The use of contact/proximity is proposed to assist in determining the predator responsible for predation events and to assist in the detection and extent of intraguild predation.  Radio telemetry monitoring will also determine if the fox population within the baited areas is being “turned over” by successive baiting events, or if there is a resident “bait shy” / “bait avoiding” population. 

Estimating cat abundance and assessment of use of the landscape by cats

A combination of lures (the felid attracting phonid, or FAP), rewards, leg hold and wire cage traps and camera stations will be used to monitor for the presence of cats.  At worst, data from these techniques will be used to derive an index to abundance.  A suite of techniques will also be trialled for collection of hair/hair follicles for identification of individuals through molecular techniques.  As per the molecular analyses of fox populations, the conservation implications of the cat population genetic structure will be examined.

Trapped cats will also be fitted with also ARGOS satellite telemetry radio tags which, again subject to developmental trials, will incorporate contact/proximity circuitry, as per the fox satellite telemetry.

Fox dietary analyses

The seasonally collected fox scats will be examined to determine the major dietary items and to examine the temporal and spatial variation in fox diet.  This variation will be compared with the temporal and spatial availability of medium and small mammal prey species and reptile species.
no_specimens: The number of voucher ringtail and brushtail specimens is dependent on the number of mortality events (a subset only of mortality events for the western ringtail possum and common brushtail possum will be forwarded to the WAM). Possums dying during the course of the study will undergo a post mortem at Murdoch University if considered necessary or appropriate. This may include cases where the cause of death is, or is not, obvious. As well as contributing to assessment of causes of mortality, post mortem at Murdoch University is likely to provide educational value for veterinary students on pathology rotation, enhancing exposure to and awareness of issues surrounding marsupial conservation in Western Australia. Python mortalities will be held initially for post mortem and subsequently forwarded to the West Australian Museum. A representative sample of each of the reptile and small mammal species trapped will be forwarded to the WAM – exact number is unknown. Retriered fox and cat carcasses will be held for examination of gut contents and, subject to the requirements of the WAM, subsequently forwarded to the WAM.
data_management: Each of the three PhD students and the honours student will have ownership and data management responsibilities for their respective research areas. However, the following general principles will be adopted: • Hard copies of data collected during processing of animals or in the field will be filed and stored for backup and reference. • All data collected during the project will be entered into the relevant relational database (in MS Access) which will be built to conform with database normalisation principles. Databases will have a purpose built front end. • The databases will be designed to enable component data sets to be easily linked and analysed. For example, the unique identifier for each individual possum/python/fox/cat will be used as a key field in a base table, with referential integrity links to secondary tables holding data on health screening, radio-collaring, radio-telemetry location monitoring records, predation events and ultimate fate. Habitat data will be stored similarly. Results such as haematology/biochemistry reference ranges may eventually be posted on external databases such as Isis. Findings will be published primarily as a PhD Theses (Murdoch University) and in scientific journals covering topics including but not limited to conservation biology, zoology, ecology, veterinary pathology and wildlife disease; unpublished internal reports where appropriate; and occasional newsletters and presentations to interest groups, e.g. FAWNA (the wildlife carer group in Busselton)

background:
Rehabilitation of sites through revegetation requires knowledge of the genetic adaptation of the species to the sites in order to manage these sites on an ecologically sustainable basis. This requires an understanding of the genetic structure and local adaptation of the species. 

 

CALM has provided guidelines to Forest Products Commission that collections of seed for rehabilitation of understorey species in forest sites should be made within a 20km radius of the site. It is generally agreed in the scientific community that local seed sources should be used in rehabilitation so as to protect the genetic integrity of sites and maintain any adaptive variation that has developed through evolutionary history. However, the definition of “local” is very vague and rarely directly specified. 

 

There is no scientific data to underpin the determination of seed collection zones in Western Australian forests. Identification of appropriate seed source distances requires information on the level and extent of local adaptation and underlying genetic diversity within species. This information can be obtained through growth trials and analysis of genetic diversity. By determining this information for a range of species with different life histories and breeding systems, general guidelines on seed collection zones can be developed that will be implemented in forest rehabilitation programs.

 

The project will initially be focused on species in the Jarrah and Karri forest where seed is used for rehabilitation after logging by Forest Products Commission. Later the project may be expanded to include species outside the south-west forest areas.

 

 

 

The project relates to the following strategy in the Corporate Plan:

 

Manage the forests and woodlands entrusted to us, and the resources they provide, on an ecologically sustainable basis over time.

 

This project relates to the following KRAs:

 

2.2 Management of State forest

 

3.8 Promotion and encouragement of sustainable environmental management systems
aims: To determine appropriate seed collection zones for representative species used in forest rehabilitation.
outcome:
The identification of appropriate seed collection zones (provenances) for representative species being used for rehabilitation.

General guidelines for seed collection zones for forest rehabilitation
knowledge_transfer: SFM and FPC will use the knowledge in preparation and implementation of guidelines for sourcing of seed for forest rehabilitation.

methodology:
From the list of species used for forest rehabilitation, five species have been selected that are representative of the range of life forms in the forest understorey. These are Bossiaea ornata (herb), Kennedia coccinea (fire dependant), Acacia pulchella (morphologically variable), Acacia saligna (two variants in the forest) Allocasuarina humilis (wind pollinated).

Collections will be made from 20 populations across the range of each species in the forest. Seed and leaf material will be collected from 20 individuals in each population. Voucher specimens will be taken from each population sampled.

The amount and distribution of genetic diversity will be determined for each species using microsatellite markers which will be developed for the species.  Growth trials will be established with the seed collected from each individual maintaining family identity. Trials will be established at three sites within the forest.

Correlations between genetic diversity and growth will be determined through statistical analysis.
data_management: Data will be backed up regularly using shared files and hardcopies

background:
The European red fox (_Vulpes vulpes_) arrived in the south-west of WA in the late 1920s (King and Smith 1985) and has been implicated in the decline of several species of medium-sized marsupials (Burbidge and McKenzie 1989).  Like all canids, foxes are highly susceptible to the toxin sodium monofluoroacetate, or 1080 (McIlroy 1981, McIlroy and King 1990) while most native WA mammals are tolerant to this poison (King _et al._ 1978, 1981; Mead _et al._ 1979).  In areas of Western Australia where foxes were controlled with regular 1080 poisoning, populations of rock-wallabies (_Petrogale lateralis_), numbat (_Myrmecobius fasciatus_), tammar wallaby (_Macropus eugenii_), woylie (_Bettongia penicillata_), brushtail possum (_Trichosurus vulpecula_), and chuditch increased significantly (Kinnear _et al._ 1988, 1998, Kinnear 1990, Friend 1990, Start _et_ _al. _1998, Morris _et al_. 2003).  In 1996, the Western Shield fauna recovery program commenced (Bailey 1996), with fox baiting occurring over approximately 3.5 million hectares of conservation estate.  In a short space of time, this led to a significant increase in woylie, quenda (southern brown bandicoot _Isoodon obesulus_) and tammar wallaby populations, and in 1998 these species were removed from the State and Commonwealth threatened fauna lists (Morris _et al._ 1998).

 

 

 

However, by 2000/2001 Western Shield monitoring started to detect declines in populations of some medium-sized mammals, most notably woylies, which had attained extremely high abundances (up to 60% trap success).  In a review of Western Shield in 2003, Orell (2005) identified several sites in the south-west of WA where fauna had not recovered, or had declines, despite ongoing fox control.  Lake Magenta nature reserve was one of these sites.  Chuditch were reintroduced to Lake Magenta in 1996 and woylies were translocated there in 1997. Following 12 months of fox control, populations of the quenda and brushtail possum were also discovered. Presumably they had persisted at Lake Magenta prior to fox control commencing, but at undetectable levels.  Trap success rates for all species increased in the period 1996-2001.  However, after this time, trap success rates for quenda and woylies declined to a point where they are no longer trapped, and chuditch and brushtail possums have persisted, but at reduced abundances.

 

 

 

This project is part of a larger program examining introduced predator control and sustained fauna recovery in the rangelands and south-west of WA.  In particular this project will be examining whether there has been a mesopredator release effect after several years of fox control ie have other introduced / native predators increased in abundance and become a threatening process for fauna survival.
aims:
• To determine the causal factors responsible for the medium-sized mammal declines at Lake Magenta nature reserve.
  • To identify the management required to ameliorate these declines.
  • To develop adequate introduced and native mammal monitoring protocols that will enable future changes in population abundances to be quantified and explained.
outcome:
Knowledge of the causal factors responsible for declines of medium-sized mammals at Lake Magenta nature reserve, leading to more effective management and species conservation.  This will be achieved through:

·         An assessment of the effectiveness of the current fox control program.

·         Determining whether mesopredator release (i.e. increased cat abundance) occurs following fox control.

·         Identifying periods of peak abundance of potential fox/cat prey items to assist in improving fox/cat baiting efficacy.

 

·         If necessary, the development of a baiting regime to effectively control both foxes and feral cats, and the testing of the effectiveness of this through translocations of vulnerable species.

 

·         An understanding as to the role disease may play in regulating wildlife populations in WA.

 

The benefits to CALM include having the information required to improve fauna recovery in the Wheatbelt, and to have available revised native and introduced fauna monitoring protocols which will allow future changes in populations to be adequately assessed and explained.  This project is also part of CALM’s contribution to the Invasive Animals CRC.
knowledge_transfer: Regional Services staff involved in Western Shield fauna monitoring, staff and stakeholders in the Invasive Animals CRC. Technology transfer through seminars, reports and publications.

methodology:
Study sites

Two study sites will be used, Lake Magenta nature reserve (104 000ha), 400 km south-east of Perth and nearby Dunn Rock nature reserve and adjacent UCL (ca 65 000ha).  Lake Magenta has been fox baited since 1996, Dunn Rock has never been fox baited.  Study sites will be visited for 5 - 10 days every 8 – 12 weeks throughout the year.  Vegetation descriptions of each of the trapping grids will be undertaken by consultant botanist Ms Anne Rick.  Plant specimens will be lodged in the Newdegate Regional Herbarium, and the WA herbarium where necessary.

Index of relative fox and feral cat abundance

Sand pads will be set at 400m intervals along replicated linear transects (tracks) of 20 – 25 km at both Lake Magenta and Dunn Rock. Sand pads will be of two types – an ‘active’ pad comprising a 1m x 1m sand pad on the side of the transect with audible (FAP) and scent lures (pongo), and a ‘passive’ pad comprising a sand strip 1 m wide across the whole 4-5 m track, with no lures. Active and passive pads will be alternated along the transect.  Presence / absence of fox, feral cat and other mammals will be recorded on each pad over four consecutive nights. An index describing relative population levels will be determined according to the methodology of Engeman (2005). The presence / absence of native species such as malleefowl, bandicoots and woylies will also be determined from sand pad monitoring. Differences in activity of foxes and feral cats will be determined through comparisons of mean indicies and their standard errors within and between sampling periods. Sand pads will be assessed at regular times after fox baiting activities on Lake Magenta to provide some indication of the effectiveness of current baiting regimes. Fox and cat scats will be collected and stored for DNA analysis by an IA CRC post-doctoral scientist. Remote digital cameras will also be used to assist in the identification of individual foxes and cats.

Fox and feral cat diet

Foxes and feral cats will be recorded and samples shot along a standard vehicle transect near the boundaries of Lake Magenta and Dunn Rock reserves.  Dietary, morphometric and reproductive information will be collected. Numbers shot is difficult to estimate, but would be in the order of 6-10 animals per shooting trip (6 times per year).

Relative abundances of small vertebrates and medium-sized mammals

Small vertebrates will be sampled in the dominant vegetation types of both reserves through a system of trapping grids.  Five grids will be installed on each reserve.  Each grid will comprise 5 x 5 pit (20 L buckets, 7 m fence) set at 20m intervals (each covering an area of 1 ha). Similarly configured trapping grids comprising medium Elliott traps will also be used to target native rodent populations. Medium-sized mammals will be sampled by linear trapping transects covering 20 km in each reserve.  Medium Sheffield wire cage traps will be set at 200 m intervals, large Sheffield wire cage traps (for feral cats) will be set at 2km intervals. Grid and transect trapping will occur for four consecutive nights. Seasonal species diversity and relative abundances will be determined for each reserve.  This will be related to cat/fox diet to determine if prey availability influences baiting effectiveness. 

Translocations of predator-vulnerable species

Once information on the effectiveness of current fox baiting regimes has been obtained, and a bait becomes available to control feral cats (anticipated in December 2007), it is proposed to introduce a baiting regime that demonstrably reduces fox and feral cat abundance, and to release predator – vulnerable native mammals into Lake Magenta.  It is proposed that in 2007, bilbies (Macrotis lagotis) would be released, followed by boodies (Bettongia lesueur) in 2008.  Translocation proposals for each species will be prepared and these will detail the release and monitoring protocols to be followed.

Disease prevalence and transmission

The occurrence of disease agents / parasites will be determined through a collaboration with Murdoch University, and potentially an ARC Linkage grant.  All native and introduced mammals trapped / shot will be investigated for haemoparasites, faecal parasites and ectoparasites and other potential diseases. A protocol for doing this will be developed in collaboration with Murdoch University. Up to 10 individual of each species could be sampled over a year.

References

Engeman R.M. (2005).  Indexing principles and a widely applicable paradigm for indexing animal populations.  Wildlife Research 32: 203-210
no_specimens: It is anticipated that between 5-25 individuals of the ca. 30 species of small mammal, reptile and frog will be trapped each year. A small number of these will be taken as voucher specimens for the WA Museum if required for positive identification or taxonomic clarification.
data_management: Data will be stored on Excel spreadsheets. Trap success information will also be provided to the FaunaFile database (Peter Orell).

background:
The Earth’s biota is facing profound risks of damaging climate change during this century. This is due to steeply rising CO~2~ emissions and positive feedbacks which reinforce and amplify human-caused global warming. Some degree of global warming is inevitable due to the concentration of CO~2~ already in the atmosphere. Thus, to protect biota, effective climate change adaptation strategies are now required.

 

Many taxa have survived past regional climate changes by contracting to dispersed refuges characterised by features that ameliorate climate impacts. Such refuges will likely contribute to the persistence of species and ecological communities under anthropogenic global warming. The identification and management of climate refugia is therefore a vital component of climate change adaptation strategies.

 

In Australia, the south-western Australian (SWWA) global biodiversity hotspot is already experiencing climate change attributed in part to global warming, and there are predictions for further warming and drying in the area. This old, highly weathered and flat landscape offers little scope for the biota to migrate to altitudinal refuges. However, the landscape is characterised by numerous granite outcrops and inselbergs scattered across the mesic to semi-arid rainfall gradient. These minor variations in topographic complexity may serve to ameliorate the impacts of climate change for the flora of this hotspot.

 

Identifying the characteristics and occurrence in landscapes of potential climate refuges is a key international climate change research agenda that requires transdisciplinary approaches in the ecological, evolutionary and spatial sciences. In this project we use a transdisciplinary approach to understand past dispersal and contraction of species and scalar relationships with regional landscape components to contribute to developing effective Climate Change Integrated Conservation Strategies.
aims:
We propose that granite outcrops (GOs) provide important climate refuges for plant species and ecological communities. We investigate the potential of GOs and their associated environments to act as refuges in the face of anthropogenic climate change across the south-western Australian climatic gradient. We investigate the biophysical mechanisms facilitating persistence of species and ecological communities in GO climate refuges by asking the following questions:

  1. How do topographic and micro-habitat features of GOs designate them as refugia?
  2. Do phylogeographic patterns demonstrate that GOs have acted as refuges in the past and are important reservoirs of genetic diversity?
  3. Are particular environments at the base of GOs more productive, and are individual plants in these environments under less stress than those in the intervening matrix?
  4. Are the plant communities of GOs more resilient to anthropogenic climate change disturbances than the communities of the surrounding landscape matrix?
outcome: By identifying areas that can act as refugia under projected climate conditions, adaptation and conservation activities can be focused where they will provide greatest benefit. The many granite outcrops scattered across the mesic to semi-arid rainfall gradient of the region include over 17 % of the State’s vascular flora in less than 1 % of its area. We contribute to developing conservation strategies for outcrop flora by examining the evidence of granite outcrops as refugia and as reservoirs of genetic diversity.

related_projects: CF 2011-106 Online GIS biodiversity mapping (NatureMap)
background:
One of the department’s corporate goals is to conserve biodiversity. A key strategy for achieving this is acquiring scientific knowledge to underpin decision-making. The department therefore invests heavily in ecological survey (from small area- inventory through to major regional surveys) and on-going monitoring projects from which data are collected through field observation and analysed to produce new information. Because of the size of Western Australia, and the inaccessibility of many sites, data collection is typically the most expensive component of producing new information and understanding, and the datasets are often irreplaceable.

However, the majority of datasets collected through survey are not lodged in a corporately accessible and managed environment. While the department maintains some corporate scientific and management databases, these capture only a small proportion of data generated through survey, probably less than 25%. The remainder of datasets are managed on a per-project basis, satisfying individual project requirements, but invariably without due attention to on-going data maintenance and availability. To compound the issue, an increasing number of scientists and project officers responsible for historical datasets are close to retirement age. The department therefore faces an increasing and significant risk of data loss.

Compounding the situation, data are stored in various ways ranging from spreadsheets to Microsoft Access, on desktops, laptops, or local file servers. As such, security and data protection are dependent on the data custodian, resulting in inconsistent practices and increased likelihood of data loss or corruption. In addition, data access is typically limited to local users, or restricted by vendor-specific applications. Departmental requirements for linking to related systems are generally not considered. And, finally, while survey methodologies are well understood, inadequate attention is paid to data collection and management standards (particularly ecological data, which still has developing standards), and therefore inconsistency and lack of documentation in how data attributes are defined.
aims:
• Build a central repository for storing, curating and distributing ecological data
  • Minimise the risk of data loss to the department
  • Increase access to ecological data
  • Create a single point of truth for ecological data within the department
  • Develop best-practice techniques for managing ecological data within a corporate context
  • Facilitate the development of ecological data standards and survey protocols
outcome:
• Increased consistency in, and availability of, ecological data
  • Data protected in perpetuity against staff turnover and change in storage technologies
  • Improved security and backup for legacy and operational databases
  • Improved integration with other departmental systems
  • Improved capacity for reporting, research and analysis of observational data.
  • Improved compliance with government requirements for knowledge management
  • Improved credibility of the department in protecting and making data available
  • Contribution to the public good by making all intellectual property publicly available, and encouraging co-development from sister organisations

In the longer term BioSys is expected to take over all or part of the role of NatureMap, built on modern, supported architecture.
knowledge_transfer:
The novel approaches to ecological data management used within BioSys will have relevance to any biological survey database. BioSys is being developed as open source software, and intellectual property and source code will be made available to the general scientific and informatics community.

Interest has already been expressed by the NSW Office of Environment and Heritage in supporting and co-developing the application.
