references:
Australian Venture Consultants (2012) Pathway to an Enhanced Western Australian Terrestrial Biodiversity Knowledge System, August, 2012, Perth, WA.

Salt, C., Burrows, N., Coates, D. & van Leeuwen, S. (2008) Vegetation information management system: the need for a new vegetation map of WA: Vegetation Mapping Workshop. Department of Environment and Conservation, 23-24 July 2008, Woodvale, WA.

Science Division (2008) A Strategic Plan for BIodiversity Conservation Research 2008-2017. Department of Environment and Conservation, Perth, WA.
methodology:
Design principles and approach for BioSys include two key attributes: open source development, and scalability. All intellectual property created during BioSys development will be made available through the open source paradigm. While early stages of development will be kept in-house, once BioSys has reached a basic level of acceptance and maturity, the source code will be housed within a publicly accessible repository. Other developers and research institutions will be able to contribute to the code base so that the software will benefit from potentially many sources.

Key reasons for making the source publicly available include a) providing a public good benefit given that BioSys has been developed using public funds, and b) benefitting from the keen interest that other parties have already expressed, and the additional expertise they could bring to the project.

There has been a high level of difficulty in the conceptual design of the database thus far. Ecological data is, by its nature, complex. Additionally, survey protocols change over time as knowledge and techniques improve, resulting in different attributes being collected. And, finally, the lack of ecological data standards, together with a culture of independence amongst some researchers, contributes to even greater variation in survey protocols and data content and organisation.

This leads to a second key design attribute: scalability. It is a challenge to design a database that will scale to increasing data complexity and variability so that all ecological data can be captured and curated, while on the other hand providing reports and outputs in consistent formats for scientific research, conservation planning or environmental impact assessment, or consumption by other information systems. Traditional methods (e.g. relational databases) do not have the flexibility to accommodate complex ecological data. BioSys is therefore being designed using the most recent techniques for storing and updating semi-structured data that provide the required scalability and flexibility.

An inherent tradeoff with the above approach is that variability in data structure will be replicated within the database. Inconsistencies in how researchers manage their data will potentially be perpetuated. It is not possible to guarantee storage and curation of any dataset, while also guaranteeing those datasets can be consolidated into a single, monolithic, relational data model (e.g. for reporting or data exchange purposes). That is a much harder proposition.

The BioSys project is therefore a long-term project. In the first instance, risk of data loss must be mitigated. It is therefore more important that data is captured and protected within a corporate system "as is", than attempting the harder task of data standardisation. BioSys will also allow data to be curated, the system potentially becoming the point of truth, rather than the desktop. Development will be incremental and adaptive - system capability and design will be enhanced as new datasets and survey protocols extend conceptual boundaries. In subsequent years, other capabilities will be added (subject to available resourcing), such as offline data capture tools that feed into BioSys.

Architecturally, BioSys is being developed as a web-based application using OIM-preferred and supported technologies.

BioSys is being implemented in a phased approach:

  • Build database to support Kimberley Land Conservation Initiative (LCI) monitoring data and Kimberley Island survey data
  • Release minimum viable product for acceptance testing
  • Test and adapt database design by accommodating Pilbara and other key survey data sets
  • Implement a standardised ecological data model based on outcomes from initiatives such as Essential Measures vegetation working group
  • Evaluate feasibility of an offline data entry tool
  • Invite co-development from interested parties

The phased approach described above is dependent on ongoing funding. Estimates below are based on current and historical funds provided from the Kimberley Land Conservation Initiative, at Director's discretion, but this is not an indication such funds will continue to be provided in the future. There is the possibility projects dependent on BioSys architecture might subsidise aspects of BioSys functionality.
no_specimens: N/A
data_management:
• Data will be managed using novel techniques to handle complex and highly variable data.
  • All data will be stored within corporate infrastructure and benefit from standard disaster recovery processes.
  • Data will be archived periodically and stored off-site.
  • Data will be audited for changes at user-level

related_projects: 1993/086 Fire induced mosaics in semi-arid shrublands and woodlands
background:
Land clearing and subsequent fragmentation of native vegetation and habitats is a major threat to biodiversity (Hobbs & Yates 2003; Burgman et al. 2007). Among the many impacts are changes to fire regimes brought about by changes in sources and frequency of ignition and continuity of fuel loads. In some landscapes, fragments experience an increase in fire frequency (one component of a fire regime) because they are exposed to more intensive use by humans and greater sources and frequency of ignition (Kemper et al. 1999; Tabarelli & Gascon 2005). In other landscapes, the displacement of traditional human societies and active fire management practices, discontinuous vegetation cover and/or advances in fire suppression cause declines in fire frequency in fragments (Ross et al. 2002; Hobbs & Yates 2003). 

 

Changes in fire regimes can have substantial impacts on plant species composition and abundance. Extremes of fire frequency and scale may cause local population declines or extinctions (Bradstock et al. 2002). Long intervals between fires risk the decline or loss of species that recruit exclusively or predominately in the post-fire environment if the interval between fires exceeds plant and seed longevity, and/or risk an ecologically dysfunctional abundance of certain fire-susceptible species (Withers & Ashton 1977; Burgman & Lamont 1992; Yates & Ladd 2005). Alternatively, fires that are too frequent can also cause species decline, either directly (if fire frequency is less than the juvenile period for obligate-seeding species, or if these species otherwise fail to recruit post-fire), or indirectly, through facilitating weed invasion (Hobbs & Yates 2003; Yates et al. 2003).

 

South-western Western Australia (SWWA) is a globally significant hotspot for plant diversity and endemism (Hopper & Gioia 2004). However, the native vegetation of large parts of this region has been extensively cleared for agriculture. In parts of the wheatbelt, as little as 2-3% of the native vegetation remains (Hobbs & Saunders 1992), existing in fragments of varying sizes, shapes, degree of isolation, tenures, history and landuses, and surrounded by agricultural land. The wheatbelt region has historically experienced fires, and many plants possess traits that enable them to persist and prosper in a fire-prone environment (Burrows & Abbott 2003). Many fragments are characterized by long intervals between fires (Brown & Hopkins 1983; Hobbs & Atkins 1991) and may be experiencing a different contemporary fire regime from the regime prior to land clearance (Yates et al. 1994; Hobbs 2003; McCaw & Hanstrum 2003). 

 

Partly as a consequence of perceived differences in fire regimes in fragments, and the subsequent biodiversity conservation problems this may pose (together with asset protection concerns), recent steps have been taken to increase active fire management in the southern wheatbelt region, particularly in larger fragments (McClusky et al. 2003). Prior to this management change, most fires resulted from lightning strike or escapes from neighboring agricultural properties, and were actively suppressed in native vegetation (McClusky et al. 2003). 

 

While the responses of some individual species and communities to particular fire regimes or fire events have been studied (Yates et al. 2003; Yates & Ladd 2004), what may constitute an appropriate fire regime for biodiversity conservation in this region is poorly understood. Regional knowledge of upper and lower limits of fire intervals for plant communities is lacking, which prevents the definition of appropriate fire-return interval ranges. 

 

Gaining this understanding of fire responses is also compromised by the lack of knowledge of landscape and historical patterns of fire, and how these may relate to current landscape configurations. An understanding of fire history is also important for interpreting current patterns of vegetation composition (Bond and van Wilgen 1996).

 

DEC uses a variety of methods prior to wildfire events to reduce the risk of fires to life, property and natural assets (Shedley 2007). One of these, scrub rolling or chaining, consists of a chained strip of natural vegetation, which is burnt at a later date. This technique facilitates fuel reduction by rendering prescribed burns easier to manage (via reduced flame heights) and initiate (through creating a more continuous fuel bed and drier fuel) (McCaw and Smith 1992). Scrub rolling and burning has the potential to have significant impacts on plant communities. Vegetation rolling (without subsequent fire) can change the composition of the vegetation community (Pelton and Conran 2002). The use of fire after chaining adds additional possibilities for impacts on vegetation, through the complex interactions of fire and plant characteristics. Some plant fire response types may be more vulnerable to burning after chaining than others. Obligate seeding species with canopy stored seed may be particularly at risk, as seed capsules may open due to desiccation following plant or shoot death after chaining, leaving the seeds unprotected during the subsequent fire (McCaw and Smith 1992; Shedley 2007). In a study of two serotinous species, McCaw and Smith (1992) found that one (Hakea pandanicarpa spp. crassifolia) released seeds soon after chaining, but another (Banksia baxteri) did not. Consequently, they recommended burning within ‘a few’ weeks of chaining to reduce the risk of local loss of serotinous species. The effects of scrub rolling and burning on other plant fire response types, other serotinous genera and species, and the vegetation community as a whole, has not been studied.
aims:
• Map the recent fire history across a sample study area of the southern WA wheatbelt to determine if there are differences in fire regime (fire frequency, season, intensity and extent) related to landscape configuration (i.e. between native vegetation fragments of differing sizes, and between fragments and extensive areas of uncleared vegetation). If differences are detected, can these be related to varying sources of ignition, spatial barriers to fire spread, or fire suppression activities?
  • Investigate how vegetation structure and composition changes with increasing time since fire in two widespread vegetation associations in the wheatbelt; mallee with an understorey of Melaleuca uncinata and Proteaceae species, and Tallerack mallee-heath. This study will also assist with the identification of target plant species for more detailed study (i.e. those sensitive to fire interval – next aim).
  • Determine the approximate upper and lower limits of inter-fire intervals for species susceptible to fire-related decline in fragments in the WA wheatbelt.
  • Investigate the of impact scrub rolling and burning on vegetation communities. We aim to determine if (i) there are differences in species composition between areas of three different fire management treatments: rolled and burnt, burnt in the same fire but not rolled, and vegetation neither (recently) burnt nor rolled; (ii) if there are differences in recruitment between assemblages of taxa grouped on the basis of traits relevant to recruitment after fires and other disturbances (Gill 1999; Pausas et al. 2004): obligate seeders (further divided into those with canopy- or soil-stored seed), resprouters (subdivided into those with canopy and soil-stored seed) and fire ephemeral herbs; and (iii) if any effects of scrub rolling and burning are consistent across multiple ‘events’.
  • Determine whether prescribed fire promotes weed invasion in mallee and heath communities in nature reserves in the wheatbelt, and to identify areas most at risk. Specifically, we aim to test whether: (i) invasions are limited by seed availability or opportunities for seedling establishment (by comparing weed establishment in plots with and without added weed seeds); (ii) fragmentation enhances vulnerability to weed invasion (by comparing plots adjacent to remnant boundaries with plots adjacent to interior roads and plots away from all edges; this tests whether invasions are limited by factors associated with edges, such as soil nutrient enrichment or greater water availability); and (iii) fire enhances weed invasion (by comparing burnt and unburnt plots).
outcome:
The various components of this project will provide much needed data for informing ecological fire management in plant communities that are widely distributed across Wheatbelt and South Coast Region Nature Reserves. Specifically:

1.   Investigating the recent fire history of vegetation fragments in the wheatbelt will increase our understanding of how recent landscape change affects fire regimes, and how current fire regimes may differ from that expected in areas of extensive equivalent vegetation.

2.   Investigating the responses of mallee and mallee-heath communities to increased time since fire will address one of the key information gaps limiting ecologically appropriate fire management in the wheatbelt; that of an appropriate fire return interval for these communities.

3.   Investigating the impacts of scrub-rolling on mallee-heath vegetation will provide data for analysis of the benefits to and impacts on biodiversity of this management treatment.

4.   Investigating the relationship between fire, landscape position and annual grass invasion will provide data on the risk of invasions following fire.
knowledge_transfer: The knowledge gained by this project will be most directly used by DEC staff in planning and undertaking fire management activities, and conserving plant species and communities, in Wheatbelt and South Coast Region Nature Reserves. The findings of the research will be disseminated through scientific publications in peer reviewed journals, Science Division information sheets, participation in conferences and workshops, and presentations to regional staff.
project_tasks: Monthly milestones will be established through the BCI reporting process and reported on at three monthly intervals. Milestones and progress will be continually reviewed by the project team.

Pelton, G.A. and Conran, J.G. (2002) Comparison of two rolled sandy heath communities within a single fire patch in Ngarkat Conservation Park, South Australia. Austral Ecology 27, 85-93.

Ross, K.A., Fox, B.J. & Fox, M.D. (2002) Changes to plant species richness in forest fragments: fragment age, disturbance and fire history may be as important as area. Journal of Biogeography, 29, 749-765.

Shedley, E. (2007) Fire and biodiversity guidelines for the Avon Basin. Department of Environment and Conservation.

Yates, C.J., Hopper, S.D., Brown, A. & van Leeuwen, S. (2003) Impact of two wildfires 13 years apart on endemic granite outcrop vegetation. Journal of Vegetation Science, 14, 185-194.

Yates, C.J. & Ladd, P.G. (2005) The relative importance of reproductive biology and establishment ecology for persistence of a rare shrub in a fragmented landscape. Conservation Biology, 19, 239-249.
methodology:
General methodologies are provided for the five components of the project.

1. Statistical analysis of spatial variation in different aspects of fire regime (number of fires since year T, current age of the vegetation post-fire, average inter-fire period, season of burn, mean fire return interval) for different vegetation communities derived from satellite imagery using GIS.

2. Measure floristic composition and vegetation structure for 8 times since fire across mallee and mallee-heath communities. All efforts will be made to minimize the variation among sites caused by diffences in soil type.

Experimental design: 2 vegetation types x 8 vegetation ages, last burnt pre-1961, 1968, 1972, 1977, 1980-2, 1987-9, 2001 and 2003-4) x 5 replicate sites 

Analysis of variance and linear regression will be used to determine relationships between time since fire and factors such as species richness, average canopy crown cover etc. Ordination/clustering will be used to investigate patterns in species composition with time since fire.

3. The chronosequence of sites used to measure changes in floristic composition and structure for mallee and mallee-heath plant communities will also be used to measure vital rates of select species with different fire-life histories. 

Analysis of variance and linear regression will be used to determine relationships between time since fire and factors such as time to first seed production, seed bank accumulation, plant growth and mortality.

4. Measure floristic composition, abundance of selected species with different fire life-histories and vegetation structure in mallee-heath subjected to 3 treatments (rolled and burnt, burnt only and unburnt).

Experimental design:  3 treatments (rolled and burnt, burnt only and unburnt) x 3 years/rolling programs x 4 blocks. Each block will contain the three treatments within it. To avoid positive correlation among samples, blocks will be widely spaced (>150 m).

Analysis of variance will be used to determine impacts of treatments on floristic composition, vegetation structure and numbers of individuals within different fire life-histories.

5. Experimental treatments will be used to measure the contributions of landscape context, fire and propagule pressure to weed invasions in mallee communities.

Experimental design: 3 landscape contexts (near roadsides (< 5 m) adjacent to paddocks, near roadsides in the reserve interior, and away (> 25m) from roads in the reserve interior) x +/- fire x +/- invasive grass seeds x 10 replicates.

Analysis of variance will be used to determine the impact of treatments on weed biomass. Analysis of variance and ordination will be use to determine the effect of treatments on soil nutrients.
no_specimens: Unknown. The procedure for lodgment has been discussed with Karina Knight at the herbarium.
data_management: During the life of the project data are being maintained and backed up at CSE (where C. Gosper is based). Raw project data are being added to an Access database, which is backed up weekly automatically at CSIRO. Hard copies of the field data sheets will also be archived at CSE. At the completion of the project, all project data will be archived at both DEC and CSE, with the exact details to be determined.

related_projects: All current and future SPP’s where invertebrate wet pit trapping is required
background:
Wet pitfall trapping has been a method used for at least the last 30 years (Martin 1977) to sample assemblages of ground dwelling invertebrate across time frames ranging from weeks to several months and, occasionally years.  This sampling method utilises open containers (often one or two litre plastic jars) containing preservative solutions and buried flush with the ground. Where these traps are set over long time frames preservative solutions that are stable and do not evaporate have been employed and these have incorporated various ratios of glycol (ethylene or propylene) with other preservatives and fixatives such as formalin or ethyl alcohol (Upton and Norris 1980). A comparison of the preservation attributes for invertebrate samples  of  these chemicals, along with a number of other additives, was conducted by Schmidt et al. (2006) where they concluded  that ethylene glycol had better sampling efficiencies and conservation attributes than brine, water or ethanol.

The long time frames over which traps can be left open, particularly in remote areas, allows a cost efficient sampling method that can span the often brief and unpredictable  activity patterns of terrestrial invertebrates. Consequently our understanding of patterns of invertebrate species incidence and species richness has been dramatically improved as a result of this technique. In Western Australia wet pitfall trapping has been critical for evaluating invertebrate assemblages in DEC’s bioregional biodiversity surveys (Burbidge et al. 2000; Keighery et al. 2004; George et al. 2010) and as part of the forest biodiversity monitoring program (Department of Environment and Conservation 2006) as well as frequently being used by environmental consultants undertaking sampling for short range endemic invertebrates.

One of the undesirable consequences of wet pitfall trapping is the amount vertebrate by-catch and this has become a major ethical concern in recent years (New 1999; Thompson et al. 2008). Of particular concern to Animal Ethics Committees are the number of individual animals caught, the way they succumb within the solutions and the fact that beyond morphological identification most vertebrate samples have no other scientific value. Ethylene glycol and additives generally denatures DNA, leave vertebrates discoloured, desiccated, distorted and sometimes partially decomposed (Western Australian Museum 2007). Death is likely to take place over a prolonged time frame while the animal swims in a chemical that  is a considerable irritant and is toxic when ingested (Hall 1991).

While it is highly desirable to continue the use of wet pitfall trapping in biogeographic survey, biodiversity monitoring and environmental impact assessments due to the utility and efficiency of the technique, Animal Ethics Committees will require key ethical issues in relation to vertebrate by-catch to be addressed (Department of Environment and Conservation 2008). Specifically this work needs to address reducing the amount of vertebrate by-catch, lessen the level of distress associated with vertebrate captures and, improve the scientific value of vertebrate by-catch. Although there has been some work examining design techniques of wet pit-fall traps to reduce by-catch(e.g. Pearce et al. 2005) and some preliminary examination of physical effects of low specific gravity non irritant fluids to reduce the time taken for by-catch to reach death(Burbidge 2004), there has been no work to improve the scientific value of vertebrate by-catch.
aims:
• Ensure rapid death for target (invertebrates) and non-target (vertebrates) species falling in to wet pit solution. This should occur with as little discomfort and suffering as possible
  • Preservation of specimens to a standard suitable for taxonomic research (maintains visible morphological characters).
  • Preservation of genetic material suitable for molecular examination
  • Solution stable for extended periods in extreme climatic conditions and prolonged periods (e.g. exposed to elements in Pilbara or Kimberley summer for up to  three months)
  • Minimal personal protective equipment required for safe use (i.e. face shield in ventilated environment with gloves) and able to handle solution, or specimens preserved in solution, without health risk.
outcome: The desired outcome is to develop a chemical alternative to the glycol solutions used in invertebrate wet pitfall trapping that reduces the ethical dilemma that currently exist in relation to vertebrate by-catch and to ensure improved scientific value of vertebrate by-catch. The specific benefits to DEC will be through the ability to continue to use invertebrate wet pitfall trapping for biogeographic survey and biodiversity monitoring.
knowledge_transfer: Biodiversity research and monitoring programs within DEC. Government and tertiary institutions involved in invertebrate research. Environmental consultants undertaking biodiversity assessments of short range endemic invertebrates. Initial information transfer will be through reporting to the Departments Animal Ethics Committee.
project_tasks:
• Review literature on  chemicals used in the preservation of invertebrates and document the physical, chemical and hazard characteristics of each preservative to be completed by June 2010
  • Review literature on  chemicals that could  accelerate euthenasia of vertebrate by-catch in wet pitfall traps and seek expert advice on any possibilities with consultant vet by June 2010
  • Trial candidate solutions for environmental stability September 2010
  • Asses candidate solutions at different intervals and temperatures for preservation of morphological characters in both model invertebrate and vertebrate material November 2010
  • Assess candidate solutions at different intervals and temperatures for preservation of DNA in both model invertebrate and vertebrate material. November 2010
  • Report on project to DEC animal ethics committee for feedback and advice in relation to field trials of any possible solutions.
references:
Burbidge, A.H., Harvey, M.S.  and McKenzie, N.L. (eds) 2000. Biodiversity of the Southern Carnarvon Basin. Records of the Western Australian Museum, Supplement 61.

Burbidge, A.H. 2004. Report to CALM’S animal ethics committee on the Pilbara biological survey. Department of Conservation and Land Management, Unpublished Report.

Thompson,S.A.and Thompson, G.G. 2008. Vertebrate by-catch in invertebrate wet pitfall traps. Journal of the Royal Society ofWestern Australia, 91: 237-241.

Upton, M.S. and Norris K.R. 1980. The collection and preservation of insects and other terrestrial arthropods. The Australian Entomological Society, Miscellaneous Publication No. 3,Brisbane.

Western Australian Museum 2007. Use of Wet Pits and the Relevance of Vertebrate By-catch. Memorandum to DEC Animal Ethics Committee.
methodology: The main aspects of this project are laboratory examinations of the environmental stability and  preservation attributes of an alternative chemistry to glycol. This work will be undertaken by the WA ChemCentre and the following assessments will be used. A shortlist of candidate chemicals will be developed for use under prolonged periods of extreme climatic conditions. Examinations will be conducted to assess and control evaporation of preservative against dehydration and ensure  invertebrates and vertebrates are rapidly submerged in preservative.  Performance indicators that meet standards in taxonomic research include; mounting (thorax), flexibility (legs, wing, antennae), brittleness (appendage joints), damage, colour (pigmentation), odour (microbiological spoilage), swelling and shrinking (abdominal, thoracic). Investigations will be made on the effects of time, temperature and ethanol on the preservation of crickets. Performance indicators that satisfy requirements in molecular research include; DNA quality and PCR amplification. This will involve the use of a  kit which enables the isolation of DNA from insects. A shortlist of priming sequences will be developed based on published data. Optimum conditions will be established for the PCR amplification of invertebrate gene sequences. This process will be repeated for a model vertebrate.

related_projects: SPPs for coral and fish community monitoring are presently in development as part of the Western Australian Marine Monitoring Program (WAMMP)
background:
The Montebello/Barrow islands are situated in the Pilbara Offshore marine bioregions (IMCRA, 1997) approximately 1,600km north of Perth.  The waters and reefs surrounding these remote islands are characterised by geomorphological and oceanographic conditions which provide a diverse range of marine habitats for a variety of both widely distributed and endemic tropical marine species.  The marine environment is generally considered to be in a relatively undisturbed condition as a result of low human usage and strict management controls on industry activities in the area. The Montebello/Barrow Islands Marine Protected Areas (MBIMPAs), incorporating the Montebello Marine Park, Barrow Island Marine Park and the Barrow Island Marine Management Area, were gazetted in 2004 and the conservation and management objectives for these reserves are expressed in the management plan for the MBIMPA.

 

The Gorgon Project (GP) which is based on Barrow Island is one of the world's largest natural gas projects and the largest single resource natural gas project in Australia's history. The plant will include three, 5 million-tonne-per-annum LNG trains, with domestic gas piped to the mainland, and a four kilometre long loading jetty for international shipping. The Gorgon Gas Development Revised and Expanded Proposal: Barrow Island Nature Reserve was approved by the Western Australian Government in September 2009 subject to a number of conditions and a commitment by the Gorgon Joint Venture participants to fund a series of conservation initiatives titled “Additional Gorgon Joint Venture Undertakings”.  A final investment decision (FID) was made by Chevron and industry partners to begin the project.

 

The GP includes a dredging program that will involved the removal and dumping of ~ 7.6M tonnes of marine sediment over a period of approximately 18 months and started in May 2010. The conditional approval for the GP included conditions for environmental compliance monitoring programs (including a marine baseline project and a ‘near-field’ marine monitoring program by Chevron) and a number of environmental offsets, one of which was a total of $2.5 M over three years to DEC to assess the potential impacts of the dredging on marine biodiversity over the broader scale of the MBIMPAs.  

 

The Gorgon Dredging Offset Monitoring Evaluation and Reporting Project (Gorgon MER) will investigate the potential impacts of the dredging and dumping activities on selected marine communities within the MBIMPAs (i.e. the ‘far-field’). The Gorgon MER project will also help inform future environmental impact assessments (EIA) by improving predictions of the spatial scale and nature of the likely impacts of dredging and dumping activities on sensitive marine communities. Additionally, this project will increase the knowledge base of the MBIMPAs.
aims:
Primary

·         To assess the nature and extent of potential impacts of the Gorgon dredging program on the condition[1] of coral, fish and other important ecological (if appropriate[2]) communities of the MBIMPA;

·         To determine the cause/s, with a particular focus on dredging, dumping and re-suspension of spoil, of any changes in the condition of the above communities;

·         To assess the effects of potential confounding natural (e.g. cyclones, disease, predation, bleaching) and other anthropogenic (e.g. fishing) pressures on the condition of coral communities of the MBIMPA.

·         To assess the nature and extent of the impacts from the Gorgon dredging program on the social assets (if appropriate2) of the MBIMPA.

Secondary

·         To ensure that the Gorgon MER is integrated with the DEC Western Australian Marine Monitoring Program (WAMMP).

·         To ensure, where possible, that the Gorgon MER is complementary to industry compliance monitoring programs

·         To contribute data, as appropriate, to the development of a strategic capability for predicting the impact of dredging and dumping on shallow tropical communities.   

[1]   Asset condition includes structure and functions

[2]   Current focus is on corals and fish but other ecological (e.g. macroalgae) and social assets should be considered. This will involve collation and assessment of existing marine habitat data in areas of interest.
outcome:
The project addresses strategies in the following documents:

·         Corporate Plan (2007-2009): 1.2; 2.4; 8.1; 8.4; 8.5****

·         DEC Science Division Strategic Plan for Conservation Research (2008-2017): 1.18; 1.21; 2.8; 3.1; 3.7; 3.8; 4.7; 4.9; 4.10; 6.3; 6.5; 6.6; 6.7

·         Management Plan for the Montebello/Barrow Islands Marine Conservation Reserves: 7.2/ 2, 4, 6, 8; 7.7/ 1, 2; 9.1.4/ 3; 9.1.6/ 3, 6; 9.1.1/ 3, 4, 5; 9.1.1 4/5; 9.2/4; 9.2.4/2; 9.2.5/ 4, 5
knowledge_transfer: The information gained from this study will be used by DEC staff for the management of the MBIMPAs. The information gained from this study will also be used to inform the EIA process for the assessment of future dredging programs, in addition to augmenting WAMPP data sets that are used to support the decision process for the management of marine protected areas. A data report containing all raw data collected during each year of the project will be produced annually and archived by DEC. A final summary technical report containing all data collected over the duration of the project will be completed at the conclusion of the study. Knowledge gained from the project in the form of all reports and other communication mediums will be distributed to all relevant DEC staff. A copy of all major reports will also be forwarded to the Karratha Department of Fisheries and the Western Australian Museum. People outside of DEC will be able to gain the information obtained during the survey by contacting DEC’s Marine Science Program. A comprehensive communication component of the project will be undertaken in order to communicate the findings of the project to DEC, other marine science providers and the wider public. Science related outputs include the publication of annual data and milestone reports in addition a final summary technical report. In addition, peer reviewed journal articles will be produced. Communication outputs will also include a DEC Landscope article, an article in the local newspaper and an article in DEC’s Conservation News. Additional communication outputs will also be explored. By communicating information about and findings of the survey we will be helping to increase Western Australians’ appreciation of the need to conserve their marine environment, including the MBIMPAs. The results of the research completed will be directly relevant to the marine management performance assessment reports that the Marine Parks and Reserves Authority requires from DEC at regular intervals. Additionally, the information gained can be used by the day to day managers of the reserves in monitoring areas of high conservation significance. Managers can then target these areas during compliance and enforcement patrols, potentially resulting in increased protection of these areas.

methodology:
1          Introduction

The Gorgon Dredging Offset Monitoring Evaluation and Reporting Project (Gorgon MER) assess the nature and extent of potential impacts of dredging and spoil dumping activities on selected marine biodiversity assets within the MBIMPAs. The ‘Condition’ (ie structure and function) of these assets is a result of the interplay between natural, anthropogenic and climate change pressures.  The primary purpose of the Gorgon MER program is to identify undesirable changes in asset condition as a result of human pressures (expressed relative to management objectives and targets).  The Gorgon MER program must therefore be able to discern when change in recognised assets is due to human activity rather than natural variability, to offer the opportunity to mitigate pressures.

Within the MBIMPAs, coral and finfish communities are identified as important biodiversity assets and are the primary focus of this project. ‘Coral community’ in the context of this work is defined as the hermatypic coral component of coral reef communities, the term being commonly used to describe the myriad of flora and fauna species that are part of a coral reef ecosystem.  Hermatypic, or reef building corals provide the physical foundation of the reef structure, three dimensional habitat for other reef biota and a source of primary production.  Coral communities are a keystone community within coral reef ecosystems and their condition is identified as a key performance indicator (KPI) in Western Australia marine protected area management plans.

Finfish communities, in the context of this project, are defined as targeted and non-targeted reef fish assemblages associated with high relief shallow benthic habitats that are being monitored at permanent coral community GMER sites within the Montbello/Barrow Islands (MBIs).  This does not include pelagic species. 

The WAMMP program Asset Knowledge Reviews highlight important asset condition, pressure and management response (CPR) indicators and recommended methods to measure these indicators (Wilson and Kendrick, in prep; Simpson et al., in prep). In some cases, due to the potential for elevated levels of human pressures faced by assets at MBIMPAs (dredging and sedimentation), standard WAMMP methodology has been enhanced, although in no case has the standard long term dataset that has been proposed for collection, assessment and reporting been proposed to be at a lower level than the standard WAMMP criteria.

Benthic cover was surveyed at 26 sites throughout the MBIMPAs in December 2006 as part of an initial characterisation of coral communities within the MPAs (Bancroft, 2010). Digital video methodologies were used to collect benthic imagery over ‘fixed’ transects at each of the sites.  Digital still images were later extracted from these videos and analysed for benthic cover in the lab using the point count method (Bancroft 2010). The digital images also provide a permanent record of the benthic community.

 

Methods

2        Site Selection Criteria

The coral and finfish reviews (Simpson et al., in prep; Wilson and Kendrick, in prep) identified the natural, anthropogenic and climate change pressures that are likely to influence the coral and finfish communities within the MBIMPAs.  Site locations were chosen to maximise the potential of recording change as a result of anthropogenic pressures (particularly dredging) while minimising the potential range of confounding factors.  The generic guidelines for site selection are detailed in Wilson et al (in prep). From 30 coral community sites established throughout the MBIMPAs, 15 sites will primarily be used for coral and finfish monitoring within the Gorgon MER (Table 1).

The 15 sites are located along a North South transect (See Table 1, Figure 1) with sites at increasing distance from the area of dredge activity in both north and south directions.  This will enable the monitoring of sites with a gradient of influence from the dredge plume both north and south.

For the measurement of coral community dynamics, at each of the 15 sites, four replicate 50 m permanently marked transects will be established by positioning star pickets at each end of the transect.  Relocation of the transects will be aided by the use of a GPS at the surface and subsurface buoys attached to star pickets to aid locating the star pickets underwater.  To help ensure the accurate relaying of the transect lines across the length of the transect, ‘reo bars’ will be driven into the substrate at 15m, 25m and 35m along the transect and cable ties will be used to improve the relocation of the transect lines between each of the reo bars.  At each of the permanently marked sites the fish community dynamics will be measured using six unmarked non overlapping 50m transects running over the same area investigated for community dynamics.

 

Figure 1. Map of the study area showing the Montebello Islands to the North, Barrow Island to the south, permanently marked survey site locations, and marine protected area boundaries.

3        Coral Community

Coral communities are subject to a range of natural and anthropogenic factors or ‘pressures’ that cause changes in their condition (or ‘health’) ranging from episodic, large scale natural pressures (e.g cyclonic wave damage) that result in extensive damage to coral communities, to chronic localise human pressures (e.g. diver impact on reefs).  In order to understand the extent to which one identified pressure is impacting a system it is necessary to determine the impact that other recognised pressures are having, or to design experiments which nullify those pressures. 

A number of natural and anthropogenic pressures have been identified as potential contributors to the change in coral communities at the MBIMPAs[2].  Monitoring information on change of each of these potential pressures is essential to identify what pressures are driving change in asset condition.

Table 2. Identified pressures that significantly influence coral condition at MBI’s

Natural

Seawater Temperature Rise

Sedimentation

Cyclones

Predation

Anoxia

Disease

Anthropogenic

Sedimentation

Chemical Pollution

The natural structuring pressures of most biological systems are varied and interdependent, especially in highly biodiverse systems such as coral communities (Dambacher et al., 2009; Done et al., 1997; Fabricius 2007, Wooldridge 2005). The variables identified in Table 2 are considered key natural pressures affecting coral community ‘health’ at sites within the MBIMPAs over time.

In the coral review, Simpson et al., (in prep) identified eight important anthropogenic pressures that are likely to impact coral reef communities within Western Australia.  The two pressures identified in Table 2 are the key pressures that have a high probability of impacting the coral communities within the MBIMPAs.

The coral review suggests that rising sea temperatures, increased intensity of storms, ocean acidification and sea level rise pose the greatest potential impact to coral reef communities as a result of climate change.  Given the relatively short time frame of the project relative to the predicted rate of change associated with climate change pressures,  these threats are not considered to be a significant impact to the coral communities over the duration of the Gorgon MER.

Coral reef communities are complex entities made of many parts. The coral review highlighted both structural and functional indicators which were likely to respond to recognised pressures, and the Gorgon MER program therefore needs to quantify significant change in these components through the suite of methodologies being employed to monitor these communities. 

 

3.1     Structure indicators

  1. Benthic cover of Live Coral,
  2. Composition and diversity,
  3. Size Class frequency distributions.

 

3.1.1    Benthic Cover__

The change in live coral cover against other benthic components provides a primary indicator of coral community change[3]. In the case of the Gorgon MER cover of the benthos (as a percentage) will be determined across the following categories: ‘live coral’, ‘dead coral’, ‘bleached coral’, ‘soft coral’, ‘macroalgae’, ‘turf algae’, ‘rubble’, ‘sand’, ‘CCA’ and ‘other’ to be consistent with the classification scheme used by WAMMP.

Surveys of the benthic community along these transects will be undertaken using digital still cameras to enable analysis of the benthic community in the laboratory while providing a permanent record for potential further investigation. For each transect digital images of quadrats will be taken every metre along one side of the transects at a height of 1m from the substrate, providing 50 images per transect which will be analysed using a point count method to determine benthic cover.  Using the point count method, 6 points will be overlayed randomly on each quadrat allowing the type of benthos underneath each point to be recorded according to the classification developed by Moore et al., (in prep).  The sum of all the points (6 x 50 quadrats) provides an estimate of the benthic cover for each transect. Power analysis of the data collected, will determine the power to detect in coral cover using this sampling regime. 

The survey of each of these transects within each site will be repeated in November 2009 and April 2010 prior to the commencement of the dredge program in May 2010 to provide a temporal baseline for the benthic communities prior to the dredging.  Surveys will be completed biannually (November and April) for the duration of the dredging project and for a year post dredging to monitor any changes in benthic cover.

3.1.2    Composition and Diversity__

Analysis of the digital imagery taken for the assessment of benthic cover will also provide data on the diversity and composition of the coral taxonomy, morphology and benthic group composition (see Benthic Cover 22.3.1.) based on the classification scheme developed for the WAMMP monitoring program (Moore et al., in prep).

All 15 GMER sites will be surveyed twice a year (see Table 1).

3.1.3    Size Frequency Distribution__

Data on size frequency distributions (SFD) will be measured along the transects at each site.  The maximum linear dimension (‘diameter’) of colonies >10mm will be measured for each individual colony intersecting the 50m x 1m belt transect.  Each transect will be filmed using stereo video methods to enable accurate measurement of coral colonies.

The stereo-video equipment comprises two downward facing video units secured to an aluminum frame. A light emitting diode is positioned on a rod in front of the cameras so the footage can be synchronized when it is viewed on a computer. The video units are configured to record the coral colonies from different angles. A computer program is then used to calculate the exact size of coral colonies by mathematical triangulation using two sets of video footage.

Colonies will be categorized into the following size classes based on the maximum colony diameter (mm): >20 – 50, >50 – 100, >100 – 200, >200 – 500, >500 - 1000, >1000 -2000, >2000 which is largely consistent with other studies of size class frequencies (e.g. Van Woesik and Done 1997) including the Chevron baseline survey (Chevron, 2009). A subset of corals would be selected from the available taxon, where size class frequency distribution varies markedly with age (a mix of fast and slow growing corals). This would include corals found consistently across sites (e.g. Acroporidae, Lobophyllia) to allow intra and inter-site comparisons.  Where colonies are divided by partial mortality into separate areas of living tissue while maintaining structural integrity these will be considered a single colony. 

SFD of corals will be recorded along belt transects at 6 sites to the north and south of dredging activity annually (Table 3).

3.2     Functional indicators

The coral asset knowledge review (Simpson et al., in prep), highlighted which functional components of corals were likely to respond to recognised pressures, and where the Gorgon MER program should focus activity. These functional components of coral communities define the processes that maintain asset ‘health’ through time, without which the integrity of the community would begin to change. These three parameters are:

  1. Coral Settlement
  2. Coral Recruitment
  3. Coral Growth and Survival

 

3.2.1    Coral Settlement

The abundance of coral settlers on replicate terracotta tiles attached to the substrate represents a measure of coral settlement rate (Mundy, 2000). Three sets of 4 artificial settlement tiles, ~10m apart will be attached to the natural substrate using stainless steel mounts and masonry push mount plugs (Mundy 2000). The artificial settlement surfaces (acid washed and scrubbed) will be deployed approximately 1 month prior to the predicted broadcast spawning peak in Autumn of 2012. The surfaces will be deployed onto horizontal surfaces away from coral colonies to reduce competition, and will be retrieved approximately 2 months later.  Retrieved tiles will be replaced to investigate the impact on larval supply of corals throughout the year.  Tiles will be left for up to four months at a time.

Retrieved tiles will be placed on a metal rod with rubber spacers between the tiles to prevent rubbing of the tiles and removal of the coral settlers.  Each rod of 12 tiles from a site will then be wrapped in bubble wrap to prevent abrasion and submerged in household bleach for 24 hrs to remove biological material before investigation of the tiles using dissecting microscopy.  Taxonomic identification based on the corallite structure (basal plates of coral skeleton) and abundance will be recorded for one of four taxonomic groups (Poritid, Acroporid, Pocilloporid or other).  Additional information including the number of polyps per settler (related to age) and location of coral settler/s on the tile will also be recorded. 

 

Settlement tiles will be deployed at 6 sites to the north and south of the dredging activity (Table 3).

3.2.2    Coral Recruitment

A subset of digital images recorded on each transect at each site will be used to quantify coral recruitment (Heyward, in prep).  Colonies will be categorized into the following size classes based on the maximum diameter (mm): <10, 10 -<25, 25 -<50, 50 – <75 and 75 - <100. Sites with similar substrate complexity will be selected (Heyward, in prep).

At 6 sites along a north/south oriented transect extending over the area of dredge activity (Table 3), coral recruitment will be assessed annually.

If time permits, in-field surveys of coral recruits <100mm will be completed in situ along belt transect at subsets of each of the 4 permanent 50m transects used for the monitoring of benthic community.  At the start and end of each of the transects, a 10m x 25cm belt transect will be surveyed to provide an indication of the recruits <100mm diameter.  Colonies will be measured to the nearest mm.

3.2.3    Growth and Survival

Survivorship of corals will be measured at a coral community level through the temporal assessment of changes in community cover at each site (see 2.2.1.1).  Changes in the coral cover component of benthic cover will indicate the survivorship of the coral communities along each of the transects.

At each of the 6 sites (Table 3) 20 Porites spp colonies will be cored approximately 1 year after the completion of the dredging program to determine the growth rate of these coral colonies for at least 10 years prior to, during and after the dredging project by drilling cores through the colony as detailed in Heyward et al., (2003).

3.3     Natural Pressures

  1. Seawater Temperature
  2. Cyclones
  3. Sedimentation
  4. Coral Predation
  5. Anoxia
  6. Coral Disease

 

3.3.1    Seawater Temperature

Seawater temperature (+0.1oC) will be measured using instantaneous insitu loggers (Sensus Ultra), and will be consistent with guidelines of minimum requirements identified for measuring water temperature within WAMMP (Bancroft, in prep). The loggers provide a dual channel temperature (resolved to 0.01°C, accuracy of +/- 0.8°C) and depth (resolved to 1.5cm, accuracy +/- 30cm) feature. Loggers are fully enclosed reducing the potential for flooding and the unit provides a large memory capacity (up to 10 years memory capacity at 10min recording intervals).  Loggers will be covered by a rubber sleeve (tyre tubes) with a thin strip of stainless wire through the opening to the water pressure sensor to reduce the rate of fouling of the sensors. 

Loggers will be double calibrated prior to deployment and downloaded data will be post-processed to ensure data accuracy to 0.1°C.  Data will be downloaded to the Australian Institute of Marine Science (http://data.aims.gov.au/aimsrtds/faces/map.xhtml) for post processing together with the Meta data for each deployment.

Loggers will be deployed at the 7 sites at the depth of the coral communities being monitored, (Table 3). Loggers will be programed to record measurements every 10 minutes, and replaced in <3months to allow regular data downloads, removal of fouling and reduce the impact of potential logger failures.

Sea surface temperature will also be monitored via products supplied by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) satellite and information service http://coralreefwatch.noaa.gov/satellite/data_nrt/sba/current_vs_alerts.txt. Sea surface temperature records and coral bleaching alerts are available for the Montebello area. The MBI virtual station alerts provide information on a weekly basis to indicate the likelihood of a bleaching event at the MBIs. 

3.3.2    Cyclones

Monitoring of severe storm activity and in particular cyclones over the duration of the Gorgon MER project will allow the correlation of any changes in the coral community to those pressures.  Monitoring will be maintained through a range of freely available web based weather monitoring media (www.bom.gov.au/cyclone) to record information on cyclone path, intensity and duration.  Additional information on the wave height and direction is also available from BoM (http://www.bom.gov.au/australia/charts/viewer/index.shtml?domain=combinedW&type=sigWaveHgt) and wind speeds (http://www.bom.gov.au/jsp/marine/wind/index.jsp) will allow more detailed correlation with any changes recorded.

Wave buoys have been deployed in the Barrow Island port by Chevron and a request will be made for the raw data from these devices as part of the project.

Regular visitation to the sites by both Chevron and DEC throughout the duration of the project will also enable spot checks for the recording of any changes in the level of mechanical damage, community size structure and composition (form and taxonomic composition) that may relate to cyclone activity that has been recorded over the duration of the project. 

Fortnightly reports from the compliance monitoring as part of the ministerial conditions (Chevron) also provide information on the extent of any mechanical damage that may have occurred.  With this knowledge we are able to make an informed decision about the mobilisation of a field team to quantify the occurrence of mechanical damage at the GMER sites.

3.3.3    Sedimentation

Measurements of natural sedimentation associated with the influence of flood plumes and cyclones will be completed as part of the assessment of the anthropogenic sedimentation monitoring (see anthropogenic sedimentation).

3.3.4    Coral Predation

The abundance and size distribution of the coralivorous gastropod snail (Drupella spp) and the Crown of Thorns starfish (Acanthaster planci) will be quantified at six sites along a north/south oriented transect extending across the area of dredge activity (Table 3). The methods used will be consistent with those generic monitoring protocols identified within the individual SPP documents (Bancroft, in prep).

Surveys of_ Drupella spp_ and A. planci will be conducted during the dredging program and a year after the completion of the dredging has been completed.  Reactive surveys of the either predator may also be completed if regular monitoring of other marine communities suggests that unusually large numbers are present at a site.

3.3.5    Anoxia

No direct measure of anoxia will be made in this project as the spatial and temporal nature of these events is too fine scaled for comprehensive recordings to be made under the scope of this project. However, coral monitoring sites were selected in locations subject to high flushing rates in shallow water to reduce the potential of anoxic events impacting coral and fish communities. However during periods of elevated threat levels for anoxia DEC and Chevron will be on the lookout for the results of any potential anoxia event (fish kills, coral mortality). If at anoxic event is suspected, field observations to identify coral community loss will be initiated and fish kill specimens will be sent to Brian Jones at the Pathology lab for confirmation of cause of death.

3.3.6    Coral Disease

A coral disease survey will be completed across the GMER coral reef monitoring sites using methods consistent with those for collecting data at Ningaloo (Onton et al., in prep) (see Table 3). At each site, three 20 x 2m belt transects will be surveyed for corals and disease in accordance with the standardized protocols developed by the Global Environmental Facility Coral Reef Targeted Research Program’s Coral Disease Working Group (Van Woesik et al., 2008). This involves in-situ visual identification of hard and soft corals to lowest taxonomic level recognized or morphological group. Each colony will be counted and categorised as healthy, bleached or assigned to a disease category. Corals exhibiting compromised health states or other notable impacts (e.g. Drupella spp. feeding scars) will also be recorded. Disease prevalence will be expressed as the mean percentage of coral colonies affected by disease per site (number of diseased coral colonies/total number of coral colonies x 100).

To confirm the type of disease observed in the field, samples from infected colonies will be collected for histological examination. Samples of coral affected by disease will be collected using bone cutters or hammer and chisel and placed in seawater in labelled plastic bags. Care will be taken to ensure both normal and abnormal tissue bordering the lesion is collected. Corals will be preserved in 10% seawater buffered formalin fixative solution. Samples will later be washed with 0.9% saline, drained and embedded in 3% bacto-agar. Corals will be decalcified through ascending concentrations of up to 10% formic acid over 24 hours, then rinsed, embedded in wax, sectioned and stained with hematoxylin and eosin and Grocott’s methenamine silver for tissue sections where fungi is expected. The sections will be mounted on slides and were examined using a stereo light microscope at magnifications ranging from 10 to 40x. Under microscopy, lesions will be described in terms of depletion of zooxanthellae, presence of associated microbes and structure of tissue layers. Digital still photographs of the tissue sections under magnification will also be collected.

 

At each of 6 sites (Table 3), along a north/south oriented transect extending over the area of dredge activity quantification of coral diseases will be completed at least once during the dredging program with a further assessment 6 – 12 months after the completion of the dredging program.

 

3.4     Anthropogenic pressures

  1. Sedimentation
  2. Chemical Pollution

3.4.1    Sedimentation

_Sediment Plume Monitoring: _The extent and duration over which an area has been covered by the dredge plume will be measured using Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) images. True colour enhancements of MODIS images will be downloaded on a daily basis from the NASA archive (modis.gsfc.nasa.gov). The images will be reprojected into GDA94 MAGA zone 50 ready to import into DEC GIS. The extent of the plume (graded assessment), and the day length duration of the plumes coverage, which will be linked to measurements of sedimentation rate (see sedimentation rate below) will be mapped from MODIS imagery.

Dredging plume boundary/ies will be drawn by digitising a line around the plume (vector digital polygon) with a new polygon created for each plume that is visible. Interpretation of the plume boundary will be completed using a predetermined set of guidelines on what constitutes a plume utilising comparative imagery of the same area captured on both plume affected and plume free days. Observer variability will be checked and differences standardised. Post processing of the daily plume boundaries will be completed to determine the frequency of days any position (monitoring sites) within the MBIMPA is affected. This will involve running a hotspot analysis in ARC GIS using ADRESI software (or related software options). The direction of the plume (north or south) and the overlap with monitoring sites will also be recorded each day as a coarse assessment of the plumes potential impact on Gorgon MER sites. 

Sediment Deposition Rate: _Sediment traps will determine the relative sedimentation rate among sites and record if there is a significant change to background levels of sedimentation as a direct result of dredging activities. Three frames, >10m apart, each holding 4 sediment traps per frame (mounted 500 mm apart) will be deployed at each site. Sediment traps consist of 50mm diameter PVC pipe cut to 300mm lengths and placed vertically in the water column.  A length/diameter aspect ratio of 6:1 was found to be ideal for sediment trap design in a previous study of sedimentation rates in nearby coastal waters (Forde, 1985) and the minimum requirement for sediment trap studies in the review by.  Approximately 4 cm below the mouth of each sediment trap, 6 strands of 0.5 mm diameter copper wire are criss-crossed across the opening to prevent most fish and invertebrates from entering the traps and disturbing the accumulated sediments. The mouths of the sediment traps are consistently held 0.75m above the substrate and each frame will be at least ~10 m apart, weighted and tied to a star picket driven into the substrate.  _

Sediment traps will be left for 6-12 weeks before retrieval and replacement of cylinders.  On retrieval each of the cylinders will be left to stand for 24 hrs to allow the sediment to settle before the excess water is decanted from the trap using a hand pump.  The remaining contents of the traps will be transferred into sample jars and frozen for transport to the laboratory for processing.  Notes will be taken on damaged/lost traps, the level of fouling on each trap and the presence of fish in the traps.  Traps will be discarded if rate sediment deposition may have been compromised.

Frozen samples will be transferred to pre-weighed dishes in the laboratory and placed in a drying oven at a temperature of approximately 100OC until reaching a constant dry weight. Subsamples will also be taken to determine total organic and carbonate fraction and refractory weight for each sample. Dried samples will be stored for subsequent analysis of a range of other physical parameters which may indicate changes to sediments as a result of the extent of the plume including: Particle size analysis; X ray Diffraction (proportion aragonite, calcite and high Mg calcite); Scanning Electron Microscopy.

Sediment traps will be deployed at seven sites positioned both to the north and south of dredging activity (Table 2).  The traps will be retrieved and replaced every 6-12 weeks for the duration of the dredging program.

3.4.2    Chemical Pollution

Major chemical spills occurring in the MBIs in association with the industrial developments are reported as part of management procedures for the developments themselves and records of these incidences can be accessed in the event of the loss of coral potentially being associated with chemical spills.

Chemical pollution arising from commercial and recreational activities within the MBIMPA will be monitored throughout the life of the project.  Incidences of chemical pollution which may be detrimental to the biodiversity of the MBI’s will result in an assessment of the damage as appropriate, particularly where spills are associated with the monitoring sites.

4     Finfish Community 

A number of natural, anthropogenic and climate change pressures have been identified as potential contributors to the change in fish communities at the MBIs[4] (see Table 4).  Monitoring each of these potential pressures is essential to identify what pressures are driving asset changes. 

Of the six climate pressures identified in the review of finfish (Kendrick and Wilson, in prep) it is unlikely that even the two pressures with the greatest potential of impacting Gorgon MER sites (water temperature and increased presence and magnitude of storms) are likely to be confirmed as related to climate change in the time frame of the Gorgon MER.  However both water temperature and storm presence and magnitude will be monitored against potential affects on fish communities (see Natural Pressures 22.2.2)

Table 4 Identified pressures that may potentially influence fish community condition at MBIs

Natural

Predation

Habitat change

Anoxia

Cyclones

Anthropogenic

Extractive Activities - Fishing

Chemical Pollution

Water Quality

Habitat Change

Introduced Species

 

In order to monitor the condition of finfish communities we need to include both the structural and functional components of the communities.

 

4.1 Structural indicators

Monitoring of the community relies on the quantification of a number of structural indicators including:  

1.    Total abundance

2.    Diversity

3.    Community Composition

4.    Size structure

5.    Total biomass

 

4.1.1    Fish Community Abundance, diversity and population structure

At each of 8 Gorgon MER monitoring sites, 6 independent 50 metre transects will be completed over the same habitat characterised for the benthic community surveys to enable fish community data to be associated with benthic structure and composition information (see Fish DOV Standard Operating Procedure).  These surveys will incorporate Diver Operated Video (DOV) methods providing a permanent record of the fish assemblage and allowing analysis of the videos in the laboratory using experienced staff (and re-analysis if necessary).  Surveys completed in 2006 were limited to quantification of the major targeted species across the 26 sites surveyed using underwater visual census methods which provides some background data for this study.  Use of stereo video equipment enables conclusive identification of species from the video footage and accurate size estimates (Harvey et al. 2002).

The stereo-video equipment comprises two forward facing video units secured to an aluminum frame. A light emitting diode is positioned on a rod in front of the cameras so the footage can be synchronized when it is viewed on a computer. The video units are configured to record the fish from different angles. A computer program is then used to calculate the exact size of fishes by mathematical triangulation using two sets of video footage.

At each site, video transects will be swum by a two diver team. Transects are swum in a roughly straight line (following habitat), in a direction away from the sun, with a 10 metre gap between each transect to maintain independence of replicate transects.  The first person in the fish dive team swims the Diver Operated Video (DOV) unit, with the second person following behind with a modified ‘chain man’ (i.e. cotton spool device used to measure distance swum).  Once 50 metres is reached on the ‘chain man’, the second diver gives a signal on a short rope tether separating the divers (approx 3m long), signalling the first diver that they have reached the end of the transect.  This process is repeated until all replicates are completed.  The transect should be swum with camera angled slightly downwards at 3-4o to the horizontal (the camera image has almost a half of the screen showing the benthos).  This will ensure the capture of both the pelagic and benthic fish communities within the video frame. Transects are swum at a steady rate such as to minimise fish disturbance and allow approximately 6 minutes per 50m transect (just over 1 knot, half normal walking pace)

Data from pre-dredge surveys will used to undertake a power analysis to determine the required number of transects needed per site using the stereo-video UVC fish survey method for the range of coral reef environments at the MBI’s. However, advice from experts in the field of stereo-video UVC and investigation into the numbers of replicates used by other researchers employing the stereo-video UVC method in Western Australian tropical reef environments (Dianne Watson pers. comm., 2007) was used to overestimate the likely number of transects required per site. The pre-dredge surveys will be used to statistically validate the number of transects needed per site (e.g. power analysis) to give a high level of statistical power to detect a desired level of relative change in community diversity/composition, fish abundance and length.

Surveys of fish will be completed in November 2009 and April 2010 to provide a temporal component to a pre-dredge baseline dataset.  This will be used for comparison with annual surveys of fish communities at each of the 16 Gorgon MER monitoring sites for 2011, 2012.

Image analysis

Analysis of High Definition video footage is completed in the laboratory following the completion of the fieldtrip allowing accurate identification of individuals and accurate length measurements.  Digital imagery is analysed using the seaGIS software ‘Event Measure’ and ‘Photo Measure’ (www.seagis.com.au).

Identification of all individuals recorded within the belt transect will be completed for initial characterisation of the fish assemblage prior to the commencement of the dredging program at each site at both spring (November 2009) and autumn (April 2010) sampling periods to provide temporal variation in fish assemblages.  A similar characterisation of fish assemblages will be completed at the conclusion of the dredging program. Analysis of subsequent videos recorded on an annual basis will be completed to trophic group, feeding guilds in addition to dominant species in order to target the indicators of change in the fish community that may occur as a result of impacts from the dredging project.

 

4.2 Functional Indicators

The only functional parameter that has been recommended for monitoring was recruitment.

4.2.1    Recruitment

Recruitment at each site will be assessed from the video footage taken using stereo cameras to provide a relative measure of fish recruits at each of the monitoring sites.    If time and resources permit, recruit counts will also be completed in-situ using underwater visual census methods. The recruit survey diver will accompany the DOV operator counting finfish recruits along a 1m X 50 belt transect. 

 

At 6 sites along a north/south oriented transect extending over the area of dredge activity (Table 3), fish recruits will be quantified annually during the dredging operations and post dredging operations to determine if there are any significant impacts of the dredge operations on the fish recruitment to the benthic communities at each of these sites.

 

4.3 Natural Pressures

There are a range of natural pressures that can impact finfish communities, indirectly impacting coral communities.  Three of these are considered within the MBIMPA and are important component for monitoring within the Gorgon MER.  These include:

  1. Habitat Change
  2. Anoxia
  3. Cyclones

 

4.3.1    Habitat Change

Habitat change at each of the Gorgon MER sites will be monitored through the biannual assessment of benthic cover at each of the sites (see 22.3.1.1 Benthic habitat). In addition, regular field observations in the interval between community surveys at each of the Gorgon MER sites will provide a qualitative indication of changes in habitat. 

4.3.2    Anoxia - See 22.3.3.5 Anoxia.

 

4.3.3    Cyclones - See 22.3.3.2 Cyclones.

4.4       Anthropogenic Pressures

There are a range of anthropogenic pressures that can impact finfish communities indirectly impacting on coral communities. Six of these listed in the fish community knowledge review (Kendrick and Wilson in prep) are considered to have a probability of impacting the coral communities within the MBIMPA and are important component for monitoring within the Gorgon MER.  These include:

  1. Extractive Activities - Fishing
  2. Chemical pollution
  3. Water Quality
  4. Habitat change
  5. Introduced species

4.4.1    Extractive Activities - Fishing

Fishing directly impacts the fish communities that characterise each of the sites being monitored altering the functional and structural characteristics of the fish community.  As a result quantifying the fishing activity at each of the sites is essential for understanding any changes occurring at the sites.

The location of the MBIMPA reduces the accessibility to small vessels. however, the recent increased awareness of the recreational fish resource associated with the islands has led to an  increased interest from both charter fishing vessels accessing the area, and larger independent recreational fisher vessels.  Anecdotal evidence has also suggested that there has been an increase in smaller vessels accessing the Islands, generally towed by larger vessels to and from the islands.

Records from the Department of Fisheries will be accessed to determine the extent of recreational, commercial and charter vessel fishing activity that is being undertaken throughout the MBIMPA.  This will provide an indication of the areas which are being targeted and the species that are being extracted at each of these areas.  This understanding will enable us to determine if changes to the coral community at monitoring sites are likely to be associated with the impacts of these extractive activities.

In addition data from the Customs department from flights over the area will be requested to provide additional information about the prevalence of small vessel activity throughout the MBIMPA.  This will be particularly important to determine the presence of recreational fishers at the MBI’s due to poor records of this resource.

 

4.4.2    Chemical pollution

At the MBIMPA, the source of chemical pollution is likely to be limited to the deliberate/accidental direct discharge from industrial activities and shipping activities associated with the existing infrastructure and new industrial developments at Barrow Island (see  22.3.4.2). 

 

4.4.3    Water Quality

The greatest anthropogenic threat to water quality associated with the fish community structure is the increase in turbidity associated with the dredging.  Monitoring of the dredge plume and the resulting change in sedimentation is being conducted as part of the Gorgon MER (see 22.3.4.1 Anthropogenic – sedimentation)

4.4.3    Habitat change

Habitat change due to anthropogenic pressures will be detected through the monitoring methods being applied for the benthic community cover (see 22.3.1.1 Benthic Cover).

4.4.4    Introduced species

Assessment of the fish community structure will completed at each of the Gorgon MER sites annually to quantify changes in the community structure.  It should be possible to identify the presence of any introduced fish species within surveys, although introduced pathogens or related species that cause disturbance to fish communities will be difficult to detect.

5          Sampling Regime

The Sampling regime for coral and fish communities and pressure field variables

Monitoring programs should be capable of detecting change attributable to a specific pressure, whilst allowing time for management to intervene and mitigate damaging effects on assets.  The Gorgon MER has used guidelines (Wilson et al. in prep) for the establishment of an appropriate sampling design to detect change in the design of the project.  Sites have been selected for the Gorgon MER project based on areas of significant coral cover that were identified in the development of a long term monitoring plan for the MBIMPA (see Table 1). These sites are characterised by high diversity and concentrated abundance of finfish due partly to the high relief and complexity that they present.

6          Spatial Scales

The spatial scale of the sampling program has been determined based on the placement of an array of sites of significant coral cover along a north – south transect along the eastern side of the  MBI chain providing sites with a gradient of influence from the increased turbidity associated with the dredging activities (See Figure 1).

7          Temporal Scales

In order to determine the most appropriate temporal scale of monitoring ecological, social and chemical-physical trends were considered (Wilson et al., in prep).  Planning of the sampling repetition will account for the temporal pattern of natural and anthropogenic pressures that drive variation in each indicator being measured.  In as much survey timing will also account for seasonal cycles, tidal cycles and daylight hours to minimize the influence of natural variation.

Table 5. Details of the number of replicates, sites and temporal sampling regime for each of the experiments being conducted.

8          Site survey design

The survey design for the Gorgon MER reflects the presumption that the sites close the dredge activities will be impact sites due to the increased sedimentation and reduced light attenuation associated with the increased turbidity.  Due to the movement of the plume in either a northerly or southerly direction due to prevailing wind, wave and tidal conditions a subset of both impact and control sites has been allocated to each of these directions.
