methodology:
The study will be conducted in fragmented landscapes within the kwongan shrublands and heathlands (Dongolocking area) in WA.  In this landscape effective management of remnant vegetation is recognised as critical for conservation per se and for maintenance of the ecosystem services remnant vegetation provides within agricultural/grazing production systems.

Three target taxa that vary in life history traits that are expected to affect ecological and genetic responses to fragmentation such as breeding system, reproductive and dispersal strategies, longevity or abundance, will be selected to represent broad life history classes (guilds) of plants.

Currently available vegetation survey and mapping databases (available from IMB CALM, Department of Agriculture and the Dongolocking Pilot Planning Project for Remnant Vegetation) will be used to select up to 10-20 vegetation remnants that contain the target taxa and that represent broad variation in remnant characteristics.  Main site variables to be investigated will be size, isolation and disturbance.  Additional information on population size and density will be collected from each site.

Within these remnant sites a combination of demographic monitoring and molecular genetic analysis will be employed to quantify ecological and genetic parameters that reflect population viability:

Genetic/breeding system parameters:

Genetic markers (allozymes, microsatellites or AFLPs) will be used to measure the amount of genetic variation in all populations, how genetically different populations are from each other, and to estimate the amount of gene flow among populations.  Measures of genetic diversity will include polymorphism (the proportion of polymorphic loci), allelic richness (the mean number of alleles per locus) and number of multilocus genotypes.  Interpopulation differentiation will be assessed as genetic distance.  Levels of inbreeding and patterns of mating will be assessed in a subset of up to ten populations per species sampled across the range of sizes and isolations.  This will involve using allozyme markers and/or microsatellites to estimate outcrossing rates, levels of correlated paternity and biparental inbreeding.

Various genetic diversity and population genetic structure statistics such as single locus diversity measures, F statistics, Nei's diversity measures, genetic distance, linkage disequilibrium, and their variances will be estimated through computer programs such as BIOSYS-1, GENESTAT, POPGENE, and GENEPOP.

Population genetic structure will also be estimated using maximum likelihood, UPGMA and Distance Wagner methods in BIOSYS and PHYLIP, and modified parsimony methods in FREQPAR.  Comparisons of genetic diversity measures between populations and species will be tested by ANOVA and relationships between genetic differentiation and geographical distance by Mantel tests.

Mating system parameters such as outcrossing rate ΔF and the correlated paternity and their variances for populations of each species will be estimated based on the mixed mating model using the computer program MLTR.

Ecological/fitness parameters:

Pollinator visitation and pollination rates, ovule to seed ratios, and seed production will be quantified in a subset of up to ten populations per species sampled across the range of sizes and isolations.  Where possible, seed from populations with varying levels of genetic diversity and inbreeding will be grown under controlled conditions to assess effects on seedling fitness.

The effect of plant population size, fragment connectivity and habitat disturbance on pollinator abundance, pollination rates and seed production will be tested with regression analysis and ANOVA in Minitab or SAS.

Ecological and genetic results will be correlated with landscape attributes using multiple regression models to identify remnant and landscape characteristics that are good predictors of demographic and genetic population viability.  Comparison of responses among target taxa will be used to identify life history traits that strongly influence ecological or genetic responses.  These two sets of responses (among-remnant and among-species) will be used to develop landscape attribute thresholds and design principles for maintenance of viable populations and the long-term persistence of remnant vegetation.

Where necessary, advice on experimental design and statistical analysis will be sought from Biometrics Services.
no_specimens: Where necessary vouchers of target taxa will be collected and lodged with the Herbarium. Costs for the lodging of any specimens will be covered by the project external funding.
data_management: The data will be archived and maintained on my personal computer and shared drives at the Western Australian Herbarium.

background:
* Extension/development from previous CALM research associated with the Kingston Project (SPP #’s 93/109, 93/0115 and 97/0007). From this previous work, the two possum species were identified as the most susceptible to logging activity. This research will be examining these species in greater detail and in a broader management context
  * This research is being conducted as part of the PhD research of Adrian Wayne with Australian National University and Department of Conservation and Land Management
  * Although there is some material available for these species within peppermint/tuart coastal woodlands (Jones, How et al. 1994; Jones, How et al. 1994; Jones and Hillcox 1995; How and Hillcox 2000), the published literature on the ecology of the ngwayir and koomal within the jarrah forest is extremely limited.
aims:
The aims of this research are to study the ngwayir (western ringtail possum) and koomal (common brushtail possum) within the jarrah forest of Western Australia and;

  1. Compare survey methods to identify the most effective means of detecting individuals.
  2. Investigate what factors explain the distribution and abundance of these species.
  3. Describe their life histories (population demographics, fertility and development), and
  4. Examine the habitat selection and preferences of these possums for food and shelter by comparing what they have available with what they use
outcome:
Given the limitations and variability of survey methods to detect ngwayir and koomal, the purpose of the survey method trials will be to identify what are the most appropriate means of surveying possum populations within the jarrah forest, refine the technique where possible and obtain a measure of the most appropriate survey method’s reliability, precision and accuracy. These results will be directly useful to the remainder of this study as well as have wider application for other research on these species and relevance to similar research in other forests and on other arboreal mammals.

The results from the ecological components of this study stand to make a substantial contribution to improving the understanding of the ecology of these possums within the jarrah forest – something which is so far almost completely absent in the published literature. The life history research will provide a fundamental biological basis of understanding of these animals within the jarrah forest. The habitat selection study and the examination into the factors explaining the distribution and abundance of these possums will provide detail of the ecology of these species with respect to their interactions within and between possum species, with predators (principally foxes), logging activities, fire and elements of the habitat such as climate, vegetation structure and floristics and topography.

This research will also make a substantial contribution to the understanding of the conservation status of the ngwayir in particular. As such the results from this study will serve to provide information directly relevant to improving the conservation and management of the ngwayir and koomal and will have broader ecological relevance.
knowledge_transfer: Peer Scientists – Forest Ecology, Disturbance Ecology, Marsupial and Possum Biologists Forest Managers – Native forest logging, Fire management, and Reserve management plans in particular Nature Conservation – Threatened Fauna Recovery Plans, data for assessing the conservation status of ngwayir and koomal and improved species understanding for general conservation management Parks and Visitors – improved detection methods of ngwayir for education purposes, increased information for interpretive exercises and education. Invited presentations and lectures at various forums including CALM/FPC training courses, University Lunch time seminars, etc 6. Availability to discuss specific details as required by interested parties within CALM, FPC and the public at large

methodology:
Part I: COMPARATIVE SURVEY METHODS TRIAL DESIGN

Preliminary Bait Selection Trial

Background:

A quick bait selection trial of alternative bait /lures was used to identify which types may potentially capture more ngwayir or western ringtail possums (WRP) and koomal, common brushtail possums (BTP). The two best lures at capturing WRP would subsequently be used in the comparative trapping trials in conjunction with the standard ‘Universal’ bait type.

Aim:

Determine which of six alternative bait types are more effective in capturing more western ringtail possums and common brushtail possums.

Null Hypothesis:

There is no significant difference in the capture rates of WRP or BTP between arboreal traps baited with six different bait types (Rose Fragrance, Aniseed Oil, Eucalypt Oil, Vanilla Essence, Tea Tree Oil, Fish (Cod Liver) Oil).

Study Design:

Factors:

6 Treatments (Baits) - Rose Fragrance, Aniseed Oil, Eucalypt Oil, Vanilla Essence, Tea Tree Oil, Fish (Cod Liver) Oil

6 Positions on each tree

9 Trees (replicates)

Trees:

6 arboreal platforms with traps per tree, evenly spaced and at the same height (~1.8 metres above ground)

9 trees, DBH >40cm (ie. circumference (2pr) >2.4metres, leaving >20cm space between 20cm wide platforms to allow possums access and thoroughfare.

Preferably >200m between trees, >100m at absolute minimum (in order to achi
no_specimens: Voucher specimens of WRP and BTP will be collected opportunistically when suitable fresh dead material is found. These will be stored in a freezer at Manjimup Science Division work center until such time as the specimens can be appropriately lodged with the Western Australian Museum. Possums that are part of this study and that are found dead either complete or partial, will as a priority be retained at the discretion of the supervising scientist. Necropsies (destructive) may be conducted on some of these carcasses to aid in determining the cause of death. Where possible skulls of study animals will be retained as a reference collection for teeth wear and possibly morphometrics. Radio-collared individuals will also have tissue sample taken for potential genetic analysis. At the completion of the study any reference material retained by the Supervising Scientist will be offered to the Western Australian Museum. Any plant material vouchered as part of the habitat surveys will be lodged with the WA Herbarium.
data_management: • Original raw field data will be stored at the Science Division Manjimup Work Center for the duration of the study and locally archived thereafter. • Electronic copies of the field data will be stored on Excell and Access Databases on local Manjimup network. Custody of the data will remain will the supervising scientist but access will be available to associated project staff and selected staff.

background:
The Walpole-Nornalup National Park contains large areas of old growth Karri, Jarrah and Tingle forest. The forests of the Walpole-Nornalup area are estimated to have a high proportion (approx. 75%, Van Heurck, Burbidge and Wheeler 2000) of arthropod species with Gondwanan affinities. These forests also contain a number of threatened and short-range endemic species. In these forests short-range endemics make up the majority of species in the following invertebrate groups: Gastropoda (snails), Oligochaeta (earthworms), Onychophora (velvet worms), Araneae (trapdoor and other spiders), Diplopoda (millipedes), Phreatoicidea (slaters) and Decapods (freshwater crayfish) (Harvey 2002). Little is known of the ability of these short-range endemic species and their litter communities to survive both wild and managed fires. Also no long term systematic survey of the fire impact on the species composition of the litter invertebrate communities of these forests has been carried out to date.

 

 

Recent worldwide estimates of the number of species of living organisms (Stork, 1999) are of the order of 12.5 million species (invertebrates, vertebrates and plants), of which 11 million are arthropod species. The inventory of arthropod species is therefore critical to the state’s requirement to conserve the biodiversity of regions such as the old growth forests. Recent bio-survey methods allow the simultaneous study of fire impacts on the majority of species of an entire ecosystem component such as the forest floor litter community. The advantage of this, is that a rapid inventory of species of a wide range of arthropod groups in the litter community of each site is achieved, in addition to determining fire impacts on any short-range endemics at each site, while also comparing the post-fire species composition between sites with a range of fire regimes. This allows extrapolation to other similar old-growth forest ecosystems containing short range endemic species, as well as predicting the impact of similar fire regimes and post-fire ages on the richness and species composition of entire litter arthropod communities in these nearby forests.

 

 

Following the March 2001 wildfire in the Nuyts Wilderness, a large group of local volunteers have been trapping and inventorying the litter arthropod species of these forest sites, as well as long unburnt sites nearby. This is establishing a comprehensive collection of local arthropod species and allowing the fire tolerances of these species to be determined. The outcome should be adaptive fire management of these old growth areas to conserve the full range of arthropod biodiversity. The extension of this study over a three year period will allow documentation of the early post-wildfire species succession.
aims: To inventory the differences in species compositions of the arthropod litter communities containing short range endemics, at forest sites, both long unburnt, prescribed burnt and burnt in a recent wildfire.
outcome:
• Inventory of the majority of arthropod species in the litter community and the establishment of the Nuyts Collection (approx. 700 species).
  • Comparison of species compositions of microhabitats such as forest floor litter, tree butt litter, hollow butt litter and perched litter/moss on logs.
  • Comparison of species compositions following differing fire regimes.
  • Documentation of the impacts on short-range endemics of differing fire regimes.
  • Comparison of taxa such as spiders, beetles as bio-indicators of post-fire responses of the whole forest floor litter community.
knowledge_transfer: Education of the local community through production of Discovery Centre displays, talks and photographic field guides. Supply of ecological information to local tour guides and operators. Education and attraction of tourists. Provision of a large species collection of an entire litter community for the use of local and international taxonomic specialists. Provision of a database, analysis and reporting of the species compositions of sites with different fire ages for the use of fire managers and planners in old growth forest parks.

methodology:
Trap Design: 16 pit traps per site, with a diameter of 90 mm one third filled with ethyl glycol and opened for 10 days. 8 traps dug into the forest floor and another 8 either attached to a log, dug into deep tree butt litter or dug inside a hollow butt.

Site Design:

  1. Tingle (Creek Gully) unburnt 64 years (1937) Douglas Hill (Floor and logs)
  2. Tingle (Creek Gully) unburnt 64 years (1937) Douglas Hill (Butts and Hollow-butts)
  3. Tingle (Creek Gully) unburnt 7 years (1993/94) Delta Rd (Floor and logs)
  4. Tingle (Deep Creek Gully) unburnt 8 months (March 2001) Nuyts Wildfire (Butts and Hollow-butts)
  5. Tingle (Deep Creek Gully) unburnt 8 months (March 2001) Nuyts Wildfire (Floor and logs)
  6. Tingle (Upland) unburnt 8 months (March 2001) Nuyts Wildfire (Floor and logs)
  7. Jarrah (Sandy Foothills) unburnt 35 years (1965/66) Sandy Beach Rd (Floor and logs)
  8. Jarrah (Sandy Foothills) unburnt 8 months, Nuyts wildfire (Floor and logs).
  9. Karri (Creek Gully) 30yrs unburnt, SE of Mt. Clare, (Floor and logs)
  10. Karri (Creek Gully) unburnt 8 months, Nuyts wildfire, (Floor and logs)
  11. Marri (Upland) long unburnt, Shedley Drive, (Floor and logs)

  15. Pines (Creek Gully) unburnt 8 months Nuyts wildfire, (Floor and logs)

All litter community species collected will all be incorporated into the Nuyts Collection (as indicated in 16). The sorting and identification methodology will follow Oliver and Beattie 1996, Van Heurck et. al. 2000 and McKenzie et. al. 2002.
no_specimens: It is estimated that at least 700 morphospecies (> 10,000 specimens) will be collected and incorporated into the Nuyts Collection. Several individuals of each of these morphospecies will be incorporated into the Nuyts Collection for use as a reference collection for the current survey. In future it is planned to house the Nuyts Collection in the local Discovery Centre for continued reference and expansion by the local community, ecology researchers and for the use of specialist taxonomists. All other specimens of each morphospecies will be lodged with the Western Australian Museum for species determination, validation and description.

Data are archived onto CD format and stored with the Forest Entomology Collection, Science Division Research Centre, Kensington. Archived CD copies will also be stored at Walpole District Office with the Nature Conservation Officer.

background:
Recent genetic work has suggested that the brush-tailed phascogale (Phascogale nov sp) in Western Australia (the wambenger) is a distinct species when compared with eastern Australian and northern populations of Phascogale tapoatafa.  There is also some evidence that wambenger populations have declined recently, although the cause of these declines remains unknown. Whilst hypothetical ‘natural’ cyclical fluctuations may account for at least some of these declines it is also possible that management activities such as fox baiting, logging and/ or fire may also be causal factors. In this study the locality records of brush-tailed phascogales will be collated from museum and other sources and will be examined to determine if reporting frequency has declined recently and if so when. 

 

 

The brush-tailed phascogale was the subject of a PhD study by Susan Rhind.  Rhind (1994) studied the abundance of wambengers at 12 sites across the state and did a concentrated ecological study at Kingston and Perup forest areas in the Warren Region.  Since Rhind completed her studies trapping for wambengers in some of her sites has been continued by staff in the Warren Region.  In this study all the sites in which wambengers were previously captured will be reinvestigated to determine their current abundance. The abundance of wambengers in other sites will also be investigated.  These sites will either be unlogged and unbaited, unlogged and baited, or baited and logged.  No sites that are logged and unbaited could be found.

 

 

The potential impact that fox baiting programmes may have on populations of wambengers will be investigated.  In a captive study wambengers were fed both the currently used dried meat bait (DMB) and the new fox bait being developed by DCLM: ‘Probait’ (Martin et al. 2002).  Some wambengers consumed sufficient amounts of both bait types for them to be potentially at risk from baiting programs.  The risk from Probaits was higher than for dried meat baits.  Before Probaits can be used operationally the risk to wambengers in the field from this bait type needs to be quantified.  When an appropriately sized population of wambengers (a minimum of 32 individuals will be required to ensure that some statistical validity can be attributed to the results but as many individuals as possible will be used) has been identified the area will be baited with non-toxic, biomarker-labelled baits.  The wambengers in that area will then be captured and their whiskers examined for the presence of the biomarker.  The biomarker rhodamine will be used and this leaves a characteristic pink band in any animal that ingests it.  The proportion of wambengers that reveal the biomarker will indicate the number that would have been affected by a lethal baiting campaign and thus whether the population is at risk can be determined.  

 

 

The distributional and abundance data collected in this study will be used to determine the appropriate IUCN status for this species.  If applicable Phascogale nov sp. might be listed on the state and Commonwealth’s endangered fauna lists.
aims:
1. to determine if significant decreases in density and/ or distribution of wambengers have occurred recently
  2. to determine the reasons for the decline in density and distribution of wambengers (if any) and in particular to assess the potential impact that fox baiting and / or logging may have had on populations
  3. to determine the potential risk to wambengers from operational fox baiting campaigns using ‘Probaits’
  4. to determine the current conservation status of Phascogale nov sp. using IUCN criteria
outcome:
1. a revised summary of the distribution and density of the wambenger
  2. an assessment of the conservation status of the wambenger
  3. a determination of the potential risk from fox baiting (in particular the use of Probaits) to populations of wambengers
knowledge_transfer: If the wambenger is a new species and has declined it will probably be recommended for listing as a threatened species. As such it will become a Departmental responsibility to ensure that no further decline in wambenger abundance occurs. A recovery plan will need to be written and the appropriate regions, Science Division and WATSCU will have responsibility for undertaking recovery actions. If the results of this study confirm that Probaits pose a substantial risk to populations of wambengers, the Department will need to amend the timing or locality of baiting operations so that any potential impact upon this species is minimised.

methodology:
Abundance investigations:

i)          All available data on the distribution of wambengers will be collated and a distribution map for different time periods will be generated. Time frames may be pre 1960, 1961-1970, 1971-1980, 1981-1990, >1991. The frequency of sightings/ captures per time-frame will be quantified and will be analysed according to the type of sighting or capture. The sighting rate of another species that is known not to have declined during this time will be used as a benchmark to try to correct for anomalies in the sighting data.

ii)         The abundance of wambengers will be compared at 8 sites: (these have been tentatively identified as the following) three logged and baited sites (Yerramin, Topanup, Kingston 5); three unlogged, baited sites (Kingston 6, Perup 1 and Perup 2); and two unlogged, unbaited sites (Dingup and Frosty Rd). No logged, unbaited sites could be found.  The sampling effort will be a 1.5 by 1.5 km grid of nest boxes, with each nestbox 300m from the next Rhind (1994). The nest boxes will be checked for 4 consecutive nights.

iii)         An additional source of data on the presence of wambengers may be available through the routine Forestcheck monitoring that is currently undertaken on 6 transects on Smeetch Rd (6) at Perup and at the Thornton and Kingston sites.  There are 50 trap points at 200 m intervals on these transects.  By incorporating the results from that monitoring into this project it may be possible to get more information about wambengers and to further understand the reasons for their decline in the forest.

Investigations into the potential impact of fox baiting

i) Determination of the effectiveness of rhodamine as a biomarker for phascogales.

A sample of approximately 4 phascogales will be caught in nest boxes. They will be transported to the animal holding facilities at Agriculture WA at Forrestfield. They will be tested initially to determine their ‘background’ level of rhodamine (if any). They will then be fed a single Probait that has been labelled with rhodamine. They will be maintained on their normal diet for 2 weeks for the rhodamine to ‘label’ their whiskers.  Approximately 8-10 whiskers will be removed from each individual. The phascogale will be anaesthetised using Isofluorane during this procedure. Rhodamine leaves a pink band in the whiskers of individuals that ingest it and this can be detected with ultraviolet light.  The whiskers will be sent to VIAS in Victoria for confirmation of the presence of rhodamine.

ii) Field testing of Probaits

If the rhodamine labelling trails are successful, two sites will be aerially baited with non-toxic ‘Probaits’ that have been labelled with rhodamine. Each bait will contain 50mg of rhodamine that was added as a solution.  The standard baiting rate of 5 baits km-2 will be used. The areas to be used are yet to be identified or quantified (probably Kingston/ Perup). The phascogale densities in each of these sites will be assessed in February and the actual sites to be used will then be identified.  Individuals that will be used for testing the ingestion of rhodamine will be obtained from the site that is not used in the main experiment.

Phascogales will be trapped in both sites approximately 2 weeks after the delivery of the biomarker labelled baits.  Individuals will be caught in nest boxes that have been strategically positioned throughout the sites. When captured each individual will have approximately 8-10 whiskers removed. They will be anaesthetised using Isoflourane during this procedure.  Approximately 100-120 nest boxes will be present in each site. The proportion of the population that can be ‘removed’ by baits without affecting population viability will be determined by population viability analysis.  If this level of ingestion is exceeded then alternative methods of controlling foxes in areas where phascogales are present will need to be devised.
no_specimens: Any wambenger that dies unexpectedly during the experiment will be lodged with the museum. All individuals trapped during the experiment will be released on site.
data_management: Data will be stored and maintained on the server at Woodvale

background:
The Order Oligochaeta (earthworms) was one of 6 terrestrial and aquatic invertebrate taxa whose native fauna were noted by Harvey (2002) to consist principally of short range endemic species. These species have small ranges (less than 10,000 km2). In the case of native Western Australian earthworms, ranges smaller than 100 km2 are common (Abbott and Wills 2002, Wills and Abbott 2003). Poor powers of dispersal and confinement to discontinuous habitats are characteristics of taxa containing high numbers of short-range endemics. These characteristics leave short-range endemic species vulnerable to habitat change or destruction and hence elevate them in priority for conservation research in areas where their habitats may be threatened. 

 

 

The vegetation and hydrology of the Swan Coastal Plain have undergone extensive modification since European settlement. 21 native species of native earthworms from 136 sites have been recovered in a study of the SCP in the Perth metropolitan area. However, an estimate of the diversity prior to European settlement is as high as 38 species, almost double that recovered from systematic survey of remaining native vegetation in the Perth sector of the coastal plain. By this estimate, it is possible that the fate of at least half the earthworm diversity depends on survival in areas either cleared of native vegetation or vegetation otherwise considered to have no conservation significance. While some native earthworm species can survive in disturbed areas such as pastures most native species tend to be scarcer in disturbed habitats. 

 

 

A primary step in the conservation of short-range endemic species is their identification through biotic surveys. We have surveyed the Perth metropolitan sector of the SCP for native earthworms, however the southern and northern parts of the SCP outside the Perth metropolitan area remain unsurveyed. The logistical requirements of comprehensive survey are not trivial. Species accumulation in regional samples is linear up to sample intensities of about 1 site per square kilometre. Sampling large regional areas at this intensity is clearly impractical. Regional sampling at the rate of 1 sample per 30-100 km2 is achievable. A modest sampling program is proposed involving a week of field work a year by two persons during June to August (depending on rainfall) over a period of 3 years. This would require an annual budget of $1600 comprising accommodation expenses of $1000 and vehicle costs of $600.

 

 

 

Documenting the terrestrial Oligochaete fauna of the entire Swan Coastal Plain will enhance the conservation of native Oligochaetes, a taxon likely to contain species vulnerable to habitat modification, by identifying species with restricted ranges. The project will do this by accumulating earthworm distribution and diversity data and evaluating the adequacy of the system of formal and informal conservation areas for terrestrial Oligocheate conservation.
aims:
1. To document the terrestrial Oligochaete fauna of the entire Swan Coastal Plain.
  2. To identify species with restricted ranges which are possibly vulnerable to threatening processes.
  3. To evaluate the adequacy of the system of formal and informal conservation areas for terrestrial Oligocheate conservation
outcome:
The process of analysing collected material will enable acquisition of taxonomic skills by technical staff involved. These skills will have potential application in allowing formal description of Western Australian terrestrial Oligochaete faunas. Earthworm distribution data will provide a basis for evaluating the longer-term survival status of species collected and broaden the recognized conservation value of elements of the conservation estate. As an example, in south eastern Australia the Gippsland giant earthworm Megascolides australis, whose biology and distribution is relatively well known, is recorded as vulnerable or threatened on the following instruments: Listed on ‘Schedule 1 - Listed Species’ ‘Part 2 – Species that are vulnerable’ under the Commonwealth Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999; listed as threatened on Schedule 2 of the Victoria Fauna & Flora Guarantee Act 1988.

Listed in the 2000 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species as Vulnerable (VU D2). Formal listing of vulnerable species underpins requirements for planned management in consideration of these species.
knowledge_transfer: WATSCU: Advice and recommendations will be provided in written format Regional Nature Conservation leaders: Advice and recommendations will be provided in written format. Community: Presentation to Naturalist clubs in the regions. Scientific colleagues: Refereed paper in international journal.

references:
Abbott I. and Wills A. (2002) Distribution of the native earthworm fauna of the Perth metropolitan sector of the Swan Coastal Plain. Pacific Conservation Biology 8:196-210.

Harvey M.S. (2002) Short-range endemism among the Australian fauna: some examples from non-marine environments. Invertebrate Systematics 16: 555-570.

Wills A. and Abbott I. (2003) Landscape-scale species richness of earthworms in the Porongurup Range, Western Australia: influence of aspect, soil fertility and vegetation type. Biology and Fertility of Soils 39, 94-102.
methodology:
Field methods: At each site, earthworms are sampled and dominant canopy species and general vegetation structure (overstorey height and composition) will be noted. Soil samples for later analysis are to be taken from the top 10 cm of mineral soil. At each site, spade divots of soil and litter will be manually broken down on a white polyurethane mat and closely examined. Divots are taken until earthworms are recovered or until 10 divots are searched. Any earthworms recovered are placed in plastic bags with a handful of moist soil and kept from direct sunlight and heat. Later, the earthworms are anaesthetized, killed and washed in 40% ethanol for about 10 minutes, then fixed in 4% formalin for between 1 and 2 hours before storage in vials containing 70% ethanol. Wash down of digging implements with ethanol will prevent transfer of pathogens between sites.

Laboratory methods: External features were used to allocate specimens to recognizable species or morphospecies analogous to species. The principal features used were: setal arrangement - perichaetine or with 8 setal rows; segmentation - tripartite or unipartite segments; number and arrangement of accessory genital markings about the male pores on 18th segment; and number and arrangement of accessory markings on 8th to 12th segments, usually markings in the intersegmental folds. Voucher specimens for species and morphospecies are lodged at the Western Australian Museum, with duplicates, if available, lodged at the Australian Museum and the CALM collection.

Soils: Soil samples will be collected at each site by bulking a series of twenty 1.5 cm diameter cores at depths of 0-10 cm and 40-50 cm. Cores will collected from areas in the vicinity of where earthworms have been collected after moving aside litter down to first signs of mineral soil.

Samples will be dried and coarse matter (> 2 mm) separated by sieve. Coarse organic matter will be separated from coarse mineral matter by flotation in water. Fractions of particle sizes less than 2 mm will be determined using the pipette method. Selected soil chemistry parameters of N, P, K, Mg and Ca content (soluble and total), total dissolved salts and pH will be measured. External analytical laboratories will be used.

Statistical analysis:

Data Analysis.  Combined earthworm and soils and vegetation data will be subjected to Canonical correspondence analysis to explore relationships between variables.
data_management: Final database will not be extensive and will likely be an appendix to report/paper compiled at the end of the survey

background:
One of the overall aims of the Forest Management Plan 2004-2013 is to protect soil and water resources in forested areas to which the Plan applies. Key performance indicator (KPI) 20 is the percentage of waterbodies (e.g. stream kilometres, lake hectares) with significant variance of biodiversity from the historic range of variability. The intent of KPI20 is to provide a measure of the success of the Forest Management Plan in protecting the ecological integrity and quality of streams.

 

 

The rationale behind this project is that logging and fire frequently cause changes to stream conditions and, consequently, their ecology. Sedimentation and opening up of canopy are usually the greatest causes of impact (see Halse and Blyth 1992), with much of the sediment coming from roads crossing streams.

 

 

The project addresses KPI20 by monitoring aquatic macroinvertebrates and measuring various aspects of water physico-chemistry at 40-50 sites in spring each year. The protocol being used is based on AUSRIVAS and AUSRIVAS models will be used to assess the degree of disturbance in the streams subject to monitoring (Halse _et al_. 2001).
aims:
The objective of KPI 20 is to assess the success of the implementation of the Forest Management Plan 2004-2013 in protecting the ecological integrity and quality of streams. The specific criteria to be used in assessing success are:

Indicator - Percentage of water bodies (e.g. stream kilometres) with significant variance of biodiversity from the historic range of variability

Biodiversity Measure - The diversity of aquatic macro-invertebrate fauna at a selected number of monitoring sites

Performance Target - No sites with fauna significantly different from the reference condition
outcome: Project will monitor whether CALM is meeting FMP commitments with regard to maintaining forest stream biodiversity. It will also provide information on forest stream biodiversity and add to knowledge of the occurrence and distribution of the State’s biota.
knowledge_transfer: (1) Monitoring results will be used by SFM and the EPA to assess compliance with the FMP. (2) Information on pattern of aquatic invertebrate occurrence will be used by CALM to examine adequacy of forest reserve system, and to compile lists of Threatened Ecological Communities and Rare or Priority Taxa. (3) Information on response of stream communities to fire, logging and dams will be used by FPC, SFM and Water Corporation to improve management of forestry activities, burning regimes and water harvesting. (4) Project results will be disseminated by: A. circulating progress reports annually to appropriate agency staff B. formal reporting of results to SFM and the EPA every five years C. scientific publications as appropriate

references:
Halse, S.A. and Blyth, J.D. (1992). Aquatic fauna of the karri forest. In: Research on the Impact of Forest Management in South-West Western Australia. CALM Occasional Paper No. 2/92. July 1992. Department of Conservation and Land Management, Western Australia, pp. 115-138

Halse, S.A., Scanlon, M.D. and Cocking, J.C. (2001). First National Assessment of River Health: Western Australian Program. Milestone Report 5 and Final Report. Unpublished report to Environment Australia. Department of Conservation and Land Management, Perth, 86 pp
methodology:
Monitoring will occur between August and October in channel habitat. This consists of unvegetated river banks and the central portion of the stream. Macroinvertebrates will be collected by 10 m of sweeping with a pond net, the sample will be washed and elutriated and then sub-sampled using a box sampler until 200 animals have been randomly encountered. All macroinvertebrates will be identified to family level and animals of the orders/families Ephemeroptera, Plecoptera, Trichoptera, Hemiptera, Coleoptera, Odonata and Chironomidae identified to species. These groups are amenable to species identification because keys exist and they are either known to be sensitive to water quality change or species-rich. Family level identifications are used in AUSRIVAS models and the species data will be used to examine biodiversity trends in more detail. Overall, methodology will follow that of Halse et al. (2001).

Data on site characteristics has been compiled for all sites. Things documented include tenure, forest type (jarrah or karri), logging and fire history, soil type, slope and expected impacts. In addition to macroinvertebrates, water quality data will be collected, including salinity, nutrients, pH, temperature, turbidity and dissolved oxygen.

The distribution of the 46 sites sampled in 2005 is shown in Figure 1 and Table 1 provides a breakdown of forest type, occurrence in CALM regions, land tenure, reason for monitoring and expected impacts. The initial basis for site selection was to examine sites previously sampled during the 1994-1999 AUSRIVAS program, for which some existing data are available. Only sites where discharge was less than 100,000 ML per annum were included. However, the project required a set of sites that are representative of forest conditions and a series of other selection criteria were imposed. These included that ca 75% of sites should be in jarrah forest, 25% in karri; ca 60% of sites should be in areas subject to logging and 40% in unlogged areas; sites should be spread across the forested area; a small number of sites should examine the impact of dams; a small number of sites should be located in areas that experienced wildfire last summer so that the impact of intense burns could be examined; a small number of sites should be in areas to be logged this year or next year so that the impact of logging could be examined. In order to fulfill the above criteria, it was necessary to include a number of sites not sampled during AUSRIVAS.

A small number of sites will be added to the program in 2006, after consultation with DoE and Water Corporation to examine the impact of Yarragadee extraction. This will include sites on St John’s Brook, Milyeannup Creek and Poison Gully. There will also be consideration of whether sites on bauxite, and other mining, leases should be included.

The framework for reporting and analysis, as stipulated by SFM, is shown below.

no_specimens: Selected specimens will be incorporated into the Woodvale aquatic invertebrate collection. Over time it is expected several hundred specimens will be vouchered in this way, with details stored on a corporate database on the Woodvale server. Type specimens of any new species will be lodged with the Western Australian Museum.
data_management: Data will be incorporated into the MRHI database on the Woodvale server, which is a corporate database for river invertebrate data. All CALM's AUSRIVAS data are held in this database (there has been periodic export to the Commonwealth Government AUSRIVAS database).

related_projects: mesopredators research projects- SPPs to be advised
background:
The abundance of some species of fauna increased significantly in several areas in Western Australia following the introduction of fox control.  However, the recovery of a number of species e.g. the woylie _(Bettongia penicillata)_ has not been sustained despite maintained fox control regimes. The suite of factors potentially responsible for the decline of these populations will be investigated in two fragmented wheatbelt reserves; Dryandra Woodland and Tutanning Nature Reserve.  The factors to be investigated include fox, feral cat, python and raptor predation. The survival of woylies (#KTBA) will be modelled as a function of these factors.  Woylies will be trapped regularly in cage traps. They will also be fitted with mortality sensing radio-collars and the factors responsible for their demise or lack of recruitment identified. 

 

 

 

Fox and feral cat abundance will be monitored at sandplots and DNA analysis will be used to identify individuals from scats, saliva and fur. Sandplots will be monitored each quarter, following the regular fox baiting program.  Foxes and feral cats, when detected, will be trapped and fitted with satellite collars (resources permitting).  Their movements will be monitored continuously and their interactions (if any) and habitat partitioning identified.  The predominate timing of reinvasion and the presence of bait wary foxes (if any) will be identified.

 

 

 

The effectiveness of the current fox baiting regime will be investigated by analysing the uptake and longevity of baits.  The 1080 content of baits and their degradation following rain will be examined.
aims:
• To test the mesopredator release hypothesis at the landscape and local scale.
  • To determine the causes of woylie decline
  • To test the effectiveness of current baiting regimes and to identify if resident foxes are present
outcome:
Quantifying (and if necessary reducing) the impact of foxes on the survival of woylies in fragmented wheatbelt reserves

Determining the interaction between a suite of factors (feral cat, python and raptor predation) and the survival of woylies in areas baited monthly for fox control

Identifying the timing of reinvasion by foxes of wheatbelt reserves baited monthly with 3mg 1080 baits

Determining (and if necessary improving) the effectiveness of the current monthly fox baiting regime with 3mg 1080 baits for fox control in fragmented wheatbelt reserves

Identifying the presence of bait wary foxes (if any) in areas baited monthly with 3mg 1080 baits and devising alternative control measures

Identifying the habitat use and partitioning (if any) by foxes and feral cats in fragmented wheatbelt reserves and the implications for fauna management

Determining if there is mesopredator release (i.e. an increase in feral cats, pythons and raptors) in areas baited for fox control

Quantifying the effectiveness of 1080 (or PAPP) cat baits in reducing cat predation on native fauna when non-target issues have been resolved
knowledge_transfer: CALM managers will be able to use the information obtained during this study to help ameliorate the decline of woylies and to improve the effectiveness of fox (and cat) baiting if necessary

references:
Allen, L. Engeman, R. and Krupa, H. (1996).  Evaluation of three relative abundance indices for assessing dingo populations. Wildlife Research 23, 197-206.

Burnham, K. and Anderson, D. (2002).  Model selection and multi-model inference: a practical information-theoretic approach.  Springer.

Cooch, E. and White, G. (2005).  Program MARK: ‘A gentle introduction’ www.phidot.org/software/mark/docs/book

Fleming, P. , Allen, L. Berghout, M., Meek, P., Pavlov, P. Stevens, P., Strong, K., Thompson, J. and Thomson, P. (1998).  The performance of wild-canid traps in Australia: efficiency, selectivity and trap-related injuries.  Wildlife Research 25, 327-338.

Piggott, M. and Taylor, A. (2003).  Extensive evaluations of faecal preservation and DNA extraction methods in Australian native and introduced species.  Australian Journal of Zoology 51, 341-355.

Thomson, P. Marlow, N. Rose, K. and Kok, N. (2000).  The effectiveness of a large-scale baiting campaign and an evaluation of a buffer zone strategy for fox control.  Wildlife Research 27, 465-472.
methodology:
Woylies will be trapped in cage traps for four consecutive nights every three months at Dryandra Woodland and Tutanning Nature Reserve. Their survival (#KTBA) will be determined using capture-recapture methodology (Cooch and White 2005). Woylie survival will be modelled as a function of several factors using the methodology described in Burnham and Anderson (2002). These factors include fox, cat, python and raptor predation.

The predatory impact of foxes, feral cats, pythons and raptors will be determined by fitting mortality sensing radio-collars to 10 woylies at each site. These collars will be monitored frequently (daily where possible) and the respective mortality agent (including the predator responsible) identified. Collars will also be fitted to juvenile woylies (if possible), and the factors responsible for their mortality similarly identified.

The presence of foxes and cats will be monitored using the methodology described in Allen et al. (1996) and Thomson et al. (2000). Sandplots will be monitored quarterly for four consecutive nights both before and after fox baiting event. Individual foxes and cats will be identified where possible from DNA analysis of scats, fur or saliva samples (Piggott and Taylor 2003). Fur samples may obtained by enticing animals to pass between two semi-vertical sticks, each with double sided tape adhered to it. Saliva samples may be obtained by encouraging individuals to lick an attractant on fine grade sandpaper.  Scats may be obtained by deliberately placing scats or urine of a conspecific at a known visitation site. 

When the tracks of foxes and cats are detected, attempts will be made to catch each individual using #1.5 size Victor soft-catch traps (Fleming et al. 1998).  A variety of lures will be used to entice foxes and cats into the trap site and these will include food, visual stimuli, aural lures (felid attracting phonics (FAPs)), or scent signals such as scats or urine.  Traps will be checked every 12 hours (minimum) and will be positioned carefully to avoid capture of non-target species or detection by the public.  Captured foxes and cats will be fitted with satellite telemetry collars (resources permitting) and data on their localities and status (alive or dead) will be recorded daily.  The data obtained will be used to determine if they interact with each and/or if they partition their use of the habitat and thus influence their predatory impact upon native fauna.  The longevity of foxes will be investigated and whether they remain resident within the study areas or are ‘turned’ over regularly by the baiting regime will be identified. The 1080 content of baits will be investigated by placing a sample in the field and determining the amount of 1080 lost during observed rain events.
data_management: Data will be stored on PCs at Woodvale and backup on the server.

related_projects: Ravensthorpe Range survey
background:
There are currently over 30 proposals to explore, commence or enlarge existing iron ore operations on Banded Ironstone Ranges in southern Western Australia. The demand is being driven by sustained growth in China that is expected to continue well into the future. A feature of these rapidly developing markets has been the desire by proponents for expedited approvals to lock in current high commodity prices.

As geological features the Banded Iron Formations in the Mid-West and Yilgarn regions form a series of isolated peaks and ranges in an ancient and generally subdues regional landscape.

The knowledge of the biodiversity significance of these environments is far from complete, but what is known indicates that these isolated peaks are behaving as important refugia for flora and fauna, they are a focus for rare and priority species, and restricted vegetation communities including some recognized as Threatened Ecological Communities, and are likely to support short range endemic fauna (Bennett (1987), Gibson et al. (1997), Gibson & Lyons (1998ab), Gibson & Lyons (2001a,b), Portman (2002), Butcher et al., 2003, Gibson (2004ab)). The loss of these landscapes on a regional scale will therefore result in the loss of unique and regionally significant flora and vegetation

At present there is no regional quantative dataset that covers the extent of the Banded Ironstone Ranges in sufficient detail to allow assessment of regional conservation significance of individual mining proposals. While the earlier work of CALM and Portman provide this overview in Mt Jackson – Bungalbin area, this only covers a portion of the extent of BIF in the Yilgarn.

There is an urgent need to develop such a dataset in order to facilitate the timely assessment of development proposals.

This project will establish a further 50 quadrats on each of 6 ranges highly prospective for minerals. These data will allow assessment of regional significance of the flora and vegetation of these areas and be available to assist in the environmental assessment of future proposed developments. Little of these data are currently available leading to delays in the environmental approval process.

Similar surveys undertaken by CALM in the eastern Goldfields and the MidWest region have lead to identification of species new to science, new populations of threatened flora and the identification of potentially threatened vegetation communities restricted to unusual geologies.
aims: To identify the biodiversity values (flora and vegetation) of 6 ranges highly prospective for exploration and mining.
outcome:
• location of new populations of threatened flora
  • identification of local endemics and possibly new species
  • reassessment of individual species conservation status
  • identification of restricted and potentially threatened plant communities
  • generate regional datasets to assist in environmental assessment process
knowledge_transfer:
• WA herbarium staff & other interstate taxonomists, processing newly identified taxa & vouchered material in revisionary studies
  • SCB processing new nominations for threatened flora
  • Mining industry using regional datasets to define regional context for mining proposals
  • General public through enhanced distributional information available via florabase
project_tasks:
Completion of fieldwork                   30th October 2007

Significant flora discoveries             28th February 2008

Final report                                    30th June 2008.

Synthesis paper submitted              30th December 2009.
references:
Markey, A.S. & Dillon S.J. (2006a) Flora and vegetation of the Banded Ironstone Formations of the Yilgarn Craton: Central Tallering land system. Conservation Science in review.

Markey, A.S. & Dillon S.J. (2006b) Flora and vegetation of the Banded Ironstone Formations of the Yilgarn Craton: Weld Range. Conservation Science in review.

Meissner, R. & Caruso, Y. (2006a) Flora and vegetation of the Banded Ironstone Formations of the Yilgarn Craton: Jack Hills. Conservation Science in review.

Meissner, R. & Caruso, Y. (2006b) Flora and vegetation of the Banded Ironstone Formations of the Yilgarn Craton: Koolanooka and Perenjori Hills. Conservation Science in review.

Meissner, R. & Caruso, Y. (2006c) Flora and vegetation of Banded Ironstone Formations of the Yilgarn Craton: Mt Gibson. Conservation Science in review.

Gibson N (2004). Flora and vegetation of the eastern goldfields ranges. Part 6, Mt Manning Range. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 87, pp. 35-47

Gibson N (2004). Flora and vegetation of the eastern goldfields ranges. Part 7, Middle and South Ironcap, Digger Rock and Hatter Hill. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 87, pp. 49-62

Gibson N, Lyons MN (2001). Flora and vegetation of the eastern goldfields ranges. Part 4, Highclere Hills. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 84, pp. 71-81

Gibson N, Lyons MN (2001). Flora and vegetation of the eastern goldfields ranges. Part 5, Hunt Range, Yendilberin and Watt Hills. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 84, pp. 129-142

Gibson N, Lyons MN (1998). Flora and vegetation of the eastern goldfields ranges. 2, Bremer Range. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 81, pp. 107-117

Gibson N, Lyons MN (1998). Flora and vegetation of the eastern goldfields ranges. 3, Parker Range. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 81, pp. 119-129

Gibson N, Lyons MN, Lepschi BJ (1997). Flora and vegetation of the eastern goldfield ranges. Part 1, Helena and Aurora Range. CALMScience 2, pp. 231-246
methodology:
For each range fifty 20 x 20 m quadrats will be established over the survey area, during the spring season in 2007. Sites will only established where road access was adequate.  Plots will be placed on the crests, slopes and outwashes associated with the ranges, and will be placed strategically to encompass the topological profile of the ranges and the general range of variation of geological landforms and associated vegetation communities in the area. A similar method has been used to survey greenstone and ironstone ranges in the eastern goldfields (Gibson 2004, Gibson and Lyons 2001).

Quadrats will be marked with four steel fence droppers and position marked by GPS and photographed at a set distance (0 – 5m) near each corner. The presence and cover of all vascular plant species (angiosperms, gymnosperms and pteridiophytes) will be recorded in each plot, with material collected for verification at the Western Australian Herbarium. Vegetation structure was described according to McDonald et al. (1998). All data on topographical position, aspect, slope, % litter, % bare ground, % rock cover class of both surface deposits and exposed bedrock, shape of surface rock fragments, soil colour and soil texture will be noted according to the definitions of McDonald et al. (1998). Percentage surface rock fragment cover class (Rock Frag), maximum rock fragment size (MxR) and exposed bedrock outcrop cover will be all coded on a semi-quantitative scale. Percentage surface rock fragment cover classes will be scored on six point scale; 0 % cover (0); < 2 % cover (1); 2 – 10%, (2); 10 – 20% (3); 20 – 50% (4); 50 – 90% (5); > 90% (6). Maximum rock size was classed on a six point scale; 2 – 6 mm (1); 6 – 20 mm (2); 20 – 60 mm (3); 60 – 200 mm (4); 200 – 600 mm (5); 600 mm – 2m (6). Leaf litter and bare ground will be visual estimates of the percentage of ground cover. Topographic position (Tp) in the landscape was coded on a six point scale which was semi-quantitative: outwash (1); lower slope (2); mid slope (3), upper slope or low ridge (4), crest (5).

For each plot a bulked soil sample was collected, this being complied from 20 smaller samples collected regularly over the area of the plot. Soils will be analysed if sufficient funds are available for a suite of 12 elements at the Chemistry Centre of Western Australia, using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP AES). This will involve the simultaneous determination of a suite of elements (P, K, S, Ca, Mg, Na, B, Co, Cu, Fe, Mg and Zn) using the Mehlich No. 3 soil test procedure (Melich 1984, Walton and Allen 2004).  Soil pH will also be determined 0.01M CaCl2, and effective cation exchange capacity (eCEC) will be calculated from the summation of exchangeable bases after multiplication of each base (Na, Ca, K and Mg) by a set standard constant (Rayment and Higginson 1992, Soil and Plant Council, 1999).

Pattern analysis will be conducted on a presence / absence data matrix of the perennial taxa, the singleton and annual taxa will be omitted from the data matrix prior to analysis. Singletons (taxa that appeared in a single plot) will be omitted as these contain little information. Annuals will be excluded because their distribution and abundance is a function of rainfall in the previous season (Mott 1972, 1973, Beard 1990). The omission of annuals allows for these results to be comparable with other data collected from other seasons and years, and is consistent with previous surveys on other greenstone and ironstone communities (Gibson and Lyons 1998, 2001, Gibson 2004). Resemblance matrices, using the Bray Curtis measure of association, will be compared using the 2 Stage algorithm in Primer (Clark and Gorley 2006) to confirm that there was little information being lost from the dataset by the omission of these taxa.

Pattern analysis will be conducted using PATN (V3.03) (Belbin 1989). The Bray-Curtis coefficient will be used for the association matrix for sites and species classification and the semi-strong hybrid (SSH) multidimensional scaling for ordination of sites (Belbin 1991). The agglomerative, hierarchical clustering was used to generate a species and site classification, using flexible UPGMA (β = -0.1) (Sneath and Sokal 1973). A sorted two-way table will be generated that was ordered by these site and species classifications. Three dimensional semi-strong hybrid (SSH) multidimensional scaling was implemented for the ordination of the presence / absence quadrat data, using 1000 random starts and 50 iterations.

Principal Component Correlation (PCC) (www.patn.com.au) runs multiple linear regression of extrinsic variables on the three dimensional ordination (Belbin 1989). The environmental variables will be not standardized or transformed before PCC analysis as the Monte-Carlo procedure (MCAO) was employed in PATN as a bootstrap analysis to evaluate the significance of these correlation coefficients. This will be done by implementing PCC on the same ordination using a simulated dataset of randomized values for each environmental variable (Belbin 1989). The Kruskal-Wallis nonparametric analysis of variance will be used to determine differences in environmental parameters among floristic community groups, followed by Dunn’s posthoc multiple comparisons test when required to identify dissimilar groups (Zar 1984). Indicator species analysis (INDVAL) will be calculated using PC-Ord (McCune and Mefford 1999), using the methods of Dufrene and Legendre (1997). These INDVAL measures will be used to determine the significant indicator species for each floristic community type.
no_specimens: Estimated number of vouchered specimens: 1750
data_management: The data will be archived at Woodvale. There is no fiunding for continued data maintenance in terms of maintaining taxonomic currency. Data will be made available to mining industry & NGO groups on completion of identifications to assist with resource proposal assessment.

related_projects: Terrestrial Baselining the Avon Project (P Gioia)
background:
This project was tendered for by Stuart Halse in 2005, in response to an Expression of Interest (EOI) put out by the Avon Catchment Council for a project titled “ND001 Getting started: “Baselining” the region’s natural diversity”. This EOI was developed in response to Management Action Targets (MAT’s) in the Avon Natural Resource Management Strategy (Avon Catchment Council, 2005). 

 

 

For the wetland component, the following Management Action Target was requested to be addressed:

 

 

W2.2.2 - Major salt lakes and other wetlands of regional significance in the Avon River Basin are identified and characterized based on hydrological and ecological criteria.

 

 

Apart from the Salinity Action Plan Wheatbelt Biological Survey and Monitoring Program (Pinder et al. 2004) little information was available on the vast numbers of wetlands in the Avon NRM region. This project partially filled this gap by providing an inventory of the wetlands in the region, with up to date mapping and classification of wetlands into groups based on hydrology, landform and other physical characteristics. It also provided a broad-scale evaluation of the conservation significance of basin and granite outcrop wetlands to enable strategic catchment planning in the region.
aims:
The wetlands component of the Avon Baselining Project had the following aims:

1.     Map every wetland in the Avon NRM region at a scale of 1:10,000, so that it is accurate to be used at a scale of 1:100,000. This includes the attribution of the landscape setting of these wetlands (amount of buffer vegetation, connectivity of vegetation, surrounding impacts, existing data available, hydrology etc.). This mapping was conducted in collaboration with the Wheatbelt Wetlands Project run by Nature Conservation Division.

2.     Develop a method for conducting regional-scale (Stage 1) wetland classification and conservation significance evaluation for wetlands greater than one hectare in the Avon Catchment (compatible with the WA Wetland Status Working Group’s Framework for Mapping, Classification and Evaluation of Wetlands in Western Australia [DEC 2007]).

3.     Use the above to classify and evaluate conservation significance of every basin, granite outcrop and reservoir wetland greater than one hectare.

4.     Develop a method for conducting on-ground (stage 3) wetland classification and conservation significance evaluations of inundated basin wetlands in the Avon NRM region (compatible with the WA Wetland Status Working Group’s Framework for Mapping, Classification and Evaluation of Wetlands in Western Australia [DEC 2007]).

The following three aims were added after additional funds were obtained from the Avon NRM.

5.     Test the above stage 3 method on a number of representative wetlands.

6.     Produce a literature review that documents what is currently known about the flow-on effects of agricultural drainage on basin wetlands. In particular, the effects of altered salinity, pH, hydrology, sediment and nutrient loads on aquatic invertebrate, waterbird and vegetation communities.

7.     Produce a colour guide to waterbirds and aquatic invertebrates inhabiting wetlands in the Avon NRM region, aimed at landholders and the general public.
outcome:
1. Knowledge of the number, type, location and significance of wetlands in the Avon NRM region. The wetland mapping GIS shapefile, with wetland boundaries attributed for landscape setting, typology and stage 1 (remote sensed) conservation status assessment, will assist DEC staff with a variety of wetland and catchment management tasks and prioritization of conservation actions. These layers have already contributed to a regional conservation planning program run by Avon NRM and DEC.
  2. A method for conducting detailed on-ground (stage 3) assessments of the conservation significance of wetlands in the Avon NRM region. This will provide regional DEC officers with standardised conservation significance assessments and provide an endorsed method for drainage proponents to follow.
  3. The literature review of potential effects (and knowledge gaps) of agricultural drainage water discharge on the biota of Avon NRM wetlands will aid assessment of drainage proposals by DEC staff.
  4. Data on aquatic invertebrates, water chemistry and waterbirds for 92 wetlands in the region, with floristic data for some of these. This adds to knowledge of aquatic biodiversity patterning in the region.
knowledge_transfer: DEC Staff, NRM groups, conservation planners, community groups and Local Government Authorities. This information will be, and has been, made available to all of these groups through the following mechanisms: • Documents have been made available through the Avon NRM website (www.wheatbeltnrm.org.au) and the DEC library. • Wetland mapping is available to DEC staff through the corporate data system. • Wetland mapping and evaluations are available to the general public through NatureMap (http://naturemap.dec.wa.gov.au). Hardcopies have been printed for each shire and sent to the shires through the Avon Catchment Council, and a copy held by the wetlands group at DEC, Woodvale. • Data collected in the field (92 sites) is available to the public through WetlandBase (www.dec.wa.gov.au > Management and protection > Wetlands > Wetland Base).

Avon Catchment Council 2005, The Avon Natural Resource Management Strategy for the Avon River Basin, Avon Catchment Council, Northam.

Department of Environment and Conservation, 2007, Framework for mapping, classification and evaluation of wetlands in Western Australia, Department of Environment and Conservation.

methodology:
Aim 1. Map every wetland in the Avon NRM region at a scale of 1:10,000, so that it is accurate to be used at a scale of 1:100,000. This includes the attribution of the landscape setting of these wetlands (amount of buffer vegetation, connectivity of vegetation, surrounding impacts, existing data available, hydrology etc.). This mapping was conducted in collaboration with the Wheatbelt Wetlands Project run by Nature Conservation Division.

  • Assemble the available digital map layers of wetlands and integrated with existing biological and hydrological datasets.
  • Use remote sensing techniques to identify extent surface water for the wettest year with imagery available (1990 and 2000).\Used previous wetland layers (e.g. GeoScience Australia), the remote sensing wetness and aerial photography to delineate areas of inundation and granite outcrops at a scale of 1:10,000.
  • Use aerial photography and other GIS layers (e.g. Ramsar, Directory of Important Wetlands) to attribute each wetland polygon with additional information. This includes, but is not limited to, surrounding vegetation amount, vegetation and hydrological connectivity, flow direction, catchment position, landform, other site information available, etc.
  • Undertake field validation of initial wetland mapping, visiting wetlands of different types, inundation periods and landforms to test boundary accuracy and how the methodology could be refined. Verifify of boundaries by examining soil and vegetation characteristics. See Lizamore (2008).
  • Desktop QA/QC of 10% of wetland mapping, including checking of attribution, spelling, duplication errors and boundaries.
  • Make layer available through DEC corporate data and online.

Aim 2. Develop a method for conducting regional-scale (Stage 1) wetland classification and conservation significance evaluation for wetlands greater than one hectare in the Avon Catchment (compatible with the WA Wetland Status Working Group’s Framework for Mapping, Classification and Evaluation of Wetlands in Western Australia [DEC 2007]).

  • Form of technical advisory group: Stuart Halse (Bennelongia Pty Ltd), Barbara Cook (UWA) and Jenny Davis (Murdoch Uni/Monash Uni).
  • Conduct a literature review of previous wetland classification and evaluation methodologies.
  • Model richness of biological assemblages using remotely available environmental data (e.g. BIOCLIM measurements, location, soils etc.).
  • Develop (with Graham Behn of GIS section) a method for assessing wetland salinity class (fresh versus saline) and permanence class using Landsat data.
  • Design a field sampling program with the aim of filling in knowledge gaps for broad-scale wetland classification and evaluation.
  • Liaise with the Wetland Status Working Group (WSWG) concerning the requirements of the methodology and previous approaches used in Western Australia.
  • Produce a draft for comment by the WSWG.
  • Incorporat changes from the WSWG and trialled methodology on a small area of the Avon NRM region.
  • Compare the results of the methodology with on ground data collected in the same area.
  • Present the methodology and trial of application for endorsement to the WSWG.
  • Refined methodology, undertake further evaluations and present the final document along with the evaluations for endorsement by the Wetlands Coordinating Committee.
  • Make document available to the general public through the Avon Natural Diversity Alliance website.

Aim 3. Regional-scale classification and evaluation of every basin, granite outcrop and reservoir wetland greater than one hectare.

  • Appliy above methodology to the whole project area.
  • Cross-check evaluations against available on-ground data and expert opinion.
  • Make GIS layer with evaluations available to the general public through NatureMap.

Aims 4 and 5. Develop a method for conducting on-ground (stage 3) wetland classification and conservation significance evaluations of inundated basin wetlands in the Avon NRM region (compatible with the WA Wetland Status Working Group’s Framework for Mapping, Classification and Evaluation of Wetlands in Western Australia [DEC 2007]). Test methodology on representative wetlands.

  • Conduct a literature review on previous wetland classification and evaluation methodologies.
  • Liaise with the Wetland Status Working Group (WSWG) concerning the requirements of the methodology and previous approaches used in Western Australia.
  • Produce a draft for comment by the WSWG.
  • Incorporated suggestions of the WSWG and test methodology on representative wetlands.
  • Refine the methodology using the results of the field trial.
  • Present the methodology and trial of application for endorsement by WSWG, and incorporate suggestions prior to presentation for endorsement by the WA Wetlands Coordinating Committee.
  • Make document available to the general public through the ANDA website.

Aim 6. Produce a literature review that documents what is currently known about the flow-on effects of agricultural drainage on basin wetlands. In particular, the effects of altered salinity, pH, hydrology, sediment and nutrient loads on aquatic invertebrate, waterbird and vegetation communities.

  • Identified the water quality and hydrological changes that have occurred in the past due to drainage discharge into wetlands.
  • Reviewed literature for implications of these changes on Avon wetland biota.
no_specimens: All invertebrate voucher specimens have been retained by the aquatic group within Science Division and incorporated into a research voucher collection. Some significant plant specimens were vouchered with the WA Herbarium.
data_management: All data entered into the DEC Science Division Aquatic Projects research database and made available for the State Wetlands Database (Wetland Base) and NatureMap.

related_projects: Yilgarn BIF
background:
The biodiversity values of the Ravensthorpe Range are poorly documented and the area is highly prospective for mineral exploration and mining. The range is know for high number of both threatened and/or locally endemic plant species. There is no consistent flora dataset available across the range making assessment impacts on of mining proposals difficult. Each of the recent mining development in the area had significant threatened flora and vegetation issues. While our knowledge of the flora and vegetation of the Range is limited even less is known of the patterns in the short range endemic invertebrates on the range.

 The proposed survey would establish 200 quadrats across the range to allow regional assessment of flora and vegetation. At a subset of sites invertebrates would also be collected. These data would allow an assessment of regional significance of the flora, vegetation and short range endemic invertebrates and be available to assist in the environmental assessment of future proposed developments. These techniques have been widely used in the eastern goldfields for this purpose (see references).
aims: To identify the biodiversity values (flora, vegetation & short range endemic invertebrates) of the Ravensthorpe Range.
outcome:
• location of new populations of threatened flora
  • identification of local endemics and possibly new species of both flora & invertebrates
  • reassessment of individual species conservation status
  • generate regional datasets to assist in environmental assessment process
knowledge_transfer:
• WA Herbarium staff, WA Museum staff & other interstate taxonomists, processing newly identified taxa & vouchered material in revisionary studies
  • SCB processing new nominations for threatened flora & fauna
  • Mining industry using regional datasets to define regional context for mining proposal
  • General public through enhanced distributional information available via florabase

Flora synthesis paper will use standard multivariate techniques to elucidate floristic patterning across the range. This will include analysis of both the floristic and abiotic datasets in the 200 quadrats established by the flora tender following methods followed in other papers in this series (see references).

related_projects: SPP 2006-003 Forestcheck - integrated forest monitoring
background:
The terrestrial vertebrate component of the Kingston Project (SPP 1993/115) employs a replicated BACI (Before, After, Control, Impact) design. Intensive field work was conducted 1994-2000. Timber-harvesting occurred in 1995-1996. Pit and Elliott trapping for small vertebrates ceased in 2000. Cage trapping to monitor medium-sized mammals has continued on about 4-yearly intervals (i.e. 2004/05 and 2009). In so doing, responses to timber harvesting has been quantified 1-2 years pre-harvesting, 1-2 years during harvesting disturbance and 1, 2, 3, 4, 8 and 13 years post disturbance. Spotlight surveys to monitor less readily captured mammals, particularly ngwayir and koomal, have been conducted along three transects since 1996 and were particularly intensive in 1997-2000. Since 2004 6 surveys per annum have been sustained on each of the three transects.

This concept plan has been prepared to replace SPP 1993/115 and provide for completion of data analysis and publication of results for the period 1996 to 2011. This will be the immediate priority for work in 2012/13. Subject to confirmation that the experimental design is robust and can be extended, the study may be expanded to examine the response of vertebrates to harvesting of mature forest retained as exclusion strips during the 1996 operation. These strips are considered important in mediating the impact of timber harvesting on arboreal mammals and birds. Understanding how fauna will respond to a further harvest cycle in important in informing the current sustainable forest management objectives.
aims:
• Investigate the impacts of silvicultural practices on terrestrial vertebrate communities in jarrah forest.
  • Determine what factors contribute to observed impacts.
  • Adapt silvicultural prescriptions to provide for ecologically sustainable management.
outcome:
• Assessment of the ecological sustainability of jarrah silvicultural practices.
  • Directly informing forest management how activities may be improved to reduce possible negative consequences for sensitive fauna.
