Shearer BL (1994) The major plant pathogens occurring in native plant ecosystems of South Western          Australia. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 77, 113-122. Australasian Plant            Pathology (2007)
methodology:
Transect establishment – Twenty transects (30 trees per transect) recording canker impact in each of Banksia baxteri and B. coccinea communities also 5 in geographically restricted DRF B. verticillata and Lambertia orbifolia. Temperature and humidity data loggers to be installed at representative sites and relevant rainfall interpolations acquired. A multiple regression analysis will be applied to the data.

In vitro test – The systemic fungicides tebuconazole, prochloraz, fenarimol and carbendazim will be added to agar in petri dishes at the concentrations of 0, 0.01, 0.1, 1.0 and 10 mg a.i./mL. Each fungicide will be tested by measuring lateral growth against 2 isolates each of the canker causing fungi Botryosphaeria, Zythiostroma and Cryptodiaporthe sp. with 4 reps each. The entire experiment will be conducted twice. EC50 (half maximal effect concentration) for each fungicide will be calculated and compared by analysis of variance.

Glasshouse trial – The top 2 performing fungicides from the in vitro trial will be become treatments on Banksia attenuatta, B. baxteri, B. coccinea and B. verticillata seedlings  in the glasshouse with 2 concentrations and 4 reps each. Efficacy will be tested by % inhibition on challenge wound inoculations of 2 isolates each of the test fungi and any deleterious effects of application recorded on a % leaf area basis.

Field trial – The 2 fungicides will be applied alternately (to lessen chances of developing resistance) to B. baxteri and B. verticillata in each of 2 field sites at the best performing concentration in the glasshouse trial. There will be 30 plants per treatment with 1 application every 3 months for one year (4 applications total, 2 of each fungicide). Efficacy will be rated by measuring canker incidence and severity on a per tree basis (following Bathgate 1999) at 6 monthly intervals and compared to a control treatment.
no_specimens: 4 plant to Herbarium and 20 fungi to Department of Agriculture Plant Pathogen Collection.
data_management: The data will be backed up on computer, external hard drive and on DEC's intranet. The data set will be maintained on a regular basis. Hardcopies of the completed data set will be filed by the data custodian.

related_projects: Gorgon Dredge Plume Program WAMMP Finfish Monitoring Program (in development)
background:
Assessing the status and trends in the condition of biodiversity assets assists DEC to fulfill its statutory responsibilities for the conservation of the State’s biodiversity. The systematic long-term monitoring, evaluation and reporting (MER) of asset condition-pressure-response (CPR) is a key strategy for assessing the efficiency and effectiveness of management action within Western Australia’s system of marine protected areas (MPAs). MER programs also determined whether conservation goals (i.e. outcomes) are being achieved. Marine management strategies include the use of zoning schemes and regulations to control human activities, compliance monitoring, public participation and community education programs and direct management intervention.  The early detection of ecosystem change through strategic MER programs allows for the modification of these management practices to changing ecosystem condition and threats within an adaptive management context.  

 

The Western Australian Marine Monitoring Program (WAMMP) was established in 2008 within DEC’s Marine Science Program to coordinate the MER of marine biodiversity asset (e.g. finfish, seagrass, and coral communities etc.) CPR status and trends within Western Australia’s MPAs.  A key biodiversity asset of WA MPAs is finfish. Finfish are listed as a Key Performance Indicator (KPI) within most WA MPAs, highlighting their biodiversity significance, social and economic value. Finfish in most MPAs are under considerable anthropogenic pressure from recreational and, to a lesser extent, commercial fishing activities.

 

In shallow, coastal waters, the condition of fish communities has traditionally been monitored, using a technique known as Underwater Visual Census (UVC; Ayling and Ayling 1987; Connell et al. 1998; Samoilys and Carlos 2000; Layman et al. 2004; Williamson et al. 2004; Hobbs et al. 2008).  More recently, a technique for assessing finfish community condition has been developed that utilises stereo-video to capture imagery of fish communities which is later analysed in the laboratory (Watson et al. 2005, 2010; Shedrawi 2008; McLaren 2009; Langlois et al. 2010).  Known as Diver Operated Video (DOV), this technique has potential advantages over UVC because sampling theoretically requires less scientific expertise, takes less time in the field and data analysts have access to reference material to help identify fish,. In addition, it provides a permanent record of the survey that can be checked or revisited at a later point if required. However, DOV datasets are significantly more costly to process and it is unclear if video imagery captures the same level of diversity and abundance as skilled divers conducting UVC. 

 

Despite the significant amount of DOV surveys that have been completed in fish communities in WA over recent years, no thorough investigation comparing the overall utility, results and cost-effectiveness of this technique to conventional UVC methods has been conducted. As such, comparable assessments need to be undertaken to assess the relative utility of these techniques in both temperate and tropical waters where WAMMP has monitoring responsibilities and to better understand the value of historical UVC and DOV datasets. This is especially relevant given the staff constraints (outlined above) and the significant financial and time constraints placed on activities conducted by WAMMP.
aims:
This project aims to compare the accuracy, comparability, cost-efficiency and appropriateness of UVC and DOV survey techniques as methods for assessing fish community condition in low diversity temperate (i.e. Jurien Bay Marine Park), near-shore high diversity tropical (i.e. Montebello/Barrow Islands MPA’s) and off-shore high diversity tropical (i.e. Rowley Shoals Marine Park) marine ecosystems in Western Australia.

The primary objectives are:

i)     Examine the comparability of the fish community dataset (diversity, abundance and size measures) resulting from collection through UVC and DOV survey techniques.

ii)    Examine the effect of varying levels of diversity and abundance on the resulting fish community datasets when data is collected through the two techniques.

iii)    Examine the effect of habitat complexity related to tropical and temperate marine ecosystems on the resulting fish datasets when data is collected through the two techniques.

iv)    Assess the relative cost and practicality of both UVC and DOV techniques in the context of long-term monitoring programs in both tropical and temperate remote locations.

The secondary objectives are:

vi)    Contribution of fish community condition data at long-term monitoring sites towards WAMMP annual audit and monitoring objectives.

vii)   Contribution of fish community condition data at long-term monitoring sites towards the Gorgon Dredge Monitoring Project.

viii)  Continue to offer fish community monitoring training and build effective working arrangements with DEC staff in the Kimberley, Pilbara and Mid-West regions.
outcome:
The outcomes of this project are:

i)     An improved understanding of the comparability of UVC and DOV methods for measuring diversity, abundance and size information of finfish communities.  This will facilitate better alignment of historical UVC data with existing DOV data and vice-versa and allow DEC to better assess the utility of historical time-series of fish community information for use in WAMMP.  These datasets would be confounded without such a study.

ii)    An improved understanding of the applicability to regional staff and relative costs of each survey technique as a monitoring tool for fish communities in tropical and temperate marine ecosystems.  This will allow WAMMP to more effectively select between the two survey techniques.

iii)    Acquisition of further data on the status of finfish communities within JBMP, MBIMP and RSMP.

The program addresses the following strategic objectives:

i)     DEC Corporate Plan (2007-2009): 1.2, 1.4;

ii)    A Strategic Plan for Biodiversity Conservation Research (2008-2017): 1.18, 1.21, 3.1, 3.7, 3.8; and

iii)   Montebello/Barrow Islands Marine Conservation Reserves management plan: 9.1.13; Jurien Bay Marine Park management plan: 7.1.12; Rowley Shoals Marine Park management plan:  9.1.6
knowledge_transfer: Although the knowledge acquired through this project will be of great use to DEC’s marine monitoring program, it is anticipated that it will also be of significant relevance to the wider scientific community both nationally and internationally. Research findings will be transferred within DEC through a technical report compiled at the completion of the project, and through direct feedback and presentations to relevant in-house scientists, managers and Marine Park Coordinators. This will allow the findings to be integrated into the future directions of the WAMMP finfish monitoring program. The outcomes will be communicated to the wider scientific community through the publication of the results in a peer-reviewed marine science journal, and their presentation at relevant scientific conferences and forums, allowing the findings to be taken up by researchers and monitoring programs in other locations. Although the direct nature of the project is somewhat technical, the outcomes will allow for more appropriate comparisons between current and historical datasets, which will in turn be communicated to the public through popular articles, local media releases and public lectures.

methodology:
Study Location

Field work for the project will be conducted at three separate locations: Rowley Shoals Marine Park, Montebello/ Barrow Islands marine conservation reserves, and Jurien Bay Marine Park.  These locations were chosen as they represent three distinctly different marine ecosystems that are typical of Western Australia’s waters, and are currently or likely to be the focus of fish monitoring programs in the near future.  The exact manner in which UVC surveys are carried out can vary slightly between researchers.  As such, it is seen as advantageous to utilize the expertise of those researchers who have experience doing surveys in each location so as to maximize the strength of the comparison with historical datasets.

- Rowley Shoals

The Rowley Shoals are located approximately 300km west of Broom, northern Western Australia.  This location represents a typical oceanic tropical coral reef ecosystem.  The reef system is comprised of 3 separate reef atolls that rise from depth at the edge of the Australian continental shelf.  Historical datasets indicate that fish species diversity, habitat complexity and water visibility/clarity are high (Allen 1983; AIMS 2007).  Surveys at this location will be run in collaboration with Mr. Mike Travers from the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS).  AIMS have been historically responsible for a majority of the fish surveys at the Rowley Shoals using conventional UVC techniques, with Mr. Travers having completed these over the past 3 years.  Surveys will be conducted primarily at AIMS Long Term Monitoring Sites, on the eastern outer slope of each of the shoals.  Three sites are located on each shoal, for a total of 9 all up.

- Montebello / Barrow Islands

The Montebello and Barrow Islands represent a typical in-shore tropical coral reef ecosystem.  They are located approximately 120km west of Dampier, northern Western Australia.  The island chain consists of a complicated series of low lying rocky islands and coral reef platforms, ranging from highly exposed outer reef, to a more typical sheltered inshore reef system.  Previous research indicates that fish species diversity is high (Allen 2000), habitat complexity is variable, and water visibility/clarity is generally low (personal observations).  Surveys at this location will be run by DEC Marine Science staff (Dr. Richard Evans, Dr. Tom Holmes, Mr. George Shedrawi).  To date, fully quantitative assessments of fish communities at the Montebello Islands using UVC techniques have been rare.  Surveys will be conducted at existing GMER monitoring sites located throughout the Montebello and Barrow Island region.  Specific sites will be chosen on the trip, to allow for variable weather, current and visibility patterns.  Eighteen sites will be surveyed in total.

- Jurien Bay

Jurien Bay is located on the Western Australian coast, approximately 200km north-west of Perth.  This location represents a typical near-shore temperate reef ecosystem for Western Australian waters.  Fish diversity in the region is mid to low (Hutchins 1994), with habitat largely consisting of low relief limestone platform reef.  Surveys at this location will be run in collaboration with Dr. Neville Barrett from the University of Tasmania.  In collaboration with Dr. Graham Edgar, Dr. Barrett has been running fish surveys at Jurien Bay on a yearly basis for the past 12 years.  Surveys will be conducted at existing UTAS Long Term Monitoring Sites throughout Jurien Bay.  Out of the 42 potential sites, 18 will be surveyed with site selection depending on weather and currents while in the field.

Fish Assemblage (diversity, abundance and biomass) Comparison

- Surveys

UVC and DOV surveys will be conducted on five replicate 5 metre x 50 metre belt transects at each of the locations.  Both survey methods will be conducted simultaneously along each of the transects to avoid any variability that may arise as a result of varying sampling times.  Briefly, 3 divers will enter the water at the start of each transect.  One diver will control the DOV unit, one will conduct the UVC, and the other will lay the transect tape and control distance.  The DOV and UVC divers will assemble at the beginning of the transect, and swim along it side by side, at a speed of approximately 8mins/50metres.  The UVC diver will record all large fishes (e.g. Serranids, Lutjanids, Lethrinids, Scarids) within the 5 metre belt, whilst the DOV diver will swim directly beside with the DOV pointed directly ahead.  The UVC will additionally record the size of all Serranids, Lutjanids and Lethrinids (additional fish groups may be added at a later point) recorded along the transects.  The third diver will follow immediately behind, laying the transect tape as they go.  At the end of the 50 metres, the tape diver will tug the fins of the UVC and DOV divers, indicating that they finish the transect.  10 metres distance will be swum, before the next transect begins and the process is repeated.  At the end of the fifth transect, the DOV diver will finish the videos.  The UVC diver will turn and swim back along each of the transects counting the smaller, more site associated species (e.g. Pomacentrids).  The DOV diver and the tape diver will follow behind, winding the tapes (five 50 metre tapes) up as they go.

The depth of the sites will vary but will generally be between 5 and 12 metres.  All individual transects will however follow a specific depth contour from start to finish.  The DOV unit will be operated following the Marine Science Program Standard Operating Procedures, with the unit being swum approximately 0.8m above the substrate, on a slight downward facing angle.

- Video Imagery Analysis

Video imagery collected using the DOV methods will be analysed using the computer software programs EventMeasure© and PhotoMeasure© (www.seagis.com). Analysis will be conducted in the computer laboratory by trained technicians who are adept and experienced at both the software and fish identification.  The abundance of all fish and the size of the same fish groups measured using the UVC method that are observed on the video footage will be recorded.

- Statistical Analysis     

A combination of multivariate (e.g. MDS, CAP Analysis, PERMANOVA) and univariate (e.g. paired T-tests, repeated measures ANOVA) will be used to examine both community level and individual level relationships in the data respectively.  Differences in the size structures between the data sets will be examined using chi-squared tests  This data will explore differences between both methods and locations.  Although time restrictions at the Rowley Shoals mean that the design will be slightly unbalanced, this will be accounted for in the statistical analysis.

Time and Cost Comparison

All time and costs spent on each of the monitoring techniques at each location will be recorded and tallied.  For UVC surveys, these time and financial costs will include, but not be restricted to:

-       staff mobilisation, sampling equipment (i.e. data sheets, slates, tapes, etc.) purchase and preparation

-       staff travel, accommodation, field expenses

-       in-water surveys

-       in-field equipment preparation and maintenance

-       data collation/cleanup

-       data post-processing (i.e. entering into computer spreadsheet)

-       review of reference material for re-familiarisation with fish fauna

-       data archiving

-       post-trip maintenance/cleanup

For DOV surveys, the time and financial costs will include, but not be restricted to:

-       staff mobilisation, sampling equipment purchase (i.e. DOV bars, video cameras, digital storage, etc.) and preparation (i.e. DOV calibration, maintenance)

-       staff travel, accommodation, field expenses

-       in-water surveys

-       in-field equipment preparation and maintenance.

-       in-field digital video download

-       in-field digital video back-up

-       in-lab video post-processing

-       data archiving

-       post-trip maintenance/cleanup.

related_projects: Previously 1993-008
background: The flora of Western Australia is still inadequately known (Gibson, Coates & Thiele, 2007, Nuytsia 17: 1-12). The state is under-explored botanically, and the existing herbarium collections are insufficiently studied. New taxa that are readily recognised as such are still being discovered, for example in _Wurmbea_ where a revision and summary Flora of Australia treatment were published in the past (Macfarlane 1980, 1987) and it might have been expected that only a few additional species might be found. However in South Australia Bates () described xx new species and subspecies as a result of extensive field observations over a number of years, and in Western Australia a similar pattern has been occurring. Whilst few new taxa have turned up in the relatively well-studied south west within the forest and agricultural regions, a remarkable 20 or so new species have been discovered or separated from existing ones through a number of years of field work at appropriate seasons in the pastoral, goldfields and desert areas. Other new species are often detected in the exisiting herbarium collections as plant groups are critically studied taxonomically, some recent examples being Williams (2007) in _Puccinellia,_ Hislop (2009) in _Leucopogon_ and Rye (2009) in _Oxymyrrhine,_ or as a result of geographically-based surveys, e.g. Keighery (2008) in Lomandra, Shepherd & Lyons (2009) and Macfarlane et al. (2010) in several genera. There are many more taxa where existing variation is not properly catered for by available identification keys, so that users are unable to satisfactorily assign a significant proportion of specimens. Identification keys are not available or are outdated or inadequate for many plant groups with much reliance still placed on the now variously aged parts of Blackall & Grieve (Blackall & Grieve 1954 to Grieve 1998) so that identifying specimens from, for example, environmental surveys, is more laborious and uncertain than it should be. Conservation of the flora is held back by these difficulties because taxa need to be defined with reasonable certainty to justify the resources needed for specific protective measures, and they need to be identifiable by regional staff and they need to be formally named according to standard scientific procedures. Whilst there are new conventional keys for some groups (e.g. Wheeler 2004, Rye 2009), interactive keys for others (Sharp & Simon , Rye et al. in prep.), and plans in process for integrated identification systems in FloraBase,  there remains an ongoing need for the basic research that will provide the authoritative and accurate taxon concepts and character information to put into those keying systems and in turn to service the users.
aims: To study taxonomically genera or individual species groups or putative un-named taxa in selected plant families and investigate the question of whether the existing taxonomy is adequate or needs changes or improvements through revision of the classification and species limits, publishing new or revised descriptions of species, provision of new or up-dated identification keys, and contribute as relevant to the broader scientific dialogue.
outcome:
• Improved understanding of the taxonomy of species etc and better means of identifying specimens or recognising species in those groups.
  • Provision of information to Species and Communties Branch for improved assessment of threat status.
  • Provision of correct formal names for as many species as possible.
  • Improve herbarium collections for the selected groups.
  • Augment the Departmental information systems, directly, or indirectly through contributing to good collections curation and information from publications.
knowledge_transfer: Taxonomic botanists and herbarium collections curators; other biological researchers; conservation managers and field staff; environmental consultants; landcare workers; students; wildflower enthusiasts.

  • 30 June 2012: papers describing at least three new species of selected genera; summary paper on Wurmbea in WA.
  • 30 June 2013: papers describing at least three new species of selected genera; summary paper on Thysanotus in WA.
  • 30 June 2014: papers describing at least three new species of selected genera; summary paper on a selected genus.

methodology: Species will be researched using mainly herbarium material but augmented by field study and use of fresh plants where possible. In cases where a whole genus is being studied, DELTA databases will be used to gather, investigate and produce text and interactive key output from the data and assist with dichotomous key preparation. In selected collaborations other techniques including anatomy and DNA will be used to add additional characters and to analyse the data phylogenetically.
no_specimens: 100 per year
data_management: Personal computer; Manjimup server: Herbarium server.

aims:
This SPP will improve the comprehensiveness, accuracy and availability of taxonomic data about Tephrosia in WA for Governemnt, NGOs and Industry personnel. Specific aims include:

  • Taxonomic description of new species and infraspecific taxa, including production of distribution maps and discussion of affinities among similar or related taxa. New species descriptions to appear in Nuytsia, as well as the journals of other Australian herbaria, as appropriate.
  • Clarification of the taxonomic boundaries of already described, but problematic, taxa.
  • Assessment of the distribution and conservation status of each Tephrosia taxon in WA.
  • Production of identification tools for the discrimination of Tephrosia taxa in WA. These will take the form of written dichotomous keys as well as an interactive electronic key.
outcome:
This SPP directly addresses the central purpose and role of DEC Science Division: to provide up-to-date and scientifically sound information to uphold effective, evidence-based conservation of biodiversity and sustainable natural resource management in Western Australia. It falls within the following strategic directions of DEC’s Corporate Plan 2007–2009: a) Biodiversity conservation; b) Maintaining community involvement & support; c) Improving the way we do business.

Resolution of the taxonomy of Tephrosia in WA will result in the correct application of existing names, the description of new taxa and the production of identification tools. In turn, these will permit the accurate identification of species, and assessment their geographic distribution and their conservation status. The provision of identification tools will allow stakeholders to identify WA species and taxonomically difficult groups in Tephrosia, which will remove or reduce uncertainties in flora surveys, and streamline the assessment of development applications.
knowledge_transfer: Users include DEC, external clients, and the public community. Knowledge will be transferred through written publications, FloraBase and an electronic key to the species of Tephrosia in WA.
project_tasks:
• Literature review – relevant taxonomic and systematic literature obtained in 2011, but ongoing.
  • Host visiting specialists to the WA Herbarium – completed 2011.
  • Sort WA specimens into morphologically cohesive groups, identify putatively new taxa – many putatively new taxa identified in 2011 and put on WA Plant Census; process is ongoing with continued study.
  • Put new phrase names on WA Plant Census – as above.
  • Field work to collect types, assess taxa in the field, gather photographs and habitat notes, make spirit collections etc: Pilbara; Gascoyne/Murchison; Kimberley; NT – Pilbara and Gascoyne/Murchison field work conducted in 2011; Kimberley and NT field work planned for 2012.
  • Visit other herbaria: MEL; NSW; BRI; DNA – MEL and NSW visited in July and November 2011, respectively; BRI visited in January 2012; DNA to be visited in 2012.
  • Request loan specimens from other herbaria – specimens relevant to the taxonomic revision of Tephrosia in WA obtained from MEL, NSW and K (Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, London) in 2011/early 2012; specimens coming from BRI in early 2012; specimens requested from BM (Natural History Museum, London).
  • Add and remove names from the Census as required – ongoing.
  • Write papers describing new species and clarifying taxonomy – ongoing until 2013 as completed.
  • Construct an electronic key – data collection ongoing throughout 20111 and 2012, to be completed by early 2013.

methodology:
Specimens for study will be sourced from the WA Herbarium and other Australian herbaria holding type and historical specimens, and significant collections from across northern Australia. Type material and historical collections of Australian species will also be examined from overseas herbaria, where possible. Fresh material, photographs taken in the field and spirit collections made from fresh flowers will also be examined, where possible, to assess colour and shape characters lost through pressing. In many cases it will be possible to resolve taxonomic questions through simple morphological examination and comparison; however multivariate morphometric studies and DNA analysis may be necessary to unravel patterns in more complex species and closely allied groups. Results will be published primarily in Nuytsia, however some collaborative work with Les Pedley may be published in the journal of the Queensland Herbarium, Austrobaileya.

The interactive key will be prepared using the identification software program Lucid and will contain a number of scanned images, field photographs, photomicroscope images and drawings, to assist in species identification.
data_management: Management of specimen data is compatible with databases and information systems of DEC's WA Herbarium. Data will be stored on personal computer and external hard-drive, as well as the Herbarium server. Data necessary for species identification will be available in hard-copy and electronic publications, as well as through the interactive key. The Lucid key can be updated and re-released in the future as necessary.

background: Preliminary results from botanical consultants suggest that calcareous paleodrainages within the Yilgarn Craton support endemic and range-limited taxa some of which are new to science and of conservation interest.  These calcareous paleodrainages are poorly represented on the conservation estate.  There is an urgent need to develop a regional dataset to assess future development proposals.
aims:
• To identify the biodiversity values (flora and vegetation) of eight to nine calcareous areas in paleodrainages in the Yilgarn which are highly prospective for uranium exploration and mining.
  • To analysis and produce draft paper on the vegetation patterning across the eight to nine calcareous areas and  lodge voucher specimens at the WA Herbarium
outcome:
• location of new populations of threatened flora;
  • identification of local endemics and possibly new species;
  • reassessment of individual species conservation status;
  • identification of restricted and potentially threatened plant communities;
  • provide regional dataset and analysis to aid resource development assessments.  This should speed up the impact assessment process and reduce the amount of data required to be supplied by proponents.
  • provide herbarium specimens of all Priority and DRF species found during the survey;
  • provide geo-referenced species lists for up to 150 quadrats; and
  • provide access to baseline data and analyses.
knowledge_transfer: Office of the EPA (Environmental Protection Agency) in assessing development proposals Environmental Management Branch (DEC) Species and Communities Branch(DEC) Regional Flora Conservation staff Environmental Consultants

background:
At a meeting held on 18/12/2007 at Kings Park attended by Greg Woodman, Cathy Godden (Woodman Environmental Consulting), DEC research staff (David Coates, Kevin Thiele) and BGPA research staff (Kingsley Dixon, Siegy Krauss, Matt Barrett, Russell Barrett, Mark Wallace), the need to understand population genetic variation and structure in DRF _Acacia woodmaniorum _Maslin & Buscomb and _A. karina _Maslin & Buscomb was identified.  This understanding was deemed critical to identify potential impacts from proposed mining activities on genetic diversity within these species and subsequent impacts on population, and species, viability.  It was also considered important to understand the evolutionary relationships between these rare species and their more common close relatives and whether their rarity is associated with habitat specialisation or historical circumstances linked possibly to past climatic events. As a result Karara mining provided funding for the appropriate research.  . 

 

Acacia woodmaniorum is a recently described species (Maslin & Buscumb 2007) endemic to the Blue Hill Banded Ironstone Ranges of the Midwest region of south-west Western Australia.  The Blue Hills area occurs on the interface between the South West Botanical Province and the arid Eremaean Province.  The taxa is listed as Declared Rare Flora on DEC’s “Declared Rare and Priority Flora List” (Atkins 2006).  _Acacia woodmaniorum _is a member of _Acacia_ sect. Alatae (Benth.) Pedley thought to be most closely aligned to _A. alata_ R. Br., and in particular, to the most northerly distributed variety of that species, var. _biglandulosa _Benth. (Maslin & Buscumb 2007).  _Acacia woodmaniorum _was discovered in 1992 by Ray Cranfield, and the most significant collections of the species were made between 2004 and 2006 by staff from Woodman Environmental Consulting and DEC (Maslin & Buscumb 2007).  _Acacia woodmaniorum _is known from around 28,000 plants found in just three populations located on top of Mungada Ridge and Jasper Hill, over an area of about 40km^2^. All three populations occur in an area covered by mining exploration leases.

 

Understanding the distribution of genetic diversity and key processes that may influence that distribution are likely to be critical for assessing a range of possible management actions that will maximise the persistence of populations of _Acacia woodmaniorum _where genetic diversity may already be limited due to rarity.  The outcomes of this project are a detailed knowledge of the levels and distribution of genetic diversity and key processes such as the mating system and patterns of gene flow that may influence that distribution as well as confirmation of the putatively related taxa.  The project is innovative in using molecular genetic techniques to assess the impact of mining activities on species genetic diversity and infer the potential effects of reduced diversity on population persistence.  Results of the project will have significant regional impact at the local scale specifically for any mining and conservation activities undertaken across the species range.
aims:
Phase 1 addresses questions on levels and partitioning of population genetic variation and the evolutionary relationships and distinctness to closest relatives. 

Phase 2 addresses questions on key population processes, such as mating and dispersal that influence future levels and patterns of genetic variation. 

Phase 1:

  1. Aims to assess population genetic variation and structure using spatial analysis of genotypes obtained with microsatellite markers in A. woodmaniorum.
  2. Aims to assess phylogenetic relationships and evolutionary distinctness of _A. woodmaniorum _to putatively related taxa using analysis of DNA sequence data and microsatellite variation where cross-species amplification is achievable.

Phase 2:

  1. Aims to assess key population genetic processes such as mating systems, gene flow and pollination influencing future levels and patterns of genetic variation in A. woodmaniorum.
outcome:
The outcomes of this project will include

  1. A detailed knowledge of the level of genetic diversity present in A. woodmaniorum, the distribution of population genetic variation across the species spatial distribution and fine scale patterns of spatial structure within populations.
  2. Knowledge of the phylogenetic relationships and evolutionary distinctness of A. woodmaniorum to putatively related taxa.
  3. Knowledge of the patterns of phylogeography of A. woodmaniorum and related taxa across the landscape.
  4. Knowledge of key population genetic processes including the mating system (degree of correlated paternity, degree of outcrossing) and levels and patterns of gene flow and migration in A. woodmaniorum.

This information will be used to inform the funding body Karara Mining Ltd on the possible impacts of various mining activities on the maintenance of genetic diversity in A. woodmaniorum and on appropriate seed sampling regimes when sourcing seed for restoration purposes.  The outcomes will have direct benefits for DEC in the conservation management of the species in situ, as it occurs on the DEC conservation reserve.  Knowledge provided by the project outcomes can be used to ensure the maintenance of genetic diversity and evolutionary potential in the species and also adds to the knowledge base of the evolutionary development of native taxa throughout the Midwest.
knowledge_transfer: Anticipated users of the knowledge to be gained include KML and DEC. Technology transfer strategy includes the provision of six monthly progress reports to Karara Mining Limited with a final report at project completion. Papers will be written for peer reviewed international scientific journals including Conservation Genetic Resources and Heredity. Results will also be reported at national conferences such as the Australian Network for Plant Conservation and at international conferences such as the Society for Ecological Research International.

references:
Atkins KJ (2006) Declared rare and priority flora list for Western Australian flora. Perth, Department of Environment and Conservation.

Maslin B and C Buscomb (2007) Two new Acacia species (Leguminosae: Mimosoideae) from banded ironstone ranges in the Midwest region. Nuytsia 17: 263-272.
methodology:
Phase 1.1 Phyllodes will be collected from a total of 33 populations (573 individuals) across the species range (Figure 1).  Voucher specimens will be labeled, identified, mounted and incorporated into the WA Herbarium following the standard protocols.  The position of all sampled individuals will be recorded using a differential Global Positioning Satellite (dGPS) and mapped using Geographical Information Software (GIS, Arcmap™ 9.1).  DNA will be sent to Genetic Identification Services (GIS) USA for the construction of a microsatellite enriched library and primer pairs for microsatellite regions created.  All phyllode samples will be lypholised, DNA extracted and all individuals genotyped using fifteen microsatellite primer pairs that have been optimised for Acacia woodmaniorum.  Loci will be tested for departures from Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium (HWE) and for linkage disequilibrium (LD) between locus pairs within populations using exact tests as implemented in the program GENEPOP version 4.0.  Sequential Bonferroni corrections will be applied to correct for multiple comparisons.  Null alleles will be assessed using the same program.  Genetic diversity parameters including the number of alleles, the number of private alleles, the mean number of alleles per locus (A), the number of effective alleles (Ne), the proportion of polymorphic loci (P), expected heterozygosity (He), observed (Ho) heterozygosity and the fixation index (F) will be assessed for each population with regions and for regions overall using the program GenAlEx 6.3.  To compensate for the bias associated with samples of different size, rarefaction will be conducted on measures of allelic richness and the number of private alleles, with standardisation to 20 genes per population and one population per region.  Levels of genetic diversity will be hierarchically partitioned using the Analysis of Molecular Variance (AMOVA) method implemented in GenAlEx and conducted on FST values at the individual, population and regional level with statistical testing conducted using 999 random permutations.  To determine if sampled populations meet the equilibrium conditions for the indirect estimation of gene flow via F-statistics we will test for founder effects or ‘genetic bottlenecks’ that may be due to recent colonisation events or recent reductions in effective population sizes.  Equilibrium conditions will be simulated for all populations where greater than eight individuals were sampled using 1000 replications assuming a Two-Phased model of Mutation (TPM) with 90% stepwise mutation, as recommended for microsatellite marker, using the BOTTLENECK 1.2.0.2 program.  Significance tests for an excess of expected heterozygosity will be conducted using Wilcoxon signed-rank tests.  Genetic differentiation will be investigated among all populations and regions based on allele identity using pairwise estimates of the intra-class kinship coefficientof Weir and Cockerham  FST using the FSTAT program with 95% confidence intervals obtained via 10 000 bootstraps.  Pairwise regional genetic differentiation will also be tested based on allele identity and based on allele size using RST values and assuming stepwise mutation.  Values of population genetic differentiation were converted to the number of migrants (Nm) following Slatkins’ island model ().  Nm will be estimated independently of FST and based on private alleles with correction for sampling size following Barton and Slatkin.  For this method, estimation will use the closest regression line on the logarithm of the spatial distance between individuals conducted with the GENEPOP program.  Mantel tests will be conducted in order to investigate the effect of isolation by distance, for multi-population regions i.e. across Mungada ridge, across Jasper Hill and for all populations across the species range combined.  Regression will be conducted on matrices of pairwise values of linearised FST () and the logarithmic geographic distance.  Significance tests for correlation will be conducted using 999 random permutations under the null hypothesis that pairwise FST values and interpopulation distances were unrelated.  Analysis will be conducted using the GenAlEx program.  The genetic landscape will be analysed across the species geographic range using the computational geometry approach implemented in the Barrier vs 2.2. software.  The first five barriers to gene flow will be constructed across the network using the Monmonier’s maximum difference algorithm and a distance matrix of FST () and mapped.

Phase 1.2 Phyllodes will be collected from five individuals in each accessible population of the putatively closest relative of A. woodmaniorum and DNA extracted as above.  The trnV-ndhC, trnQ-rps16, ndhF-trnL, trns-trnG, psbA-trnH, psbD-trnT and other regions will be tested for interspecific variation.  DNA will be sequenced at three noncoding chloroplast regions that show maximal variation.  Sequences will be manually edited using the Bioedit program and contiguous alignments constructed using the CAPContig program.  Sequences will then be aligned using the ClustalW program.  Phylogenetic trees will be obtained using both parsimony and Bayesian inference methods using programs such as PAUP, DNAsp and Phylip using appropriate models once determined.  Appropriate outgroup taxa will be used to root the trees. Phylogenetic structure will also be investigated using Spatial Analysis of Molecular Variance to identify groups of populations that are highly divergent yet geographically homogeneous.  Once the overall genetic structure has been described a range of standard measures of population differentiation, haplotype diversity and pairwise nucleotide diversity will be estimated for divergent lineages within each species. 

Phase 2.1 Seed will be collected from plants bearing pods in all populations in which individuals have been exhaustively sampled and from one population within the main range.  Seed will be raised in the glasshouse and DNA extracted from phyllodes once plants are sufficiently large using the methods above.  All individuals will be genotyped at 12 microsatellite loci and mating system parameters such as outcrossing rates, biparental inbreeding ,correlation of outcrossed paternity, and correlation of outcrossing (or correlation of selfing) among plants will be estimated using the computer program MLTR version 2.4.  Pollen dispersal patterns (gene flow) will be assessed for populations where seed was collected using maximum likelihood methods paternity assignment as implemented in CERVUS 2.0 and using the exclusion method as implemented in the NEWPAT software.  Patterns of pollen dispersal within and between plants will be evaluated by determining the distance between mother and pollen source for each of the progeny if paternity is assigned with confidence.  The degree of gene flow within and among populations will be determined and the impact of population isolation and size on mating system parameters and patterns of gene flow determined using basic statistical analysis.
data_management: Data is being maintained on a personal computer and archived on an external data storage device of which the data custodian is in charge.

SP 2016-068 South West Threatened Fauna Recovery Project: Southern Jarrah Forest
background:
SW Threatened Fauna Recovery Project Background

Over the last 200 years, 50 per cent of the world’s mammal extinctions have occurred in Australia (Short and Smith 1994). In Western Australia alone, 12 mammals and two birds have become extinct and at 30 June 2015, 39 terrestrial mammals and 23 terrestrial birds native to the State were classified as being threatened with extinction. Of these, three mammals and two birds are ranked as critically endangered. In mammals, most extinctions and declines have occurred in medium size species, in the so called ‘critical weight range’ of 35g to 5500g (Burbidge and McKenzie 1989).

Predation by feral cats and foxes is a key threatening process in the decline of many, if not all, of these species. Foxes have been successfully controlled for many years in a range of locations across Western Australia using dried meat sausage baits containing 1080 poison. Over a decade of research by Parks and Wildlife scientists has led to the development of the Eradicat® feral cat bait, a moister meat bait, also containing 1080, that is more palatable to feral cats. Eradicat® was registered for operational use in Western Australia in December 2014, providing the opportunity to integrate broadscale feral cat control with existing fox baiting programs and other actions, such as translocation, that are implemented to improve the recovery of threatened native animals.

On 16 July 2015, the Minister for Environment, Hon. Albert Jacob MLA, and the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Hon. Greg Hunt MP, announced $1.7 million in funding for the Department of Parks and Wildlife to assist threatened animal recovery. The funding will be used to integrate the new Eradicat® feral cat bait with current fox baiting in four different Western Australian environments. Sites have been specifically selected to direct the funding to improving conservation of species identified in the Commonwealth’s Threatened Species Strategy and to align with fauna recovery programs already underway or planned by Parks and Wildlife in the south-west of WA.

This project fits within a broader suite of actions delivered by Parks and Wildlife to reduce the impacts of feral cats and foxes on threatened species in Western Australia. This includes Western Shield, the Integrated Fauna Recovery Project on the south coast, Rangelands Restoration at Matuwa and many other smaller scale projects.

The primary goal of the project is to contribute to the recovery of key threatened mammal and bird species found at each of these sites, through integrating feral cat baiting with existing fox baiting to reduce the impact of introduced predators, and undertaking translocations to establish new, secure populations, where necessary.

While the Eradicat® feral cat bait is a key tool in achieving effective feral cat control, other methods, such as shooting and/or trapping, may also be employed. For example, some individual cats appear to be reluctant to take baits or local climatic conditions may reduce the effectiveness of baiting alone.  Some flexibility is built into the project plan to allow this suite of control options to be employed, as necessary.

The project is funded for three years over the 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 financial years. A project agreement has been signed with the Commonwealth Government outlining funding to be provided in each financial year and key deliverables.

Dryandra Woylie/Numbat project

The woylie and numbat are iconic WA species.  Recovery with fox control resulted in the woylie being the first fauna species to be removed from the State (and subsequently Commonwealth) threatened species lists in 1996.  It was relisted in 2008 following a dramatic decline in numbers, and following continuing declines was ranked as Critically Endangered in 2014.  The numbat is ranked as Endangered and has also continued to undergo population decline at some sites, including Dryandra.

Since the mid 2000’s woylie numbers in particular have declined at Dryandra.  This is a trend for most known non-fenced wild populations in W.A. The State Government has committed to safeguarding woylies and numbats from predators in Dryandra Woodland through an election commitment in 2013. This project outline is based upon the spirit of this announcement; to preserve the numbat and woylie at Dryandra.

The Woodland is one of the most important areas for fauna conservation in the State. Woylie and numbat populations within the Woodland are genetically valuable and the localised extinction of either species would result in an irreparable loss of genetic diversity of the species. It could also potentially reduce opportunities for visitors to the Woodland to see these animals in the wild.

There is published evidence that feral cats are now the primary predator of both woylies in the Woodland (Marlow et al 2015a), with feral cats having become an emerging predator as fox numbers have been reduced (Marlow et al 2015b). Recent research also implicates feral cats in the decline of numbats (DPaW, unpublished data). There has and continues to be active research into the cause of the decline and effective techniques to control feral cats and this project draws on this knowledge in an attempt to undertake feral cat control at an operational scale. This project acknowledges that baiting alone may not be effective in mitigating feral cat numbers and predation, and consequently additional effort and tools will be incorporated in an attempt to prevent the local extinction of woylies and numbats in the Woodland.
aims:
To contribute to the long term recovery of the wild populations of woylies and numbats at Dryandra Woodland through:

  • Effective integrated control of feral cats with existing fox control;
  • Maintain and build a sustainable woylie and numbat population at Dryandra with the assistance of population augmentation;
  • Continued and improved monitoring techniques and analysis of data; and
  • Effective neighbour engagement.
outcome:
• Integration of feral cat and fox control, including developing standard protocols for delivery of both Eradicat® and Probait® to maximise effectiveness and the use of other introduced predator control techniques;
  • Monitoring feral cat and fox populations to measure success of management actions;
  • Monitoring woylies and numbats to measure success of management actions;
  • Translocations of numbats and woylies to supplement existing populations; and
  • Community awareness and engagement, including with neighbouring landholders, to ensure understanding of, and support for, management actions.
knowledge_transfer: Managers of other sites with threatened fauna that would benefit from the integrated introduced predator control.

methodology:
a) Monitoring Feral Cats and Foxes

A landscape camera trap grid design is used to monitor introduced predators and native species. This has been established at Dryandra since 2014. The design was informed by a 60 day pilot study that tested transects vs grids, and lures vs non-lures.

Sixty camera traps with a constrained randomisation are distributed across the main central block of Dryandra with a minimum distance of 750m between cameras. All cameras are offset 50 m from boundaries and tracks (Fig. 1).

Cameras are placed on 450 mm plastic peg, facing south. Vegetation within approximately 3 m in front of cameras is pruned to near ground level. No lures are used. Cameras are serviced every ~2 months with cards and batteries changed.

Approaches to analysis are still being trialled but recognise that these can only provide information on trends in introduced predator activity over time and space. Data can be presented as

  • Species sccumulation analysis
  • Detection Rates
  • Activity (i.e. heat maps)
  • Occupancy
  • Cusum control charts.

Limitations:

  • Only provided indices and/or trends (i.e. occupancy, relative abundance, activity)
  • Time to process images
  • Space to store data
  • Time lag between analysis and informing management actions (i.e. targeting feral activity hotspots)

Advantages:

  • Simultaneously collect data on native species and species assemblages
  • Effective and consistent data collection
  • Capture landscape scale data over long temporal sequences

b) Monitoring Woylies

Woylies at Dryandra will be monitored by targeted trapping events and long-term camera trap monitoring. Targeted trapping will incorporate two transects:

  • Standard Western Shield trapping of 75 cage traps set along a pre-existing transect, at 200m interval (see Figure 2)
  • York Williams transect of 50 traps set at 200m intervals.

Both transects will be undertaken in Autumn and Spring each year.

Camera traps will be used to monitor introduced predator and native fauna activity (see section a).

c) Monitoring Numbats

Post translocation monitoring

All numbats released will be fitted with radio-collars (Biotrack Pip3 Ag357 with brass collar).  These collars weigh 6-7g, less than 2% of the body weight of a small numbat.

The fate of individuals will be determined by monitoring at weekly intervals for the first month, then monthly for six months. A forensic investigation will be conducted into any death recorded, including swabbing of the collar for predator DNA and comparison of carcass and site information with a database of previous numbat deaths.  DNA swabs will be submitted to a suitable laboratory, such as Helix Molecular Solutions, for predator identification (species level) and genotyping of cat or fox DNA (individual level).

Standard annual monitoring

Driven surveys to measure sighting rates along a set transect of 362 km are carried out in the main block of Dryandra in April and November each year. This transect is driven six times during each survey and all sightings are  recorded. The data collected contribute to a sighting rate (sightings/100 km).

Proposed Site Baiting Prescription

Monthly ground fox baiting (Jan, Feb, March, July, Aug, Nov, Dec) + feral cat baiting in other months (April, May, June, Sept, Oct)

Each month of fox baiting includes 1330 Probaits® distributed at 200m intervals along tracks in the main block.

Each month of cat baiting (March-May) includes 2660 Eradicat® baits distributed at 100m intervals along tracks in the main block.

Other complementary measures including with neighbours: Targeted fox and feral cat baiting, trapping and shooting around perimeter of reserve. Trial of raised platform trapping within main block of the Woodland. Encourage trapping, shooting and baiting on neighbouring lands.
data_management:
• Woylie trap monitoring data is inputted into faunafile by WB Region,
  • Tony Friend manages numbat tracking and driven survey data
  • Camera trap data is stored in an open source MSAccess database (CPW Photo Warehouse). Outputs from camera data will be produced by Thomas/Cowan. District and Regional staff will be trained in analysis and output techniques and a training document produced.

background:
The flora of Western Australia is inadequately known and insufficiently studied. Putative new taxa are discovered through survey, herbarium studies and by observant members of the public. Many of the new taxa so discovered are appropriately dealt with and formally described in the context of revisionary studies by specialist botanists in the Western Australian Herbarium and elsewhere in Australia and the world. Others, however, particularly putative new taxa in smaller genera or in genera for which there are no active revisionary studies, are in danger of being set aside – phrase-named – for a substantial period of time.

 

 

This Plan relates to occasional taxonomic studies in such poorly-served groups, arising on an as-needs basis. A typical scenario occurred with the discovery of two putative new taxa, one in _Banksia_ and one in _Darwinia,_ by DEC volunteers Fred & Jean Hort. Morphological assessments confirmed that the species were clearly distinct, and they were formally described in single-species papers in _Nuytsia (Thiele,_ 2009, 2010). Similar work has been done in a series of papers on the genus _Hibbertia_ (Thiele 2009a,b; Thiele & Wege 2009).

 

While the work under this plan often results in single-species papers rather than revisionary studies, it nevertheless contributes significantly to our knowledge of the Western Australian flora and reduces the likelihood of a taxon remaining phrase-named, with little supporting information or identification tools, for extended periods.

 

A second common scenario involves dealing with taxa that have been listed as phrase-named or manuscript names on the Census of Western Australian Plants for a considerable period with little ongoing activity, and to either remove them from the Census, with a Short Communication in Nuytsia, or to describe them as new. An example is _Epiblema grandiflorum var. cyaneum ms_, a putative new DRF taxon that has remained on the Census for many years despite evidence that it represents a mere colour variant of the colour-variable _E. grandiflorum_, and has been the subject of Recovery Planning expenditures and management efforts. Following assessment, this taxon was removed from the Census (Thiele & Brown, 2011) and hence removed from Department funding priorities.
aims: To study taxonomically genera or individual putative un-named taxa in selected plant families as the need arises, to investigate their taxonomic status using appropriate tools, and to formally describe taxa where warranted.
outcome:
• Improved understanding of the taxonomy of plant taxa in Western Australia and better means of identifying specimens.
  • Provision of information relevant to Species and Communties Branch threat and conservation assessments.
  • Provision of correct formal names for as many species as possible.
  • Removal from the Census and from funding prioritizations of phrase-named taxa that do not warrant formal recognition.
knowledge_transfer: Taxonomic botanists and herbarium collections curators; other biological researchers; conservation managers and field staff; environmental consultants; landcare workers; students; wildflower enthusiasts.
project_tasks: Given the needs-driven approach of this Plan and its ongoing nature, specific milestones and deliverables cannot be specified. It is anticipated that the project will result in 1-4 published taxonomic papers per annum.
references:
Thiele, K.R. (2010). Darwinia hortiorum (Myrtaceae: Chamelaucieae), a new species from the Darling Range, Western Australia. Nuytsia 20: 277–281.

Wege, J.A. & Thiele, K.R. (2009). Two new species of Hibbertia (Dilleniaceae) from near Ravensthorpe in Western Australia. Nuytsia 19: 303–310.

Thiele, K.R. (2009a). Three new species of Hibbertia (Dilleniaceae) from Western Australia Australia. Nuytsia 19: 283–293

Thiele, K.R. (2009b). Banksia recurvistylis (Proteaceae), a new species from Western Australia. Nuytsia 19: 277–281.

Thiele, K. R. & Brown, A. P. (2007) Recombinations in Western Australian Orchidaceae 1. Nuytsia 16(2): 473–4
methodology: Specimens for study will be sourced from the Western Australian Herbarium collections, from other Australian and overseas herbaria as appropriate, and from field surveys as far as practicable. Appropriate methods will depend on particular taxonomic questions – some taxa may be resolved adequately using simple observations and conventional taxonomic methods, some may require multivariate morphometric and statistical analyses, others may require genetic methods to help delimit and resolve taxon boundaries. Results of these assessments will be published as peer-reviewed papers, principally in the Herbarium’s house-journal Nuytsia.
no_specimens: 100 per year
data_management: Personal computer; Herbarium server.

background:
The flora of Western Australia is inadequately known and insufficiently studied. Potential new taxa are discovered through survey, herbarium studies and by observant members of the public. 

 

 

The genera _Ptilotus_ (Amaranthaceae) and Swainsona (Fabaceae) are important and common in arid regions of Western Australia, with some taxa occurring also in more mesic areas such as the south-west. There has been a need for studies into these genera in regards to newly discovered species and a review of currently named taxa. A Flora of Australia treatment of Amaranthaceae is under preparation with Terena Lally (CANB) and Tony Bean (BRI). Some species complexes within Ptilotus need review and a number of phrased-named taxa require formal names and descriptions. New taxa in Ptilotus, such as a rare new species first collected in 2010 on the Swan Coastal Plain, are discovered from time to time.

 

 

While there are some old conventional dichotomous keys to Ptilotus, there is a need for the development of up to date electronic keys to _Ptilotus, Gomphrena_ (a related genus in Amaranthaceae) and _Swainsona._ These will assist other botanists, DEC staff, environmental consultants and members of the public with their assessments of regional development proposals, particularly in our north-west where these genera are most common.
aims:
• To study taxonomically genera or individual putative un-named taxa in selected plant families as the need arises, to investigate their taxonomic status using appropriate tools, and to formally describe taxa where warranted.
  • To publish new or revised descriptions of species and provide up to date electronic keys available for taxonomists, DEC staff, consultants and the general public to the genera Ptilotus, Gomphrena and Swainsona.
outcome:
• Improved understanding of the taxonomy of plant taxa in Western Australia and better means of identifying specimens.
  • Provision of information relevant to Species and Communities Branch threat and conservation assessments.
  • Provision of correct formal names for as many species as possible.
  • Removal from the Census and from funding prioritizations of phrase-named taxa that do not warrant formal recognition.
  • To assist in the easy identification of plants species for consultants and DEC staff.
knowledge_transfer: Taxonomic botanists and herbarium collections curators; other biological researchers; conservation managers and field staff; environmental consultants; landcare workers; students; wildflower enthusiasts.
project_tasks: Given the needs-driven approach of this Plan and its ongoing nature, specific milestones and deliverables cannot be specified. It is anticipated that the project will result in 1-4 published taxonomic papers per annum.

methodology: Specimens for study will be sourced from the Western Australian Herbarium collections, from other Australian and overseas herbaria as appropriate, and from field surveys as far as practicable. Appropriate methods will depend on particular taxonomic questions – some taxa may be resolved adequately using simple observations and conventional taxonomic methods, some may require multivariate morphometric and statistical analyses, others may require genetic methods to help delimit and resolve taxon boundaries. Results of these assessments will be published as peer-reviewed papers, principally in the Herbarium’s house-journal Nuytsia.

related_projects: SPP#1993-097 Control of jarrah leafminer: selective retention of JLM resistant trees and ground coppice in a demonstration forest plot SPP# 2006-003 Forestcheck SPP# 2004-004 Walpole Fine grain Fire Mosaic SPP# 2009-011: Monitoring Jarrah Leafminer incursion into the northern Jarrah Forest
background:
Within the history of forest and natural landscape management in Western Australia many invertebrates are known to utilize forest biomass for their survival and in doing so impart some form of damage to leaves, shoot, roots, stems or branches. There are 10 recognized invertebrate species with demonstrated significant impact on tree health, vitality and timber quality within our natural environment. These are: Attractocerus krusleri (pin hole borer); Creiis periculosa (western horned lerp), Cardiaspina jerramungae (brown basket lerp); Perga spp (saw fly); Perthida glyphopa (jarrah leaf-miner, JLM); Perthida glyphopa ssp rudis (flooded gum leaf miner); Phoracantha acanthocera (bullseye borer, formerly known as Tryphocaria acanthocera, BEB); Phoracantha impavida (tuart borer); Phoracantha semipunctata and Uraba lugens (gumleaf skeletonizer, GLS) (Abbott 1992, Abbott 1995, Abbott 1993, Abbott et al 1991, Abbott et al 1993, Clay and Majer 2001). Of the species listed above, JLM, BEB and GLS are currently the most prevalent insect pests of concern in native forests such that both JLM and GLS have documented population outbreak periods (Abbott 1993, Farr 2004, Strelein 1988) and BEB incidence appears to be responsive to drought stress and likely to increase (Farr et al 2000, Wills 2011). However, Western Australian forests and woodlands also have a history of developing unexpected insect outbreaks with dramatic consequences for the ecosystem health and vitality. For example, in 1982 a previously unknown species of Cardiaspina severely defoliated large areas of Eucalyptus occidentalis in the Lower great Southern (Farr 1992, 1999).

The decline in mean annual rainfall in the south-west Western Australia since the 1970s is well documented (Hughes 2003, McKellar 2010), and global climate models predict that the trend to a warmer and dryer environment will intensify. Thus conditions for invertebrate pests will alter significantly in the next decade as our environment shifts toward a new climatic regime. Baseline populations of known forest and woodland invertebrate pests such as those mentioned above will shift, establishing new population equilibria. Although some currently recognised invertebrate species may drop in population, many of the new baseline pest population levels may be above thresholds that the associated environment can sustain for prolonged periods and as a consequence will be recognised as outbreak populations.  It has long been recognized that water stress induces insect outbreaks, particularly in forest environments (White 1993). Research into GLS and BEB in south-west Western Australia support this (Farr et al 2004, Farr 2002, Farr 2000, Farr et al 2000). Evidence from Forestcheck monitoring since 2001 suggest other recognised potential forest pests such as helena gum moth (Opodiphthera helena) and cup moth (Doratifera spp) are also increasing in abundance (Farr et al 2009).  Furthermore accidental introductions of non-indigenous invertebrate species (both intra- and trans- continental) are a potential for new forest pest problems for both known and formerly unknown pest species, the impacts of which could be exacerbated by a changing climate once populations are established. One introduced species already falls into this category, namely Phylacteophaga froggatti (the non-indigenous leaf blister sawfly).  Other examples include species of psyllid within the genus Cardiaspina which have been introduced to WA within the last 10 years.  These particular species (C. fiscella; C. albitextura or C. densitexta, specific identity yet to be confirmed) regularly develop into serious outbreak levels in eastern Australia (Collett 2001, Morgan 1984) and therefore already have a recognised potential to seriously impact on our environment.  Also of relevance is that since the south-west of WA has one of the least known invertebrate faunas globally, some emergent species are likely to be currently unknown, or, at the very least there will be little known about their biology.

This Science Project Plan therefore targets both recognised and new forest pests in terms of research directed toward understanding their biology, population dynamics, forest and environmental impacts, the influence of departmental management regimes on such populations and potentials for the implementation of adaptive management strategies to ameliorate such events if possible. Primary pest species will be targeted, rather than secondary pest species naturally dependent on a host with declining health. This project will augment strategies being developed for Forest health Surveillance as outline in the current and new Forest Management Plan (2014-23).
aims: To understand the biology, population dynamics, impacts, and influence of management practices on existing, emerging and potential invertebrate forest pests. To investigate opportunities for implementation of adaptive management strategies to ameliorate pest outbreaks on lands managed by DEC.
outcome: Knowledge of the behaviour, extent and impact of invertebrate forest pests will provide a sound understanding of outbreak dynamics and facilitate the development of management strategies.
knowledge_transfer: Sustainable Forest Management Division, Nature Conservation Division and Forest Products Commission

methodology:
Detailed methods will vary according to the pest under study. Here a basic approach to study of a new recognised insect pest is outlined (ref: Robinson et al. 1998).

Research will be directed into five main areas:

  • Survey

Pest distribution, measurement of the area affected and/or potential area to be affected. Survey method will depend on the nature of the outbreak expression. Pests causing some form of visual damage (e.g. canopy defoliation) can be assessed using aerial and/or ground based observation, including drive-by surveys. This would be coupled with satellite imagery and GIS techniques where possible to establish reference guidelines for future remote sensing applications for the specific pest of interest.  If GIS techniques are applicable to the pest, further development of this technology can be applied to determine for example areas of forest more prone to attack (see Farr et al 2004).

  • Population level

Population size will be determined using an absolute measure for repeatable comparison over space and time. Measurements will be of the actual organism involved (i.e. egg, juvenile, adult) or an aspect of its impact on its host (e.g. shot holes/mines in leaves as for JLM; frass expulsion vents as for BEB), relative to a standard such as leaf area, leaf weight, number of tree boles, area of tree bole; forest area, ground area etc. This can be achieved through direct sampling such as branch clipping, or litter searching within a quadrat, transect or per tree and will ultimately depend on the nature of the invertebrate under study. The sample unit will also be stratified where possible to reduce variation.
Indirect measurements of populations will be achieved by methods including light, pheromone, sticky, pitfall and other appropriate trapping applications. With these methods the population will be measured in unknown units allowing for comparisons in space and time only (Southwood 1989). Such population measures are often less demanding on time and resources and are a useful quantitative monitoring tool in the longer term, however since this method does not give an absolute population measure it will be done in conjunction with a more defined population measure in the first instance. Once such a relationship has been determined population levels will be monitored using the method less demanding on resources/time.

  • Impact

Development of damage thresholds relative to pest population using criteria such as leaf area index, dry foliage weight, area of tree bole, and/or related to forest areas affected by the pest as determined from the distribution survey. Since in most cases the pest will be indigenous to WA forests, damage thresholds relative to population levels need to be considered in respect to consideration of “reasonable” population densities for the pest involved in order to maintain and effective “balanced” population.

  • Pest biology and phenology

According to the emergence of a pest species, knowledge on its biology, phenology and pathology will be variable. Considerable information may be available for already recognised pests but for some species there will be little or no biological information. Biological features such as host range, life cycle, egg production, parasites, survival and mortality, will be examined where such knowledge will benefit population management and understanding the nature of the pest in respect to its forest ecology. More focused studies on particular aspects of the pest biology e.g. thermal thresholds, micro habitat requirements etc. may need to be achieved through a more academic approach such as a dedicated PhD study. This will be taken into consideration as the need arises.

  • Adaptive management to ameliorate outbreaks and impacts

Trapping using pheromones or other means specific to the target organism (if available) can be used to monitor pest populations and determine periods when populations start to rise above levels normally supported in the forest environment.  This allows determination of factors which contribute to population increases using meta-data analysis and GIS technology.  Furthermore application of these trapping techniques can, in some cases, be used to target population hot spots in order to dampen dramatic population fluctuations. A potential example of this is the possible application of “SPLAT” technology for the control of GLS.
no_specimens: As required for new and developing invertebrate pests and their associated pathological fauna.
data_management: Numerical data will be included in “Access” data bases which will be lodged on the T share drive at Manjimup and on the Data custodian's computer. Hard copies of raw data will be lodged with the recognised data custodian at Manjimup (V. Tunsell and J. Farr), and in Kensington with A. Wills. Observational information will be lodged as above, as either Word or Excel documents.

related_projects: This SPP is designed to include localised terrestrial fauna surveys and monitoring, and complements the Western Australian Wetland Fauna Survey project (new SPP). Larger survey projects with similar methods and objectives are the biological surveys of the Carnarvon Basin, Wheatbelt (SPP1998-020), Pilbara (SPP2004-002 and 2004-004) and Kimberley islands (2007-001).
background: The Department of Environment and Conservation (with the assistance of the WA Museum) has a long-standing commitment to undertaking regional biogeographic surveys of the State. Since the 1970s, there have been major regional surveys of the Eastern Goldfields, Nullarbor, Kimberley rainforests, southern Carnarvon Basin, the Wheatbelt and the Pilbara (e.g. McKenzie et al. 1991; Burbidge et al. 2000; Keighery et al. 2004, George et al. 2011). Other major surveys cover parts of the Kimberley islands, Great Sandy Desert, Gibson Desert, Little Sandy Desert, Dampier Peninsula, Murchison, Gascoyne, southern forests and numerous existing and proposed conservation reserves (e.g. Miles and Burbidge 1975; Burbidge and McKenzie 1983; Gibson and McKenzie 2012, Keighery et al. 2007). These surveys have underpinned the selection of areas for the conservation reserve system, provided information to determine conservation status of species and filled significant gaps in biodiversity knowledge. While these large scale surveys provide analyses of biodiversity patterning for regional-scale conservation planning, sites are usually too sparse and often lack detail at finer scales. The more localised surveys undertaken will fill spatial and/or habitat gaps in the larger surveys, extend geographic coverage, assist in resolving taxonomic issues, increase ecological understanding, provide information on fine-scale biodiversity patterns and in many cases complement regional surveys.
aims:
The aims of the surveys covered by this SPP are:

  • To provide understanding of landscape scale terrestrial fauna biodiversity and concomitant patterning to inform local conservation planning and as baselines for future monitoring.
  • To provide better data on the distribution, ecological tolerances and conservation status of terrestrial species and communities.
outcome:
The immediate aims of the individual projects vary depending on the needs of the funding source, but usually contribute to improved species distributional and ecological understanding, prioritizing conservation actions by local managers and/or assessing potential environmental impacts of land use proposals.

Individual survey projects: Ability of regional conservation managers to understand local biodiversity patterning and its underlying drivers and use it to a) assess environmental impacts, b) prioritise conservation actions, c) set biodiversity targets d) establish baselines for monitoring and e) monitor change.

Projects in combination: Improved understanding of species distributions and habitat requirements at a State level. This will contribute to bioregionalisation analyses, analysis of species’ conservation status and analyses of the relationships between species and broad scale gradients and threats such as climate change.
knowledge_transfer: Primary users of the knowledge coming out of these projects are Commonwealth government agencies and/or facilitated projects (e.g. ABRS, ANHAT, TERN, ACRIS), DEC conservation managers, including those in regional offices, Species and Communities Branch, Natural Resources Management Branch and Environmental Management Branch and WA Museum. This knowledge is primarily transferred to the above users via reports (e.g. Cowan 2011, Cowan and Parkin 2012), physical data and oral presentations tailored to the needs of particular users (usually those that provided the funding).
project_tasks: There are no set timelines for this SPP as it covers one or more surveys at a time, each with their own milestones and timelines. Some years there may be no surveys run under this SPP.
