methodology:
Site selection. This is dependent on the objectives of each survey, but usually involves selecting a suite of survey sites that best represent the diversity of geological/habitat types present.

Survey techniques. Standard survey methods used in other recent biological surveys (e.g. Pilbara survey, the Kimberley island survey) will be employed. This includes any combination of pitfall, cage, Elliott, funnel and camera traps, foraging, spotlighting and opportunistic sightings.

Physical/chemical habitat descriptions. Site descriptors (e.g. Landsystem, vegetation, landform setting and substrate attributes) will be recorded for each survey site. Additionally, soil samples may be collected and analysed for their chemical properties (budget and specific project dependent).

Identifications. Identifications will be to the lowest taxonomic resolution possible. External taxonomic assistance will be sought where needed.

Data analysis. Dependant on aim of specific project and may range from basic inventory to a combination of multivariate analyses including modelling and ordination/classification methods.
no_specimens: This is likely to vary widely depending on the focus of the individual project and taxa.
data_management: Data will be managed by the relevant Project Leader within the Biogeography Program at the Woodvale Wildlife Research Centre. Depending on the nature of the project, datasets will be made available within reports and provided to public databases such as NatureMap. Specimens will be lodged at the Western Australian Museum.

background:
In June 2011 the Western Australian Government released the Kimberley Science and Conservation Strategy (KSCS) with its overarching aim to recognize and conserve one of the world’s last great wilderness areas. Funding for the KSCS was announced as part of the State budget and included $12 M over 6 years, from 2011/12, for the Kimberley Marine Research Program (KMRP). The goal of the KMRP is to undertake a program of marine research to support the management of the proposed State marine parks at Camden Sound, North Kimberley, Roebuck Bay and Eighty Mile Beach and the coastal waters outside of these proposed marine parks. The KMRP will be developed and implemented through the Western Australian Marine Science Institution (WAMSI), with DEC as lead agency responsible for the direction, coordination and administration of the research program.

A research plan for the KMRP is being developed in consultation with DEC marine resource manageres and scientists to address priority research and information needs to support the management of ecological and social values in the Kimberley region. The plan will comprise a suite of research projects focussed around two themes:

  * **_Bio-physical and social characterization_** \- to provide the foundational datasets required for marine park and marine resource management as well as better understanding and managing current human impacts; and
  * **_Understanding key ecosystem processes_** – to provide the scientific understanding of ecosystem functioning and response to a range of potential human impacts that are likely to arise in the future, including climate change.
The Marine Science Program of DEC will lead the research program, providing guidance on project development to address key State priorities and providing science administration, coordiination and integration throughout the 6 year research program. A critical role in this regard will be the transfer of knowledge gained through the research to the relevant resource managers and operational staff as well as to the community.   


* * *
aims:
• Ensure the KMRP research projects are developed in line with State prioirty needs, and will meet DEC management strategies for the newly formed and proposed Marine Protected areas in the Kimberley;
  • Ensrue the coordination and administration of the KMRP;
  • Ensure integration of research projects within the KMRP both in terms of field logistics and science findings;
  • Ensure the outputs of the reserach underktan through the KMRP reach targe taudiences;
  • Ensure that knowledge transfer and uptake occurs between scientists, resource managers and decision-makers;
outcome:
• Improved capacity to plan and manage the regional network of Kimberley marine parks and reserves;
  • Enhanced capacity to identify and manage current human impacts and predict risks in the coastal waters of the Kimberley;
  • Enhanced capacity to understand, adapt and mitigate climate change impacts in the coastal waters of the Kimberley;
  • Improved capacity to plan and manage tourism, recreational and commercial fisheries, pearling and aquaculture in the coastal waters of the Kimberley;
  • Enhanced use of Indigenous knowledge and participation in marine management;
  • Increased capacity to respond to and mitigate the impacts of oil spills;
  • Improved regional understanding, context and relative ecological and conservation significance of the key marine biodiversity assets of the Kimberley;
  • Increased capacity to assess the regional environmental significance of resource development projects ;
  • Improved capacity for marine science knowledge transfer and uptake into policy, planning and management in Western Australia;
  • Enhanced capacity to determine ‘value for money’ and assess management efficiency and effectiveness of Government-funded conservation and management programs in the coastal waters of the Kimberley;
  • Improved knowledge base for environmental planning and management by industry, NGOs and community;
  • Improved links and collaboration in marine science between State and Commonwealth agencies, universities, industry and NGOs in Western Australia ;
  • Improved community understanding and support for Government conservation and management programs in the coastal waters of the Kimberley;
  • Enhanced marine scientific capacity (including student training) in Western Australia; and
  • Improved facilities and infrastructure for marine research and management in the Kimberley.

aims:
1.  What are the objectives?

This project seeks options for facilitating climate adaptation by targeting the question "Can adaptive variation in widespread species be used to enhance resilience to climate change and maintain ecological function in landscape restoration investments?"

2.  What are the deliverables?

The project will deliver a new framework for determining the most climate-resilient genotypes within eucalypt species for use in landscape revegetation, commercial plantings and other restoration approaches. Multi-million dollar investments in restoration of Australia’s degraded and fragmented multi-use landscapes currently take little account of climate change. Until recently there has been a strong focus on maintaining local genetic patterns for optimal restoration. In a changing climate this paradigm may no longer be relevant and a new framework is urgently needed. The proposed project will deliver such a framework by undertaking pioneering research and development at the interface between molecular genetics, plant physiology and climate adaptation. Specifically, it will test hypotheses of adaptation in widespread eucalypt species, by investigating correlations between key physiological traits and genetic signatures of adaptation across climatic gradients utilising recent advances in eucalypt genomics. Addressing this question will ensure optimal, climate-resilient outcomes for Australia-wide investment in ecological restoration, offering a novel solution to ecosystem adaptation in changing environments.

3. What is the timeline?

The project will be undertaken from 1 October 2011 to 28 March 2013. Field design and sampling will be completed by December 2011, ecophysiology and genetic analyses will be completed by April 2012 and combined analysis and interpretation will be completed by July 2012.  Production of report, journal articles and communication of project results will be undertaken by December 2012.

knowledge_transfer: The project has high relevance to end-users through its capacity to enhance outcomes of multi-million dollar investments in revegetation of multi-use landscapes, by promoting use of the most climate-resilient genotypes. Further, it will facilitate selection of climate-resilient genotypes for use in commercial plantings. The project design was informed by twenty years experience working directly with end-users (farmers, state and federal agencies and non-government organizations) in agricultural landscapes thus ensuring that it has practical application in land management. The Principal Investigators have a strong track-record in end-user engagement that provides an effective path to adoption for the research outcomes and maximises the impact of the project. The Principal Investigators are also members of the scientific advisory group for the Great Western Woodlands Conservation Strategy that is the subject of a major policy commitment of the WA Government. Investigators at UTAS are involved in adaptive genetic research backing the development of resilient carbon and restoration tree plantings with Greening Australia as well as research supporting the management of native forest gene pools with the CRC for Forestry which includes State Agencies managing large native forest estates. Direct involvement with government agencies and NGO’s will enable the project team to influence policy frameworks for assisted migration as a climate change adaptation strategy. To ensure end-user engagement from the start of the project, we propose to establish a Reference Group comprising individuals from a range of organizations that are directly involved in on-ground revegetation. Consultation with the reference group will be undertaken prior to sampling to seek advice on project design including identification of species and appropriate site locations for sampling. The reference group will also be consulted in relation to the interpretation of research findings and their implications for industry practice. The group will play a role in technology transfer and dissemination of information to relevant end users, by reviewing extension materials and demonstrating adoption of recommendations into practice. We anticipate the following end user products will be produced from the project: a) project report, b) technical article, c) information Sheet, including recommendations for revegetation practice. We will disseminate these products with the assistance of the reference group through Information days, websites of NGOs and state agencies (eg. GERI, GondwanaLink, SWAEI, GWW Initiative, DEC WA, DECC NSW), and industry publications, mailing lists and communication networks

Schulze ED, Turner NC, Nicolle D, Schumacher J (2006) Leaf and wood carbon isotope ratios, specific leaf areas and wood growth of Eucalyptus species across a rainfall gradient in Australia. Tree Physiology 26, 479-492.

Sansaloni CP, Petroli CD, Carling J, Hudson CJ, Steane DA, Myburg AA, Grattapaglia D, Vaillancourt RE, Kilian A (2010) A high-density Diversity Arrays Technology (DArT) microarray for genome-wide genotyping in Eucalyptus. Plant methods 6, 16  doi:10.1186/1746-4811-6-16

Bailey JK , Schweitzer JA, Úbeda F, O’Reilly-Wapstra J, Pregitzer CC, Rehill BJ, LeRoy CJ, Potts BM, Whitham TG, Genung M, Keith A, Matt Z, Fitzpatrick B, Fischer DG (2011) From Genes to Ecosystems: Emerging Concepts Bridging Ecological and Evolutionary Dynamics. Ecological Reviews. In ‘The Ecology of Plant Secondary Metabolites: from Genes to Landscapes’. edited by Iason GR, Dicke M, and Hartley SE. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. in press.

Bell TL, Stock WD. Linder HP (2000) Ecophysiological investigations of the distribution of Poaceae and Restionaceae in the Cape Floristic Region, South Africa. In: Jacobs, S.W.L & Everett, J. (eds). Grass Systematics and Evolution. pp 267-278.
methodology:
Ecological restoration to maximise climate resilience is likely to be at odds with current genetic paradigms used to inform restoration (Pertoldi et al. 2007). Until recently, there has been a strong theoretical and practical focus on maintaining local genetic patterns of variation and associated genetic-environmental relationships. Inappropriate sourcing of seed for revegetation can lead to a range of negative outcomes, including founder effects, genetic swamping of local populations, and outbreeding depression (Hufford and Mazer 2003). Yet in a changing climate, maintenance of ecological function will be imperative and a static view of genetic-environmental relationships may no longer be relevant. Strategies to maximise resilience (Hoegh-Gulberg et al. 2008) should instead utilise the adaptive variation present in key species to facilitate persistence of plantings and maintain ecosystem and landscape function.

Identifying adaptive variation requires targeted analysis of eco-physiological traits and signatures of adaptation reflecting differential regulation of genes during stress (water availability or temperature). Studies of eco-physiological trait variability along climatic gradients in Australia are beginning to provide insights into the adaptability of native taxa, especially Eucalyptus species (e.g. Schulze et al. 2006). Correlation of variation in eco-physiological traits with variation in gene frequency will provide a molecular basis for predicting the adaptive response of species to differing climatic environments and provide tools for identification of appropriate adaptation management responses in multi-use landscapes where maintenance of ecosystem function is critical.

The project will test the following alternative hypotheses:

1. Widespread species, having evolved under highly variable environments, retain high potential for adaptability to environmental change within the gene pool of local populations or individuals (implying that genetic material sourced from local populations will have tolerance to changing climatic conditions).

2. Widespread species, having evolved across wide ecological gradients, comprise a suite of locally adapted sub-populations each (implying that genetic material should be sourced not from local populations but from distant and potentially resilient populations which are pre-adapted to the future climate).

The project will be implemented along the following lines, focusing on widespread eucalypt species spanning climatic gradients across the Western Australian wheatbelt and Great Western Woodlands, and the box woodlands of the eastern Australian wheatbelt.

1. Identify target eucalypt species and physiological traits relevant to climate change (e.g. specific leaf area, instantaneous water use efficiency, season length water use efficiency, photosynthetic capacity, stomatal conductance).

2. Characterize variation in selected physiological traits within and between populations across climatic gradients.

3. Analyse patterns of adaptive genetic variation within and between populations across the same environmental gradients. This will be achieved via a genome scan using DArT markers developed at University of Tasmania.

4. Combined analysis of ecophysiological and genetic data to evaluate potential effectiveness of the genome scan approach for detecting adaptive variation across environmental gradients.

5. Integrate findings into decision tools for evaluation of assisted migration and sourcing genetic material for ecological restoration and revegetation under the effects of climate change.

The following methodology will be used in the project:

Species selection – The project will study eucalypt species of the intensive agricultural zones of southern Australia, including one species from the east and one from the west. Eucalyptus is the choice of genus for this work because (1) it is the most important genus used in revegetation and forestry across southern Australia and (2) it is the only native genus in Australia for which DArT markers have been developed (other species where DArT markers are available are those used in agricultural enterprises). DArT markers offer an exciting new opportunity to undertake the genome scans required for this study, and analysis is available through Diversity Array Technologies (Canberra).

Criteria for species selection within Eucalyptus are that they are widely used in revegetation in the relevant regions, and that they are widespread across rainfall gradients. We propose to use E. melliodora or E. blakelyi in the east, as they are widespread species capturing a rainfall gradient of >800 mm (Fig. 1) and used for revegetation across the eastern-Australian wheat-sheep zone. In Western Australia we propose to use E. salubris or the E. loxophleba complex. Both of these are prominent in revegetation in the WA wheatbelt and cover the widest rainfall gradient available. Final confirmation of species selections will be made in consultation with the reference Group (see (ii) below).

Sampling – Sampling aims to characterize physiological and adaptive genetic variation within and between populations of each species. Climatic details (rainfall, temperature, aridity index) for selected species will be sourced from Bureau of Meteorology SILO data and Atlas of Living Australia (ALA), and visualised using ALA and GIS technology. Nine populations will be selected across the gradient to maximise the climatic range, using a combined grouped endpoint / dispersed sampling strategy.

Data generation – Genetic data will be generated by undertaking DNA extraction and DArT marker assays for 30 sampled trees from each population. Ecophysiological data will be generated from leaf and wood samples from 10 trees in each population. Leaf analyses will include plant height, leaf area, specific leaf area, total nitrogen and phosphorus, and carbon (δ13C) and nitrogen isotope (δ15N) ratios - measures reflecting responses to water deficits or arid conditions integrated across periods of approximately one year. Wood density will be measured as an integrated measure of water stress over longer periods. Soil nutrient analysis will also be undertaken at each site to account for interactions with site management history.

Data analysis – The ecophysiological data will be analysed to determine patterns of variation across the climate gradient. The genotypic data will be analysed to detect differential signatures of adaptation, and variation in the markers will be correlated with environmental and ecophysiological variation. Data analysis techniques will include multiple regression to determine univariate relationships between measured variables and climate data (using Genstat) and ordination (non-metric multidimensional scaling and principal components analysis, using PC-Ord) to simultaneously assess relationships among populations and all measured traits.

related_projects: This SPP is designed to include small flora survey projects such as the Bush Blitz surveys of Cane River and Credo Stations. Larger survey projects with similar methods and objectives are the biological surveys of the BIF and Greenstone ranges (SPP 2007-005) and the Ravensthorpe Range survey (SPP 2007-.006).
background: There have been a number of regional and subregional scale flora surveys in Western Australia, While the larger scale surveys provide analyses of biodiversity patterning for regional-scale conservation planning, sites are usually too sparse for more local scale planning. However, the larger surveys can be used to identify subregions of high biodiversity (such as Biodiversity Recovery Catchments in the Wheatbelt), which then require more detailed survey for local conservation planning. Subregional surveys have higher sampling densities are provide an assessment of conservation significance and the context for future development proposals such as the studies on the Swan Coastal Plain (Gibson et al. 1994), the BIF ranges (Gibson et al. 2012). Recently the Biogeography Program has been asked to undertake a number of smaller scale surveys for particular purposes such as Naturebank (preliminary surveys of areas of interest in Cape Le Grand National Park, Fitzgerald River National Park) and Bush Blitz surveys of Cane River and Credo Station funded by DSEWPaC. Presently these short duration surveys do not fall within any current SPP, the proposed SPP would capture these projects into our reporting framework.
aims:
The aims of the surveys covered by this SPP are:

  • To provide understanding of small scale floristic biodiversity patterning to inform local conservation planning and as baselines for future monitoring.
  • To provide better data on the distribution and conservation status of flora species and vegetation communities.
outcome: Knowledge of the distribution of species and composition of communities has a myriad of benefits to DEC’s core conservation work. Data collected to date has been used as baselines for monitoring management actions, prioritization of conservation actions based on survey results, identification of threatened ecological communities and assessment of species conservation status. Some of this data could also be used for environmental impact assessment. Voucher collections and site based species records will help build the State’s database of the distribution of the flora into the future.
knowledge_transfer: Primary users of the knowledge coming out of these projects are DEC conservation managers, including those in regional offices, Species and Communities Branch, Natural Resources Management Branch and Environmental Management Branch.
project_tasks:
There are no set timelines for this SPP as it covers one or more surveys at a time, each with their own milestones and timelines. Some years there may be no surveys run under this SPP. All previous surveys have been completed on time.

For a current projects (Cane River & Credo Bush  Blitz flora surveys 2011-12)

  • First quarter 2011 – liaison with funding bodies (DSEWPaC) and Regions.
  • Second quarter 2011 – Cane River fieldwork
  • Third quarter 2011 – Credo fieldwork
  • Fourth quarter 2011 – identification work
  • First quarter 2012 – identification work
  • Second quarter 2012 –final reports due

Primary output will be a report to the DSEWPaC and 650 voucher collections lodged in the Herbarium.

methodology:
Site selection. This is dependent on the objectives of each survey, but usually involves selecting a series of sites that best represent the diversity of floristic variation, geographical and topographical spread and with replication (where possible) within these types.

Floristic sampling. If budgets and aims of the study allow there is a strong preference to use plots to sample the flora of an area, this has the added advantage of contribution to the statewide network of floristic plots.

Physical site descriptions. At each site a variety of physical properties are recorded consistent with the methodologies of McDonald et al. (1990). The precise parameters measured will depend on the purpose of the survey.

Identifications. Flora will be identified to species level using WACSC Herbarium and confirmed by experts where necessary.  A set of voucher collections will be lodged to maintain data currency through time.

Data analysis. Generally a combination of multivariate analyses including modelling and ordination/classification methods using data from the project in question and comparable pre-existing datasets. Species distributions and conservation assessments are made by comparison with previous records and ecological knowledge.
no_specimens: All collections of specimens of rare and priority species are incorporated into herbarium collection. All other species will have two representative collections lodges from each survey as is the standard Biogeography Program protocol for regional and subregional surveys.
data_management: All data is stored in the Access databases entered using standard datacode. As resources become available these datasets will be uploaded onto NatureMap to facilitate public access.

related_projects: SPP 2010-004 has been revised and renewed. It is replaced by SPP 2012-011.
background:
The contribution of canker fungi to stem and branch death in South Western Australia has largely been ignored (Davison & Tay 1983, Shearer 1992). Past records have shown that two days with temperatures over 40ºC and high winds was associated with rapid extension of _Botryosphaeria _sp. lesions in _Banksia speciosa _leading to the death of affected trees near Hopetoun (Shearer 1994). Since 1994 there has been a steady increase in canker reports and samples received for identification particularly in the declared rare flora _Banksia verticillata_, _B.brownii _as well as non threatened taxa such as _B. baxteri, B. coccinea_, and _B. sessilis_. South Coast Regional staff have expressed concern that many of the natural populations of _B. anatona, B. verticillata_ and _Lambertia orbifolia_ spp. _orbifolia_ (including a translocated population) DRF appear to be succumbing to canker by degrees. Families outside the Proteaceae are also impacted, eg. _Acacia accuminatus _and _Calothamnus quadrifidus _are also recorded as having high rates of branch and stem cankers (Pathogen of the month 2007, DEC records).

 

Observation and increase in sample numbers suggests that the incidence and severity of these events is increasing which indicates a shift in the host/pathogen/environment disease triangle has occurred. As the hosts are endemic and the pathogens also appear endemic this leaves environmental change as the likely reason for the change in impact. Quantification of canker incidence and severity requires semi permanent transects to be established and monitored across the region and compared simultaneously with climatic data.

 

Direct therapy for the affected hosts is one management option available within a holistic disease management strategy. As Denman (2004) has been able to show reduced canker activity with application of several fungicides in _Protea magnifica _in the field it is quite likely that these fungicides will be capable of reducing impact of cankers in affected species particularly _B. verticillata_ and_ L. orbifolia _in the South Coast of Western Australia.
aims: To advance understanding of canker disease biology and epidemiology in the native plant communities within the National Parks of the South Coast Region of Western Australia in relation to predicted climate change. To develop direct therapy methods of mitigating impact of canker pathogens in high value natural and translocated DRF populations including TEC’s.
outcome: Predictive capacity of canker impact in Proteaceae with temperature increases. Increased management options by development of prescriptions for fungicidal treatments to reduce cankers in affected DRF (including translocated populations), TEC’S and native plant communities of significant biodiversity value in South Western Australia. Improved knowledge of a threatening process impacting high value plant communities.
knowledge_transfer: It is expected that the prescriptions will be taken up by Nature Conservation and Threatened Flora officers in the South Coast Region some of whom will be involved with implementing the trial. This will be of value to land managers including local governments, natural resource management groups, private landholders and community conservation groups.
project_tasks:
• Establishment and scoring (4 times) of canker impact for semi permanent transects in 4 species of Proteaceae across rainfall and geographic gradients on the south coast of Western Australia. January 2013.
  • Conduct and analyze efficacy study of a range of fungicides in vitro on mycelial inhibition of 3 canker fungi. December 2012.
  • Testing efficacy and phytotoxicity of top 4 fungicides selected from the in vitro trial in the glasshouse in vivo for 4 Proteaceous species. September – November  2012.
  • NRM  Final report due May 2013.
  • Testing efficacy and phytotoxicity of fungicides on B. baxteri and B. verticillata in the shadehouse and write up as research paper for submission to Australasian Plant Pathology. December 2013.
  • Description of novel canker fungus for submission to Persoonia. March 2013.
references:
Bathgate J (1999) Phd thesis  Infection of Banksia coccinea by the canker pathogen Cryptodiaporthe melanocraspeda and the epidemology of the disease it causes. University of Western Australia.

Davison EM & Tay FCS (1983) Twig, branch and upper trunk cankers of Eucalyptus marginata. Plant Disease 67:1285-1287.

Pathogen of the month, December 2007.  http://www.australasianplantpathologysociety.org.au/Regions/dec07%20POTM.pdf.

Shearer BL (1994) The major plant pathogens occurring in native plant ecosystems of South Western          Australia. Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia 77, 113-122. Australasian Plant            Pathology (2007).
methodology:
Transect establishment – Twenty transects (30 trees per transect) recording canker impact in each of Banksia baxteri and B. coccinea communities also 5 in geographically restricted DRF B. verticillata and Lambertia orbifolia. Temperature and humidity data loggers to be installed at representative sites and relevant rainfall interpolations acquired. A multiple regression analysis will be applied to the data.

In vitro test – The systemic fungicides tebuconazole, prochloraz, fenarimol, iprodione,cyprodinil and thiophanate methyl will be added to agar in petri dishes at the concentrations of 0, 0.01, 0.1, 1.0 and 10 mg a.i./mL. Each fungicide will be tested by measuring lateral growth against 2 isolates each of the canker causing fungi Botryosphaeria, Zythiostroma and Cryptodiaporthe sp. with 4 reps each. The entire experiment will be conducted twice. EC50 (half maximal effect concentration) for each fungicide will be calculated and compared by analysis of variance.

Glasshouse trial – The top4 performing fungicides from the in vitro trial will be become treatments on Banksia attenuatta, B. baxteri, B. coccinea and B. verticillata seedlings  in the glasshouse with 2 concentrations and 4 reps each. Efficacy will be tested by % inhibition on challenge wound inoculations of 2 isolates each of the test fungi and any deleterious effects of application recorded on a % leaf area basis.

Field trial – The best performing fungicides will be applied alternately (to lessen chances of developing resistance) to B. coccinea and DRF translocation species with identified canker issues in each of 2 field sites at the best performing concentration in the glasshouse trial. There will be. Efficacy will be rated by measuring canker incidence and severity on a per tree basis (following Bathgate 1999) at 6 monthly intervals and compared to a control treatment.
no_specimens: 4 plant to Herbarium and 8 fungi to Department of Agriculture Plant Pathogen Collection.
data_management: The data will be backed up on computer, external hard drive and on DEC's intranet. The data set will be maintained on a regular basis. Hardcopies of the completed data set will be filed by the data custodian.

background: See Maslin and van Leeuwen (2006).
aims: To elucidate the patterns of variation in the Mulga group (i.e. Acacia aneura and its closest relatives) and to provide a reliable means of identifying the taxa.
outcome:
• Taxonomic revision of Acacia aneura and closely related species in Western Australia.
  • Production of a user-friendly, electronic identification key enabling Mulga taxa to be easily and reliably named. 
  • Production of a user-friendly “Mulga Manual” that will comprehensively describe, discuss and illustrate the different Mulga taxa.
  • Determination of the genetic factors responsible of causing and maintaining diversity within the Mulga group.
  • Provision of direction for future biological and ecological studies of Mulga so that the species and its congeners may be effectively managed, conserved and sustainably utilized.
  • Assessment of the conservation status of Mulga taxa in Western Australia.
  • A basis for understanding Mulga across its entire geographic range within Australia.
  • Promotion of the project and its sponsors in CALM’s Landscope journal and on the web through the WorldWideWattle website.
knowledge_transfer:
Beneficiaries will include those requiring reliable names for Mulga taxa, particularly, research and applied scientists, environmental consultants, land managers and community groups involved in rangeland management, sustainable utilisation and conservation. Consequently, the knowledge gained will enable Mulga species and communities to be better-protected from environmental perturbations, to be more effectively managed and sustainably utilized, will facilitate the identification of high priority areas for conservation together with other land uses and will lead to significant capacity-building within rangeland user communities that will result in numerous benefits such as:

  • Increased capacity for land managers to implement programs to mitigate threats and/or reduce pressures on Mulga and the environment. 
  • Better enable land managers and regulators to develop, assess and approve land use plans while ensuring appropriate biodiversity conservation outcomes.
  • An increased capacity throughout the pastoral estate to sustainably utilize Mulga.
  • Greater certainty for land rehabilitation practitioners to implement rehabilitation programs and attain completion criteria because the ecological requirements of different Mulga types can be quantified and addressed through the design of site rehabilitation programs aimed at creating self perpetuating Mulga ecosystem.
  • Better insights into the biological basis for differences in the traditional uses of different Mulga types and potentially the resolution of uncertainty in respect to the ethnobotanical use/potential of these types.
project_tasks:
1. Undertake sort of Herbarium material of Mulga preparatory to commencing field program. Performance indicators: Herbarium material sorted & field sampling sites identified.
  2. Undertake field work to locate and sample ‘pure’ and ‘mixed’ populations of Mulga; sample for taxonomic, genetic and ontogenetic studies. Performance indicators: Populations sampled for flowers, fruits and material for genetic and other analyses; specimens processed and incorporated into W.A. Herbarium; material distributed to collaborators for genetic analysis and anatomical study.
  3. Morphological analyses of collections. Performance indicators: Morphological characters based on previously-existing and newly-acquired material scrutinized, and data recorded.
  4. Undertake genetic studies by developing/acquiring microsatellite libraries, extracting DNA from newly-acquired material, and undertaking microsatellite and cDNA analyses. Performance indicators: Microsatellite library completed, DNA extracted and genetic fingerprinting undertaken.
  5. Undertake ontogenetic study based on seedlings. Performance indicators: Seedling trials established; seedlings destructively sampled and measured.
  6. Undertake anatomical study of Mulga pod structure. Pods sampled and send to Rutishauser for examination; prepare publication based on results. Performance indicators: Material examined anatomically; paper published.
  7. Refer taxa to CALM’s Declared Rare Flora and Priority Flora Lists where appropriate. Performance indicator: taxa referred to list if necessary.
  8. Prepare taxonomic revision, and a simplified version of same, of Mulga group. Performance indicators: Papers published, including description of any new taxa.
  9. Construct interactive identification key for identification of W.A. Mulga taxa. Performance indicator: key constructed and made available to public for use.
  10. Promote the project through the construction of pages on Worldwidewattle web site and publishing article in Landscope. Performance indicators: Worldwidewattle content describing project and acknowledging sponsors established and maintained; Landscope article prepared.

methodology:
Morphological analysis of Mulga variation will be undertaken using conventional taxonomic methodology.

Genetic and phylogenetic analyses will involve microsatellite and cDNA analyses.
no_specimens: 1500 specimens
data_management: Information generated from this project is contained in specimens lodged at the WA Herbarium, in DEC database systems, the Lucid identification key (DEC managed),

background:
Human-mediated landscape disturbance can affect the amount of genetic diversity present in populations of threatened species and its distribution across the landscape. One challenge facing conservation managers is understanding how management tools can be used to protect and facilitate genetic and demographic patterns and processes. For example, reserve design principles (comprehensiveness, adequacy, representativeness (CAR); single large or several small (SLOSS)) can be applied to conserve genetic diversity, as well as species diversity (Moritz & Faith 1998; Vandergast _et al._ 2008, Thomassen _et al._ 2011). New approaches in phylogeography and landscape genetics are being used to investigate patterns of contemporary and historical infraspecific diversity in a spatially-explicit context (Vandergast _et al._ 2008, Dudaneic _et al._ 2013). In combination with predictive modeling these datasets can be used in conservation planning for achieving CAR in reserve design, as well as inferring refugia under future climate change.   
  
Our initial work will focus on genetic diversity of quenda (or southern brown bandicoot, _Isoodon obesulus_ _fusciventer_) in fragmented coastal populations compared to populations in intact forest that have greater representation within the reserve system. Quenda are one of the last critical weight range mammals to persist in the Perth metropolitan area, but are increasingly becoming restricted to small, isolated patches of remnant vegetation. We will survey the genetic diversity and genetic structure of quenda populations across the Swan plain and the Darling Range to evaluate the role of reserves in conserving population genetic diversity and maintaining genetic processes such as gene flow.  
  
A second project will employ a comparative phylogeographic approach to investigate the genetic diversity and genetic structure of a range of species in the Pilbara, a region of high endemism and landform diversity under significant conservation pressure. Information on the distribution of genetic diversity within target mammal species will be overlain on climate and environmental GIS datasets generated by DEC to identify environmental conditions and landscape features correlated with high genetic diversity. Analysis of historical population structure will also be used to identify areas in the landscape that have acted as refugia under past climate change. We will then assess how well these features are protected within the current reserve system as well as under future climate change.
aims:
Specifically, to understand the landscape genetics of quenda in the Perth region we will:
•    investigate how much genetic diversity is present in quenda in reserve populations compared to fragmented populations
•    investigate whether gene flow amongst populations is greater in continuous populations compared to fragmented populations
•    identify natural and imposed breaks in continuity between populations in fragmented landscapes and continuous forest and whether there is evidence of animals being able to use corridors for movement in fragmented landscapes
•    use GIS to identify areas of high quality habitat and correlate habitat features with genetic diversity patterns (in conjunction with Swan District office). Taken together these results should highlight important populations and habitat for conservation.
•    understand genetic relationships within and amongst coastal and forest regions to better manage quenda relocations

To investigate the phylogeography of Pilbara mammal species we will:
•    use phylogenetic approaches to investigate the infraspecific genetic diversity and genetic structure of target mammal species in the Pilbara region
•    map clades identified within each species to the landscape to determine whether a phylogeographic signal is evident
•    use niche-based species distribution modelling to identify environmental factors important for species persistence and correlate these with genetic diversity and gene flow parameters in each species to identify putative refugia
•    use GIS to determine whether patterns of infraspecific diversity and genetic structure are conserved within the current reserve system, and whether putative refugia under future climate change will be adequately conserved
outcome: It is increasingly recognized that conserving species genetic diversity is integral to facilitating species persistence under multiple threats, including predicted climate change. Genetic information when combined with landscape and environmental data provides a powerful tool for conservation planning, including reserve design and prioritisation. These projects will provide insight into the distribution of genetic diversity across a range of species and how the reserve system acts to protect the patterns and processes that generate this diversity.
knowledge_transfer: Information from this project will primarily inform management actions for DPaW Fauna Conservation and Nature Conservation groups for current and future management of I. obesulus in the Perth region, and more broadly will inform development applications particularly in the metropolitan area. Knowledge of the distribution of genetic diversity of key mammal species in- and off-reserve in the Pilbara will be useful information in the context of considering mining development applications. Both projects incorporate a species distribution modeling approach which will be used to predict future distributions of species with climate change.

methodology:
A. Landscape genetics of I. obesulus (quenda)
We will examine genetic diversity and gene flow amongst populations (up to 30 individuals/pop) of quenda across the Swan coastal plain and adjacent Darling Range using 12 published I. obesulus microsatellite markers (Zenger & Johnston, 2001; Li et al., 2012). We will compare levels of genetic diversity within populations (number of alleles, heterozygosity, allele frequencies; calculated in the program GenAlEx (Peakall & Smouse, 2012) and estimate rates of gene flow between populations using F-statistics (calculated in Genepop, Raymond & Rousset, 1995), and compare these metrics for fragmented vs. continuous populations. We will use the software Structure (Pritchard et al., 2000) to infer the ‘true’ population genetic structure of quenda populations across the Perth region to identify natural or imposed breaks in population continuity. In collaboration with Swan District Office staff, we will attempt to correlate genetic patterns with climate and habitat models using landscape genetic approaches (e.g. using regression analysis between landscape and genetic variables, Dudaneic et al. 2013). These analyses will allow us to identify centres of high genetic diversity and connectivity and to assess how well these areas are represented in the reserve system.  

B. Comparative phylogeography of Pilbara mammal species       
We will examine the population genetic and phylogeographic structure of several mammal species across the Pilbara, including a rocky habitat specialist (e.g. Pseudomys chapmani), a sandy habitat specialist (e.g. P. hermannsbergensis) and a habitat generalist (e.g. Ningaui timealeyi) using mitochondrial and nuclear genetic markers. We will reconstruct single- and multiple-gene phylogenies using Bayesian inference (implemented in the program MrBayes (Ronquist & Huelsenbeck, 2003)) to identify clades within each species that may be correlated with landscape structure. Niche-based species distribution models will be developed using Maxent software (Elith et al., 2011) with distribution records obtained from DPaW and Atlas of Living Australia databases. Important habitat and climate variables identified during species modeling will be correlated with genetic diversity information to identify areas in the landscape that may have acted as refugia in the past and we will investigate how refugia will be distributed under future climates. Maps of the current distribution of nature reserves in the Pilbara will be overlain onto composite genetic and species distribution maps to investigate how well the reserve system captures current species genetic diversity and future refugial areas, and how congruent this is between species.
no_specimens: This project is unlikely to generate novel specimens for vouchering.
data_management: Genetic data generated through this project will be stored on the departmental T: drive and/or submitted to public databases, typically as a requirement for publication in scientific journals. Sequence data will be submitted to Genbank (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/) and microsatellite data is typically submitted to Dryad (http://datadryad.org/).

related_projects: Pilbara Biological Survey (SPP2004/002). Wetland Biological Surveys (SPP2011/18), Forest Stream Biodiversity Monitoring (SPP2006/002), State Salinity Strategy Wetland Monitoring (SPP1998/008).
background:
Aquatic oligochaetes are important components of aquatic systems, playing a similar role in sediment processes tyhat earthworms do in soils (aeration, turnover, carbon dynamics, structuring microbial communities etc). Early work by Brinkhurst (1971, 1979, 1980, 1982, 1984) suggested that Australia has considerable diversity and a greater level of endemism amongst the group than any other continent, yet the Australian fauna remained very poorly known.

Between 1992 and 1994 the Australian Biological Resources Study funded Dr Brinkhurst (USA) and Dr Richard Marchant (Museum Victoria) to employ the principal investigator of this SPP (Adrian Pinder) to undertake research on the systematics of this group, resulting in several publications (Pinder and Brinkhurst 1994; 1997abc, 2000; Pinder et al. 1998, Pinder and Erseus 2000).

This current project is a continuation of this work, with a strong emphasis on describing the diversity, biogeography and endemism of the Western Australian aquatic oligochaete fauna, which had been underrepresented in studies undertaken to date.
aims:
1) To publish taxonomic descriptions of new taxa of Western Australian aquatic Oligochaeta (earthworms) and investigate the phlogenetic relationships within an Australian and global context.

2) To study the zoogeography, endemicity and conservation status of aquatic oligochaetes in Western Australia.

3) Establish a zoogeographic database for Australian aquatic oligochaetes and create a Delta database of taxonomic information suitable for the production of interactive keys and phylogenetic studies.

4) To investigate the environmental factors controlling the occurrence of the worms, where adequate environmental data are available (e.g. the Salinity Action Plan project).
outcome:
Provision of more comprehensive aquatic invertebrate datasets for descriptions of aquatic invertebrate communities, analyses of invertebrate/environment relationships and studies on the condition of aquatic environments.
Addition to knowledge of a poorly known group of aquatic animals, made available through published systematics papers, traditional and interactive identification products and the distributional and taxonomic databases.
These outcomes will benefit other CALM projects such as the Monitoring of River Health Project, the Salinity Action Plan and surveys of biogeographic regions.
knowledge_transfer: Staff working on other aquatic community projects within CALM in the first instance, then other aquatic scientists elsewhere in the state and country that need to routinely identify aquatic invertebrates in ecological collections, then oligochaete taxonomists overseas.

methodology:
A survey of the aquatic oligochaetes of the south coast of WA, funded by the Australian Biological Resources Study, was undertaken in 1996. This involved collections from a wide variety of flowing and standing waters between Esperance and Augusta. This area was selected to investigate the eastern limit to occurrence of the Phreodrilidae in the state, to determine the extent of undescribed diversity in the south-west in general and to collect more specimens of some new but undescribed species found by Dr. Pierre Horwitz in the far south-west peat wetlands.

Other collections have arisen from samples taken during the Salinity Action Plan (SAP), Monitoring of River Health Initiative (MRHI) and the Carnarvon Basin Survey projects.

Laboratory methods are as outlined in Pinder and Brinkhurst (1994, CRC for Freshwater Ecology publication).

Zoogeographic data will be entered onto an Access database to be designed by myself.

Morphological and systematic data will be entered onto a Delta database system.

Statistical analysis:

Not applicable
no_specimens: All type material will be lodged with the Museum of Western Australia. Voucher specimens (which will probably number in the hundreds) will be kept with the appropriate project voucher collections (e.g. Salinity Action Plan voucher collection).
data_management: All data kept on one of two MS Access databases. Data for identifications from other CALM projects kept on the Aquatic Projects Database. Data for other ad-hoc collections of externally collected specimens kept on a separate database. Both of these are backed up regularly.

background:
The increases in ocean sprawl, urbanisation and associated modifications of coastal and estuary areas, are driving habitat and biodiversity declines within these ecosystems (Vozzo et al. 2020; Vozzo et al. 2021). Additionally, these changes often lead to the installation of single-purpose coastal infrastructures such as seawalls and breakwaters to reduce shoreline erosion, however, this can result in the removal of complex intertidal zone structures (Bugnot et al. 2020; Nunn et al. 2021; Vozzo et al. 2020; Vozzo et al. 2021). Eco-engineering technologies can be an alternative resource to assist in protecting shorelines, whilst promoting biodiversity and alleviating declines in habitats (Mitsch 2012; Waltham & Sheaves 2018; Bugnot et al. 2020; Vozzo et al. 2020; Vozzo et al. 2021).

Eco-engineered habitats vary in scale and design based on their purpose, the system they are implemented in and the available budget. For example, simplistic changes to structural materials can occur, by substituting concrete and cement with materials that have a lot environmental footprint and improve the casting of habitat structures, such as Reefcrete, a recycled ground granulated blast-furnace slag (Dennis et al. 2018). These alternative materials have been found to support significantly more canopy-forming algae, which may facilitate other taxa (Dennis et al. 2018). By increasing the settlement of micro-organisms, such as algae, more complex organisms can be established, re-establishing predator species that could have been removed from the system when single-purpose structures were implemented (Herbert et al. 2018; Toledo et al. 2020).  

New ecoengineering designs are continuously emerging, with companies specialising in the production of a wide range of pre-fabricated reef units that incorporate the use of environmentally conscious materials. Living Seawalls (LSW) is a flagship program of the Sydney Institute of Marine Science (SIMS) in collaboration with Reef Design Lab (RDL), that design and produce topographically complex habitat panels that can be retrofitted to existing coastal infrastructures. These habitat panel designs focus on the promotion of foundation species, such as algae, coral, barnacles and oysters, to create superficial structures and further develop the complexity of the panels to promote more mobile species to colonise (Dennis et al. 2018). As a result, they have been proven to restore lost intertidal habitats and improve species diversity along simplistic surfaces of seawalls, bridge footings and other coastal and estuarine infrastructures that typically lack species complexity (Strain et al. 2017; Strain et al. 2018; Strain et al. 2020; Vozzo et al. 2020; Vozzo et al. 2021,). In addition, the re-establishment of foundation species has been found to provide key ecosystem services including improved water quality, fisheries productivity and shoreline protection (Beheshti et al. 2021). As a result, habitat panels and other reef designs that promote foundation species growth are at the forefront of coastal and estuarine initiatives.

The Swan-Canning Estuary (SCE) in Western Australia is a microtidal system situated in the Perth Metropolitan area. As with most urban estuarine systems, the SCE has been subject to ocean sprawl and has undergone heavy modification and development along its shorelines. Additionally, increases in local population and improve accessibility to the SCE have increased boat traffic and recreational activities through the system. Towards the lower end of the estuary, river walls and rock revetments have been used to control erosion caused by wind and boat waves, whereas elsewhere along the system, increased levels of erosion and habitat degradation have occurred, especially in areas where modifications have not been implemented. As existing modifications in the SCE reach the end of their intended lifespan and new structures are built to reduce erosion, the potential to integrate eco-engineered technologies and nature-based solutions could be possible to help increase habitats and reduce shoreline erosion.
aims:
Evaluate and incorporate the use of LSW habitat panels along three sections of the river wall within the lower SCE to assess their effectiveness in enhancing habitats. This aim will be achieved by investigating three parts;

Part 1:

Provide baseline information on the effectiveness of two commonly used erosion control techniques (rock revetments and seawalls) for enhancing habitat. Species richness and percentage cover will be measured to determine the effectiveness of these structures preceding the instalment of habitat enhancement techniques.

This part of the overarching aim will be addressed by testing the following hypothesis:

  • Species richness and functional diversity will be greater along limestone rock revetments compared to limestone seawalls.
Part 2:

Determine the effectiveness of LSW habitat panels for enhancing habitat percentage cover and richness along stretches of river wall compared to stretches of unmodified walls. Similar to part one, species richness and percentage cover will be used to measure habitat cover. In addition, the influence of exposure and tidal height on habitat provision will be considered.

This part of the overarching aim will be achieved by testing the following hypotheses:

  • Installing habitat panels will result in enhanced habitat complexity, and will increase species richness and functional diversity compared to unmodified seawalls.
  • The effectiveness of the panels in enhancing richness and diversity will be increased by localised tidal height, the duration each tile spends submerged.
  • Changes in localised wave exposure will influence establishment rate and species richness.
Part 3:

Investigate the influence each habitat panel design has on colonisation rates and species diversity on all panels by measuring species richness and percentage cover.  

Part three will address the overarching aim by testing the following hypotheses:

  • Habitat panels with higher complexities will have a greater influence on the rate of colonisation and diversity in colonising species.
  • Colonised species will be similar to those observed at similar latitudes across Australia.
  • The application of habitat panels across different latitudes will influence species diversity and the functional roles of the species.
outcome: This project will determine the suitability and effectiveness of the Living Seawalls habitat panels within the SCE, with the rate at which individual panel designs recruit benthic habitat growth being evaluated. At a wider scale, the interactions between fish and invertebrate communities and the habitat panels will be assessed to determine the effectiveness of the habitat panels. The outcomes from this project will provide planners with baseline information on how these habitat panels can improve complexities and recruitment rates of species in comparison to unmodified sea walls in a relatively cost-efficient approach. In addition, it will demonstrate that this method can work on existing modified shorelines and proposed modifications.
knowledge_transfer:
The project will help to develop knowledge and capability to support the protection and rehabilitation of foreshores and habitats in the SCE and more broadly, the Swan Canning Riverpark. The project is a partnership between DBCA Rivers and Estuaries Science, DBCA Riverbank Management branches with the Town of East Fremantle (ToEF) local government authority. The project also works collaboratively with the LSW project run through SIMS and the RDL in New South Wales and more broadly, alongside The Nature Conservancy (TNC).

Following pre-established LSW protocols the transfer and comparison of data between this trial and other studies both nationally and internationally will be possible. This will allow for the development of open understanding and knowledge sharing around how these types of habitat enhancement approaches respond under differing geographical and environmental scenarios.
project_tasks:
Throughout the project timeline, annual reporting in the form of milestone emails will be sent to each of the partners (DBCA Rivers and Estuaries Science, DBCA Riverbank Management and ToEF). These updates can also be sent across to LSW and RDL to give progress updates on how the installed habitat panels are performing.

At the end of the trial, the outcomes will be consolidated into a research report. This report will give in-depth details about the background of the trial, the methodologies used and the results of the study, comparing the habitat complexities of the different panels and the unmodified seawall sections. This report will be provided to each of the partners and will also be provided to LSW and RDL.

As this is the first time a trial using these methods has occurred in WA, a scientific publication of the findings will be produced and submitted to a high-impact journal. From the outset, this trial has been established to follow documented protocols and advice from the DBCA biometrician.
