methodology:
To achieve the aim, and test the hypotheses in Parts 1 and 2, data collection will directly align with the Living Seawalls (LSW) Macro Quadrat Biodiversity Survey Protocol and the approach in Part 3 will align with the methods highlighted in the LSW Panel-scale Monitoring Protocol for macro and micro quadrat sampling. Following these protocols will keep methodologies consistent across geographical ranges and allow for future collaborations between DBCA, LSW and other research institutes to occur. 

Parts 1 and 2 will also be assessed using an underwater video survey that follows the LSW Fish Processing Protocol. This will be comprised of a remote underwater video (RUV) assessment and a transect snorkel video assessment at each treatment site. 

Study sites 

Three study sites (HE1 – HE3) along Riverside Road under the ToEF local government authority form the initial locations for this research outlined in parts 1-3. The three sites are further divided and each includes three treatment types:  

  • 1 x stretch (~30 m) of rock revetment (Rr1 – Rr3)
  • 1 x stretch (~30 m) of seawall (Sw1 – Sw3) that will remain unmodified
  • 1 x stretch (~30 m) of seawall that will be modified with habitat panels (Mw1-Mw3)

Part 1 Approach: Comparison of revetment to the unmodified seawall

Here, the following two treatments: limestone rock revetment (Rr1 – Rr3) and limestone river walls (Sw1 – Sw3) will be used to assess the differences in macro species richness and functional diversity. At each site (HE1 -HE3), the central 10 m stretch of both treatment types will be assessed using a randomly placed 25 cm x 25 cm quadrat to count macro species richness and percentage cover. Ten replicate quadrats will be assessed at three tidal heights (low, medium, and high tide heights) equating to 30 quadrats in total within each stretch of treatment. Macro species richness will be collected by recording each of the mobile and sessile species that fall within each of the 25 individual quadrants. Macro percentage cover will be collected by recording the dominant sessile species that fall under each of the 25 intersecting points of each quadrat. Any mobile species that fall within the 25 individual quadrants will also be recorded.

The RUV assessments will be used across each treatment at each site to quantify differences in fish assemblages. To complete these assessments, three GoPro cameras will be haphazardly placed along the same central 10 m stretch from the quadrat sampling. Cameras will be situated facing the treatment at approximately 70 cm distance from the wall/rock revetment. They will be set to record video footage for 40 minutes each. The first and last 5 minutes will be trimmed from each video to remove any influence of the operator when setting the cameras in place. This will result in three thirty-minute videos being recorded for each treatment per site. Each video will be used to quantify species diversity, counts and behaviour using the analytical software EventMeasure.

To document broader species diversity, primarily of fish, a snorkel transect will be used. An operator carrying a GoPro will slowly swim the entire length of each treatment at each site at a distance of approximately 1.5m from each treatment and a speed of 3 m/min. The videos will be analysed in EventMeasure to document fish species diversity, abundance and size that are more broadly associated with each treatment.

The assessment of comparing habitat growth on revetment and unmodified seawalls will occur twice, once at the start of the project and once at the end to determine differences in diversity between the two treatments.

A more detailed description of the methodology for this part of the project is detailed in the Habitat Panel Assessment Plan.

Data Collection

The methodology for the data collection of the quadrats will apply to all parts and will include the following:

Land-based assessment of quadrats to determine percentage cover and diversity species per quadrat.  

  • Identify the primary and secondary sessile species at each intersecting point. If the intersecting point lands on a mobile species count the substrate underneath (i.e. bare substrate).
  • Record the presence of other sessile species that are present within each plot.
  • Count the number of mobile species to the lowest taxonomic resolution within each quadrat.

Data will be transcribed using the Macro quadrat field input file on the field Getac computers.

Underwater video (note: this methodology will apply to parts 1 and 2)

Multiple types of data will be recorded during the RUV survey including diversity abundance, habitat use and behaviour. Abundance will be measured with MaxN, habitat use will be measured through observations and the behaviour will be measured following the hierarchy of multiple behaviours. These variables will be recorded if a fish appears within the frame of the video and is tagged. 

  • Tagging the fish – each video will be paused at the time a fish enters the view. Click on the fish and enter the species, number, part, activity and comment (see protocol for detailed instructions).
  • MaxN – is the conservative measure of abundance and measures the number of individuals from a species in a single frame.
  • Observations – is the measure of habitat use and quantifies the number of times a species enters a frame rather than the number of fish within a frame at any given time. The observation data type follows three rules detailed within the protocol.
  • Behaviour – is the measure of the behaviour of each tagged species. This categorises the behaviour of a species into five different parameters. And where multiple behaviours are displayed, one is recorded based on the hierarchy of behaviours detailed in the protocol.

The transect snorkel assessment video data will be used to analyse fish diversity within the local vicinity of the modified seawall. The data collected will include diversity, abundance and general size class.

Wave climate (note: this methodology will apply to parts 1 and 2)

This data will be analysed to look at wave frequency and intensity to derive a metric of exposure at each site throughout the trial. 

  • The RBR Solo3D will be running continuously throughout each of the parts.
  • The loggers will be downloaded every 4 weeks when the batteries are replaced.
  • Data will initially be downloaded using the RBR software. This software can analyse the data however it also produces a CSV file of the raw data for complete control. MatLab mfiles and R scripts can be used to further interrogate data if necessary.

Sampling frequency

  • 1 x initial assessment with a review at the end of the project.
  • Battery replacement and wave logger download every 4 – 6 weeks depending on availability and survey frequency

Part 2 Approach: Comparison of modified and unmodified river walls

Here, the following two treatments: modified limestone river walls (Ms1 – Ms3) and unmodified limestone river walls (Sw1 – Sw3) will be used to test the hypotheses. The modified river wall sites will consist of 50 panels that are in an interlocking repetitive pattern of the five different panel structure types (control – flat panel, ridges, honeycomb, swim-through & large rockpools). The macro sampling effort of the panels and the unmodified river wall will follow the same methodology outlined in Part 1.

Wave climate data will be recorded using RBR Solo3D wave loggers. These will be deployed at each site at a depth of approximately 1.5 m. The loggers will be fixed to a concrete block to keep them in place. They will be downloaded and serviced every month to avoid data loss. This servicing will be carried out by two operators snorkelling from a boat.

Tidal height in the form of saturation curve data will also be obtained to investigate how long each panel spends submerged during each tidal cycle.

A more detailed description of the methodology for this part is detailed within the Habitat Panel Assessment Plan.

Data Collection 

Quadrat assessment

The same macro quadrat assessment methodology outlined in Part 1 will be used here. 

Species Identification

The same species identification methodology outlined in Part 1 will be used here. 

Remote underwater video surveys

The same underwater video survey methodology outlined in Part 1 will be used here. 

Wave climate

The same wave loggers will be used across the duration of Parts 1-3. The download of the loggers will occur on a 4 – 6 weekly basis coinciding with the surveys if possible.  

Sampling frequency

Except for the baseline survey sample events (Part 2 only), Parts 2 and 3 will align with the following sampling frequency:

  • 3 x monthly baseline sample events between August and October 2022 before panel installation.
  • 1 x time zero sample event (November 2022 with two weeks of panel installation)
  • 1 x 3 monthly sample events (commencing January 2023)
  • 6 x 6 monthly sample events commencing in April 2023 sampling effort and will continue to the end of the project.

Part 3 Approach: Locations in Australia and globally

Here the research focus is just on the habitat panels. The habitat panel methodologies outlined in Parts 1 and 2 will be used, in conjunction with micro quadrat species assessments.

Three randomly selected panels for each of the five different panel designs (15 panels in total) will be assessed per site, per survey. Each panel will be analysed using a macro quadrat (the same 25 cm x 25 cm with 25 intersecting points as used in Parts 1 and 2) along with two micro quadrats (4cm x 4cm with 9 intersecting points). The placement of the quadrats will differ from Part 2. The macro quadrat will be placed squarely onto the centre of the panel, not randomly placed. The micro quadrats will be haphazardly placed with one on the external surface of the panel feature and the other on the internal surface, for example, the crest and trough of the ridges panel. The quadrats will be analysed using a similar method to Parts 1 and 2 whereby dominant sessile species will be used to calculate percentage cover, and additional sessile and mobile species will be used to provide insight into overall abundance. The count of mobile species will be recorded.

A more detailed description of the methodology for this part is detailed within the Habitat Panel Assessment Plan.

Data collection

Quadrat assessment

The same macro quadrat assessment methodology as Parts 1 and 2 will be used within Part 3 for the macro quadrat assessment. The micro quadrat assessment for Part 3 will follow a similar methodology however will assess the external and internal features of a panel using 9 intersecting points rather than 25. The placement of each of the quadrats will also differ slightly from Parts 1 and 2 as the macro quadrat will be placed squarely on the centre of each panel rather than haphazardly at different tidal heights.

Species Identification

The same species identification methodology outlined in Parts 1 and 2 will be used here. 

Sampling frequency  

The sampling frequency for Part 3 will run simultaneously with Part 2 and follow the same sampling frequency detailed above.

Data management and processing

During sampling efforts, data will be recorded in Excel and saved on external hard drives and cloud services (i.e. DBCA Sharepoint). After each sampling effort, the results collected from the quadrant sampling in parts 1-3 will be analysed using R Statistical Programming (ref). Overall species diversity, percentage cover and the number of unique taxa (sessile and mobile) will be assessed. In addition to comparing these results, generalised additive mixed models (GAMMs) or boosted regression trees (BRTs) will be used to determine what factors (e.g. tidal height of panels, time of year) are influencing the species richness and diversity previously analysed in R. All results will be collated to form publication worthy figures and tables.
no_specimens: N/A
data_management:
Data Analysis

At the end of each survey, analyses will be completed to provide an insight into the overall species diversity, percentage cover and the number of unique taxa (sessile and mobile) occurring at each site. Dominant sessile species will be used to assess percentage cover, and extra sessile and mobile species will be used to understand general diversity. The results from the percentage cover, species composition and abundance will be plotted on time series plots for the entirety of the trial and used in milestone reporting and updates and communication with stakeholders.

Part 1 Approach: Comparison of revetment to unmodified seawall 

At the end of the project, the data for the two treatments surveyed in Part 1 will be analysed using a one-way ANOVA with pairwise comparison. This will test for significant differences in species composition and richness between the two treatments.

Part 2 Approach: comparison modified and unmodified river walls 

Baseline data will be analysed using pairwise comparison tests to assess the level of difference between the two treatments before the installation of the habitat panels. Following the installation similar pairwise comparison tests will be used to preliminarily assess the changes between the treatments after each survey event. This will help provide an insight into the ecological succession across the installations over time and updates and communication with stakeholders. 

At the end of the trial, the effectiveness of Part 2 will be statistically analysed and detailed in the final research report. These findings will also be used in any scientific publication that may be produced. This analysis will be performed under the guidance of the Department’s biometrician Matthew Williams. Following an initial consultation, it has been recommended that the data for this part will be assessed simultaneously and will loosely follow the analysis used by Strain et al. 2017. The analysis will use BACI (Before-After x Control-Impact) analysis to assess the success of each treatment. This will be achieved by using mixed-effect ANOVAs to test for significance in diversity in relation to the site, treatment type and tidal height. Due to the nature of this trial, a test for distribution will likely return an overdispersion from the Poisson distribution, in which case this family will be used when fitting GAMMs (negative binomial model) to the data when testing for variability.  These analyses may also include the nested covariates; exposure, complexity and saturation times. In addition to GAMMs, boosted regression trees (BRTs) may be used (Elith et al. 2008). BRTs are statistical learning techniques that use a combination of regression trees and boosting to fit numerous individual trees in a forward stage-wise method. These models incorporate different types of predictor variables (i.e. quantitative and qualitative) to fit additive regression models giving insights into ecological variables (Elith et al. 2008). Unlike GAMMs, BRTs can automatically handle interaction effects between predictors and can fit complex nonlinear relationships. These models may be used as an alternative to GAMMs during this project.

To further investigate if there is a significance in species diversity a PERMANOVA will be performed to understand any association between species composition, site, treatment and tidal height.

Data analysis from fish assemblage assessments will be analysed using a similar approach. Analyses will be performed frequently to visualise species composition, abundance and behaviour over time that may be used in progress updates and milestone reporting to stakeholders. At the end of the trial, the data from this assessment will be statistically analysed using BACI analysis like that detailed above. The analysis will follow the guidance of published literature and consultation with the Department’s biometrician will be sought at each stage of analysis to determine the most suitable approach.  

The complementary data collected alongside this trial such as the wave climate data, panel complexity (surface area) and saturation curve data will be assessed annually to visualise variation over time. At the end of the trial, these data will be further explored to investigate the influence on species richness using the most appropriate statistical analysis. Guidance from peer-reviewed literature and the Department’s biometrician will be sought at this stage.

Part 3 Approach: Evaluate of the colonisation of habitat panels in comparison to other locations in Australia and globally  

This part of the trial will be assessed using inference from change over space approach. This will be achieved by using multivariate and univariate PERMANOVA to test the effects of panel design complexity (using the surface area as a proxy) and site on biodiversity. Similarly, to Bishop et al., 2022, the multivariate analyses can use Bray-Curtis dissimilarity matrices on untransformed matrices of each of the sessile species percentage cover and mobile species abundances. Univariate analyses will use Euclidean distances on species richness (for sessile and mobile species both combined and independently), the total cover of fouling species, the total abundance of mobile species and the key functional groups of habitat-forming species.

Temporal panel-scale effects of complexity will be assessed using three-way analyses using design (fixed), time (fixed) and panel identity (random but nested in panel design). These analyses can be run on the same multivariate and univariate metrics detailed above except for the functional groups which will be on an annual scale.

Data management: 

Living Seawalls Habitat Panel trial in East Fremantle. 

After completion of the fieldwork, the raw data will be copied into an edited data folder where it will then be checked for completeness and cleaned, and the identification of any unknown species can be updated. Each survey will produce a unique version of raw and edited data that, at no point, poses the risk of replacing any existing data. All data will be stored on external hard drives and uploaded to the DBCA SharePoint where it can be accessed for analysis. Any results produced from the study will also be stored on external HDDs and SharePoint.

Biometrician's Endorsement: 

Living Seawalls Habitat Panel trial in East Fremantle. 

Guidance and endorsement from the Department’s contract biometrician Matthew Williams has been sought for Aim 1 of this project.

related_projects: This project is part of the Dirk Hartog ecological restoration and fauna reconstruction plan (Gillen et al. 2011; Morris et al. 2016).
background:
Dirk Hartog Island was established as a national park on 29 October 2009 and this provided the opportunity to restore the island’s natural environment and reconstruct its native vertebrate fauna. The island formerly supported at least 13 species of mammal of which only three still persisted following introduction of feral cats, mice and goats and over 100 years of pastoral use (Gillen et al. 2011; Morris et al. 2016).

The island also supports three threatened bird subspecies (Dirk Hartog Island Southern Emu-wren, Dirk Hartog Island White-winged Fairy-wren and Dirk Hartog Island Rufous Fieldwren), while another, the Dirk Hartog Island Western Grasswren, became extinct during the last century (Burbidge et al. 2013). However, despite the fact that the three threatened bird taxa were known to be endemic to Dirk Hartog Island, virtually nothing was known of their distribution on the island, habitat preferences, or abundance. In addition, the taxonomic status of the fieldwren was unclear - while some authors considered the island population to be an endemic subspecies (e.g. Schodde and Mason 1999), others (e.g. Johnstone and Storr 2004) hypothesised that variation in this species in Western Australia was clinal, and no subspecies should be recognised.

 There has therefore been a clear need to clarify the taxonomic and conservation status of the fieldwren, to characterise the ecological requirements of the endemic taxa, and to determine their population sizes, in order to provide baseline data against which outcomes of future management actions can be evaluated.
aims:
(a) clarification of the taxonomic status of the Dirk Hartog Island Fieldwren

(b)  species distribution modeling for each of the threatened bird taxa

(c) assessment of population levels and density surface modeling for each of the threatened taxa.
outcome:
1. Base line data against which to evaluate management actions in the future

2. Recommendations regarding the conservation status of the fieldwren, and the level of sensitivity of each of the threatened bird taxa to potential management actions such as prescribed fire

3. Scientific publications

(a) clarifying the taxonomic status of the Dirk Hartog Island Fieldwren

(b) describing species distribution models for each of the threatened bird taxa

(c) describing population levels and density surface models for each of the threatened taxa.

4. Conference presentations.

5. Popular articles and presentations, e.g for Landscope.
knowledge_transfer: Users will include other participants in the Dirk Hartog Island Fauna Reconstruction project, including scientific and management staff. Transfer of knowledge will be via ongoing personal contact with management and scientific staff, together with provision of reports, etc.

methodology:
Genetics: Genomic and mitochondrial DNA extracted from museum specimens. Using the ND2 locus, apply Rapid Maximum likelihood methods (RaxML) to generate a phylogeny. Cluster analysis on the matrix of genome-wide identity by state pairwise distances, with groups determined by a permutation score (using SNPRelate, an R/Bioconductor Package). For details, see Burbidge et al. (2018a).

Occurrence data: Presence in unbounded quadrats (see Burbidge et al. 2013).

Abundance data: Line transects surveyed using distance sampling (Buckland et al. 2001; Burbidge et al. 2015, 2018b);

Surface density modelling: Model based methods to model the density of each species as a function of spatially indexed environmental covariates (Thomas et al. 2010); analysis in R using the mrds and dsm packages (for details see Burbidge et al. 2018b).
data_management: Currently maintained in an Access database (occurrence data) and in csv files (abundance data).

background:
Urbanisation leads to many direct and indirect impacts in natural remnants, including eutrophication, frequent disturbance, loss of connectivity, loss of key faunal elements and their ecological functions, additional heat island stress, climate and groundwater change. In many urban and peri-urban bushland reserves, changed fire regime and weed invasion, compound these threats and each other, but are potentially the easiest to manage. Invasive grasses, in particular change fuel dynamics (accumulation, structure, connectivity, availability), and their spread and cover is enhanced by fire. Clearly the stakes are high here too, with their high exposure, both the fire risk to neighbors and visitors and the biodiversity and community values of these remnant reserves are acute. As invasive grasses are ubiquitous in urban bushlands, burning to manage fuels, without weed management, might lead to perverse outcomes for both biodiversity and fire hazard. This long-term study examines the impacts of different proposed or actual bushland management approaches on fire risk, biodiversity conservation and weed invasion. 

In this study we compare the abundance and cover of native and non-native plant species, vegetation structure, and the distribution and abundance of fuels with both pre-treatment baselines, and across treatments and controls. The maximal design includes six treatments, with three burn treatments – fire exclusion, and ‘medium’ and ‘short’ rotations (~12-14 and 6-8 years) ­– each crossed by the presence and absence of standard weed management approaches. With the time component of these treatments, the study is inherently long-term, and likely site, burn treatment and year differences require increasing replication. The program commenced with pre-burn survey in spring 2014 for a burn implemented in autumn 2015 in Kings Park, follow-up monitoring of this site and similar work for sites burned in Bold Park, Jandakot Regional Park and Beeliar Regional Park (Yangebup) continuing. Preparations are underway for two other in 2018 or 2019.

related_projects: Nil.
background:
The broad goal of this project is to prioritize island management actions so that we maximize the number of achievable conservation outcomes for island biodiversity in the face of threats from invasive species. Western Australia has over 3,700 islands, many of which are essential for the survival of threatened species and provide critical breeding sites for seabirds and sea turtles. In some cases, islands support the last remaining populations of plant and animal species making their long term protection highly desirable. Many of Western Australia’s islands are also popular sites for recreation, and tourism, and contain many culturally significant sites. Invasive species are the single biggest cause of loss of native species from islands across the globe. The increased use of islands by the public for recreation, and oil, gas and mining industries means an increased likelihood that invasive species will colonize pristine islands.   
Prioritization of management investments is essential because funds for turning national, state or regional conservation goals into actions are typically limited. Implementation of actions therefore generally proceeds incrementally while biodiversity continues to decline, even in areas earmarked for future management. Funds to manage established protected areas are also insufficient, so these areas too can be expected to suffer declines in biodiversity. Reversing these declines presents researchers and managers with difficult challenges.   
In the past prioritizing conservation actions has relied on the experience and expertise of conservation land managers. The field of Strategic Conservation Planning is an organized field of research that attempts to design explicit frameworks and models for guiding conservation actions that generate cost-effective and accountable recommendations for prioritizing actions. Four specific and relatively independent areas of research have generated models and knowledge relevant to the problem of prioritizing conservation actions.   
The first area of research on prioritizing or scheduling conservation investments (Pressey et al. 2004) has modeled conservation and loss of biodiversity from an area through design of variable conservation networks given spatial variability in conservation and use values (Spring et al. 2010, Visconti et al. 2010). These models do not consider the multiple threats to biodiversity or multiple actions managers may implement to mitigate biodiversity loss. The second area has ranked lists of possible actions for species management in a single area, recognizing the costs, benefits and probability of success associated with each action (Bottrill et al. 2008, Joseph et al. 2008a, Joseph et al. 2008b). Action are treated independently and prioritized according to their marginal contributions to conservation goals, with the final list of high priority projects being limited by available funds (Weitzman 1998). However, actions are rarely implemented independently, so optimal search algorithms should instead identify combinations of actions that optimize costs, benefits, probability of success and budget constraints (Westphal and Possingham 2003). A third research area has allocated different conservation actions to regions globally or across continents (Wilson et al. 2006, Wilson et al. 2007, Bode et al. 2008, Underwood et al. 2008). These studies ignored almost all spatial variation in intensity of threats, costs of actions, and responses of species and other features to management interventions. A fourth area of research allocates actions spatially using a global search algorithm (Watts et al. 2009, Klein et al. 2010, Wilson et al. 2010), but matches only one action with each area and ignore the temporal variation of threats as they respond to management or environmental variables. These studies also did not deal with uncertainty.   
This project will combine these four areas of research into a single comprehensive formulation that will create a decision support tool for day-to-day use in making accountable and cost-effective decisions about where to spend limited funding on management of islands. The need for this project is underlined by the limitations of the four research areas described above, all of which have limited applicability to field managers faced with immediate, real-world problems. This project fills a crucial need. The project will be developed collaboratively with practitioners to ensure that: 1. the science is properly grounded so that it provides answers useful to day-to-day management; and 2. decisions are based on the best available expert judgment where hard data are lacking.
aims: This aim of this project will be to develop a decision support tool for day-to-day use in making accountable and cost-effective decisions about where to spend limited funding on management of islands to promote the persistence of native species. The decision support tool will assist in prioritizing WA islands for conservation surveillance and management and could contribute to a future biosecurity plans for other islands both in Western Australia and across Australia. The project will initially focus on the islands along the Pilbara coast between Exmouth Gulf and Eighty Mile Beach. The decision support tool will eventually be applied to the management all of Western Australia’s islands, and potentially to all Australian islands.
outcome:
This project will generate several beneficial products for island conservation in Western Australia including: 1) An operational decision support tool for island management with the aim of promoting the persistence of native species on islands.  2) Training sessions to develop the capacity of DEC staff to apply the model in managing the conservation estate. DEC officers will also be able to update the decision support tool as new data become available, and will remain in contact with the research group at James Cook University, ensuring that access to improved versions of the software tool are obtainable. An MOU will be established between DEC and James Cook University to ensure ongoing collaboration. 3) Accountable and cost effective decisions that aid the conservation of WA’s idyllic islands and native species. 4) A single comprehensive database on Western Australian island characteristics, fauna, flora, and threats and; 5) the project has the support of the Conservation Commission and will address several recommendations in the Commission’s two Status Performance Assessments on Biodiversity Conservation on Western Australian Islands.

In developing and testing the full decision model, the project team will also create three scientific innovations. First, the method will integrate, for the first time, components of four disparate areas of research, refining each component and developing new links between them. Second, essential to addressing real-world complexity, the project will develop three new sub-models to account for the temporal and spatial dynamics of threats from invasive species, varying contributions of different management actions to management goals, and the costs of actions. Each sub-model will be an important conceptual and technical advance in its own right and will interact with the others to adjust, for example, the choice and sequence of management actions as threats to biodiversity are ameliorated. Third, the project will deal explicitly with uncertainties in key parameters, using plausible bounds and, where possible, probability distributions of abundances and extent of species and ecosystems, distributions of threats and species-specific responses, and contributions and costs of management actions
knowledge_transfer:
The purpose of this project is to develop a decision support tool that will help managers make day-to-day decisions regarding island management. Conservation and resource managers are the anticipated users of the knowledge generated by this project. DEC, as an active partner in the project, will directly absorb the improved data on island biota and management, apply the decision support tool to conservation problems, and enhance its technical capacity to prioritize management actions for the conservation of native species on islands.
Each party (JCU and DEC) retains ownership, and the rights to use, exploit, and grant licenses for the use of its pre-existing intellectual material. Each party grants the other a non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use the other party’s pre-existing material. All intellectual property rights in material generated, created, or developed by this project vest immediately in DEC. DEC grants JCU an irrevocable, non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use the project material for the purposes of carrying out the project and for any other non-commercial purpose relating to environmental research or management.

methodology:
The islands of Western Australia are a perfect study system for this project, with native species of global and national significance, interacting pressures on these species from invasive plants and animals, alternative management actions with uncertain effectiveness, and insufficient management funds to achieve all goals. This project will focus on the islands along the Pilbara coast between the Exmouth Gulf and Eighty Mile Beach. A workshop held within the first four months of this project will identify the particular islands to be used during model development. The final decision support model generated by the project will be applicable to all WA islands.

The process of designing this decision support tool has 11 components (Figure 1), which have been adapted from the stages of systematic conservation planning (Pressey and Bottrill 2009) and informed by previous work on prioritizing management actions. Details of each model component are outlined below.

1. Guiding principles (Tear et al. 2005)  shape decisions about species to be managed. The guiding principles will draw on national and state conservation policy and strategies and the expertise of island managers in Western Australia and elsewhere (e.g. managers from the Pilbara region).

2. A basic requirement for the project will be accurate data on the occurrence, abundance and, population trends of native species on the islands. These data will be compiled from field work, scientific literature and unpublished information held by DEC.

3. Species weightings will guide solutions in the event (typically) that not all goals can be achieved (Polasky et al. 2008). One of the realities of management within budget constraints is that hard choices will be necessary about, for example, which native species should benefit from management intervention in a given period. While a common currency for comparing species is still hotly debated, and not part of this proposal, the project will require explicit choices and rationale for these inevitable decisions.

4. Threat models will help to define quantitative goals for each species (Pressey et al. 2003) and estimate potential losses of species in the absence of management. Understanding the potential spread of invasives, within and between islands and from outside sources, in the absence of intervention is necessary to formulate goals and identify priorities. Quantitative conservation goals will probably be larger for more highly threatened species, for example; and priorities will reflect expected declines in native species, and the options for achieving goals on the islands being studied. The threat sub-model (Figure 1) will consider temporally explicit (annual) changes and the potential effects of climate change. Year-zero of the threat sub-model will assume no management intervention, whereas subsequent years will consider management actions. The threat sub-model will also predict species-specific responses to threats, ranging from categorisation of threat status to estimates of population trends and stage-based demographic models (Bolten et al. 2011).

5. Quantitative management goals are at the core of emerging systematic methods for identifying priorities for investment. They allow managers to be explicit about what they intend to achieve over defined periods, allow progress to be tracked, and facilitate the use of the cutting-edge analytical techniques that will be applied in this project. The project team will define time-bound conservation goals for protection (prevention of decline) and/or restoration (Didier et al. 2009). Goals will recognise the need for complementary management in adjacent marine or terrestrial environments (Dryden et al. 2008).

6. Areas will be the candidate spatial units assessed for actions (Pressey and Logan 1998). These might be small islands or parts of islands defined as having relatively uniform management requirements. In the Pilbara each island (defined as land not connected to other land masses at low tide) will be considered an independent area.

7. Actions (Table 1) used to reduce or prevent the arrival of invasive species, will be assigned relative contributions toward each management goal (Edwards et al. 2010). Actions will include biosecurity measures as well as methods to eradicate populations of invasive species in situ. These could be expressed, for example, as the expected reduction in density of an invasive species per hectare of treatment in a given period. The sub-model for relative contributions of actions to goals (Figure 1) will recognise spatial variation in contributions, including probability of success, and synergies and interferences between actions. Actions may vary among targeted invasive species.
8. Management actions will be costed per hectare of treatment (Wilson et al. 2007). The cost sub-model (Figure 1) will address spatial interactions (e.g. travel times) and temporal dynamics of costs in relation to the cost-efficiencies of both early intervention and follow-up work to avoid returns to pre-treatment conditions.
9. There will be two formulations of the problem. The first, and most applicable, will maximise the achievement of goals within cost constraints (Church et al. 1996). The second will find the minimum cost required to achieve all goals.
10.  Application will produce a decision-support tool for managers, allowing them to alter any of the parameters from the previous steps and identify cost-effective options for management of islands. This will involve new coding, linked interactively to a graphical user interface, and identifying multiple cost-effective solutions. Application will also explore alternative funding scenarios, such as the benefits of a biosecurity strategy (Nias et al. 2010) vs. ameliorative management after arrival of invasives, implications of funding cuts or increases on control of invasive species, and effects on overall cost-effectiveness of committing funds to particular island groups or iconic species. The application phase of the project will also explore uncertainties in key parameters as a basis for sensitivity analysis and guiding risk-averse and risk-seeking decisions (Halpern et al. 2006).

related_projects:
SP 2016-075 Threatened animal recovery through feral cat control in Western Australia - Dryandra component

SP 2016-072 Threatened animal recovery through feral cat control in Western Australia - South coast component

SP 2016-068 South West Threatened Fauna Recovery Project: Southern Jarrah Forest
background:
Over the last 200 years, 50 per cent of the world’s mammal extinctions have occurred in Australia (Short and Smith 1994). In Western Australia alone, 12 mammals and two birds have become extinct and at 30 June 2015, 39 terrestrial mammals and 23 terrestrial birds native to the State were classified as being threatened with extinction. Of these, three mammals and two birds are ranked as critically endangered. In mammals, most extinctions and declines have occurred in medium size species, in the so called ‘critical weight range’ of 35g to 5500g (Burbidge and McKenzie 1989).

Predation by feral cats and foxes is a key threatening process in the decline of many, if not all, these species. Foxes have been successfully controlled for many years in a range of locations across Western Australia using dried meat sausage baits containing 1080 poison. Over a decade of research by Parks and Wildlife scientists has led to the development of the Eradicat® feral cat bait, a moister meat bait, also containing 1080, that is more palatable to feral cats. Eradicat® was registered for operational use in Western Australia in December 2014, providing the opportunity to integrate broadscale feral cat control with existing fox baiting programs and other actions, such as translocation, that are implemented to improve the recovery of threatened native animals.

On 16 July 2015, the Minister for Environment, Hon Albert Jacob MLA, and the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Hon Greg Hunt MP, announced $1.7 million in funding for the Department of Parks and Wildlife to assist threatened animal recovery. The funding will be used to integrate the new Eradicat® feral cat bait with current fox baiting in four different Western Australian environments. Sites have been specifically selected to direct the funding to improving conservation of species identified in the Commonwealth’s Threatened Species Strategy, and to align with fauna recovery programs already underway or planned by Parks and Wildlife in the south-west of WA.

This project fits within a broader suite of actions delivered by Parks and Wildlife to reduce the impacts of feral cats and foxes on threatened species in Western Australia. This includes Western Shield, the Integrated Fauna Recovery Project on the south coast, Rangelands Restoration at Matuwa and many other smaller scale projects.

The primary goal of the project is to contribute to the recovery of key threatened mammal and bird species found at each of these sites, through integrating feral cat baiting with existing fox baiting to reduce the impact of introduced predators, and undertaking translocations to establish new, secure populations, where necessary.

While the Eradicat® feral cat bait is a key tool in achieving effective feral cat control, other methods, such as shooting and/or trapping, may also be employed. For example, some individual cats appear to be reluctant to take baits or local climatic conditions may reduce the effectiveness of baiting alone.  Some flexibility is built into the project plan to allow this suite of control options to be employed, as necessary.

The project is funded for three years over the 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 financial years. A project agreement has been signed with the Commonwealth Government outlining funding to be provided in each financial year and key deliverables.

Four key areas are targeted under the broader project: Kalbarri NP, South Coast region, Upper Warren region and Dryandra Woodland.  This proposal relates to the Kalbarri NP component.

Kalbarri National Park covers an area of 183,000ha and straddles the lower reaches of the Murchison River.  The park supports a range of threatened fauna including malleefowl, chuditch and a small population of black-flanked rock wallabies (BFRW) (re-discovered in 2015, thought extinct since mid 1990s). The primary objective of this project is to recover a wild population of BFRW in Kalbarri NP, through effective integration of feral cat control with existing fox control, successful translocation of rock-wallabies and effective neighbor engagement.  Two translocations are proposed to supplement the current population and establish further populations. Integration of the Eradicat feral cat bait with existing fox baiting will be initiated in Kalbarri NP in 2016.  Monitoring of foxes and feral cats to assess the effectiveness of feral cat and fox baiting will be undertaken.
aims:
To recover a wild population of black-flanked rock-wallabies in Kalbarri National Park, through:

(a) effective integration of feral cat control with existing fox control;

(b) successful translocation of rock-wallabies; and

(c) effective neighbour engagement.
outcome:
Effective integration of fox and feral cat control that maximises reduction in the number of introduced predators at Kalbarri NP.

  • Identification of the most appropriate time of year to use Eradicat, with the information being applied in other similar areas of the Midwest.
  • A reduction in the impact of foxes and feral cats on threatened species, resulting in continued persistence, an increase in distribution and positive trends in population abundance of threatened species in the short to medium term (5-10 years)
  • An effective method of monitoring the change in abundance of foxes and feral cats using cameras

An increased understanding of the factors influencing successful feral cat and fox control.

Establish persistent and resilient populations of black-flanked rock wallabies, through translocations and control of foxes, feral cats and goats.

Community awareness and engagement to ensure understanding of and support for management actions.
knowledge_transfer:
Regional nature conservation programs, introduced pest control programs, BFRW recovery team, Parks and Wildlife nature conservation and science programs.

Technology transfer through reports, media, recovery team and broader communication strategy for the SWTFRP.

methodology:
a) Monitoring Feral Cats and Foxes

Camera Monitoring

Sampling sites: Kalbarri National Park (baited site), Murchison House Station and unallocated crown land to the north of KNP (Number: 1012103).

Sampling method: Camera monitoring will be the primary method used to monitor predators throughout the park.  Cameras will remain in place for the life of the project. 

Camera set up – cameras will be placed horizontally at a height of 30-40cm on pickets, facing south.  Vegetation will be cleared to ground level in front of cameras to a maximum area of 3m, where necessary.  

Sampling design: a minimum of 65 cameras will be used in total across KNP and the unbaited reference site.  Approximately 50 cameras will be set in KNP and 15 cameras will be set in the unbaited area (smaller area).  Camera placement across KNP and the unbaited reference area will be determined using a constrained, randomised model to allocate camera positions.  Camera placement is constrained to tracks and randomised with a minimum distance of 3km between placement points. In areas where there is a risk of camera theft, the camera will be moved off, but close to the track, and set up in a cleared area.

In the south two cameras will be installed either side of the track at each monitoring point to improve detectability across the wider tracks.  In the north, one camera will be placed at each monitoring point.  Cameras will be placed perpendicular (or at a slight 5-10o angle) to the track. 

Cameras will be passive (non-lured).  Detection rates will be assessed before the Eradicat baiting to check that the detections are sufficient to indicate a change in the system.  If not, consideration will be given to increasing the number of cameras across the study site or using lures with cameras (visual and olfactory lures).   If lures are used they would be installed at each monitoring point 2-4 weeks prior to the Eradicat baiting; would be removed during the baiting round and then replaced two weeks post baiting for a period of 2-4 weeks.

Cameras will remain in place (subject to fire) for the entirety of the project.  Cameras will be checked, on average, every 3-4 months, dependent on battery life and SD card use.

Camera monitoring of predators will only be carried out on the ‘flats’ – no specific predator monitoring will be done in the gorge due to the difficulty of installing and servicing cameras and the increased risk of injury to staff.  Foxes and feral cats may be picked up on the cameras set up to monitor the BFRWs (40 cameras across Four Ways and Promenade).

Data capture and analysis:  Images for predator monitoring will be processed every 3-4 months using FastStone Image viewer and CPW Photo Warehouse.  Where possible, feral cats and foxes will be individually identified to try to identify the geographic range over which individuals are detected.  Data summaries will be produced every six months; including species detected, activity index, heat maps and cumulative sum control charts. Occupancy modelling will be carried out post Eradicat baiting to determine the impact of the baiting on feral cats and foxes.

Tracking

GPS tracking of foxes and feral cats: In 2016/17 up to ten cats and foxes will be trapped on the flats near the gorge and fitted with GPS collars.  The intention is to get some information on how predators use the gorge system so we can better understand the threats to the BFRW and chuditch populations.  Collars have a mortality signal so we will also be able to identify whether feral cats and foxes are killed through the  Eradicat baiting.  Five GPS fixes will be taken at each of the peak activity times (sunrise and sunset) and one fix will also be taken at midday to provide an indication of likely den/resting areas.  Collars will be fitted to foxes and feral cats 3-4 months prior to aerial baiting (dependent on collar battery life).  GPS information from collars – a qualitative assessment of land use area (gorge vs flats) will be determined from location information.  Indicative home ranges will be determined using kernel density estimates.  Percent of feral cats alive post-baiting will provide information to calibrate camera data and indicate effectiveness of Eradicat baiting.

Intended outcomes:

  • Improved timing and location of Eradicat baiting.
  • Foxes and feral cat abundance will be reduced.
  • Recovery of threatened species will be improved.

b) Monitoring Rock Wallabies

  1. Source populations
  2. In situ Kalbarri population (Promenade)
  3. Translocated population (Four Ways; possibly Hawks Head) – approved translocation proposal attached.

Detail on the BFRW monitoring is provided in the translocation plan, a summary is provided below (see appendix 3 (separate document)).

Source Populations:  Mt Caroline and Nangeen Hill BFRW populations will be used as the source populations in year one of translocation and possibly year two.  Consideration may be given to sourcing animals from Pilbara and Cape Range populations in year two or year three depending on logistics, discussions with traditional owners and consideration of broadening genetic diversity of the founder population.

2016 monitoring of Mt Caroline and Nangeen:  Intensive trapping (using Thomas traps) was undertaken in March and April/May 2016 at Mt Caroline and Nangeen – the population was trapped for up to 14 days until the number of recaptures indicated that most of the population had been trapped. 

Trapping data was analysed to determine number of founder animals that could be removed from each site (up to 23 in total for year one of the translocation); sex ratios of source populations, number of females with pouch young, age structure and an indication of health (weight, body condition).

Subsequent to the removal of founder animals, source sites will be monitored again in early 2017 and 2018 to ensure that the population hasn’t been negatively impacted by the translocation. An assessment of number of females with young, sex ratio and age structure should indicate if the populations have been impacted negatively in the short term and the implications for the longer term.  If it is determined that the source populations cannot sustain further removal of animals, animals required for year two of the translocation will be sourced from other Wheatbelt sites or Cape Range/Pilbara populations.

In situ Kalbarri population (Promenade; one male and one female BFRW): cameras have been installed around the Promenade site.  Scat searches and camera arrays placed between Promenade and Four Ways will be used to indicate continued presence and possible dispersal of the BFRW.  The three female animals that will be translocated in 2016 will be fitted with VHF collars and radio-tracked for 12months.

Translocated population: Animals released in 2016 at Four Ways will be monitored using a combination of techniques.  The primary method of monitoring will be using VHF collars and radio-tracking the animals for 12months.  In 2016 all translocated animals will be fitted with collars.  Radio-tracking will be carried out initially by both aerial and ground tracking (up to three months) and then by ground tracking only.  Collars will indicate mortality and location of animals.  Cameras placed around the release site will also be used to monitor the presence and breeding status of animals.  Cameras will remain in place for 12 months after the translocation (and possibly for the life of the project depending on the quantity and quality of data that the cameras provide relative to other sampling techniques).  Sighting the animals will also be carried out every 2-3 months when staff go in to check cameras.

In subsequent translocations a proportion of the founder animals will be fitted with VHF collars and radio-tracked.  Depending on the success of the VHF collars in year one, consideration may be given to using GPS collars on some animals.  Cameras will also be installed around the Hawks Head release site to monitor animals.

Intended outcomes:

  • Kalbarri genetic lineage will be retained by producing Wheatbelt-Kalbarri offspring and increasing the number of individuals carrying Kalbarri alleles.
  • Two subpopulations of BFRW will be established, increasing the number of animals in the Kalbarri population and creating opportunity for dispersal throughout the gorge.
  • A persistent and resilient population of BFRW in the Midwest region.

Proposed Site Baiting Prescription

Kalbarri NP

Current baiting prescription: two times aerial fox bait (spring and autumn) + quarterly ground fox baiting of tracks.

Proposed prescription 2016:  two aerial fox bait (autumn, spring); one aerial feral cat bait end of winter (northern section of park only).  Quarterly ground fox baiting of tracks.

The northern section of the park will be aerially baited with Eradicat in winter 2016 (late August).  The southern section of the park will remain unbaited with Eradicat until 2017.  In 2017 both the northern and southern sections of the park will be baited in summer or autumn (to be determined). 

Additional baiting around BFRW sites – Promenade and Four Ways will have additional fox ground baiting before and after the translocation and Eradicat baiting if and when cats are identified near the release sites (through cameras or sighting cat tracks).

Other complementary measures including with neighbours: Encourage trapping, shooting and baiting on neighbouring lands.

background:
The advance of Cane Toads towards Western Australia has caused tremendous concern about their impacts on the native fauna of the Kimberley region. Despite, the presence of this introduced species in Australia since the 1930s, surprisingly little is known about its ecological effects. While Northern Quolls (_Dasyurus hallucatus, _Oakwood 2003), some goannas (Burnett 1997) and a couple of snakes (Phillips, Brown and Shine 2003) are known to be killed by toads; data on impacts on other fauna is either anecdotal or non-existent ( for a review, see [www.deh.gov.au/biodiversity/threatened](http://www.deh.gov.au/biodiversity/threatened)). Impacts of cane toads are potentially threefold: competition with native species, predation of native invertebrates/vertebrates and destruction of wildlife due to lethal toxic ingestion.

 

 

CALM has supported the nomination of Cane Toads as a “key threatening process” under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Act 1999, noting that “it was a significant threat to biodiversity and ecosystem function.” Most of the limited research conducted in the Northern Territory and Queensland has focused on the impacts of Cane Toads on frogs and those species that might consume toads (e.g. quolls). Vertebrates most at risk would appear to be frogs, frog-eating snakes, goannas and dasyruids. This proposal deals with major reptile, frog and marsupial groups most at risk. Other research is required on turtles, birds and invertebrate groups, especially endemic land snails.

 

 

Research underway in the Northern Territory is examining the impacts of toads on goannas and a range of terrestrial vertebrates in Kakadu National Park (Watson and Woinarski 2003). Unfortunately, sites were only sampled for 1-2 years prior to the arrival of toads, limiting the interpretation of results. However, it was concluded that quolls, goannas (considered as a group), gilbert’s dragons and perhaps elapid snakes had declined. Other research on impacts on goannas and crocodiles (Griffiths, pers. comm.; Doody, pers. comm.) is ongoing. Cane Toads reached Fogg Dam (NT) this wet season allowing observation on the effects on floodplain snakes and some frogs (Shine, University of Sydney, pers. comm.). Toad competition and predation on native invertebrates has received little attention, but is constrained by sampling/ taxonomic problems and seasonal and temporal variation in invertebrate populations. Much of the information available on Cane Toad impacts is anecdotal or based on studies that have lacked sufficient pre-toad data to determine the impact of cane toads relative to other environmental variables such as rainfall or disturbances such as fire. Further, many species have not been studied at all; at present we can only guess the probable impact of cane toads.

 

 

CALM has an opportunity to carry out complimentary and novel research on the impact of cane toads which can be used to plan for the conservation of species including localized control of toads, small scale fencing, translocation of threatened fauna, establishment of captive populations; among other options. The Kimberley region contains many endemic vertebrates as well as species with broader tropical distributions that may be severely affected by Cane Toads. Given the proximity of Cane Toads to the East Kimberley, it is important to establish research projects now, in advance of the potential arrival of cane toads to ensure that adequate data on existing assemblages of terrestrial vertebrates are collected so impacts can be detected.

 

 

Is this approach fatalistic? Should we be putting all our efforts into stopping cane toads and not worrying about research on impacts? Current trapping efforts will not stop toads. If some research work is not undertaken, we will have lost an opportunity to understand their impacts on East Kimberley and other northern fauna. This would severely limit our capacity to understand the susceptible elements of the fauna and so restrict management efforts to prevent populations declines and extinctions.  

 

 

After discussions with a range of colleagues within and beyond CALM, it appears that where we can target our research most usefully is to examine some of those faunal groups either endemic to the Kimberley, largely restricted to Western Australia or not studied in any detail in the N.T. or Queensland. Those vertebrates most likely to be impacted by cane toads (i.e. frogs, large predatory reptiles and dasyurids) are not well sampled by standard survey techniques such as pitfall trapping (Woinarski _et al._ 2004). This project advocates the use of “cafeteria trials” to quickly assess the susceptibility of a range of fauna to cane toad ingestion with radio-telemetry of large individuals where captive trials are unsuitable.
aims:
a.  Update an available model on the spread of cane toads based on recent and past data to predict the arrival times of cane toads across the Kimberley.

b.  Identify native frog, snake, dasyruids, skink, dragon and goanna taxa susceptible to cane toad poisioning or predation through captive experiments (proposed ARC linkage with Uni of Sydney).

c.   Document pre-toad species assemblages of reptiles and amphibians at a number of “benchmark” sites in the East and North Kimberley, especially those containing undescribed species such as frogs in the genus Uperoleia.

d.  Conduct radio-telemetry of a small number of localized endemic snakes (including the Ord Snake and Rough-scaled Python) to determine their basic ecology and possible susceptibility to toads.

e.   Regular collections and preservation of toads at the “front” for future study of changes to toads as they invade new habitat (morphology, parasite loads, reproductive output) which may assist with the development of control measures in the longer term.
outcome:
a. Accurate model of the spread of cane toads to allow planning and action by managers in advance of their arrival at various sites in the Kimberley.

b. The identification of taxa that will ingest cane toads (and those that don’t) to guide managers in what species will persist after the arrival of toads and those that may need conservation assistance.

c. A good understanding of the pre-toad reptile and amphibian communities in the Kimberley to assess their changes over the longer term (also relevant to fire impacts).

d. Data on the ecology of regional endemics that may be susceptible to cane toads, but for which we have insufficient information.

e. Samples of preserved cane toads for later research on the nature of their invasive qualities.
knowledge_transfer: CALM managers, land-holders in the Kimberley region, indigenous communities. Information would be disseminated in publications, newspapers, public talks and in public meetings.
project_tasks:
1)       Preparation of a dynamic model of cane toad spread across the Kimberley – May 2007

2)       Completion of a report on susceptibility trials for frogs, dragons, snakes and dasyruids – June 2007

3)       Published description of frog assemblages at a range of sites in the East Kimberley – June 2008

4)       Collection of snake specimens (primarily roadkills) and draft paper on the analysis of the importance of frogs in the diet of several species – June 2008

5)       Publication of scientific paper and popular articles on the impacts of cane toads on native fauna in the East Kimberley region – December 2009
references:
Burnett, S. 1997. Colonising cane toads cause population declines in native predators: Reliable anecdotal information and management implications. Pacific Conservation Biology 3:65-72.

Oakwood, M. 2003. The effect of cane toads on a marsupial carnivore, the northern quoll, Dasyurus hallucatus. Unpublished progress report to Parks Australia North. February 2003

Phillips, B. L., G. P. Brown & R. Shine. 2003. Assessing the potential impact of cane toads Bufo marinus on Australian snakes. Conservation Biology 17:1738-1747.

Watson, M, & Woinarski, J. 2003. A preliminary assessment of impacts of cane toads on terrestrial vertebrate fauna in Kakadu National Park. Unpublished report to Kakadu Research Advisory Committee, February 2003

Woinarski, J.C.Z., Armstrong, M., Price, O., McCartney, J., Griffiths, A.D. and Fisher, A. (2004). The terrestrial vertebrate fauna of Litchfield National Park, Northern Territory: monitoring over a 6-year period and response to fire history. Wildlife Research 31: 587-596.
methodology:
The modeling of cane toad advance will build on a model earlier developed by Dr Ben Phillips using data on the known arrival times of toads at various points in the NT. This will enable the calculation of rates of spread and through overlaying environmental information in ArcView, determination of rates of spread in different landscape types.

Determining inventories of species at various sites would be undertaken by hand-searching, road driving, rock-turning and tape-recording calls and sites compared with classification procedures within PATN.

“Cafetaria trials” will use wild-caught animals and be undertaken at the University of Sydney’s research facility at Fogg Dam (NT) where there are pens and cages to house a large number of animals. Between 5 and 20 individuals of each species to be tested will be offered cane toad eggs or different sized metamorphs. The metamorphs will have their parotid gland removed prior to the test to minimize the chances of death of the test animals. Sydney University has Animal Ethics approval for this work and is able to supply large numbers of cane toad eggs and metamorphs. It would be exceedingly problematic to carry out this work out in WA due to the restrictions and dangers associated with moving cane toads into WA. At the conclusions of the trials, animals would be sacrificed and lodged either in the WA or NT Museum depending on their original site of origin. Simple stats to compare proportions of animals that took cane toads in subsequent trials would be utilized.

Radio-telemetry work would involved the surgical implantation of Holohil transmitters in a variety of snakes and their regular location. Data would be analysed using various home ranges descriptors in the package “Ranges”.
data_management: Databases will be used to store data collected in cafeteria trials, from radio-telemetry and listings of species and abundances from site based collections.

background: Provide support for off-reserve conservation activity through the Roadside Conservation Committee, Nature Conservation Covenants and the Land for Wildlife Program.
aims: Achieve improved nature conservation outcomes on lands outside the CALM Act estate through voluntary management initiatives, permanent covenants established on land titles, and training and awareness raising for roadside managers.
outcome: Greater community awareness of nature conservation management, and improved conservation outcomes on lands that do not have nature conservation as their primary purpose.
knowledge_transfer: The operation of the off-reserve conservation programs is heavily dependent on effective knowledge transfer.  The programs utilise knowledge from other internal and external science and technical programs to develop effective information products, training and education programs.
methodology:
The Land for Wildlife program is a voluntary scheme for land owners to sign up to and get information to assist them to manage natural areas on their properties for the benefit of wildlife.  The scheme is being delivered in a partnership with the WA NRM Regions who are provided local contacts and in some cases, on-site inspections and management advice.

 

The Nature Conservation Covenant program provides a mechanism for private land owners to place a restrictive covenant on the land title over natural areas on their property.  These areas are protected in perpetuity under the covenant.  Management Guidelines are provided for each property which identify the means by which management actions can be undertaken in compliance with the covenant.  Some financial assistance is also available for voluntary covenants to assist with initial management actions.

 

The Roadside Conservation Committee is composed of representative from government, local government, business, utilities and community that are involved in roadside management.  The Committee, through the Executive Officer, prepared advisory material, conducts training, and provides advice on roadside conservation.

related_projects: other SWTFRP projects
background:
Over the last 200 years, 50 per cent of the world’s mammal extinctions have occurred in Australia (Short and Smith 1994). In Western Australia alone, 12 mammals and two birds have become extinct and at 30 June 2015, 39 terrestrial mammals and 23 terrestrial birds native to the State were classified as being threatened with extinction. Of these, three mammals and two birds are ranked as critically endangered. In mammals, most extinctions and declines have occurred in medium size species, in the so called ‘critical weight range’ of 35g to 5500g (Burbidge and McKenzie 1989).

Predation by feral cats and foxes is a key threatening process in the decline of many, if not all, these species. Foxes have been successfully controlled for many years in a range of locations across Western Australia using dried meat sausage baits containing 1080 poison. Over a decade of research by Parks and Wildlife scientists has led to the development of the Eradicat® feral cat bait, a moister meat bait, also containing 1080, that is more palatable to feral cats. Eradicat® was registered for operational use in Western Australia in December 2014, providing the opportunity to integrate broadscale feral cat control with existing fox baiting programs and other actions, such as translocation, that are implemented to improve the recovery of threatened native animals. 

On 16 July 2015, the Minister for Environment, Hon Albert Jacob MLA, and the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Hon Greg Hunt MP, announced $1.7 million in funding for the Department of Parks and Wildlife to assist threatened animal recovery. The funding will be used to integrate the new Eradicat® feral cat bait with current fox baiting in four different Western Australian environments. Sites have been specifically selected to direct the funding to improving conservation of species identified in the Commonwealth’s Threatened Species Strategy, and to align with fauna recovery programs already underway or planned by Parks and Wildlife in the south-west of WA.

This project fits within a broader suite of actions delivered by Parks and Wildlife to reduce the impacts of feral cats and foxes on threatened species in Western Australia. This includes Western Shield, the Integrated Fauna Recovery Project on the south coast, Rangelands Restoration at Matuwa and many other smaller scale projects.

The primary goal of the project is to contribute to the recovery of key threatened mammal and bird species found at each of these sites, through integrating feral cat baiting with existing fox baiting to reduce the impact of introduced predators, and undertaking translocations to establish new, secure populations, where necessary.

 While the Eradicat® feral cat bait is a key tool in achieving effective feral cat control, other methods, such as shooting and/or trapping, may also be employed. For example, some individual cats appear to be reluctant to take baits or local climatic conditions may reduce the effectiveness of baiting alone. Some flexibility is built into the project plan to allow this suite of control options to be employed, as necessary.

The project is funded for three years over the 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 financial years. A project agreement has been signed with the Commonwealth Government outlining funding to be provided in each financial year and key deliverables.
aims:
To sustainably recover the wild populations of woylies and numbats in the Upper Warren region, through:

(a) developing protocols to allow the effective integration of feral cat control with existing fox control in the southern jarrah forest; and

(b) effective neighbour engagement.
outcome:
Integration of feral cat control with the current fox control program, including developing standard protocols for delivery of Eradicat® to maximise its effectiveness and the use of other introduced predator control techniques designed to minimise the impact of introduced predators on native fauna;

  • Identification of the efficacy of Eradicat® baiting according to current operational delivery methods aerial and ground) and time of year.
  • Quantification of the risk to potentially vulnerable non-target native mammals in the southern jarrah forest to operational use of Eradicat®
  • Understand the effect of integrated fox and cat control on i) introduced predators, ii) non-target native mammals potentially at risk from management actions (i.e. chuditch, brush-tailed phascogale, quenda), and iii) numbats, woylies and other native species vulnerable to introduced predators by means of monitoring.
  • Community awareness and engagement to ensure understanding of and support for management actions.
