methodology:
To achieve these outcomes various spatial technologies are used including digital elevation models, current and historic imagery, water observations from space, and utilisation of remote sensing for purposes such as calculation of Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI).

The Project Team collaborates with other sections of the department such as Remote Sensing & Spatial Analysis Program, Ecosystem Science Branch and Fire and Regional Management Services and other government agencies such as the Department of Water and Environmental Regulation and federal Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water.
no_specimens:
Plant specimens are collected as required during field visits to confirm plant identification. Generally, specimens are disposed of once they are no longer required or held in local herbaria to assist with future identification.

When new populations of threatened or priority species are identified they are forwarded to the herbarium as voucher specimens. All collection is undertaken with appropriate collection licenses.
data_management:
Data and documentation is stored on Species and Communities DBCA's SharePoint

background: BIO is developing a central platform for Western Australian biodiversity data (the WA-BDR), unlocking the value in this data by making it easily discoverable, searchable, and accessible. This project is part of the as part of the Western Australian Government’s commitment to its Digital Environmental Assessment Program (DEAP) partnership with Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment (DAWE). BIO’s objective in delivering the WA-BDR is drive evidence‑based decision making, better regulation, and biodiversity research by enabling data sharing and fostering a culture of collaboration.
aims:
In developing, delivering, and managing the WA-BDR, BIO aims to:

  • unlock the value in Western Australian biodiversity data by making it easily discoverable, searchable, and accessible for all users;
  • improve the exchange of biodiversity data between jurisdictions, via integration of the BIO platform with the federated national Biodiversity Data Repository;
  • develop a model that can be deployed in other States and Territories to automate the contribution of biodiversity data to an Australia-wide repository;
  • drive better decision‑making, providing data for the forthcoming Environment Online portal to support digital transformation of environmental assessment and approval, and making a greater body of biodiversity data available to other agency decision-makers; and
  • expand opportunities for research and enhance the quality of research outputs.
outcome:
The expected outcomes are:

  • data users from all sectors will look to the WA-BDR as Western Australia's trusted source of biodiversity data (much as data.wa has become the authoritative website to search the State's open data collections);
  • provision of data from large proponents and agencies will encourage other firms and sectors to participate in data sharing, using the WA-BDR platform;
  • the Environment Online and national Biodiversity Data Repositories will use BIO as a key data source.
knowledge_transfer: not applicable
project_tasks:
Key milestones include:

  • Appointment of a supplier (Sep 2021)
  • Conclusion of development work and entry into UAT phase (Apr-May 2022)
  • Launch of initial version of WA-BDR (Jun 2022)
  • Collection of user feedback to inform a second phase of development (2022-23)
references: not applicable
methodology: not applicable
no_specimens: not applicable
data_management: The project will involve any data collection.  Rather, it involves the development of a data management platform.

related_projects: Not applicable.
background:
BIO’s objective is to deliver a fully functional first iteration of the WA‑BDR by mid-June - a platform that:

  • provides a central store for Western Australian biodiversity datasets;
  • applies quality assurance, quality control, access management, and archival processes to those datasets; and
  • makes those datasets discoverable, searchable, and viewable by WA‑BDR users.

The WA-BDR will need to be adequately populated with historical biodiversity data prior to launch, with this seed data expected to be sourced from a range of custodians, including agencies and industry.  It its first year, the BIO data collation program will focus on sourcing high-volume, high-quality seed data to prepare for launch.

In subsequent years, BIO will transition to a rolling BIO data collection program identifying new sources, identifying datasets that fill known temporal and spatial gaps in the existing collection, developing capability handle difficult-to-transform and pre-digital data, and developing behavioural and professional incentivies to encourage data custodians to contribute data to the WA-BDR.

Both work during the initial year of the BIO data collation program, and work undertaken in subsequent years, will look to use automation and process re-engineering to allow new data to enter the WA-BDR without the need for extensive manual processing.
aims:
• To seed the WA-BDR with a robust collection of high-volume, high-quality, and high-value datasets prior to launch.
  • To establish business processes to review existing WA-BDR content, identify spatial and temporal gaps, and seek new datasets to populate those gaps.
  • Identify valuable biodiversity datasets that are pre-digital or otherwise difficult to transform, and explore technologies and techniques to extract data in a form that can be ingested in the WA-BDR.
  • Work with peak bodies to identify how members can best be incentivised to contribute data to the WA-BDR.
outcome:
This work program will:

  • support the timely launch of the WA-BDR;
  • improve the discoverability and accessibility of previously-siloed biodiversity data; and
  • contribute to the ongoing improvement of the WA-BDR and its data coverage.
knowledge_transfer: All WA-BDR users will gain value from this work, as the data will allow for a greater and more accurate knowledge of the distribution of species in Western Australia.  This knowledge will equip industry, regulators, and other government agencies to make evidence-based decisions, open up new opportunities for research, and enhance the quality of research outputs.
project_tasks:
Key tasks include:

  • finalising a review and refresh of DBCA datasets for ingestion;
  • finalising key industry discussion regarding data provision;
  • outreach to key agencies to identify additional data holdings;
  • definition of the Initial Datasets to be ingested into the WA-BDR before launch;
  • procuring pre-mapped (Darwin Core) IBSA data from ALA;
  • sourcing and mapping (to standards) of the initial datasets (including DCBA data, IBSA data where practical, industry data, and data from other agencies);
  • establishment of automated data transfer processes for new data, where appropriate;
  • establishment of business processes for annual review of WA-BDR data, and identification of key spatial and temporal gaps; and
  • further consultation with peak bodies to promote interest in contributing to the WA-BDR amongst members.

Key milestones are:

  • Populating the WA-BDR with mapped biodiversity data from the Initial Datasets (Q3-Q4 2021-22);
  • Establishment of automated data provision from the forthcoming TSC and EO platforms (date dependent on external developers); and
  • Scoping a detailed implementation plan for post-launch BIO data collation program BAU.

background:
A warming and drying climate in southwestern Australia has, and increasingly will, put forest ecosystems under chronic and acute moisture and temperature stress. A decline in rainfall since the 1970s and increased frequency of heatwaves have resulted in declining groundwater levels, reduced streamflow, and less plant-available water. Concurrently, past management of the forest for timber production have produced legacies of altered stand structure. Portions of the forests are currently characterised by dense stands of regrowth, which may be increasingly vulnerable to warming and drying because they use more water than a more mature forest. There may also be flow-on consequences of these changes in water availability and use for the biodiversity that the forest sustains, including for riparian ecosystems and habitats.

This project expands on SPP 2000-003 (Hydrological response to timber harvesting and associated stand management in the intermediate rainfall zone of the northern jarrah forest) and SPP 2011-20 (Long-term stand dynamics of regrowth forest in relation to site productivity and climate), both of which will be closed. SPP 2000-003 provided an important, long-term record of the groundwater and stream flow responses of the jarrah forest (via the Yarragil catchments) to a drying climate and forest thinning. Hydrological responses to a recent thinning, in 2019, will continue to be monitored by this new project.

Knowledge gaps remain regarding the coupling of the forest to groundwater and the unsaturated zone and there remains a need to develop ecohydrological models to support decision making regarding forest management for biodiversity and forest resilience outcomes. SPP 2011-20 demonstrated the effects of forest thinning on growth and inter tree competition in regrowth stands of jarrah and karri, and produced important information on thinning activities in relation to <em>Armillaria</em> root disease and organic matter build up. However, that project had a timber resource focus so did not address many of the ecological questions that we now need answered about forest health, fuel loads, fauna habitat and biodiversity responses. This new project will build on the outcomes of these previous projects and will help fill knowledge gaps regarding forest conservation and management under the challenges of ongoing and predicted climate change, as outlined in the FMP 2024-2033.

One of the main intervention techniques to help the forest adjust to a drying and warming climate is to alter forest stand structure via thinning to reduce competition for water. A range of thinning trials were established as part of harvesting for timber production in southwestern Australia in the past 50 years. These show that thinning can increase available water, increase protection of riparian zones and other habitats, and increase growth rates of remaining trees. However, the ecological implications of thinning for conservation outcomes are less well known.

To understand how thinning may assist in increasing the resilience of south-west forests to a drying and warming climate, this project will investigate three main components: 1) climate drivers and forest health: that is, how forest responds to climate variability under differing management treatments; 2) hydrology: how forest structure and health influence and in turn are influenced by the storage of water in the vadose and groundwater zones and how this in turn influences streamflow and evapotranspiration; and 3) thinning: can changing stem number (functional sapwood, basal area) increase resilience, and what are the ecological responses to thinning. In addition, the forest, with and without thinning, will experience disturbance interactions such as fire, pests, pathogens, and thus these will also be investigated.

Previous social research suggests that in some areas thinning may not be palatable to the wider community. This requires further work to understand attitudes and perceptions to thinning and forest management.&nbsp
aims:
The aim of this project is to examine the potential of stand management such as thinning to maintain or increase forest ecosystem resilience and inform management for forest adaptation to climate change. Specifically, aims include:

Climatic drivers and forest health

Examine, using remote sensing and geophysics, depth to groundwater and bedrock, when and where forest cover changes are occurring, to identify key thresholds and inform stand management.

Examine responses of thinned forest, riparian zones, dense regrowth, and old growth, during drought/ heatwaves using remote sensing (e.g., NDVI, i35, LAI).

Mine FORESTCHECK data for relationships between biological diversity, composition and stand density, e.g., examine the temperature and precipitation gradient across the forest to show impacts of a drying and warming climate on forest structure, composition, and function.

Maintain, periodically monitor (5-10yrs), and report on stand management measurements, e.g., population and health, for long-term trials in jarrah (Yarragil 4L, 4X, 6C, Wungong, Inglehope, Munro) and karri forest (Warren, Treen Brook, Sutton blocks).

Hydrology

Quantify hydrological responses (soil moisture, groundwater, surface water and evapotranspiration) to thinning and declining rainfall in experimental catchments and examine how forest structure regulates streamflow volumes/quality at landscape scales. Apply novel technologies, geophysics, remote sensing, water tracers and soil analyses to measure these responses.

Develop models for landscape-scale assessment of ecohydrological responses to climate change and management such as thinning.

Undertake research to understand water use and responses to thinning of key forest species.

Thinning

Examine habitat values and use (foraging, roosting, nesting) of thinned and unthinned catchments (e.g., Wungong) by fauna (key species and broader diversity measures) using novel techniques (e.g., eco-acoustics, camera traps, eDNA) and compare with traditional methods.

Examine carbon dynamics of thinned and unthinned catchments and ForestCheck plots and clarify allometrics and provide more accurate above and below ground carbon accounting.

Identify the effects of thinning on forest function (e.g., water, soil carbon, nutrients, microbes), and soil disturbance (movement, compaction), and understorey diversity (Wungong, Munro).

Quantify herbicide residue following thinning operations.

Interactions

Examine the vulnerability of thinned and unthinned forest blocks to high severity fire.

Quantify fuel loads and fire potentials following different methods of thinning using standard and publishable fuels surveys, for older (e.g., Wungong) and newly thinned sites (e.g., Munro, Hamilton).

Examine the responses of Phytophthora cinnamomi -affected forest, in thinned and unthinned areas using remote sensing techniques, validated with in situ data collection.

Social licence

Quantify current attitudes regarding forest thinning. Build on the Beckwith et al. (2010) study from Wungong to determine attitudes to longer-term forest development after thinning.

Assist with demonstration sites to increase understanding of forest thinning.
outcome:
A clearer understanding of the responses of forest ecosystems to climate change with and without intervention activities such as thinning.

Findings will be shared with EHB and FMB as part of the FMP implementation via guidelines, manuals, and procedures. Outputs will include journal papers, presentations, science notes, etc., as required.
knowledge_transfer:
The outcomes and outputs generated by the SPP will be directly used by DBCA staff, including staff from Remote Sensing, Forest Management Branch, and various Districts. Research findings from the project will be integrated into management planning, and management responses including future research. Knowledge gained will be delivered to relevant staff in the form of technical reports and presentations. Inclusion of staff from the Forest Management Branch, Remote Sensing and BGPA will ensure knowledge transfer.

Research findings will be published in peer-reviewed journals so that it is available to researchers and managers locally, nationally and internationally. Findings will also be communicated to a wide range of stakeholders through reports, seminars, and newsletters local media and popular articles, as required.

background:
The increasing disturbance associated with the urbanisation of marine coastal systems is facilitating a phenomenon called ocean sprawl (Firth et al. 2016). This phenomenon sees the replacement of complex marine habitats with simplistic artificial structures and is directly associated with a decline in species richness and abundance (Davis et al. 2015; Heery et al. 2017). Due to the difficulty in quantifying this decline, habitat type is often used as a proxy for marine and estuarine communities. The protection of these habitats is regularly seen as a mechanism for protecting overall diversity within a system (Davis et al. 2015).  

The effective management of an estuary system depends on sufficient ecological data and the extent and diversity of the component habitats (Davis et al. 2015). Within the Swan-Canning Estuary (SCE), the Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA) has collected extensive ecological data through an environmental monitoring program. This program focuses on water quality but also includes biological indicators including fish and seagrass communities. These long-term data contribute towards the ongoing management of the SCE and establishing a range of targets used within the Swan Canning River Protection Strategy to promote ecological health.

Previous efforts have been made to describe the habitats within the SCE (Valesini et al. 2010; Valesini et al. 2018; Cottingham et al. 2023) and rely on sampling and surveys. Satellite and aerial imagery surveys have proven problematic as there are limitations associated with turbidity and depth, that restrict the ability to classify and map habitats. This often results in the deeper benthic habitats remaining largely unquantified (Valesini et al. 2010; Davis et al. 2015). Remote marine habitat mapping techniques (including tow-camera, drop-camera, swath acoustics and ROVs) are increasingly being used within these environments to better describe the extent, structure, and distribution of benthic habitats (Davis et al. 2015).

Other approaches that classify habitats within coastal systems use the categorisation of dominant characteristics. Habitat classification systems (HCS) aim to describe all habitats within a determined region using mutually exclusive and easily identifiable categories to provide sufficient detail for effective management (Ball et al. 2006; Davis et al. 2015). Limitations of the HCS approach include the strong dependence on the size of the area being assessed and the influence of variation in biological assemblages over small distances (Davis et al. 2015).

Seagrass is an important habitat in coastal areas and has been the focus of some research in the SCE focused on condition and health  (Forbes & Kilminster 2014; Kilminster & Forbes 2014; Jung et al., 2022). Annual surveys of seagrass health and 5-yearly surveys of distribution are conducted as part of DBCA monitoring.  This information, combined with benthic surveys can be used to establish distribution maps of habitat with repeatable methodologies.
aims:
This project will aim to improve habitat mapping approaches within the Swan-Canning Estuary through the following aims:

  1. Produce broadscale habitat mapping of the benthic habitat in the Lower Swan-Canning Estuary.
  2. Map the distribution of species, communities and habitats for the Swan-Canning Estuary.

Aim 1: Produce broadscale habitat mapping of the benthic habitat in the Lower Swan-Canning Estuary

Produce a broadscale benthic habitat map of the LSCE, which will assist in filling some of the knowledge gaps around benthic habitat diversity.

Aim 2: Map the distribution of species, communities and habitats for the Swan Canning Estuary

Develop and consolidate maps of key species and communities and identify areas of ecological significance in the SCE.
outcome: The project will provide a key understanding of the benthic habitats in the Lower Swan-Canning Estuary and the distribution of key species and communities by producing broadscale habitat and species distribution maps (geospatial shapefile layers). These maps will be used to inform management decision-making in the Swan-Canning Estuary, and more widely the Swan-Canning River Park. Additionally, the methodologies used in this project will act as a framework for extended habitat and species mapping studies within the upper reaches of the Swan and Canning Estuaries.
knowledge_transfer:
The project will include collaborations between DBCA Rivers and Estuaries Science (RES), the Nature Conservancy (TNC) and Murdoch University. A data-sharing agreement has been established between all parties involved, allowing the usage of data associated with this project.

At the end of the project, all outputs will be shared between the collaborators as well as other stakeholders involved as the second aim of the project develops. This will assist in identifying information gaps in habitat composition within the system.
project_tasks:
Aim 1: Produce broadscale habitat mapping of the benthic habitat in the Lower Swan-Canning Estuary

Annual reporting will take place in the form of a milestone email sent to each of the partners. These reports will detail the progress of the mapping process, the steps used in the data collection and collation from each source along with processing and analysis of data. A final report will be produced at the end, including the full methodology and results used in the study and sent to all collaborators involved.

Where possible scientific publications of the findings of this phase, or broader project will be produced. This phase could provide insight into the distribution of benthic habitats in the LSCE and identify the effectiveness of the marine parks within the system in maintaining these habitats.

Aim 2: Map the distribution of species, communities and habitats for the Swan Canning Estuary

A review of existing maps of habitat, species and communities for Swan Canning and their location will be produced, resulting in the consolidation of existing maps into a singular location. In addition, new maps will be developed based on available datasets on agreed taxa. Annual reviews and updates will be given to all partners involved in this part of the project.

At the end of the project, both aims will be collated together to form a wider report documenting the habitat mapping findings in the Swan-Canning Estuary.
references:
Ball, D., Blake, S., Plummer, A. and Victoria, P. (2006). Review of marine habitat classification systems (Vol. 26). Melbourne, Australia: Parks Victoria. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237636095

methodology:
Aim 1: Produce broadscale habitat mapping of the benthic habitat in the Lower Swan-Canning Estuary

Study area                         

The LSCE, the study area for the project, is a section of the SCE spanning from the Stirling Highway Bridge in East Fremantle, upstream to the Narrows Bridge and the Shelley Bridge in Perth.

Drop camera imagery data collection

DBCA data

The DBCA data will use images taken from the 2019 and February and March 2023 Habitat Mapping Survey along with bathymetric interfaces in the LSCE. Between the two sampling periods, approximately 6000 images across 51 transects in the LSCE were collected. The raw images and georeferencing (NMEA strings) data for this survey were supplied in-house.

Murdoch/TNC data (MT data)

The MT data were collected during the summer 2019 survey that investigated the distribution of A. senhousia within the LSCE and resulted in 2037 images using a drop-cam to record a video for each site.

Shoreline ground-truthing

Shallow shoreline ground truthing data were collected in early 2023 to help provide an understanding of habitat in the areas that were inaccessible by boat. Haphazard transects were conducted on foot at depths of less than 1.2 m across 17 sites over a distance of 14.14 km. Within these sites, 887 data points were collected which contributed to the computer training program.

Satellite imagery data  

Satellite imagery data will be used alongside the drop-cam images and will be sourced by DBCA (via the Remote Sensing Branch at DBCA) for the same period as the above surveys and supplied in-house.  

Drop camera imagery data cleaning 

DBCA data

Before analysis, unusable images, including those that are blurry, skewed and duplicated will be removed from the dataset. Using code written in R Statistical Programming, the usable images will be georeferenced using the NMEA GPS strings recorded in the photos. Using the NMEA string from the photo dates, the start and finish times of each string will be used as the survey start and end points. To identify images that fall within the survey time, the timestamps in the metadata of each image (synched at the beginning of each trip) will be used. Any images that are outside of the survey time will be discarded. Once cleaned, georeferenced, and survey images identified, shape files of the vessel track will be produced overlaid with the images taken. These will be displayed as points, with each point in the track corresponding to the image taken at that time. If images fail to align with the track during the survey time (as identified through R scripts), those images will be discarded.

MT data 

Video data had already been used by Murdoch University and TNC in previous research projects and had been cleaned before DBCA obtained the data. The files were renamed relative to their site name and date of collection.

To overlay the MT video footage and DBCA images, a still image will be taken from each video at the last possible moment that renders a clear image of the substrate before the drop-cam frame contacts the sediment. As the frame will likely disturb the sediment, resulting in a plume, the images will be distorted, taking the image just before the drop-cam hits the sediment will avoid this issue. Each still image will be then saved with the site name from the video. Positioning data for each site was provided alongside the video data. These were used in conjunction with the output from the video analysis in the creation of shapefiles.

Drop camera imagery analysis 

The still images from the DBCA and MT data will be analysed using ecological analytical techniques, such as Transect Measure (TM) or ReefCloud. Images analysed using TM will follow the methods outlined by Langlois et al. in the Standard Operating Procedure for Habitat Annotation using TransectMeaure (SOP) and work from Davis et al. (2015). Images analysed using ReefCloud will follow the approaches outlined in the .

In both instances, images will be analysed by classifying the benthic habitat to the lowest taxonomic level. After the classification of all images, a .csv file (known as a TransectMeasure Observation file for TM) will be produced and uploaded into R for statistical analysis. The data in the .csv, or alternative file will be used to calculate the percentage cover and species diversity of benthic habitat in the LSCE.

Drop camera imagery data categorisation and confidence 

Each image will be allocated a confidence threshold, with >90% being high, 75-90% being medium, 50-75% being low and <50% being unusable, applied. These confidence thresholds will allow for the use of data from images that would have otherwise been regarded as unusable. The overall confidence of analysis at each site will be spatially displayed in the spatial analysis software, QGIS, using the respective GPS coordinates and a spatial layer created for the individual habitat classifications.

Drop camera imagery data spatial mapping and representation

Image point data from the above analysis will be imported into spatial analytical software for interpolation at 20 m and 40 m grid cells. Contour maps will be produced showing the density of benthic habitats and will be validated using the ground-truthing datasets.

Satellite imagery data incorporation

Drop camera imagery data preparation 

To combine the image analysis data with the satellite imagery those data with an overall confidence value of >50% will be used. As the satellite imagery data is of such high resolution, keeping images with >50% confidence will most likely result in an overlap between the drop-cam images and the satellite data. 

Each record will need to be consolidated into its dominant classification (that being over 70%). This will reduce the data at each site to one classification. The overall spatial representation can therefore be comprised of multiple habitat types where these classifications change in dominance. 

Satellite imagery data training 

This step will use the broader categories established in the previous step to train and then validate the individual pixels of the satellite image to an associated habitat classification where possible. This step will likely require reiteration to ensure the best association of data is achieved. This training will be done through R-scripts produced and supplied by the DBCA Remote Sensing branch. Guidance will be sought from the same branch to achieve the best association in data. 

Bathymetry cut-off

During the data training process, there will be a threshold where the deeper water obscures the reliability of using satellite imagery. Where this reliability threshold occurs, the depth will be used to create a bathymetric cut-off. A combination of satellite imagery and drop-cam imagery will be used in the depths leading up to this threshold (shallower depths). Below this threshold, the benthic habitat will be classified using drop-cam imagery only. 

Aim 2: Map the distribution of species, communities and habitats for the Swan Canning Estuary

Known species distribution data in the SCE will be collected from the literature, TNC, Murdoch University and the DBCA database. Once obtained, data will be cleaned and analysed within computer programming software, such as R or Python. To produce maps that are suitable for stakeholders and organisations, the data will be uploaded into mapping software, such as QGIS, and the species distributions will be overlaid with maps of the SCE to highlight areas of potential ecological significance.

data_management:
Aim 1: Produce broadscale habitat mapping of the benthic habitat in the Lower Swan-Canning Estuary

Raw images will be stored on external hard drives and uploaded to the DBCA Sharepoint, with each sampling dataset being stored in separate folders. Once raw images have been filtered and cleaned, the selected images will be uploaded and stored in separate folders on Sharepoint. All data, scripts and maps will be stored on Sharepoint going forward.

Aim 2: Map the distribution of species, communities and habitats in the Swan-Canning Estuary

Consolidated maps will be stored on external hard drives and uploaded to the DBCA SharePoint.

Biometrician's Endorsement

Advice from the Remote Sensing Branch around the appropriate methodology for incorporating satellite imagery into the habitat mapping process. Advice from the Department’s biometrician Matthew Williams will be sought when reporting on the data, especially in future phases where scientific publications may occur.

related_projects: None
background:
The occurrences of anoxia (no oxygen) and hypoxia (very low oxygen) are often observed in the bottom waters of many estuaries (Roberts et al., 2012), as a result of environmental conditions associated with the interaction between tides, riverine inflows, meteorological forcing and internal biogeochemical processes. The balance between tide-driven pulsing of oceanic water (saline water) and riverine inflows (fresh water) typically sets up a salt-wedge stratification pattern that restrict vertical mixing between oxygen-depleted bottom waters and oxygen-saturated upper water.

The extent and severity of oxygen depletion can vary across the estuary depending upon the hydrodynamic condition as well as biogeochemical processes such as mineralisation of organic matters, photosynthesis and sediment oxygen demand (Zhu et al, 2016). The negative impacts of persistent low oxygen on the estuarine internal nutrient loading and estuarine biota have been well documented (Howarth et al., 2011; Testa and Kemp, 2012), however finding long-term solutions remain a challenge in many parts of the world (Zhang et al., 2010).

The Swan River estuary is a diurnal, micro-tidal estuary which passes the city of Perth and discharges to the Indian Ocean at Fremantle in Western Australia. The upper estuary is a narrow, shallow and meandering channel, generally well-mixed in winter and partially to highly stratified in other seasons, depending on the salt-wedge and relative intensity of tidal mixing and gravitational circulation (O’Callaghan et al., 2007). This morphology and dynamic cause the tide-driven salt wedge to reach the upper estuary.

Eutrophication-related oxygen depletion in the upper reaches of the Swan River estuary has been recorded and has contributed to poor water quality and fish deaths in 2003-2005, 2009 and 2012. As part of a multi-pronged strategy to mitigate the eutrophication in the estuary, side-stream supersaturation oxygenation plants have been installed in the upper reaches of the estuary in Guildford (in 2008) and Caversham (in 2011). Testing over five days of operation showed that these plants can influence oxygen conditions in the upper Swan River estuary over a stretch of 11.5km (Larsen et al., 2019).  

Key performance indicators (KPI’s) are in place to ensure the oxygenation plants achieve the target oxygen concentration. These are applied at the operational level as monitoring guideline and reported to the Minister for Environment as KPI target for the River Protection Strategy requiring that >80% of all individual dissolved oxygen measurements in the oxygenation zone are above 4 mg/L.

Estuarine environments are complex and detailed investigations are required to ensure oxygenated water distribution is responsive to the changes in hydrodynamic and biogeochemical conditions.  These are essential to improve the oxygenation in the Swan River estuary.

But these conditions are dynamic at many temporal scales. In addition, climate change needs to be factored into management of the oxygenation plants.  Observations on the effect of climate change to freshwater, estuarine water coastal water and marine water have seen higher adverse impacts than predicted (IPCC, 2022). Since surface warming in 1950s, ocean acidification (as a result of increasing CO2 levels in the atmosphere) and deoxygenation are identified as key threatening factors to the biodiversity of aquatic environment, particularly in estuarine waters. The seventh biennial State of Climate report (bom.gov.au/state-of-climate) reported, since 1910 Australia’s climate has warmed by an average of 1.47+0.24oC, and since 1970 in southwest of Australia a decline rainfall approx. 15% in April to October and 19% in May to July, leading to a significant decrease in streamflow.

There are plausible adverse impacts of this climate change on the current oxygenation operation in the upper Swan River estuary and these need to be investigated to proactively define the necessary adaptation approach for oxygenation over the coming decade.
aims:
The project will contribute to improve oxygenation approaches in the Swan River estuary by developing better understandings of variability and drivers of oxygen conditions. This will be achieved through application of the 3D hydrodynamic oxygen predictive model, namely the Swan Canning Estuarine Response Model (SCERM) to address the specific aims:

  1. Understanding of the impact of seasonal variations of the estuary conditions on the extent of the oxygenation plant generated plumes.
  2. Understanding how salt wedge dynamics influence oxygen distribution.
  3. Understanding the influence of the catchment inflow water quantity and quality.
  4. Assessment on possible improvement of the oxygenation plants efficiency by changing the current diffuser locations and flow-rate.
  5. Assessment on the need to alter the oxygenation plants capacity as a response to climate change scenario 2030, i.e., increase in air temperature, ocean acidification, less rainfall.
outcome: The project will provide key understandings on the Swan River estuary’s hydrodynamic (water level, temperature and salinity) and oxygen dynamic based on 5-years (2018-2023) validated oxygen model, which will assist the oxygenation plants managers in optimizing the plants operation and adaptation of climate change impact on the operation.
knowledge_transfer:
During the life of the project, reference group meetings are scheduled every 6 weeks. At the meeting, the project leader presents the project progress and discusses any issues that arise with reference/experts, project team members and stakeholders which include the oxygenation team in Rivers and Estuaries Branch (REB). This forms an on-going knowledge transfer process. Additional meetings and discussions will be organized as required.

The project leader will work with managers during the project to enable their input of data supporting model validation. In addition managers will be able to input their expertise in oxygenation management into scenario development (Aims 4 & 5).

The project leader will also provide some additional educational material (in the form of a presentation) to support learnings of managers / junior scientists in model frameworks. 

At the end of the project, knowledge gained will be conveyed to the oxygenation team in Rivers and Estuaries Branch of the Conservation and Ecosystem Management Division and other relevant teams in Rivers and Estuaries Science (RES).
project_tasks:
Deliverables and time frames:

Year 1:

  • Calibrated and Validated SCERM29 (meshgrids from Upper Swan to Narrows, 2D inflow at Narrows, 29 1D catchment inflows, 2D meteorological forcing) hydrodynamic model for simulation period 2018-2022: 31 May 2023.
  • Flow measurements using a boat-mounted Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) performing continuous transects across the estuary around Guilford and Caversham over a tide cycle: June and November 2023 (exact dates TBC).
  • Creation of new meshgrids using an updated Swan Canning bathymetry based on the latest hydrographic survey from Ashfield Flat to Belhus (planned in July 2023): 11 August 2023.
  • Application of oxygen module, oxygenation spargers hydraulic and operational parameters in SCERM29 hydrodynamic-oxygen model, calibration and validation: 22 September 2023.
  • Application of some climate change scenarios (multiple cases of meteorological and rainfall) and impact assessment on oxygenation dynamic: 30 April

Note, WA future climate model by Climate Science Initiative will be accessible from DWER platform in 2024. 

Year 2:

  • Application of some scenarios of diffuser/spargers locations / operational management to adopt results of climate change scenarios (Year 1 output) and maximise efficiency : 31 May 2024.
  • Draft report: 30 September 2024.
  • Final report: 31 October 2024.

methodology:
Detailed steps required to achieve the 5 specific aims are described below.

Aim 1: Understanding of the impact of seasonal variations of the estuary conditions on the extent of the oxygenation plant generated plumes, and Aim 2:  how salt wedge dynamics influence oxygen distribution.

The Swan Canning Estuarine Response Model (SCERM) developed by the UWA-AED group (Paraska, et al. 2022) in collaboration with DBCA will be modified to suit the purpose of this project. Modifications to the original SCERM (with 44 catchment inflows; hence it’s called SCERM44) will include a more localised model domain (spanning from the upper reach/Yagan Bridge in Belhus to the Narrows in Perth), 2D meteorological forcing, and 29 inflows from the contributing catchments; herewith is called SCERM29.

The SCERM29 will require calibration and validation processes using data collected by the oxygenation team in Rivers and Estuaries Branch of the Conservation and Ecosystem Management Division and estuarine monitoring by the Rivers and Estuaries Science (RES) team.

Detailed steps required to achieve Aims 1 and 2 include the model setup, calibration and validation described below. 

  1. The SCERM29 setup

The SCERM29 consists of a 3D flexible-mesh (finite volume) utilizing the TUFLOW-FV (TFV) hydrodynamic driver and TFV Water Quality Oxygen module. TFV accounts for variations in water level, horizontal salinity distribution and vertical density stratification in response to tides, inflows, salt-wedge dynamics and surface thermodynamics. The mesh consists of triangular and quadrilateral elements of different size that are suited to simulating areas of complex estuarine morphometry. The finite volume numerical scheme solves the conservative integral form of the nonlinear shallow water equations in addition to the advection and transport of scalar constituents such as salinity and temperature as well as dissolved oxygen (DO) concentration.

Boundary condition inputs to the model include:

  1. 2D (horizontal grids) initial condition, values are extracted from monitoring data.  
  2. 2D (vertical grids) hourly inflow at Narrows, values are extracted from SCERM44 model output for the same simulation period.
  3. 1D daily 29 inflows (flow, temperature, salinity and DO), values are the output of the Swan Canning Catchment Model (SCCM) simulated using eWater Source for the same simulation period.
  4. 2D (horizontal grids) hourly meteorological fluxes: air temperature, air humidity, wind components (u component, parallel to x-axis and v component, parallel to y-axis) are calculated from gridded data of wind speed and direction, incoming shortwave and longwave radiation, and rainfall. Data (1.5km grid) are extracted from Bureau of Meteorology Atmospheric high-resolution Regional Reanalysis for Australia (https://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog.html).

Parameters input to the model will be applied from the results of calibration process.

  1. The SCCM setup

SCCM domain and parameterizations (including runoff parameters) utilized in the SCCM for this project are derived from Paraska, et al. (2022). The eWater Source version 5.20 will be used for this project, instead of the older version Source 4.9 utilized in Paraska, et al. (2022). Rainfall and evaporation data inputs for SCCM are from SILO Australian climate data (https://www.longpaddock.qld.gov.au/silo/).

  1. Model validations and assessments

Comparisons between simulated and measured state variables (water level, temperature, salinity and DO) will be presented using time-series plots, vertical profiles, 2D horizontal contours, 2D curtain contours, and animation.

To understand the impact of seasonal (summer, autumn, winter and spring) variations of the estuary conditions on the extent of the oxygenation plumes, and salt wedge dynamics influence on oxygen distribution, the following will be presented:

3a. Time-series plots: seasonal comparison of bottom water DO comparison and percentage of bottom area under hypoxia and low DO in the oxygenation target zone.

3b. Contour plots: comparison of the oxygenation distribution in each season for each year simulation.

3c. Calculation of the exceedance of probability of benthic water experiencing hypoxia and low DO for each season.

3d. Time-series overlay plots of DO, salinity stratification, total hypoxia and low DO area, each at surface and bottom layer.

3e. Time-series overlay plots of DO (surface layer-average) and salt-wedge intrusion variation, from Narrows upstream.

3f. Vertical profiles (seasonally averaged) current speeds at same locations around oxygenation diffusers.

Aim 3: Understanding the influence of the catchment inflow water quantity and quality.

The relationship between inflow water quality and estuarine water quality is complex. Hence the assessment will be based on the sensitivity analysis on the 29 inflows water quality on the calibrated and validated models, to gain insights the most critical catchments outflows on the estuarine oxygen dynamics. When applicable, multi-variate statistical analysis will be applied to evaluate different inflow effects.

Aim 4: Assessment on possible improvement of the oxygenation plants efficiency by changing the current diffuser/sparger locations and flowrate.

Assessment methods described in items 3d to 3f will be utilised.

Aim 5: Assessment on the need to alter oxygenation plants capacity as a response to climate change scenario 2030, i.e., increase in air temperature, increase in ocean-driven tide levels, ocean acidification and less rainfall. 

2D boundary conditions meteorological inputs derived from Western Australia future climate produced by Climate Science Initiative will be utilised. The 4km grids datasets are expected to be ready in 2024, accessible via DWER Platform.

Assessment methods described in items 3a to 3f will be utilised to inform the resulting changes in oxygen dynamic. When applicable, metrics such as R2 (coefficient determination), RMSE (root mean square standard error), and NSE (Nash-Sutcliffe Efficiency) will be utilized.

List of softwares utilised:

Technique Programming Software:

Programming and numeric computing MATLAB® and programming languages Python and R are used for the project for data acquisition, processing and extraction throughout the project.

Mapping Software:

Commercial licence and open-source geographic information system ArcMap ArcGIS and QGIS (respectively) are used to process spatial dataset, a community edition SMS (Surface-water Modeling System) is used for the model meshgrids preparation.

Surface Hydrological Model Software:

eWater SOURCE catchment model is used for generating sub-catchment inflow water quantity (daily flow) and water quality (TN and TP concentrations).

data_management:
Data utilised and resulted from this project are huge. Simulations are run using GPU and need to be run locally (not on OneDrive storage) as otherwise the simulation time will be very slow.

An external hard drive (5TB) is used as a backup storage and updated for every addition of the files. Every month the data will be transferred to the project share point, following DBCA Record Keeping Policy. Model setup and input files will be shared via DBCA Science GitHub:

https://github.com/orgs/dbca-wa/teams/science
